title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDERBERG, ELINOR DREWS
description: ANDERBERG--Elinor Drews. 89. Died March 28, 2006. She was predeceased by her sisters Mary Ralston Kenney, Jannet Douglass and her brother Edward and is survived by three nieces, two great nephews and one great niece. She was born on Staten Island on January 21, 1916, educated in White Plains, N.Y. public schools and graduated from Skidmore College in 1938 with honors in English. She had a long career in publishing, for many decades with Book-of-the-Month Club in the Art Department. After retirement, her focus changed to social work directed through her Church. With two parishioners she founded the West Side Campaign for Hunger. She also founded the Christ & St. Stephen Brown Bag Program. Funeral Saturday, April 8, 11AM at Christ & St. Stephen, 122 W. 69 St, NYC 10003. Contributions appreciated to either of above agencies.

But at the New York City Opera on Thursday night, at the second performance of the opera's run there, I was struck by how tightly and satisfyingly the sections fit together, each falling into place with an audible click, like some sort of aural Rubik's Cube.

She will be remembered for the grace with which she lived and the support she gave unfailingly. Her gentleness and generosity will be missed by all who loved her. Funeral services were held March 30 at Temple Bet Am Shalom, White Plains, at 10:45 A.M. Friends may call for Shiva at her home, 17 Harrows Lane, Purchase, 5-9 P.M. on March 30 and April 1-5. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Joan Silverman Family Foundation at the Foundation for the Jewish Community, 520 8th Avenue, 20th floor, New York, New York 10018. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINHARDT, JEAN STETTHEIMER
description: STEINHARDT--Jean Stettheimer. A consistent and significant contributor to many Santa Barbara charities and organizations, Jean Stettheimer Steinhardt passed away on Saturday, March 25. She was the daughter of the late Florence and Walter Stettheimer of Atherton, CA, the sister of the late Barbara S. Adler and the sister-in-law of the late Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President and General Manager of The New York Times, both of New York City. Mrs. Steinhardt lived her later years at the Casa Dorinda in Montecito, CA. Jean was a quiet force in making public and private gifts with a definite plan and a strong sense that such were her responsibilities. She did not seek public recognition but would have wanted to be remembered as a person who made a positive difference. Jean had a zest for life and leaves a legacy of wisdom, of strong conviction and of resolute character. She always cared and taught by example that life could be a blend of social concern and glamorous fun. She is survived by her daughters Felicia W. Rogan of Charlottesville, VA and Jill W. Cartter of Beverly Hills, CA. She was also the beloved friend and quintessential aunt of Bobbie Adler Katzander of New York City. No services are to be held. In keeping with her great sense of charitable responsibility donations can be made to the Cancer Center of Santa Barbara.

The gains in pay came as the bank's profit rose 90 percent, to $8.48 billion, largely reflecting its July 2004 acquisition of the Bank One Corporation, which Mr. Dimon ran. title: Arts, Briefly; Without Basketball, CBS Piles Up Points

In particular, the CBS shows hindered ABC, which had gained Thursday ground against basketball. Part 2 of the special ABC series "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition," featuring Hurricane Katrina wreckage, drew 7.44 million viewers. After that, "American Inventor" brought in 9.3 million. But NBC placed second for the night. "Will & Grace" got a bump from Britney Spears's appearance. Ms. Spears delivered lines like "Whatever you've got, I'll eat it, snort it or ride it, baby" before an audience of 9.33 million. Perhaps Michael Eisner should have invited Ms. Spears to the debut of "Conversations With Michael Eisner" on CNBC on Tuesday. I like waterfalls a lot. In the many different countries I've been to, I usually like to spend time around waterfalls. I wanted to sit down on the rocks because it is so close to the waterfall, and I can concentrate there. When I close my eyes, it's very nice and I can relax. You know that sit-down style? It's Zen. It's a kind of Japanese meditation. When I sit down, Zen style, I'm trying to concentrate. I will not think about anything, and I will not feel anything. I just concentrate." On him, though, the get-up looked slept in, dusty and too tight -- perfect, in other words, for the occasion: the Tokyo International Anime Fair, the sublimely dorky annual convention for Japanese animation. As the crown prince of anime screenwriting, Mr. Sato, at 36, is a consummate creator of the characters, busty schoolgirls and shaggy-haired heroes, that inspire Asian teenagers to devote their irreplaceable youth to the worship of cartoons. He hadn't shaved. He was smoking American Spirits. He looked rumpled, and obscurely amused, as he almost always does.

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: There's a new way to bypass all that traffic on the way to Kennedy Airport. Last week, US Helicopter (www.flyush.com) started a new shuttle service between the Downtown Manhattan Heliport at Wall Street and Terminal 9 (American Airlines) at the airport. Tickets for the eight-minute ride initially cost $129 each way, not including taxes and fees. Passengers traveling on American can check in at the heliport. Others must take the AirTrain to other terminals for check-in. The State Department recently issued a public announcement to alert Americans to security concerns in Italy. Demonstrations are planned in various parts of the country in anticipation of parliamentary elections April 9 and 10 and municipal elections in May, the alert said. Mesa Air Group touched off an air fare war in Hawaii last month when it began offering interisland fares as low as $39 at www.iflygo.com to introduce its new Go! airline, which will begin flying between Honolulu and Lihue, Kahului, Hilo and Kona on June 9. Hawaiian and Aloha Airlines matched the sale, which runs through April 7 for travel June 9 through September, cutting air fares by 50 percent, according to Terry Trippler, a spokesman for CheapSeats.com. For the first time in nearly a decade, entrance fees for Grand Canyon National Park, below, are going up. Effective May 1, the fee for private vehicles, which is good for seven days, will rise by $5, to $25, while per-person passes, also good for seven days, will cost $12, up from $10. The Annual Grand Canyon Pass was raised to $50 from $40.

title: Baseball on the Screen: Some Hits, Many Errors

The incongruity isn't so much in the low-culture-in-a-high-culture-setting aspect of the series -- nobody's fazed by that anymore -- as it is in the fact that the baseball picture is not, to put it gently, one of the distinguished genres in cinema history. (As a subject of good movies, baseball trails boxing by a significant margin, while remaining comfortably ahead of football, basketball, hockey, golf and tennis. If you're keeping score.) That the interest of MoMA's baseball festival is more sociological than aesthetic is pretty clearly signaled by its title: "Baseball and American Culture."

description: In my 20th week of pregnancy a few years ago, I was informed by my physician that the son I was carrying had Down syndrome. The issues addressed in Elizabeth Weil's insightful article (March 12) bring up profound moral questions. title: Berlin: Lux 11
description: THE BASICS -- Considering the amount of buzz East Berlin's trendy Mitte neighborhood has been attracting recently, it's surprising that it lacks equally trendy design hotels. Until now, that is, thanks to the recent opening of Lux 11, a 72-room apartment boutique hotel, which is spread over three connected, seven-story, 19th-century whitewashed buildings. The ground floor is primarily taken up by the hotel's Aveda salon and spa, the all-white Shiro i Shiro restaurant and Ulf Haines, a concept store that sells minimalist fashion gear. Despite its chic upmarket surroundings, the relatively small reception area makes it clear that the hotel is for independent (read low-maintenance) guests. Lux 11 lacks round-the-clock service; it calls itself an apartment hotel because the front desk is closed and guests are on their own after 5 p.m. on weekends and 10 p.m. on weekdays.

description: The French industrial designer Matali Crasset once characterized the home as a machine for play. Her show at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum makes her vision public. From May 19 through Sept. 17, Crasset will transform the room into an otherworldly landscape, a place where rivers flow beside igloos and singalongs are encouraged. "It's an oneiric vision," Crasset muses, explaining that this exhibition (the fourth in the museum's "Solos" series) called for more fantasy than her usual commercial outlets, like the Milan furniture fair or her Paris shop. To show visitors how to experience her designs in a more communal way, Crasset has created an interactive playground around her "d--fuse" igloo, her flat-screen- and speaker-embedded "Immersion" chair, and the brand-new "Sounddrops" piece, which features microphones for easy-access karaoke. The "Solos" series might take on a whole new meaning. MONICA KHEMSUROV

description: The architect Morris Lapidus, who brought pleasure palaces like Eden Roc and the Fontainebleau hotels to Miami Beach, was so loathed by Modernist hard-liners that, in 1983, he bitterly destroyed much of his archives. "He thought, If they didn't like it once, why would they like it again?" explains the Miami-based architect Deborah Desilets, a friend and colleague in his later years. Fortunately, Lapidus, who died in 2001, lived long enough to see his work rediscovered by the Philippe Starck generation. This summer, Desilets, in collaboration with Dennis Miller Associates, will introduce a collection of Lapidus's furniture designs. Recreated almost entirely from old photographs, the initial offerings will include a swank upholstered lounge chair and a sofa with clear acrylic arms (right). "It used to be the ultimate fantasy for aspirational families to stay at a Lapidus hotel," Dennis Miller says. Now the fantasy is coming home.

title: Banishing a Television Antenna From a Co-op
description: Q. I moved into my co-op building as a tenant in 1980 and bought my apartment last year. title: In Baghdad, Rice Urges Iraqis to Form Government Quickly
description: BAGHDAD, April 2  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, saying she is distressed by the slow movement toward forming a new government in Iraq, arrived here today with Jack Straw, the British foreign secretary, and both of them told Iraq's leaders in unambiguous terms that they need to complete the process right away.

title: Buenos Aires
description: WHY GO NOW -- Four years after its currency crash and one year after a nightclub fire claimed 194 lives, Argentina's capital has recovered a lot of its swagger and fun. The populist President Nstor Kirchner's early payoff of Argentina's International Monetary Fund debt, and less-than-friendly treatment of President Bush at the Summit of the Americas in November, played well in a country tired of international advice, and in last October's midterm elections Mr. Kirchner's mascara-caked wife, Cristina, won a senate seat amid a wave of Evita nostalgia. The economy is booming, too: After hitting bottom in 2002, it bounced back in 2004 and 2005, a turnaround that is visible in the sheer number of new apartment towers and clothing stores popping up in the trendy Palermo area. And yet it is still shockingly inexpensive, with first-rate meals rarely costing more than 78 pesos a person, or $25 at 3.14 Argentine pesos to $1.

Take the mysterious sister of Louis Paulsen, who accompanied her famous brother to the United States championship in New York in 1857. title: 'Our Town'
description: I was an adult before I ever saw the picture. But even as a girl, I knew there'd been a lynching in Marion, Indiana. That was my father's hometown. And on one of many trips to visit my grandparents, I heard the family story: the night it happened back in 1930, someone called the house and spoke to my grandfather, whose shift at the post office began at three in the morning. "Don't walk through the courthouse square tonight on your way to work," the caller said. "You might see something you don't want to see." Apparently that was the punchline-which puzzled me. Something you don't want to see. Then laughter.

title: The Remix; Literary Salon
description: A store that sells books is, by all accounts, a bookstore. But refer to the new Assouline boutique in Paris by such a name and be prepared for a tart correction from its French owner. "If you want to buy books, go to a bookstore," says Prosper Assouline, somewhat mysteriously, considering he, along with his wife, Martine, owns this luxe publishing house, which recently opened its first shop on the chic Rue Bonaparte (011 33 143 292 323). The storied former frame store (where Picasso was a client) feels more like a museum devoted to the written word. The stock is lined up like artworks along the brown lizard-skin shelves or stacked in the jigsaw-puzzle-like wall unit made to fit the exact size of each publication, and plasma screens continually play short films based on its books. "The idea is to sit on the couch and have a coffee and stay for hours," Assouline says. And, of course, have a good read. WHITNEY McNALLY

You can see the result in "Modernism: Designing a New World," an exhibition that is opening this month at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. The show pays homage to her Frankfurt Kitchen, a streamlined, functional ancestor to today's integrated designs.

title: Paperback Row
description: NEVER LET ME GO, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Vintage International, $14.) A finalist for the Man Booker Prize last year, Ishiguro's bold novel imagines a school in the English countryside where clones are trained for a terrible destiny as organ donors. At first meeting, the teenagers at Hailsham seem like any other group of privileged boarding school students. But gradually, the elliptical reminiscences of Ishiguro's narrator, a 31-year-old Hailsham graduate named Kathy H., provide clues to the bizarre truth about the school and its students' eventual purpose in the larger world. "The eeriest feature of this alien world is how familiar it feels," Sarah Kerr wrote in the Book Review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IASON, GIRARD (JERRY)
description: IASON--Girard (Jerry). Born November 12, 1918, the son of Lawrence and Sadie Robinson Iason, died on March 29, 2006. Much loved father of Larry, John and Barbara. Devoted father-in-law of Cara, Valorie and Rob. Extraordinary Poppy of Scott, Sara, Lizzie, Jessica and Emily. Loving husband of the late Jeanne Hirsh Iason. Special friend of Edie Finck. Loving care provided by Carol Houser, Carren Serrette and Ann Williams. Jerry was an alumnus of Phillips Exeter Academy (1935) where he was elected captain of the first lacrosse team, and he was also an alumnus of Yale College (1939). Jerry volunteered for military service after Pearl Harbor and became an officer in the U.S. Navy. On D-Day he participated in the Normandy invasion. He also participated in the landings at Sicily, Salerno and Anzio. After the war he worked with his father at N. Erlanger, Blumgart & Co., Inc. where he became president. He enjoyed squash, golf and travel, but his greatest love was his family. He was an extraordinary father and husband who thoroughly enjoyed life and left his children and grandchildren a great legacy through his devotion to each of us. "A man's reach should exceed his grasp or what's a heaven for." Services private. Family receiving Sunday 28pm. Contributions to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.

title: Dream Land
description: The French industrial designer Matali Crasset once characterized the home as a machine for play. Her show at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum makes her vision public. From May 19 through Sept. 17, Crasset will transform the room into an otherworldly landscape, a place where rivers flow beside igloos and singalongs are encouraged. "It's an oneiric vision," Crasset muses, explaining that this exhibition (the fourth in the museum's "Solos" series) called for more fantasy than her usual commercial outlets, like the Milan furniture fair or her Paris shop. To show visitors how to experience her designs in a more communal way, Crasset has created an interactive playground around her "d_fuse" igloo, her flat-screen- and speaker-embedded "Immersion" chair, and the brand-new "Sounddrops" piece, which features microphones for easy-access karaoke. The "Solos" series might take on a whole new meaning.

title: HURRICANES DON'T COUNT
description: Hurricane Katrina was powerful enough to blow a loophole in rules laid down by the board of a big development company based in Cleveland, Forest City Enterprises. All but one of the company's independent directors approved a $1 million gift to the Tulane University Katrina Relief Fund, half of which was paid in November, according to the company's proxy statement. Why did the other director, Scott S. Cowen, abstain? Well, he happens to be the president of Tulane. Forest City's corporate governance guidelines prohibit "substantial charitable contributions to organizations to which a director is affiliated." But the board made an exception after determining that the gift would not compromise Mr. Cowen's independence, the proxy said.

description: STEINHARDT--Jean Stettheimer. A consistent and significant contributor to many Santa Barbara charities and organizations, Jean Stettheimer Steinhardt passed away on Saturday, March 25. She was the daughter of the late Florence and Walter Stettheimer of Atherton, CA, the sister of the late Barbara S. Adler and the sister-in-law of the late Major General Julius Ochs Adler, Vice President and General Manager of The New York Times, both of New York City. Mrs. Steinhardt lived her later years at the Casa Dorinda in Montecito, CA. Jean was a quiet force in making public and private gifts with a definite plan and a strong sense that such were her responsibilities. She did not seek public recognition but would have wanted to be remembered as a person who made a positive difference. Jean had a zest for life and leaves a legacy of wisdom, of strong conviction and of resolute character. She always cared and taught by example that life could be a blend of social concern and glamorous fun. She is survived by her daughters Felicia W. Rogan of Charlottesville, VA and Jill W. Cartter of Beverly Hills, CA. She was also the beloved friend and quintessential aunt of Bobbie Adler Katzander of New York City. No services are to be held. In keeping with her great sense of charitable responsibility donations can be made to the Cancer Center of Santa Barbara.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALBERTS, WILLIAM W.
description: ALBERTS--William W. Age 81, died at his home in Lake Forest Park, Washington, the afternoon of March 28th after a long illness. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where he graduated from public high school. He was an infantryman in the U.S. Army during World War II and a combat veteran of the Battle of the Ruhr and other action in the European Theater of Operations. Dr Alberts took his Bachelor's, Master's and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Chicago, where he studied under Milton Friedman, Abba Lerner and Frank Knight. He taught Business Economics and Finance at the University of Washington Graduate School of Business from 1967 to 1995. He was known for his rigorous academic standards and his excellence in teaching. In 1978, Dr. Alberts co-founded Marakon Associates, the international management consulting firm described by "The Economist" as "a consultancy that has advised some of the world's most consistently successful companies." Marakon now has offices in New York, London, Singapore, Chicago and San Francisco. Dr. Alberts was a driving force in developing the firm's strategy and organizational practice and training the consulting staff. He worked parttime for Marakon while he was on the University of Washington faculty, and fulltime after he retired from teaching, remaining active in the firm until his death. An associate remembers Dr. "Bill" (as he was affectionately known) as a "teacher and colleague who enabled people to achieve a level of excellence far above what they thought themselves capable of achieving." Another recalls "He was a person who always left you better than you were." He will be sadly and deeply missed by Patricia, his wife of 54 years, his daughters, Mary Allender of Portland, Oregon, Susan Alberts of Durham, North Carolina, five grandchildren, and his many friends, co-workers and associates. A celebration of his life will be held April 19th in Manhattan. Interment will be at Doddridge Chapel Cemetery, Chapel Road, Wayne County, Indiana, after a service at Mills Funeral Home in Centerville, Indiana, Saturday, April 22, at 11 AM. A memorial service will be held in Seattle on May 1st, at 4:15 PM, in the Peterson Room of the Allen Library at University of Washington. In lieu of flowers please donate to Retired Bolivian Ministers, 6401 The Paseo, Kansas City, Missouri 64131, in memory of Dr. Bill Alberts. Please call 919-401-4411.

title: Rough Gems
description: You are living in a world created by Elizabeth Bishop. Granted, our culture owes its shape to plenty of other forces  Hollywood, Microsoft, Rachael Ray  but nothing matches the impact of a great artist, and in the second half of the 20th century, no American artist in any medium was greater than Bishop (1911-79). That she worked in one of our country's least popular fields, poetry, doesn't matter. That she was a woman doesn't matter. That she was gay doesn't matter. That she was an alcoholic, an expatriate and essentially an orphan  none of this matters. What matters is that she left behind a body of work that teaches us, as Italo Calvino once said of literature generally, "a method subtle and flexible enough to be the same thing as an absence of any method whatever." The publication of "Edgar Allan Poe & the Juke-Box," which gathers for the first time Bishop's unpublished material, isn't just a significant event in our poetry; it's part of a continuing alteration in the scale of American life.

title: Mourning Becomes Lockerbie
description: LONG BRANCH - THE phrase "good grief" can be an expression of exasperation. But taken another way, it is perhaps even more confounding. After all, can grief ever be good? In Deborah Brevoort's drama "The Women of Lockerbie," based on the 1988 terrorist attack on Pan Am Flight 103, it is possible. She explores the many personal pathways of grief: from a patrician American stoicism to a mad Medea-like pathos to a spiritual Celtic worldview.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: April 2 - April 8; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: As they used to say of the British Empire, the sun never sets on shows of Andy Warhol's work. And small wonder. When the Pop star died in 1987, he left a lode of material from which to mine exhibitions, not just big-market paintings but also photographs that emphasize his voyeuristic obsession with the camera. Only a few months ago Cheim & Read showed his very graphic images of male nudes from the 1980's, and now at Zwirner & Wirth the focus is on "WARHOL'S WORLD: PHOTOGRAPHY AND TELEVISION," candid snaps of friends, celebrities and sidekicks.

title: The Remix; Eye Candy
description: Maria Pergay created a silver candelabrum for Princess Grace of Monaco and a tortoiseshell couch for Pierre Cardin. "Beauty is like food," says Pergay, who is 75. "I feed my eyes." This spring, Pergay's latest works are displayed at the Demisch Danant and Lehmann Maupin galleries in New York, and the monograph "Maria Pergay: Between Ideas and Design," by Suzanne Demisch (Demisch Danant/D.A.P., $85), will be released. Pergay's wit is evident in new pieces, like a stainless-steel and Macassar ebony cabinet, adorned with a giant safety pin. Though she says she can't draw, relying on a team of artisans to realize her ideas, Pergay is unabashed. "I could lie and tell you it's terribly hard work," she says with a chuckle. "But really, I've had a life of fun!" STEPHEN HENDERSON

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: April 2 - April 8; FILM
description: When "Match Point" hit last year, a few critics rightly pointed out that the best Woody Allen film in years bore resemblance both to the Dreiser novel "An American Tragedy" and George Stevens's exceptionally fine adaptation, "A Place in the Sun." I took another look at Stevens's 1951 melodrama after I saw "Match Point" and, when the great Shelley Winters died in January, I gladly revisited one of her most celebrated films once more. The story of a social climber who becomes involved with a rich debutante and a factory worker, "A Place in the Sun" is justly famous for its choker close-ups and the sexual heat generated by Elizabeth Taylor and Montgomery Clift. Just as remarkable, though, is its third-billed star, as the factory girl who comes between all those ravishing close-ups like a rebuke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SHERBININ, ROBERT INGVAR
description: de SHERBININ--Robert Ingvar. Died on March 31, 2006 at the UNC Hosptial, in Chapel Hill, North Carolina, after a brief illness. He was 83. Bob de Sherbinin was born on January 5, 1923, in New York City to Michael Jacques de Sherbinin Sr. and Grace (Wellwood) de Sherbinin. He attended public schools in New York and also attended the Admiral Billard Academy in Groton, CT. Bob had his college studies interrupted by World War II. He served in the Navy twice, from 1942-1943, and again from 1945-1946, as a Seaman 1st class. He returned to Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Maine, and graduated as part of the class of 1945 with an AB in Mathematics. At Bowdoin, he was a member of the Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity and continued to be very active with Bowdoin as a class agent, class secretary and pre-admissions interviewer. In 1948, after graduating from Bowdoin, Bob began his career with General Electric in the then small products division. He married Betty Jane Callan on June 24, 1950. In 1958, he joined Martindale-Hubbell, publishers of a legal law directory and worked in increasing responsible positions until his retirement as Vice President in 1988. Longtime residents of Chatham, New Jersey, Bob and his wife, Betty retired to Fearrington Village, Pittsboro, North Carolina, in 1990. Bob served as the President of the Homeowners Association in Fearrington in the early 90's. Bob's love of music was a constant theme throughout his life. He was an active member of the Glee Club at Bowdoin. During his retirement years, he enjoyed singing with the Harmony Grits and the Mini Grits, volunteer singing groups in Fearrington Village. His ready smile, wit and love of life will be sorely missed by his family and many friends. Survivors include his wife, Betty Jane (Callan), a daughter Lynne, in Indiana, and another daughter, son-in-law and grandson, Bruce, Jan and Nigel McIntosh, in Pennsylvania, a brother and sister-inlaw, Michael Jacques de Sherbinin Jr. and Jan Stephens of Amherst, MA, and a brother-in-law and sister-inlaw, James Michael and Rinda Callan, in Florida, plus many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Robert I. de Sherbinin Memorial Fund, c/o Eric Foushee, Bowdoin College, 4100 College Street, Brunswick, Maine 04011. A memorial service will be held at a future date for friends and colleagues. For information call: Crematiion Society of the Carolinas, Raleigh, NC.

title: Exile on High Street
description: Nancy Lancaster was born on the verge of the 20th century, into a world already filled with things. Fire tongs, cachepots, camelback sofas, four-poster beds and needlepoint rugs were being dislodged at an alarming rate from the stately homes that had housed them, as the homes themselves came on the auction block or slid into dereliction. Like Elsie de Wolfe and Syrie Maugham, her contemporaries, Lancaster was instrumental in banishing the Victorian era's velvet-and-mahogany gloom. To the extent that she injected her own brand of American exuberance into the calcified English conventions that governed dcor and entertaining, Lancaster was viewed as a reformer. But a reformer in an age dominated by revolutionaries: while the Modernists set about making everything new, breaking with history, consigning centuries' worth of stuff to the junkyard, Lancaster made a compelling case for continuity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EUBANK, HAROLD PORTER
description: EUBANK--Harold Porter. A pioneer in magnetic fusion engery research, died of cancer on March 23 in Kilmarnock, VA, at age 81. Dr. Eubank worked at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory in Princeton, NJ from 1959 -1985, where he headed neutral beam research. He was the chairman of the Division of Plasma Physics at the American Physical Society in 1977, and recieved a Distinguished Associate Award from the U.S. Department of Energy in 1981 for his leadership in the study of neutral beam-heated high temperature plasmas in support of the nation's fusion energy research program. In 1982 he was awarded the Elliot Cresson Medal and made a Life Fellow by the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. He published over 100 papers and spoke frequently at conferences around the world. Dr. Eubank grew up in rural Virginia. After serving in World War II, he returned to complete his B.S. at the College of William and Mary in 1948. He received an M.S. from Syracuse University in 1950, and a Ph.D. from Brown University in 1953. Upon retirement he moved back to to his family's farm in Kilmarnock, VA, and was an active supporter of creative and performing arts in the local community. He is survived by his wife, Mary Alice; children, Porter Eubank, Charles Eubank, and Elizabeth Stern; granddaughters, Caitlin and Hailey Stern; step-children, Diane Jettinghoff and Steven Witte; and first wife, Harriet Eubank.

"Glass of the Maharajahs" opens on May 19 and showcases some of the earliest glass furniture, cut by France's and Britain's finest. (The show notes the cultural oddity of European artisans making goods for Indian royalty, a reversal of the era's usual order.) The collection includes a 27-foot-tall fountain by F&C Osler from 1851 -- made from four tons of glass -- and an eye-popping blue table (below). Excess never looked so exquisite. Go to www.cmog.org. title: Kid Rock
description: Moments before a recent show in Peoria, Ill., the world's No. 1 preschool band appeared on two projection screens flanking a stage already set with a drum kit, an electric guitar, a Spanish galleon and a smiley-face house. Calling into the camera with their standard welcome -- "Hi everyone, we're the Wiggles: I'm Greg. . .I'm Murray. . .I'm Jeff. . .and I'm Anthony" -- the Australian quartet seemed to come straight toward the audience in a cartoony red car, smiling, waving and giving everyone a big thumbs up. The car soon disappeared behind an opening marked "Stage Door," a tip surely lost on the fans in attendance, most of whom could not yet read. Then a dozen red-coated dancers skipped brightly from the wings, waving shimmering flags of gold and maroon to the tape-tracked chords of "Toot Toot Chugga Chugga Big Red Car." Close on the dancers' heels and fastened into a real red car with fake seat belts came the Wiggles in the flesh: four Australians otherwise known as Murray Cook, Anthony Field, Jeff Fatt and Greg Page. All wore single-color jerseys with stripe-legged pants and logo-emblazoned belt buckles. "Toot, toot, chugga, chugga, big red car," Page sang in a smooth baritone. "We'll travel near, and we'll travel far. Toot, toot, chugga, chugga, big red car. We're going to ride the whole day long." The song bounced atop an infectious eight-bar pop, and the audience quickly became a roiling sea of 2-, 3-, 4- and 5-year-olds, some dressed as their favorite Wiggle and others clutching some colorful piece of Wiggles-sanctioned toyage purchased deep within the crush that earlier swarmed the merchandise tables out front. The cautious sat staring from laps, while the less cautious began to bob in the spirit of proximal disconnectedness otherwise known as parallel play, dancing without paying attention to one another. They spilled into the rows and aisles, forming a light cluster at the foot of the stage in a kind of preschool mosh pit.

title: The Time Trap
description: Since my daughter joined her high school's crew team, I've gained several hours a week of uncluttered time. That's what I tell myself on her predawn practice mornings as I climb out of my warm bed at 4:45 a.m. and then try to savor the dark stillness, a couple of girls nestled quietly in the car with me. That's also what I would report if I was asked to participate in the kind of time-use diary surveys that are the bedrock of two noteworthy recent studies, one on leisure trends and the other on family caregiving trends. The drive to and from the boathouse takes barely 40 minutes, I would say in the hour-by-hour account that surveyors collect, so I'm soon home to enjoy the newspaper in the kitchen, listening to music, with nobody else awake bustling or bothering me. What I wouldn't take the time to explain is that although this sounds like a lovely balance of special solicitude and unexpected solitude (a mother's dream), I seem more susceptible to feeling parental stress than newfound leisure.

title: 'Slaphappy'

I had gone to quite a few shows, yet always in the same spirit I had crashing debutante balls, cult gatherings, and Ku Klux Klan marches - to smirk and sneer. Channel surfing, I'd stop on the wrestling broadcasts long enough to feel superior. Maybe I just didn't get it, though. Those tribal rituals you see on PBS, where swaybacked savages dance about shamelessly naked, have always seemed pretty ridiculous, too. There was that reverent voice-over, however, explaining how the seeming imbecilities of the tribal rite contained and communicated everything that mattered to its culture. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, KENNETH

A recent retiree after 14 years as consulting editor at Bloomberg News, he spent most of his career with Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, starting in 1965. He built his reputation on covering the oil nationalizations of the 1970's, and served as executive editor from 1983-88. In 2002, OPEC cited him for journalistic excellence. His father, Webb Miller, was a leading war correspondent. The dapper man, seldom without coat and tie, was educated in Europe before attending Princeton University, class of 1944, interrupting his classes to serve as an Army artillery and infantry officer. In early 60's, he was foreign press adviser to the new Republic of Congo. He leaves his devoted wife of five decades, the former Helene Glavani of Athens, and dozens of friends and oil industry associates worldwide.

title: Sampling the Sounds of Mali Without Leaving Home
description: HISTORY echoes through Malian music, new and old. It's in the ancient modal scales of the melodies, which can sound like American blues. It's in the circling, hypnotic vamps that those melodies soar above. It's in songs that might well be modern versions of the epics passed down by generations of the troubadours known as griots. And it's in the way electric guitars and synthesizers are often used to recall the pointillistic patterns of traditional instruments like the kora  the griot's traditional harp-guitar  and the balafon, an African xylophone.

title: Inside the List
description: THE AGNOSTIC: Books about religion are staples on the Times best-seller list, but they do particularly well just before Easter. This week, Garry Wills's new book, "What Jesus Meant," enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 12 and "The Journey," by Billy Graham, climbs onto the extended list at No. 22. This season's subversive best seller, however, is one that takes direct aim at the Bible: Bart D. Ehrman's "Misquoting Jesus: The Story Behind Who Changed the Bible and Why" (HarperSanFrancisco). It rises on the nonfiction list to No. 5. Ehrman, who heads the department of religious studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, methodically chips away at the underpinnings of some of the Bible's best-known passages. (One example: Ehrman writes that the story of Jesus and the woman accused of adultery -- the one where Jesus supposedly said, "Let the one who is without sin among you cast the first stone" -- wasn't part of the Gospels, but was added later by unreliable scribes.) Much of Ehrman's research isn't groundbreaking. "This material has been known to scholars," he told me in a telephone interview, "but there hasn't been a book for the lay audience." The author, who is 50 and has written 18 previous books, grew up in a not overly religious Episcopal family, but became a fundamentalist while still a teenager and attended college at the Moody Bible Institute. His probing into the composition of the Bible ultimately led him to lose his faith. "Misquoting Jesus" makes for sober Easter reading. The problem with divining the meanings of the New Testament, he writes, is that we not only don't have the originals, "we don't even have copies of the copies of the originals." Ehrman notes: "It would have been no more difficult for God to preserve the words of Scripture than it would have been for him to inspire them in the first place. . . . The fact that we don't have the words surely must show, I reasoned, that he did not preserve them for us. And if he didn't perform that miracle, there seemed to be no reason to think that he performed the earlier miracle of inspiring those words."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIGGS, MARC MICHAEL
description: GRIGGS--Marc Michael. August 15, 1921-March 5, 2006. He was a Vice-President of Batten, Barton, Durstine and Osborn, advertising agency in New York. He graduated from the Hotchkiss School in 1940 and was Secretary of the Hotchkiss Alumni Association. He was a graduate of Williams College where he was President of the Class of 1944, President of the Alumni Association, member of the Executive Council, Class Secretary, I. F. C. Secretary, Kappa Alpha Fraternity, and President of Gargoyle, an Honorary Society. At Williams he played baseball, was College Champion of the squash team, and Commodore of the Yacht Club. From 1944 until 1946 he was with the 2nd U.S. Marine Division and was honorably discharged with the rank of Captain, U.S.M.C.R. He was on the Board of Governors of the Williams Club, New York City and Secretary-Treasurer of the Williams Association of Fairfield County. A long time resident of Greenwich, Connecticut, he was a sailing instructor at Indian Harbor Yacht Club, served on the Board of Governors and Chairman of the American Red Cross and the Board of the Field Club of Greenwich. Donations may be made to the Williams College Scholarship Fund if desired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATZKA, JOHN
description: MATZKA--John. Died peacefully at the age of 82, in La Jolla, California, on March 26, 2006. Born in 1924 in Vienna, Austria, he fled to New York in 1941 and lived 40 years in Hicksville, NY, before moving to La Jolla in 2005. At his retirement, he was Vice-President of Plenum Publishing, NY. He was the beloved husband of the late Lee (Liselotte) Matzka and devoted father of Michael and Peter. He was also the proud grandfather of Liesl and Nathan, and the supportive and caring uncle of Wendy and Sandra Austin, Catherine, Elizabeth and Helen Lederer, as well as beloved brother-in law of Dr. Gerda Lederer. Until his death he cherished the friendships of Patrick Austin and Princess Cosia-Fomba. He was a quiet man of strong principles. We will miss him. No services are to be held. In keeping with his great sense of charitable responsibility, in lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the ACLU.

title: Curve Appeal
description: Foresight and intuition can be as important as cash in acquiring a collection. Just ask Mera Rubell, the Miami art patron and collector. When, as a young art enthusiast with not a lot of money but infinite taste, she discovered six Norman Cherner chairs for $25 each in the early 1980's, she knew she had to have them. She credits Dewey Dufresne (a restaurateur, a former design scavenger and the father of the New York chef Wylie) with tipping her off. "I've always been really proud of these chairs," says Rubell, who has since acquired 12 more. "They're not gold-plated, the materials are not precious, but the invention is innovative." Cherner's 1958 design combines a molded plywood seat and back with curved bentwood arms that generously wrap around to the slender legs. As Rubell describes it, the design is "fragile yet strong, and extremely biomorphic." Even Philippe Starck could not resist the chairs' simple allure: he designed a matching dining table for the Rubells, who have, over the years, gathered art stars around it, like Andy Warhol, Cindy Sherman, Keith Haring and Jean-Michel Basquiat, each perched on one of Cherner's chairs. "We've had a lifetime of people sitting on these for hours on end, and we've never had a broken one," Rubell says. Which is proof -- sort of -- that the quality of life extends to the objects that support it. MADHU PURI Timeless

title: The Surreal Deal
description: Sometime in 1930, a troubled 40-year-old Manhattan decorator named Dorothy Draper stretched herself across a sofa in her psychiatrist's office and began divulging a litany of blue-blood woes. Her husband, a famous doctor, had dumped her for another woman. Her role as a mother, never too eagerly embraced in the first place, had been usurped by nannies and boarding schools. Her plummy voice and fluttery gestures were cruelly mimicked by her sister-in-law, a writer and performer of comic monologues. A statuesque brunette in a world of candy-box blondes, Draper was also tormented by feelings of physical inadequacy: too tall and too clumsy. Worst of all, these personal dissatisfactions were affecting her professionally. Who wanted to hire a decorator who kept using a dispirited palette of brown, beige and black?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORSINI, RAY PIERRE, NEE EISENSTEIN
description: CORSINI--Ray Pierre, nee Eisenstein, a pioneering journalist/editor, who influenced American publishing for much of her 95 years, passed away March 18. With her mother, she made the arduous journey from revolutionary Russia to Americain 1916. Initially unable to speak English, she earned BA and Masters from UCLA before becoming an editor at Glamour, and Vogue, and was among Time's first female writers. She also contributed to the NY Times. As a book editor, she was friend and confidante to authors such as Helen Hayes, Princess Grace and Anita Loos, representing their estates until her death. Mrs. Corsini's Caviar for Breakfast, reflected on her return to Russia, with her mother. She married into Italian royalty, becoming a Marquessa. A celebration of her life will occur in April. For information, e-mail: RayCorsini@aol.com.

title: Rescuing reform in Paris
Literary Salon
description: A store that sells books is, by all accounts, a bookstore. But refer to the new Assouline boutique in Paris by such a name and be prepared for a tart correction from its French owner. "If you want to buy books, go to a bookstore," says Prosper Assouline, somewhat mysteriously, considering he, along with his wife, Martine, owns this luxe publishing house, which recently opened its first shop on the chic Rue Bonaparte (011 33 143 292 323). The storied former frame store (where Picasso was a client) feels more like a museum devoted to the written word. The stock is lined up like artworks along the brown lizard-skin shelves or stacked in the jigsaw-puzzle-like wall unit made to fit the exact size of each publication, and plasma screens continually play short films based on its books. "The idea is to sit on the couch and have a coffee and stay for hours," Assouline says. And, of course, have a good read.

title: A Depression Switch?
description: Deanna Cole-Benjamin never figured to be a test case for a radical new brain surgery for depression. Her youth contained no traumas; her adult life, as she describes it, was blessed. At 22 she joined Gary Benjamin, a career financial officer in the Canadian Army, in a marriage that brought her happiness and, in the 1990's, three children. They lived in a comfortable house in Kingston, a pleasant university town on Lake Ontario's north shore, and Deanna, a public-health nurse, loved her work. But in the last months of 2000, apropos of nothing -- no life changes, no losses -- she slid into a depression of extraordinary depth and duration.

title: 'Programming the Universe'
description: This book is the story of the universe and the bit. The universe is the biggest thing there is and the bit is the smallest possible chunk of information. The universe is made of bits. Every molecule, atom, and elementary particle registers bits of information. Every interaction between those pieces of the universe processes that information by altering those bits. That is, the universe computes, and because the universe is governed by the laws of quantum mechanics, it computes in an intrinsically quantum-mechanical fashion; its bits are quantum bits. The history of the universe is, in effect, a huge and ongoing quantum computation. The universe is a quantum computer.

"The good things in life still exist" is the company's mantra, and it took only a cursory flick to see that it was selling good, ordinary, daily things transformed into nuggets of fabulousness. That is, everything from the most efficient cleaning products (the catalog is German: it has many pages of cleaning products) to the most comfortable cotton underwear, alongside old-fashioned toys, well-designed lamps, brown bread and a $925 fountain pen. I'm a sucker for armchair shopping. I buy things I would never trawl the high street for, most recently: a Pussycat Dolls CD, a red cardigan (not yet worn) and a Homer Simpson doll that shouts obscene messages to passing drivers. The good things in life still exist? I'm a 34-year-old, single, freelance journalist. I was just getting used to settling for the crummy.

description: MICHAEL--Sidney, 85 years old, passed away on Saturday, April 1, 2006, from injuries sustained in a fall on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Sid, a lifelong resident of New York, was the owner of Capitol Distributors Corporation and a former board member of the City Athletic Club. A veteran of World War II, Sid served in the Army artillery, taking part in the Battle of the Bulge, avoiding capture by leading a group of men off the road and into the hills after discerning that the road signs had been reversed by German infiltrators. Sid later joined up with Airborne troops who had liberated Bastogne and, later still, rejoined the artillery units that marched into Germany. A gentle giant of a man, Sid was a superb athlete, avid sportsman, and was once asked to audition for the role of Tarzan, later given to Johnny Weissmuller. As a young man he was an expert rider and starred on the track and field team at DeWitt Clinton High School. Later in life loved deep sea fishing, golf and tennis. Sid loved taking adventuresome trips to places such as the Amazon, China, Africa, the Galapagos, New Zealand, etc. When a family member was not available to accompany him, Sid thought nothing of striking out on an adventure on his own, frequently telling his children that they should live with memories, not regrets. Family was the most important thing in Sid's life. He is survived by his wife of fifty three years, the former Lea Wynperle, as well as his two children, Lawrence Michaels and Leslie Michael Tabet, and their spouses Kathryn Flynn Michaels and Christian Antoine Tabet. In addition, he is survived by his adoring grandchildren Serena Michaels, Sarah-Rose Tabet and Max Tabet. Their loss is profound. Sid is also survived by his sisters, Miriam Schoeneman and Frances Randall, their children and grandchildren, as well as the family of his late brother, Melvin Michaels, with whom he worked in partnership for nearly fifty years. In addition, he is survived by his brotherin-law Bernard Wynperle, his wife Ann, and his mother-inlaw Sara Wynperle, as well as numerous friends and associates. The family also wishes to acknowledge the longtime devotion of the Michael's housekeeper Gloria Ortiz. All our hearts are broken by this unexpected tragedy. Services will be held at 12:45, Tuesday, April 4th, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family is requesting that any donations be made in Sid's name to his longtime friend, Dr. Edgar Housepian at the Neurological Institute, 710 West 168th Street, New York, NY 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLIGAN, PHOEBE ZASLOVE
description: MILLIGAN--Phoebe Zaslove. Well - known investment banking executive and sponsor of the musical arts, died on April 1, 2006, at her home in Newport, RI, at the age of 52. She was surrounded by her family. Born Phoebe Butler Zaslove on June 12, 1953, to Jean and Herbert Zaslove in Kingston, TN, she was raised in New York, where she gave her first piano concert at the age of nine, having received formal training at both Julliard and the Manhattan School of Music. She later studied music at the University of Kentucky and Boston University, from which she received her BFA. She returned to New York to further study music at Julliard. While in Boston, Phoebe performed with the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Ms. Milligan began her career in investment banking in 1978 when she joined First Boston as an options trader. In 1980 she joined Morgan Stanley and became the first woman managing director at the firm. Phoebe later became president of London & Bishopgate International, a money management firm with $1.5 billion in assets. Most recently, Phoebe has been a senior financial advisor at UBS in Providence. Ms. Milligan had the magic ability to intertwine her love of music and success at managing investors' money, while at the same time devoting herself to family and friends. She was an active member of the Boston and New York music and philanthropic communities, serving on the Board of the Berklee College of Music and University of Limerick in Ireland. She is survived by her husband, Charles Milligan, two stepsons, Sean and Chad Milligan, Greenwich, CT, sister, Bette Absolve Novak and husband, Marty, Pittsburgh, PA; and cousins, Kristen Gossett and husband Jerry, Wichita Falls, TX, and Charles Kreutz and wife Linda, Austin, TX, and their children. A celebration of Phoebe's life will be held at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, RI, on Friday, April 28, at 11 am. Memorials may be sent to the Berklee College of Music or a charity of your choice.

description: "Ice Age: The Meltdown" (Fox) arrived on Friday and had by far the best opening-weekend ticket sales of any movie this year. If estimates hold, it will narrowly take the slot for the second-best opening weekend ever for an animated film. The sequel to the 2002 "Ice Age," the film, whose characters include Scrat (right), took in $70.5 million, according to Exhibitor Relations, a box office tracking company. That was $24 million more than the original "Ice Age" grossed in its first weekend, and about $33,000 more than "The Incredibles" had for its opening in November 2004. ("Shrek 2," also from 2004, has a comfortable lead for the best debut for an animated picture, with $108 million.) It is a long drop to second-biggest movie this weekend, Spike Lee's "Inside Man" (Universal). That film took in $15.7 million in its second week, for total sales of $52.8 million. "ATL" (Warner Brothers), starring the rappers T. I. and Big Boi, opened at No. 3 with $12.5 million. "Failure to Launch" (Paramount), now in its fourth week, held the No. 4 spot with $6.6 million, and "V for Vendetta" (Warner Brothers) rounded out the Top 5 with $6.4 million. "Basic Instinct 2" (MGM/Columbia), which got some of the most savage reviews of any film this year, opened with only $3.2 million in sales, tying for 10th place with "Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector" (Lionsgate). description: The authorities in Salzburg, Austria, plan to prosecute two men who painted and feathered an avant-garde sculpture of a nude Mozart because they considered it pornographic, The Associated Press reported. The public prosecutor's office said the two men painted part of the "Homage to Mozart" sculpture by the German artist Markus Lpertz with red and green enamel and stuck white feathers on it in August. One man was an unidentified 79-year-old; the other was identified as Martin Humer, 80, a former photographer and a self-proclaimed "porn hunter." The vote, which The Associated Press reported as 1,488 in favor and 1,416 opposed, ended a six-week strike. The workers will receive a pay raise of roughly 11 percent over three years, a company spokesman said, but will have to make increased contributions for health insurance. The workers will begin to return over the next seven days, and the company is scheduled to return to full production by next Monday, said Bud Grebey, a company spokesman. A phone call to a union representative was not returned yesterday evening. Sikorsky is a leading manufacturer of helicopters.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BARLOW, FREDERICK R.
description: BARLOW--Frederick R. Beloved husband of Anita, father of Douglas, Jennifer and Matthew, father-in-law of Thomas Amodio, grandfather of Jessica, Jonathan, Tyler and Madison. Born in the Bronx, September 9, 1929, Fred grew up with the "gang" (Bernie, Sol, Sonny and Sye). He attended Tulane University earning a degree in chemical engineering. He then volunteered and became a Lieutenant for the U.S. Army serving in Korea and Europe. Upon his return to NYC, he met the love of his life, Anita. He worked for the Plastics Division of Celanese Corporation, Plastic Materials in Hicksville and then formed his own company in 1967, Polymer Materials Incorporated, headquartered in Farmingdale. By not being afraid to hire young people and getting them started in their careers, PMI ultimately grew to over 2000 employees with facilities in Chicago, Rhode Island, Atlanta and Newark. PMI was listed on the NYSE until he arranged the sale to Georgia Pacific in 1981. He retired shortly thereafter and lived primarily in Palm Beach Gardens enjoying his life of golf, the stock market, dear friends and family. He was everyone's "go to" guy, offering sound advice, encouragement, help and love to anyone who asked. Services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, in Woodbury, LI, at 2 PM, on Monday, April 3rd. The family is requesting that donations be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering in NYC.

description: SHANGHAI, March 28 - Song Tiping, a peasant from rural Jiangsu Province, and Bernie Kearsley-pratt, an Australian executive, would not at first glance seem to have much in common, and they do not, except for one thing: both were drawn here by the unlikely financial promise of garbage, towering mountains of refuse that attest to this city's status as a raging boomtown. And now they spend their days in a cat-and-mouse game, Mr. Song joining throngs of poor Chinese scavenging in the trash and Mr. Kearsley-pratt, who manages Shanghai's largest municipal dump, trying to keep them out.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Detained By Police Dies
description: A Queens man died on Saturday afternoon after police officers and medical workers restrained him and took him to a hospital, the police said. Officers answering a report of a man walking in traffic near Hillside Avenue and Francis Lewis Boulevard took the man into custody after he became uncooperative, the police said. The man, who was identified as Nacole Davenport, 29, of 97th Avenue, was taken to Queens Hospital Center, where he suffered a heart attack and died, the police said.

description: WASHINGTON, April 2 - For the second time in two weeks, a former general has called for the resignation of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld over what both generals described as serious mistakes made in the war in Iraq.

description: WASHINGTON, April 4 - Rep. Tom DeLay will announce on Tuesday that he will not seek re-election and will leave Congress within months, according to congressional aides.

description: Well, I'll be damned. At least, that's what the Rev. Jerry Falwell says. Last month Mr. Falwell issued a statement explaining that, in his view, Jews can't go to heaven unless they convert to Christianity. And what Mr. Falwell says matters -- maybe not in heaven, but here on earth. After all, he's a kingmaker in today's Republican Party.

description: The chaotic Medicare prescription drug program seems to be stumbling less lately. Complaints and callers' waiting times are diminishing, and many previously uninsured patients are clearly saving money on drug purchases. But the program now faces two hurdles that may shed light on whether it is on the road to recovery or perhaps irredeemably flawed.

description: Patronage hiring was so pervasive at New Jersey's state medical school, that the job applications of potential employees were given a numerical grade to indicate the strength of their political connections, according a report released today by the federal monitor.

description: A gunman opened fire in a crowded Bronx nightclub early yesterday, killing a 30-year-old man and wounding two other people before fleeing, the police said.

title: The Numbers Do Not Lie: 43 for Carter, 12 for the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 2 - Heat Coach Pat Riley praised the Nets for their balance before Sunday night's game, saying there was more to the N.B.A.'s hottest team than the high-flying Vince Carter.

title: Caleb Foote, Law Professor and Pacifist Organizer, 88, Dies
description: Caleb Foote, whose moral sense influenced him to go to prison for refusing to do even noncombatant work in World War II, then led him to become a law professor known for advocacy of criminal rights, died on March 4 at a hospital in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 88.

description: "Maybe I'm kidding myself, but having a gun makes me feel safer."

title: Delgado Will Bat Cleanup in Today's Opener
description: On a sun-splashed afternoon, about 13,000 season-ticket holders showed up at Shea Stadium yesterday to watch the Mets work out. Opening day was 24 hours away -- with the forecast calling for rain this afternoon -- but the boisterous fans were in midseason form, clamoring for autographs and offering encouragement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Scuffles With Police
description: A 19-year-old man who threatened a police officer with a knife yesterday was wounded in a scuffle with the officer, the police said. The police said the man, whom they declined to identify, had a history of mental problems. Shortly before 5 p.m., in the Liberty Avenue subway station of the C line in East New York, witnesses saw the man lunge at the officer, the police said. The officer then fired his gun, the police said, and although the man was not struck, he sustained a head wound in the confrontation. They said the man was in stable condition last night at Brookdale Hospital. The officer was not injured.

title: Frist Is Treading a Perilous Path Leading to 2008
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 - History does not bode well for Bill Frist, and he knows it.

title: Mitsubishi Harnesses Colored Lasers to Produce New-Generation Lightweight HDTV
description: As if shopping for new flat-panel, high-definition television is not hard enough, Mitsubishi is scheduled to announce this week that it has developed commercial television that uses colored lasers to display bright, deep images on large, thin, lightweight screens -- surpassing images seen on film. The television sets, which Mitsubishi is calling the first of their kind, are expected to reach stores sometime late next year.

title: Charles Taylor Pleads Not Guilty to War Crimes
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, April 3 A In his first appearance before a special international tribunal, Charles G. Taylor, the former Liberian president, pleaded not guilty to 11 counts of war crimes, but not before refusing to recognize the court's jurisdiction and accusing it of attempting to meddle in the region's affairs.

title: At the Four A's, a Focus on Getting Stronger
description: AS the leaders of Madison Avenue prepare to gather for a major annual conference, they are being advised to heed some famous words from the German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche: What does not kill you makes you stronger.

title: Wright Helps Mets Open With a Bang
description: David Wright's sixth-inning home run provided the margin of victory as the Mets defeated the Washington Nationals, 3-2, in their season opener today on a chilly, blustery afternoon at Shea Stadium. Billy Wagner, making his Mets debut, punctuated the triumph by recording the save and preserving Tom Glavine's 276th career victory.

title: CBS News Appears to Be Close to a Deal With Katie Couric
description: CBS's long courtship of Katie Couric has moved close to a conclusion, and a deal to recruit her away from NBC's "Today" show and into the nightly anchor chair at CBS News may be completed as early as this week, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Justices, 6-3, Sidestep Ruling on Padilla Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 A A sharply split Supreme Court today rejected an appeal from the terrorism suspect Jose Padilla, leaving undecided for now deeper questions about the Bush administration's handling of detainees since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

description: BADY--Sophie. Of Delray Beach, FL, passed away on March 31, 2006. Cherished wife of David; beloved mother of Michael. For information call Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel: 1 - 800 992-9262.

title: Citing a Legal Snarl, Official at Deutsche Bank Resigns
description: FRANKFURT, April 2 - Unable to shake a long-running legal dispute with a former client of his bank, the supervisory board chairman of Deutsche Bank, Rolf E. Breuer, resigned on Sunday, saying he wanted to "relieve Deutsche Bank of further discussion" of his case.

title: As Kurds Protest, Violence Claims 4 More in Turkey
description: KIZILTEPE, Turkey, April 2 - The police opened fire to disperse Kurdish demonstrators in southeastern Turkey on Sunday, killing one protester, security officials said. Three more people died when a gasoline bomb that the police said appeared to be linked to the Kurdish protests was thrown into a bus in Istanbul, the officials said.

title: Wireless: Internet calling via cellphones
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLAFFER, HELEN
description: SCHLAFFER--Helen. Attorney, born in Oshawa, Canada, died on March 26, 2006. Wife of the late Alex Schlaffer. Daughter of the Reverend Vladamir Kupchynski and Theodora. She practiced law with her sister Olga Kupchin, also an attorney, among the Ukranian immigrants who came to the US after WWII. After 40 years of law practice she devoted her life to church work at the Church of the Covenant. She is survived by her sister Olga Kupchin and two nieces, Mary Pohli and Joan Mahony. A memorial will be held at the Church of the Covenant on East 42nd St. on Thursday, April 6, at 11AM

title: The Health of a Nation
description: Washington - IN the past five years, private health insurance premiums have risen 73 percent. Some businesses have responded by dropping healthcare coverage, leaving employees uninsured. Other employers pass the costs on to workers, both by raising co-payments and premiums and by denying workers the wage increases they need to afford these higher prices.

description: California may become the first state to impose limits on the emissions of all greenhouse gases, under legislation introduced today in the State Assembly.

description: WASHINGTON, April 2 - It was just a few hours after President Bush named Joshua B. Bolten as his new chief of staff last Tuesday, and Mr. Bolten was already acting on one of the White House's top priorities: soothing disgruntled Republicans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, PATRICIA FREEMAN
description: BROWN--Patricia Freeman. Beloved wife of the late Lees S. Brown. Loving mother of Alison and David, and dear sister of Joan Freeman Williams. Her gentle, caring spirit and beautiful mind touched more people than we will ever know. Patricia was an active member of the Audubon Society.

description: GIVEN that it was a memorial for the recently departed, the cramped affair stuffed into a Harlem apartment was an upbeat, fashion-forward event. Young women moved about in vintage black dresses with well-coiffed hair topped by Jackie O. pillboxes.
