title: Terrorists or Victims?
description: In Sierra Leone there is a woman who was kept captive in her house for four days by guerrillas. The rebels raped her and her daughter and cut them with machetes. Under America's program to resettle refugees, she would be eligible to come to safety in the United States. But her application for refuge has been put on indefinite hold -- because American law says that she provided "material support" to terrorists by giving them shelter.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Proposal To Buy Police Vests
description: The speaker of the City Council, Christine C. Quinn, proposed yesterday that the city spend $9.9 million to buy better bulletproof vests for the Police Department. Ms. Quinn, who was joined at a news conference at City Hall by Patrick J. Lynch, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said that only about half of the city's 36,000 police officers have been outfitted with the newest vest, known as Level 3A. Ms. Quinn said she would include the money in her budget response this week. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the Police Department should decide what was in the best interests of its officers.

title: Slide Show: Dream Night for Florida
description: The greatest night in Florida basketball history came at the expense of U.C.L.A.

title: Photos
description: The following soldiers were photographed by Warrant Officer Michael D. Fay in Ubaydi, Iraq, in Nov. 2005, during Operation Steel Curtain. All three died in fighting a few days later.

title: Slide Show: Characters of All Shapes and Sizes
description: Scenes from the Tokyo International Anime Fair, the sublimely dorky annual convention for Japanese animation.

title: Canadian Grocer Sells Stores
description: Sobeys Inc. announced Friday it has sold 11 Ontario Cash and Carry stores and is closing three outlets of the no-frills banner in Ontario and Quebec. Canadas second-largest grocery store chain said it has sold the 11 Ontario stores to The Skor Food Group Inc.

title: Ameristar Casinos Enters Bidding War for Owner of Tropicanas
description: Ameristar Casinos offered to buy Aztar for $42 a share, creating a three-way bidding contest with Colony Capital and Pinnacle Entertainment Corp. The offer values Phoenix-based Aztar at $2.25 billion.

title: BAE Said to Be Considering Sale of Airbus Stake
description: BAE Systems, Britains largest defense contractor, is considering selling its 20 per cent stake in Airbus, the European aircraft maker. Senior industry executives told The Telegraph that the company could make a final decision on the sale, which could raise more than 3 billion pounds, within the next few months.

title: Two Funeral Giants to Merge in $856 Million Deal
description: Service Corporation International is expected to announce today that it has agreed to buy the outstanding shares of Alderwoods Group in an $856 million deal that would combine the nations largest and second-largest funeral and cemetery companies.

title: Votes Back Boston Scientific-Guidant Deal
description: American and European regulatory approval is the final hurdle for Boston Scientifics $27 billion acquisition of the Guidant Corporation after shareholders of both companies approved the merger Friday.

title: AT&T and BellSouth Formally Ask for Merger Approval
description: Allowing the parent companies of Cingular Wireless  to merge will help eliminate challenges they now face in managing the nations largest cell phone provider, AT&T and BellSouth said in papers filed with the government Friday.

title: Citic Buys Stake in Hong Kong Bank
description: Citic International Financial Holdings Ltd., controlled by Chinas biggest investment firm, plans to buy a stake in its parents Beijing-based lender for HK$5.54 billion ($715 million). The company, which has banking, asset management and investment bank units in Hong Kong, said in a statement today it will buy 19.9 percent of China Citic Bank.

title: Goldman Consortium May Be Planning Revised Offer for British Ports
description: A Goldman Sachs-led consortium that last week made an unsolicited indicative offer for Associated British Ports was this weekend considering raising its offer in order to win the backing of management for its bid.

title: Chiron Shareholders Get Conflicting Opinions on Novartis Offer
description: Two firms that evaluate merger and acquisition offers are giving Chiron shareholders conflicting advice on the veteran biotechnology companys proposed purchase by Novartis .

title: British Supermarket Chain Hires Rothschild as Bid Rumors Swirl
description: Supermarket group Wm Morrison has appointed investment bank NM Rothschild as its adviser, prompting speculation that the beleaguered retailer is possibly expecting some form of takeover activity. Morrisons long-time investment bank was ABN Amro, which advised chairman Sir Ken Morrison on his takeover of Safeway  an acquisition that has proved very costly to profits and reputations.

title: Energy Alliance Seen for Nymex and Chicago Mercantile Exchange
description: As the Chicago Mercantile Exchange hammers out its new strategy for capturing a piece of the highly prized energy futures business, it might again turn to the New York Mercantile Exchange to play a leading role.

title: Citigroup Sells Indonesian Asset Management Firm to Fortis
description: Citigroup has sold its asset management business in Indonesia to the local arm of Fortis Investment for an undisclosed amount.

title: Readers Digest Gobbles Up Allrecipes.com
description: Seattle recipe-sharing site Allrecipes.com is quoting Food Network host Rachael Rays trademark line  How awesome is that?  after being sold for $66 million to the publisher of Rays new magazine. Readers Digest Association will use Allrecipes.com as an online portal to its food Web sites and magazines, such as Taste of Home and Every Day with Rachael Ray.

title: Fred Leighton, Jeweler to the Stars, Is Sold
description: Fred Leighton, purveyor of estate jewels to the rich and famous, has a new owner of its own to chime about. Ralph Esmerian, a fourth-generation fine jewelry dealer, has acquired the 35-year-old jewelry company in cooperation with lending partner Global Asset Based Finance Group, a division of Merrill Lynch, for an undisclosed sum.

title: McClatchy In Bind Over Newspaper Sale
description: As McClatchy weighs the bids it received this week for the 12 Knight Ridder papers it is selling  including The San Jose Mercury News  observers say the Sacramento company must balance the need for a quick deal with holding out for top dollar.

title: Newark and Boston Law Firms to Merge
description: Midsize litigation and construction law firm Gadsby Hannah  of Boston has agreed to merge with McCarter & English  to create a 430-lawyer firm with eight offices in the Northeast. If both firms partners approve, Gadsby and Newark, N.J.-based McCarter expect to combine on June 1.

title: Investment Ranks Raise Advising Rates as M&A Demand Grows
description: The boom in mergers and acquisitions that is sweeping the globe has just about everyone from Wall Street to Canary Wharf working overtime and getting a lot richer. If Goldman Sachs , the No. 1 merger specialist the past five years, is any indication, the New York-based firm is selling its advice in 83 transactions so far in 2006, up 24 percent from this point last year.

title: Morgan Stanley and LVMH Await Paris Courts Ruling
description: A French appeals court has set June 30 as the date it will deliver its decision as Morgan Stanley seeks to fend off a January 2004 ruling of gross misconduct and a 30 million euro, or $36 million, penalty related to its equity research about LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton.

title: Valero Holdings Files for I.P.O.
description: Valero GP Holdings , a holding company of Valero Energy , filed with regulators Friday to offer up to $474 million in an initial public offering of units.

title: Polar Capital Plans Offering on Londons AIM
description: Polar Capital Partners, the hedge fund manager backed by Caledonia Investments, is to go public on Londons AIM market later this year with an expected value of between 50 million pounds and 70 million pounds.

title: Chinese Chip Maker Prices I.P.O. at Mid-Range
description: Chinese chip maker Advanced Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp  has priced its IPO at the mid-point of the indicated range, allowing it to raise HK$650.7 million ($84 million) before the April 7 trading debut.

title: Death by Smiley Face: When Media Rivals Disdain Profit
description: There is a new breed of rival lurking online for traditional media. These new-media ventures dont really aim to compete in the first place; their creators are merely taking advantage of the economics of the online medium to do something that they feel good about. If your name were, say, Rupert or Sumner, they would represent the kind of terror that might keep you up at night: death by smiley face.

title: Freewebs Looking to Be the Next  MySpace
description: Freewebs is $1 million closer to turning its Web site-building service into the worlds next MySpace.com. The company already has 10 million members using its tools to create Web sites, online photo albums and blogs. I

title: Deutsche Bank Finance Chief to Replace Chairman
description: Deutsche Bank, Germanys biggest bank, said finance chief Clemens Boersig will become supervisory board chairman and replace Rolf Breuer, who resigned to help shield the company from a legal battle with media entrepreneur Leo Kirch.

title: Google Pockets $2 Billion in Stock Sale
description: Google  raised $2.07 billion in a stock sale that will bolster cash reserves to fight Yahoo and Microsoft. The 5.3 million shares were priced at $389.75 each, Mountain View, California-based Google said Friday in a statement. Its second stock sale in seven months raised more than Googles $1.67 billion initial public offering in August 2004.

title: Monster.com Founder Starts New Venture for Those 50 and Older
description: Jeff Taylor, the Bay State entrepreneur who founded the popular job search Web site Monster.com, is preparing for his golden years  and everyone elses too. Taylor has raised $10 million in venture capital for a new project called Eons, designed to cater to the millions of Americans aged 50 or older. Mr. Taylor described Eons as a media company but refused to provide details about what features and services it will offer. He wouldnt even confirm that Eons will be an Internet business when it launches in July.

title: Cosmetic  Surgery Firms are Sitting Pretty With VC Dollars
description: Aesthetic medical device makers have never looked better to venture investors. Companies targeting such flaws as crows feet, sun spots and cellulite have attracted a flurry of interest from financiers lately, with at least three Bay Area firms raising more than $40 million in the past two months.

title: G.M. to Sell Majority Stake in GMAC for $8 Billion
description: General Motors is expected to announce a deal today to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, GMAC, to a group of investors led by Cerberus Capital Management for about $8 billion in cash, according to people involved in the negotiations. The complex deal could be worth as much as $14 billion total over time, these people said.

title: Consortium Said to Be Opening Tender for VNU Amid Shareholder Resistance
description: A group of private equity firms is set to open the tender for its takeover of information provider VNU on Monday, The Wall Street Journal reported. The consortium  including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and Blackstone Group  announced a bid of 28.75 euros per share on March 8 for Netherlands-based VNU, but some shareholders have said they would not support the offer once it was formally opened.

title: British Entrepreneur  Poised for Pubs Bid
description: Robert Tchenguizs R20 investment vehicle is putting the finishing touches on a 2.6 billion pound bid for Mitchells & Butlers, the owner of the All Bar One chain of bars and Harvester restaurants.

title: Air America Founders Seek Their Own Stations
description: Anita and Sheldon Drobny, two of the founders of Air America Radio, are taking the next step to ensure that liberal programming stays on the air: obtaining radio stations. The couple has announced plans to begin buying or leasing radio stations across the United States through their new company, Nova M Radio.

title: A Passion for Racing Got Formula 1 Deal Done
description: CVC Capital Partners last week completed its acquisition of Formula 1 by buying out the remaining 14 percent shareholder, Lehman Brothers, in Formula 1 founder Bernie Ecclestones holding company.

title: Radio Industry Said to Seek Deal to Settle Payoff Accusations
description: The nations biggest radio broadcasters are in discussions with the Federal Communications Commission to resolve accusations that station programmers accepted improper payments from record companies in exchange for playing specific songs, according to press reports.

title: Questions in Germany Over Secret Gazprom Loan
description: Germanys former chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, faces calls for a parliamentary inquiry after it emerged that his ministers approved a secret 900 million loan guarantee for a Gazprom project last October, just before he left office.

title: 2 Sides Differ Over Results of Hearing on Microsoft
description: Microsoft left a two-day antitrust hearing in Brussels on Friday claiming it had reached a breakthrough with European regulators, but regulators and rivals dismissed the claim as an exaggeration. Microsoft was making a last-ditch attempt to avoid daily fines of up to two million euros ($2.4 million) for failing to honor an antitrust ruling handed down by the European Commission in March 2004.

title: European Regulators Likely to Start Action Against France Over Foreign Investment
description: The European Commission is likely to begin legal action against France on Tuesday over a French decree declaring 11 business sectors, from casinos to military technology, off limits to foreign investment. The decision will intensify a growing showdown between the commission and Paris over concerns that France is increasingly skewing markets and industries for domestic political and commercial ends

title: In the Enron Trial, Intent Is in the Mind of Defendants
description: What were Ken Lay and Jeff Skilling thinking? A lot of what will happen to them in their fraud and conspiracy trial will come down to what was in their heads. That is, what they knew about Enrons financial health and what they intended while talking about it to investors, analysts and their own employees.

title: Google Earth May Get Support in Patent Suit
description: Google may get a break from a federal judge in a lawsuit claiming the companys 3D Earth-mapping program violates patent rights. In a preliminary order released last week, U.S. District Judge Douglas Woodlock in Massachusetts appeared to side with Googles interpretations of the patent in question, a stance that could bode well for the search giant as the case moves on.

title: Does the S.E.C. Have It Out for Hedge Funds?
description: No one in the hedge fund community would risk saying it publicly, but some hedge fund money managers are claiming the Securities and Exchange Commission is on a vendetta against the $1.2 trillion industry.

title: Law Firms Wonder if Hedge Funds Are Really a Boon
description: The breathtaking size of the hedge fund industry is enough to make any corporate lawyer salivate. And its not just the dollars that demand attention: Hedge funds have been behind some splashy deals in the last few years.

title: The Math Whiz vs. the Media Moguls in a Battle for Millions
description: The relationship between News Corporation, Liberty Media and Henry C. Yuen, the former chairman and chief executive of Gemstar who has been accused of manipulating hundreds of millions in revenue to make the company look more profitable, has turned into a tangled web of lawsuits and broken partnerships.

title: The Nuisance That May Cost Billions
description: In a surprising and devastating verdict for the paint industry, a Rhode Island jury found four paint manufactuers liable for the states decades-old lead-contamination problem.

title: Sourcefire Forges Ahead With I.P.O. Plans
description: Sourcefire, undeterred by the breakup of its $225 million sale to an Israeli company, is planning to go public in the fourth quarter. The company agreed in October to be sold to Check Point Software Technologies. But the companies called it off March 23 as the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States neared the end of an investigation into the deal.

title: Charity Accuses Thomas Lee and Merrill Lynch of Inflating Investment Values
description: A Florida-based charitable foundation is accusing TH Lee Putnam Ventures and Merrill Lynch Alternative Investments of inflating the value of companies that TH Lee Putnam financed via a $1.1 billion fund it launched in 2000.

title: Lucent and Alcatel Do Some Fancy Footwork to Allay Merger Fears
description: To allay concerns in Washington about a foreign company having access to the secretive work Bell Labs does for American defense and intelligence agencies, Lucent and Alcatel  said as part of the merger agreement they would create an independent subsidiary that would be overseen by a board of three American citizens. Defense contractors in similar situations frequently use such corporate structures to assure government officials that classified research is not available to foreign powers.

title: 60 Minutes Gives Its Take on the Biovail-Hedge Fund Lawsuit
description: Whenever the mass media drops in on Wall Street, the results are always, well, strange. After all, mass media is all about simple nostrums and lowest common denominators, merrily dividing the world into predators and victims. Much of Wall Street, however, thrives on complexity; its hard to assign white hats and black hats.

title: Ameristar Ups the Ante With $2.25 Billion Aztar Bid
description: A third bidder entered the race to acquire casino operator Aztar early Monday, as Ameristar Casinos announced an all-cash offer of $42 a share for the company. The offer, which Ameristar valued at $2.25 billion including the assumption of debt, tops previous bids from real estate investor Colony Capital and casino owner Pinnacle Entertainment.

title: Slide Show: Mets Start With a Bang
description: The Mets defeated the Washington Nationals in their season opener on a chilly, blustery afternoon at Shea Stadium.

title: Newark, U.S.A.: Robert Curvin
description: Robert Curvin is still haunted by the summer night in 1967 when the Newark riots began. He was then one of the citys leading Civil Rights activists, so when rumors started swirling that a black cab driver, John Smith, had been arrested, beaten and killed by white police officers, he was among those chosen to enter the precinct where Mr. Smith was being held.

title: Alcatel Shares Jump as Lucent Deal Terms Emerge
description: Shares of Alcatel surged more than 7 percent in Paris trading on Monday, after the French telecommunications company announced that it had nailed down terms of its proposed $13.4 billion merger with United States-based Lucent Technologies. Many French research analysts praised the match-up and the synergies it would create.

title: For Hedge Funds, Life Just Got a Bit More Complicated
description: The hedge fund industry has its fair share of complaints about news coverage, but one issue that particularly irks managers and that can be easily remedied is a frequently employed two-word description: lightly regulated. According to The Times Jenny Anderson, however, the new registration requirements make hedge fund advisers subject to the same rules as mutual fund advisers, except that they do not face the limitations that mutual fund advisers face on performance fees. Nothing lightly regulated about that. But compared with mutual funds or broker dealers, hedge funds still have it easy.

title: Justices, 6-3, Sidestep Ruling on Padilla Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  A sharply split Supreme Court today rejected an appeal from the terrorism suspect Jose Padilla, leaving undecided for now deeper questions about the Bush administration's handling of detainees since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Questions of Security in Iraq
description: There were no gold watches and bland encomiums from colleagues for Bill Emmott, the longtime editor of The Economist who stepped down over the weekend. Rather, he used his farewell column to defend one of the magazines most heavily criticized editorial stands: its support for the invasion of Iraq.

title: That Old Cru of Mine
description: Do you have time for a story? Its about Grand Crew, my martial arts wine and food group, which Ive mentioned a few times in The Pour. But more important, its about how I like to drink wine and what makes it important, to me and probably to most people who really love it. I would guess that many of you even have a story similar to the one Im about to tell.

title: Swatting Down a Merger Rumor

title: Texas Pacifics Latest Fund Said to Reach $14 Billion
description: Who has the biggest buyout fund? So far, Blackstone Group seemed to be in the lead with its latest $13.5 billion investment vehicle, which is expected to close shortly. But now comes private equity firm Texas Pacific Group, which reportedly will tell investors this week that it has raised a record $14 billion for its latest buyout fund.

title: How To Help Mukhtaran
description: I should have thought of it ahead of time, but Ive had plenty of inquiries about how readers can help Mukhtar Mai. There are two ways to donate funds. One is through www.4anaa.org (a great human rights organization that has championed her case) and another is through www.mercycorps.org, which set up the original fund for her. In either case, you should specify in your donation that it is for Mukhtar.

The reporter's phone rings at 5 a.m. with a text message directing her to a "code red" breaking news story  a bank robbery. The camera pans a sleek instant-espresso machine, a well-groomed hand methodically applying pink lipstick, a foot snuggling into a stiletto-heeled pump, and a row of identical expensive ballpoint pens. The reporter selects one, then sails out the door, ready for her stand-up.

(What did she say when St. Peter offered her whatever she wished?) In his rare interviews, the playwright Martin McDonagh has insistently sounded like that joke, making it clear that he is a child of the movies, a playwright by default despite his brilliant career. Well, it turns out that he's right.

title: Tonsil-Adenoid Surgery May Help Behavior, Too

description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 3  A federal jury on Monday found that Zacarias Moussaoui was responsible for some of the deaths that occurred on Sept. 11, 2001, and was thus eligible to be executed. The unanimous verdict removes the greatest hurdle to the government's obtaining a death sentence.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 3  In the deadliest day for American forces since the beginning of the year, at least nine members of the military were killed in the insurgent stronghold of Anbar Province, including four in a rebel attack and at least five when their truck accidentally flipped over, the American military command said Monday.

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Spitzer's Medicaid Investigations Cleared
description: A federal examination of the politically charged field of Medicaid fraud found nothing striking about how Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's office investigates such cases. The Department of Health and Human Services' Office of the Inspector General reported that Mr. Spitzer's office generally complies with federal rules, with minor failings in certain areas and strengths in others. It found that Mr. Spitzer's office did not have a written policy on undercover investigations, and had used equipment intended for Medicaid fraud work on unrelated cases, both violations of federal policies. As Mr. Spitzer, a Democrat, runs for governor, his rivals have called him weak on Medicaid fraud, and Republican lawmakers requested the federal review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARAKASH, JOHN J.
description: KARAKASH--John J., 1914-2006. Educator, humanitarian and athlete, died Wednesday, March 22. Distinguished Professor and Dean Emeritus of Engineering at Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA, he was also internationally recognized for focusing attention on citizenship, foreign affairs and ethics in public policy. Many recent Editorial Page contributions on these issues were published in the Allentown based Morning Call. Born in Turkey June 14, 1914 of Greek parents, he entered the U.S. with an athletic scholarship after winning the 1935 Balkan nations' Olympic Games javelin event. He earned a B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering from Duke in 1937, and entered the University of Pennsylvania as a Moore Fellow, completing a Master of Science degree in 1938. He taught briefly at Park College outside Kansas City and served as Education Director at American Television Laboratories in Chicago. He helped improve and train military staff in the use of defense equipment including radar, later joining the team developing ENIAC, recognized as the first electronic computer. He also collaborated with Hanemann Medical College scientists in the study of mechanical hearts. Professor Karakash joined the Lehigh faculty in 1946, was named Head of the Electrical Engineering department in 1956 and ten years later became Dean of the College of Engineering, a position he held until retirement in 1981. He received many University awards including an Honorary Doctorate in 1971 and the naming of a rebuilt wing of Parkard Laboratory in his honor in 1981. A quotation on the dedication plaque expresses his way of life: "...our goal is to produce good people-young men and women who learn to think to the point where thinking is a habit, who have been exposed to and encouraged to develop and live by a set of values, who have developed methods and approaches to the intelligent application of knowledge and, last but not least, who accept the virtue of work as a vehicle of service and the will to work as a self-discipline." He was active in professional and honorary societies, served on advisory boards, was a member of the Professional Accrediting Society for Engineering Colleges and consulted for major corporations. His listing in Who's Who in America ends with this quote: "In free societies, whenever rules and regulations, because of changing times, are in conflict with principles, it is the principles that need be conserved, and the conflicting rules and regulations summarily discarded." He was predeceased by the late Marjorie Rutherford Karakash, his wife of fifty years; a brother, Theodore and sister, Nina Karakash Papadopoulos. Surviving are a son, John of Lewisburg, PA, sister-in-law Roxanne, grandchildren, nieces, nephews and two great - granddaughters. He resided at Kirkland Village, Bethlehem, PA in recent years. A memorial service will be held Monday, April 10 at 4:10pm in Packer Chapel on the Lehigh University Campus. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to the donor's choice of The Salvation Army, PO Box 269, Alexandria, VA 22313; the Northampton County ASPCA, 1165 Island Park Road, Easton, PA 18042; or the Cancer Research and Prevention Foundation, 1600 Duke Street, Alexandria, VA 22314.

Mphasis, based in Bangalore, employs 12,000 workers who provide accounting, customer support and payroll services to companies in industries like financial services, technology and health care. Progress in Distributing New Book Formats
description: Efforts to bring readers new formats for books are continuing as Sony Electronics announced a deal yesterday to sell its much vaunted Sony Reader in 200 Borders stores when the Reader begins sales in midsummer (a delay from original plans for spring). Borders will be the only book chain to sell the Reader at first. It will also be available at SonyStyle stores and online, and will cost $300 to $400. Borders will sell accessories and prepaid cards to use when downloading the books from Sony's Web site (connect.com). Several thousand titles will be available for the Reader, right. In a separate deal, a consortium of nonprofit publishers, booksellers and a print-on-demand publisher announced that it was starting a project called Caravan, scheduled for spring 2007, to make 24 forthcoming titles simultaneously available in hardcover, paperback, print-on-demand, digital and audio formats. The idea is that no buyer should ever go into a bookstore and be turned away because the book is out of stock, said Peter Osnos, publisher of PublicAffairs and executive director of Caravan. Participating publishers include University of North Carolina Press, Yale University Press and the Council on Foreign Relations Press.

description: The family of Elizabeth Shin, a 19-year-old college student who died in a fire she set in her dormitory room in 2000, has reached a settlement with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she was a sophomore, the university said. The settlement, whose terms were not disclosed, resolved a wrongful-death lawsuit brought by Ms. Shin's parents. The lawsuit charged that two members of the university's staff, a university librarian who was a faculty mentor or "house master" in Ms. Shin's dormitory and an associate dean, did not provide adequate care for their daughter and failed to notify her family of her psychiatric problems. Ms. Shin's family also agreed to drop a separate lawsuit against four M.I.T. psychiatrists; a lawsuit against M.I.T. itself was dismissed last year. JONATHAN D. GLATER (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Fresh Fare Sells
description: Reruns littered the Sunday schedule, making it all the easier for ABC's lineup of original episodes to squash the competition. Its "Desperate Housewives" (an estimated 22.03 million viewers) and "Grey's Anatomy" (22.39 million) cleaned up in all ratings measurements. Earlier in the evening, two episodes of ABC's "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (7.87 million, then 13.2 million) were on the low end of the ratings for the sob-inducing home show, but they still dominated their time slots among 18-to-49 year-olds in Nielsen's estimates. The 8 p.m. "Home" beat a new episode of CBS's "Cold Case" (12.23 million), Fox's "Simpsons" (7.83 million) and a "Loop" rerun (5.73 million), and NBC's "West Wing" (7.31 million). That political drama, once formidable in the ratings, ended the Election Day episode with Annabeth (Kristin Chenoweth) walking into Leo's room, presumably to find him collapsed. Leo, the vice presidential candidate, was played by John Spencer, who died of a heart attack in December; next week's "West Wing" will deal with the death of the character.

MEMO PAD
description: FARE FANDANGO -- On Friday, United Airlines announced a $50 increase in one-way business fares (the last-minute ones typically purchased by business travelers). Desperate for revenue as oil prices rise, most major airlines matched the increases by United Airlines over the weekend. But they hastily withdrew them yesterday when American Airlines failed to join in. "American would just not go along with the $50," said Terry Trippler, who is an analyst at Cheapseats.com. By early last night, all of the major airlines except the recently merged US Airways/America West Airlines had said "Never mind" and backed away. On the other hand, major airlines raised fares $2 to $5 each way on their lowest-priced tickets, commonly referred to as leisure fares. "That seems to be holding," Mr. Trippler said. And on Friday, Delta Air Lines began passing on to customers "airport passenger facility fees," user charges that many airports assess airlines. As of yesterday, United Airlines had joined Delta in passing on the airport fees, which airlines have traditionally absorbed and which can range up to $18 for a round trip, Mr. Trippler said. American Airlines was absorbing the fees in some competitive markets and passing them on in others, while other competitors had not yet clearly signaled their intentions, he said.

title: Taking the Jumpy Pulse of Life in a Rio Slum
description: An American director who made a series like "City of Men," a Brazilian import that starts tonight (in Portuguese, with English subtitles) on the Sundance Channel, would probably be urged to have his meds adjusted. Shot with handheld cameras, "City of Men" is so jumpy and jangling, darting from one scene to the next, that it feels hyperactive. The show also races through dramatic mood swings, spinning in an instant from, say, slapstick to violence, or else dropping in an ominous slide show or a clever little cartoon sequence, and in an addicting, caffeinated way it gets on your nerves. If you look away for an instant, you'll probably miss something.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Ex-Colonel Ordered To Pay $47 Million In Torture Case
description: A United States District Court judge in Miami found a former Honduran Army colonel responsible for killings and kidnappings in Honduras during the 1980's and ordered him to pay $47 million to several torture victims and surviving relatives of the dead. Judge Joan A. Lenard found that the colonel, Juan Lpez Grijalba, served as chief of an intelligence unit known as Battalion 3-16, which received money and training from the United States. The unit, organized as part of the Reagan administration's effort to stop the spread of Communism in Central America, was responsible for systematic abuses against civilians suspected as subversives. Mr. Lpez Grijalba moved to Miami in 1998 but was deported in 2004. He has not faced criminal prosecution. Among the plaintiffs in the Florida suit, filed by the Center for Justice and Accountability, a human rights organization, were scar Reyes, a journalist, and his wife, Gloria, who were tortured, held for nearly five months and then forced into exile in the United States. GINGER THOMPSON (NYT)

title: Iraq Court Charges Hussein with Genocide of Kurds
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 4 - The special Iraqi court that is trying Saddam Hussein announced today t it had charged the ex-president with genocide for attempting to annihilate the Kurdish race through military operations in 1988 that killed at least 50,000 civilians and destroyed thousands of villages.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Strike Shuts Down Bus And Rail Routes
description: The Regional Transportation District in Denver was forced to shut down more than half of its daily bus and light rail routes after union workers voted to strike, leaving thousands of Denver residents stranded on their morning commute. The strike began at 2 a.m. after 55 percent of the 1,750 workers rejected a proposal that would have given them their largest wage increase to date. Officials from the Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1001 say the proposal, offering a wage increase of $1.80 an hour over a three-year period, a $250 bonus and health care contributions, was not enough. KATIE KELLEY (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Construction Platform Falls, Killing 3
description: A construction platform fell onto a traffic-choked street in downtown Boston, killing three people and injuring two. A 2,000-pound piece of the 45,000-pound lift platform broke off and fell to the street, crushing cars and sending pedestrians fleeing, said Scott Saoman, a spokesman for the Boston Fire Department. Two of the people killed were construction workers, Mr. Saoman said, and a third was crushed while sitting in a car. The building, on Boylston Street across from Boston Common, is an Emerson College dormitory that was undergoing renovations. The company, Macomber Builders, said it was investigating the matter; the police said their homicide unit was also investigating, along with the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the State Department of Public Safety. John Hynes was driving when his car was struck by metal and its roof caved in. "I'm lucky to be standing up," Mr. Hynes said. KATIE ZEZIMA (NYT)

title: Wingless Gliders May Reveal the Origins of Insect Flight

Motorolas auto unit, which traces its history back to 1930 and the first commercially successful car radio, manufactures controls, sensors, interior electronics, telematics and other equipment, selling to customers including General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler.

description: In an effort to thwart a hostile bid from Mitttal Steel, Arcelor, the worlds second biggest steelmaker, plans to transfer the shares it holds in Dofasco to a foundation, making it difficult to sell the Canadian peer, Reuters reported. Mittal has said if it succeeds in its $25.1 billion bid for Arcelor, it would sell Dofasco to ThyssenKrupp, the German company that Arcelor outbid.

description: Goldman Sachs Henry Paulson, the highest-paid chief executive on Wall Street, transferred about $100 million to a charitable foundation he established to donate to environmental causes.

title: Merrill Lynch Will Take $1.2 Billion 1Q Charge
description: Merrill Lynch & Co. said Monday it will take a $1.2 billion first-quarter charge, $850 million more than it had expected, as it switches to new accounting rules for employee stock compensation and modifies existing stock awards. The charge will nearly wipe out the $1.4 billion that analysts expect Merrill to earn in the quarter.

description: In an era of multimedia platforms and surging blogs, being the No. 2 newspaper company in the nation wont count for much without a deep commitment to an Internet strategy That challenge has not gone unnoticed by McClatchy, which in mid-March agreed to buy Knight Ridder for $6.5 billion in cash, stock and debt.

title: Electronic Data Systems Expands in India
description: Electronic Data Systems, the worlds No. 2 seller of computer services, will offer $380 million for a majority stake in Mphasis BFL to expand its business for processing loans and credit applications in India.

description: Poland on Monday maintained a tough stance in its battle to foil UniCredits plan to merge its banking units there. Warsaw rejected a European Commission demand that it accept the purchase of Bank BPH by UniCredit and BPHs merger with a Polish unit of the Italian bank.

title: Sears Boost Bid for Canadian Unit
description: Sears Holdings, the largest department-store chain in the U.S., raised its offer for Sears Canada Monday to $18 a share and extended the offer to April 18.

title: Microsoft Buys ProClarity
description: Microsoft announced Monday that it plans to acquire business analytics software developer ProClarity to increase its presence in the business intelligence market.

title: VNU Investor Rejects $7 Billion Buyout Offer
description: A private equity buyout bid of 5 billion pounds for media and information giant VNU faces failure after activist shareholder Knight Vinke rejected the offer. A consortium comprising some of the worlds largest private equity buyout firms  including Alpinvest, Carlyle, Hellman and Friedman, Thomas H Lee, KKR and Blackstone Group  sent out its offer document for VNU yesterday.

title: Iconix Tries On 2 Clothing Companies
description: Iconix Brand Group on Monday said it has agreed to buy Mossimo, which makes clothes sold in Target stores, in a deal valued at about $119 million, as the company looks to expand its brand portfolio. New York-based Iconix also agreed to buy the Mudd brand for $88 million, and raised its earnings forecast for the year.

title: Buyout Group Acquires  Worlds Largest Dialysis Maker
description: Investor AB and EQT Partners AB agreed to buy Gambro AB, the worlds largest maker of dialysis products, for 38.3 billion Swedish kronor ($4.9 billion).

title: Signs That Biotech Has a Healthier Future
description: The biotechnology industry is finally getting closer to an elusive goal: breaking even. The industry has lost tens of billions of dollars since Genentech, the first genetic engineering company, was founded 30 years ago this Friday.

title: Medical Treatment Startup Gets a little Help from Hedge Funds
description: Seeking to develop treatments for autoimmune diseases and cancer, Cambridge, Mass.-based Merrimack Pharmaceuticals Inc. said it has raised $65 million in Series E financing supported by hedge funds and other public market investors. First-time backers participating in the round include mutual fund Jennison Associates, hedge funds Noonday Asset Management and TPG-Axon Capital, and Credit Suisse affiliate Modal Capital.

title: SAP Grabs Risk-Management Software Firm
description: SAP announced on Monday plans to acquire Virsa Systems, a regulatory-compliance and risk-management software company. Virsaalready one of SAPs partners and investment portfolio companiesis the latest acquisition target of the business applications giant. Over the past year, SAP has increased its pace of buyouts to fill out its product portfolio.

title: Venture Capitalist Backs Ballot Initiative
description: Vinod Khosla is bankrolling a ballot initiative that would tax oil producers and subsidize alternative energy  technologies he invests in as one of the valleys most prominent venture capitalists.

title: Sega Recruits Secret Level
description: Sega Holdings of USA said on Monday it has paid $15 million for Secret Level, a video game developer that helped make the console versions of the military title Americas Army.

title: Himax Stock Gains After Lackluster Nasdaq I.P.O.
description: Himax Technologies may have fallen 2.8 percent in its first day of trading on Nasdaq last Friday, but strong bidding from large investors in the aftermarket indicated good support for the fabless integrated-circuit design house at current valuations, market watchers said. In early trading Monday in the United States, the stock was up 3.4 percent at an above-I.P.O. price of $9.05.

title: In Deutsche Bank Battle, Ackermann Emerges Victorious
description: Joseph Ackermann, the controversial chief executive of Deutsche Bank, emerged yesterday as the clear winner in one of the longest and most bitter rivalries in the German banking world.

title: Marshall & Ilsley Complete Gold Bank Buy
description: The Gold Banc offices in Floridas Hillsborough, Manatee and Sarasota counties are now part of Marshall & Ilsley. Marshall & Ilsley, based in Milwaukee, bought Gold Banc in a $700 million dollar cash-and-stock deal that was completed April 1.

title: Citigroups Australian Insider-Trading Charges Will Be Test Case
description: Citigroup Inc.s insider-trading hearing in Australia will be a test case for whether barriers between investment bankers and traders can prevent conflicts of interest with clients, the countrys securities regulator said.

title: Frontenac Unloads IT Firm 101 Communications
description: Midmarket buyout firm Frontenac Co. has agreed to sell IT media company 101 Communications to fellow buyout firm Nautic Partners for $75 million, according to LBO Wire.

title: In Enron Trial, a Calculated Risk
description: Two of the countrys best corporate salesmen are about to make the most important pitches of their lives. After prosecutors rested their case last week against Enrons former chief executives, the trial has moved to what may be the make-or-break moment for both sides: the testimony of Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay. Mr. Skilling could take the stand as early as Wednesday.

title: Medical Device Maker Spiration Lands $13.4 Million
description: Spiration, a Redmond, Wash. company developing devices to treat lung disease, landed $13.4 million in venture capital to conduct clinical trials of its lead product, it said today. This latest round was led by new investor Olympus Medical Systems of Japan. Returning backers include Guidant, New Enterprise Associates, and Sprout Group.

title: Ex-Westar Officials Sentenced to Prison
description: A federal judge on Monday sentenced the former chief executive of Westar Energy, David C. Wittig, to 18 years in prison for looting millions from Westar, a Kansas utility.

title: Icahn Said to Be Backing Off Blockbuster
description: Financier Carl Icahn will not seek control of Blockbuster Inc. at its shareholder meeting next month, despite his earlier threat and the companys declining video rental revenue, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Claria, Ditching Its Unpopular Adware Profile, Nabs Funding for Web Software
description: Claria Corp. has raised $40 million as it looks to jump out of the adware business and into the increasingly crowded market for personalized homepages. Once derided for barraging users with pop-up ads, Claria has worked in recent years to clean up its act. But the company recently decided to sell off its adware technology and instead focus on its new PersonalWeb software, designed to automatically organize content, news and information on a home page customized for each user

title: G.M. Board Gives Chief Some Time
description: The board of General Motors expressed support Monday for Rick Wagoner, the companys embattled chief executive, as G.M. announced a long-anticipated deal to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, for $7.4 billion.

title: Chipotle I.P.O. Top Performer of 1st Quarter
description: Chipotle Mexican Grill, the McDonalds spinoff, closed out the first quarter as the top performer among 2006s crop of 46 IPOs. Meanwhile, the IPO market kicks off the second quarter with three hefty deals: $400 million from air-conditioning-equipment maker Goodman Global, $350 million from mattress maker Sealy, and $240 million from shipbuilder Omega Navigation Enterprises.

title: Spitzer Irked by F.C.C. Talks With Radio Groups
description: New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said Monday that federal regulators were negotiating behind his back with radio-station groups to settle illegal pay for play allegations, potentially helping the chains avoid serious punishment.

title: Andrew Kissel, Brother of Murdered Banker, Found Dead
description: Andrew Kissel, the real estate developer charged with defrauding mortgage lenders and stealing from a co-op, was found dead today in his home with multiple stab wounds, less than three years after the murder of his brother.

title: HealthSouth Woes Line Lawyers Pockets
description: HealthSouth Corp. has helped lots of lawyers become more prosperous in recent years. The Birmingham, Ala., company expects eventually to pay a total of about $147 million in legal fees for litigation expenses incurred since 2003, according to the companys annual report, which was filed last Wednesday.

title: Film Director Is Accused of Lie to F.B.I.
description: Prosecutors investigating illegal wiretapping by a former private detective, Anthony Pellicano, have charged a film director, John McTiernan, with hiring the detective to wiretap conversations of a movie producer and then lying about it to F.B.I. agents.

title: With Acquisitions Scarce, Buffett Bets on Global Markets
description: Warren Buffett, struggling to find acquisitions large enough to improve Berkshire Hathaways returns, is making a $14 billion bet on the global stock market. Berkshire sold a form of insurance to buyers who wanted protection from a drop in four major equity indexes over the next 15 to 20 years. Instead of buying the individual shares, Mr. Buffett is wagering the indexes, three of which are outside the United States, will not fall and force Berkshire to pay a claim.

title: Computer Sciences to Explore Sale and Cut Work Force
description: Computer Sciences, a technology outsourcer that engaged in failed buyout talks last year, announced early Tuesday it would consider strategic options, including a possible sale of the company. It said it has hired Goldman Sachs  as financial adviser for the strategic review, which was initiated in response to recent expressions of interest.

title: Photographs: Oil Windfall Spent on Foreign Aid
description: Venezuela's president is spending his country's oil windfall on pet projects abroad, with the aim of greater influence in the Americas.

title: Real Farming
description: Selborne Journal: Sunday, 4 April 1784: 29 7/10; 38, 42; NE, NW, SW. Frost, sun, soft & pleasant. The rooks at Faringdon have got young. Very little spring corn sown yet. Wagtail. Snow as deep as the horses belly under the hedges in the North field. Snow melts. A brace more of hares frequenting my grounds were killed in my absence: so that I hope now the garden will be safe for some time.

title: International Paper Unloads Timberlands for $6.1 Billion
description: Taking a huge step in its planned exit of the forestry business, International Paper on Tuesday announced two deals to sell about 5.1 million acres of timberland for $6.1 billion. Combined with land sales that were announced last week, the paper giant said it has reached agreements to sell about 85 percent of its United States forestlands for total proceeds of $6.5 billion.

title: M&A Bragging Rights Go to AT&T-BellSouth Advisers
description: AT&Ts $89.4 billion acquisition of BellSouth gave a big boost to the financial advisers on both sides of the deal: all five topped the the United States mergers and acquisitions league tables for the first quarter of 2006, according to the latest rankings from Thomson Financial.

title: Hedgestock: A Festival of Peace, Love and Greed

title: Science on Religion
description: A survey by University of Minnesota sociologists that found that atheists are seen as a threat to the American way of life by a large portion of the American public has Ilya Somin of The Volokh Conspiracy on the defensive. While such a prejudice may seem subtle or even illusory to many Americans, Somin catalogues ways in which open atheism hampers ones public and private life and wonders if he and his fellow nonbelievers may be in part to blame for their pariah status:To avoid misunderstanding, I am NOT suggesting that the position of atheists in the United States is worse than that of homosexuals or African-Americans. In fact, I believe the opposite is actually closer to the truth. However, the data do strongly suggest that hostility towards atheists is more widespread (even if perhaps less intensely felt) and considered more socially acceptable than racism and homophobia. Even if the survey results are biased by the unwillingness of some respondents to admit racist views, it is still noteworthy that fewer people seem to have such inhibitions about admitting hostility towards atheists.

title: Where Small Wineries Have Their Day

That helps explain why they show saintly patience with losing sports teams and touching fidelity to small shopkeepers. Also why half the country has seemed to be in revolt against a new labor law that affects a relative handful of youthful job-seekers. But for the most enduring, enjoyable and perhaps self-serving display of French fondness for the underdog, come to the Espace Champerret, a convention center in northwestern Paris, from April 7 to 10. There, as they have for more than two decades, smart Parisians flock to buy their wine. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATTERSON, JERE W.
description: PATTERSON--Jere W., 88. Resident of NYC, died April 1, 2006. He is survived by his son, Jere, Jr. & his daughters Bettina Murray, Dean Bauer and Knight Meem, eight grandchildren, two great grandchildren and a sister, Julia Hansen. A Princetonian and Rhodes Scholar at Magdalen College, Oxford, he long headed the international consulting and negotiating firm he founded in his name in 1956. He was a mergers and acquisitions pioneer for domestic and international advertising agencies and a four-time world president of the International Advertising Association. An officer and director of various corporations, he was also a member of several clubs. A longtime supporter of the Fund for Park Avenue, he was instrumental in preserving the aesthetic integrity of the Avenue. A memorial service will be held April 10 12:30 PM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St and 5th Ave., followed by a reception at the home of James Raleigh, 1112 Park Ave (90 St). Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNCAN, CHARLOTTE M.
description: DUNCAN--Charlotte M. "Betty" died Saturday, April 1, 2006. She was 89. She was born in Geneva, New York on November 25, 1916 to George and Charlotte Mulchay. She graduated with a BA from SUNY Buffalo and received her Master's in nursing from Yale University School of Nursing. A resident of Rye, New York for more than 55 years, she married Dr. Peter A. Duncan in 1942. Mrs. Duncan was a public health nurse for several years at the Henry Street Nursing Service before leaving the profession to raise her five children. She then returned to nursing in the 1970s in Tarrytown and then Stamford, CT, where she helped found the Stamford Hospice Hospital. After her retirement, she remained on the Board of Directors for several years at the Stamford Hospice Hospital. Mrs. Duncan loved to sail on Long Island Sound and elsewhere, often in the 210 class. She belonged to American Yacht Club, where she was active in the ladies and junior sailing program. She was part of teams that won two Adam's Cup National Women's Championships and the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup. She was a communicant of Christ Church in Rye. She was also a member and former director of the Good Samaritan Council, as well as a member of the 16th Twig and plum pudding maker extraordinaire. She leaves her husband; a daughter, Margaret Duncan Comfort of Newport, RI; sons, Michael B. Duncan and Peter S. Duncan of Rye; and nine grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her parents, a son, James B. Duncan and a daughter, Nancy P. Duncan. Her funeral will be Friday at 11 A.M. at Christ Church, Rye. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Richard L. Rosenthal Hospice Residence, 1029 East Main Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: Where Small Wineries Have Their Day
description: One nice thing about the French is that they like to stand up for the little guy. That helps explain why they show saintly patience with losing sports teams and touching fidelity to small shopkeepers. Also why half the country has seemed to be in revolt against a new labor law that affects a relative handful of youthful job-seekers. But for the most enduring, enjoyable and perhaps self-serving display of French fondness for the underdog, come to the Espace Champerret, a convention center in northwestern Paris, from April 7 to 10. There, as they have for more than two decades, smart Parisians flock to buy their wine. It's the Salon des Vins et Vignerons Indpendants, the semiannual show of wines from small producers representing every French wine-growing region from Aloxe-Corton to Vouvray.

description: QUICK--Regina Clarkson. Of North Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Laurel Hollow, NY, died peacefully on April 3, 2006. She was the loving daughter of the late Thomas and Mary Clarkson. Beloved wife of the late Leslie C. Quick, Jr. Loving mother of Leslie C. Quick III of Bernardsville, NJ, Thomas of Palm Beach, FL, Peter of Mill Neck, NY, Christopher of Purchase, NY, Mary Pedersen of Purchase, NY, Nancy Gibson of Winchester, MA, and Patricia deVisser of Greenwich, CT and their spouses. Devoted grandmother of Christopher, Ryan, Kelsey, Maura, Mary, Elaine, Diane, Peter, Grace, Michele, Elisabeth, Courtney, Sarah, Margaret, Rosemary, Craig, Katherine, Caroline, Peer, Paige, Madeline, Samantha, Margaret, Paul Joseph and the late Raymond Crile. Dear sister of Loretta Gallo, and the late Charles, Thomas and Mae Boch. She was a Dame of Malta, and a Dame of the Holy Sepulcher. Visiting at Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South St., Oyster Bay, NY 11771 Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. There will be a private burial with a Memorial Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue, New York, NY, on Saturday, April 8, 2006 at 9am. In lieu of flowers, donations to the LI Arthritis Foundation, 501 Walt Whitman Rd., Melville, NY 11747, or The Arthritis Foundation, 400 Hibiscus St., West Palm Beach, FL 33401, or The Intercity-Scholarship Foundation, Archdiocese of New York, 1011 First Avenue, New York, NY 10022 would be appreciated. $(6$)QUICK--Regina. The administration, trustees and staff of St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center, in Roslyn, NY, mourn the passing of Regina (Jean) Quick, longstanding friend and benefactor of the Hospital. Mrs. Quick and her late husband, Leslie, were incomparable pillars of the St. Francis community for many years, and their extraordinary leadership and generosity helped to secure St. Francis's position as one of the leading heart centers in the nation. Jean Quick was a lifetime member of the Guild of St. Francis Hospital and Les Quick, a Founder and Chairman of the discount brokerage, Quick & Reilly, was formerly Chairman of the St. Francis Board of Trustees and leader of the Hospital's most successful capital campaign to date. Jean and Les were close to the hearts of all of the members of the St. Francis family, and their friendship and support will never be forgotten. Our deepest sympathies are extended to their son Peter, who, as a member of the Board of Trustees and Co-Chair of the current capital campaign, has carried on the family tradition of leadership at St. Francis Hospital. Our condolences are also extended to Peter's brothers and sisters and the entire Quick family.

It is his dream to be a champion bodybuilder in the super heavyweight category in a sport dominated by much shorter men. Mr. Mullen is six inches taller than Arnold Schwarzenegger, who is about 6-foot-1.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Executive Named In Discrimination Lawsuit
description: A former security officer for Del Laboratories, a Long Island cosmetics and pharmaceutical company, alleges in a lawsuit that he was fired for complaining that Del's chief executive had sexually harassed him. The security officer, Stephen Dux, a retired New York police officer, says that on three occasions in April 2003, he reported to work at the Manhattan apartment and Southampton home of the executive, Dan K. Wassong, left, and found Mr. Wassong naked and screaming and cursing at him. He says that when he complained, he was fired. In his suit, filed Monday in State Supreme Court, Mr. Dux, who alleges job discrimination, is seeking unspecified financial damages from Del and Mr. Wassong, who is now retired. In 1995, Del paid $1.185 million to settle a government complaint that Mr. Wassong had sexually harassed 15 women who worked at the company. Mr. Wassong denied that he had been naked in Mr. Dux's presence or had verbally abused him. Shawn Smith, a lawyer for Del, declined to comment.

Canada Apologizes for Tax on Chinese
description: The government said it would apologize for imposing a discriminatory tax on Chinese immigrants between 1885 and 1923. "It has been a couple decades that the community has been asking for an apology from government, so I am very pleased to say the prime minister is moving forward on this," said Beverley J. Oda, the heritage minister. She did not say when the apology would be made. The head tax was intended to discourage Chinese immigration after the completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway by many Chinese laborers. Some 82,000 Chinese migrants paid the tax, which was set at $50 in 1885. It grew to $500 by 1903, the equivalent of two years' wages for many of the immigrants. CHRIS MASON (NYT)

The American citizen was identified as Dimitri Kieffer, 40, of Anchorage, Alaska. They also had a Colt magnum pistol and a global positioning system, the authorities said. Russian officials, speaking by telephone, said the men were in the village of Uelen and were being investigated. Mr. Bushby, 36, is halfway through a 12-year, 36,000-mile walk from South America to Britain, according to his Web site, goliath.mail2web.com. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

Both domestic and international carriers have steadily lost market share and revenue to private airlines like Jet Airways, Air Deccan and Kingfisher Airlines, which have attracted passengers with newer fleets, better service and cheaper tickets. The two state-run airlines have aging fleets and large work forces but they have started to buy new planes and are making efforts to improve service.

It led NBC to a win for the night in adults 18 to 49 and in total viewers, despite the fact that a 10 p.m. edition of "The Apprentice" (10.5 million) lost a large portion of "Deal" viewers. CBS's broadcast of the N.C.A.A. championship basketball game put the network in second place over all. Fox ranked third for the night.
