description: A sports article yesterday about a rally at North Carolina Central University in Durham in support of a student who said she had been raped by three Duke University lacrosse players referred incorrectly in some copies to the campus position held by Renee Clark, who said, "We want the woman to know that we're not going to let this issue just slide by." She is president of the student government association, not of the senior class.

title: Goodyear to shut 2 Europe factories
Saddam admits he swiftly doomed 148 villagers
Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about issues on the agenda as President Bush arrived in Mexico for a summit meeting referred incorrectly to a Mexican action in the United Nations Security Council. While the Mexicans have not supported he war in Iraq, they did not vote against it. A Security Council resolution effectively authorizing an attack on Iraq never came to a vote. (Go to Article)

title: Pins point to next N. Korean leader
A Clash Over Antiquities
description: To the Editor:

title: Cup Means Extra to Donovan
description: Landon Donovan said there had never been a time when the United States men's team was expected to do well in the World Cup. Until now.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill Would Penalize Utilities For Stray Voltage
description: One day after a man received an electric shock from a metal plate on a downtown street, three City Council members yesterday introduced a bill to penalize utilities for stray voltage accidents and manhole cover explosions. Consolidated Edison has said its inspectors found no stray voltage at the site where the man was jolted on Monday night, at the intersection of Broadway and White Street. The utility, responding to rules imposed after a woman was electrocuted by a metal plate in 2004, found 1,214 instances of stray voltage from December 2004 to November 2005.

title: Hussein Charged With Genocide in 50,000 Deaths
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 4 - The Iraqi court trying Saddam Hussein announced Tuesday that it had charged him with genocide, saying he sought to annihilate the Kurdish people in 1988, when the military killed at least 50,000 Kurdish civilians and destroyed 2,000 villages.

title: Merrill Expects A Cut in Profit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that first-quarter profit would be cut by $1.2 billion because of a change in policy and in accounting treatment of stock-based compensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, IRVING
description: HIRSCH--Irving. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University extends condolences to our good friend Howard Hirsch and his family on the loss of his beloved father Irving. The Hirsch family has generously supported biomedical research at the College for two decades. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his children Howard, Martin, Steven and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson, Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D, The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: British banks come under fire over fees
Yes, the New Macintosh and Windows Can Be Friends
description: YOU should see my new Windows XP computer. It's so cool looking. It's a compact, silent, rounded six-inch slab, only two inches tall. Its sidewalls are brushed aluminum, and the top is white acrylic -- with a big gray Apple logo in the middle.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe, Asia
description: EUROPE

title: Bridge Pairs Title Is Awarded
description: DALLAS, April 4 - At the Spring North American Bridge Championships of the American Contract Bridge League here, the Leventritt Silver Ribbon Pairs was won Monday by Lewis Finkel of Jupiter, Fla., and Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla. In a field of 130 pairs, they finished two boards ahead of the defending champions, Marla Chaikin of Monmouth Beach, N.J., and William Esberg of Long Branch, N.J. Third were Nell Cahn of Shreveport, La., and Joe Quinn of Richmond, Tex.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Barry Bingham Jr., former editor and publisher of The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, referred incorrectly to his battle with Hodgkin's disease. It had been in remission since the early 1970's, the family said; he had not been suffering from it in recent years. The obituary also misstated the background of Mary Lily Kenan Flagler, who married Robert Worth Bingham, founder of the family businesses. She was the widow of Henry Flagler, the early developer of South Florida, not his daughter.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about financial losses of biotechnology companies, misstated the increase in the share price for one such company, New River Pharmaceuticals. Adjusted for a split, the stock now sells for more than eight times the price of its initial offering in 2004; it has not just quadrupled.

title: CALENDAR
description: Chapter 1: The Appetizer Food in fiction will be discussed tonight at 6:30 at New York City College of Technology, 300 Jay Street (Tillary Street), Brooklyn. The event is sponsored by Alimentum to benefit the American Institute of Wine and Food. Free for student members, $15 for others: (718) 229-6565.

title: Free Flow: Can Boeing keep its lead?
5 drug makers are criminally charged in Britain
Squeezed in the Health Care Maze
description: To the Editor:

title: Citigroups Next Big Deal?
description: Charles Prince, chief executive of Citigroup, is pooh-poohing the possibility that his company will make a big acquisition  I dont think you will see us going off to the races as our primary focus has to be on organic growth, he told Bloomberg News  but that hasnt stopped Wall Street denizens from speculating about what might be his next target following the Federal Reserve Bank of New Yorks decision on Tuesday to lift a ban preventing it from making big deals.

title: Can Justice Be Taylor-Made?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Slide Show: Party Crashers
description: Scenes from the new Broadway play "Festen."

title: Slide Show: Urban Gaucho
description: In Buenos Aires, the shirts are anything but stuffed.

title: Slide Show: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Tiger by the Tail" and "Mercy on the Doorstep."

title: Slide Show: Personal Shopper
description: Flowery, colorful tableware is headed for Passover and Easter dinner tables.

title: Slide Show: Currents
description: Multiculturalism, woven into the upholstery, the art of the deal, gawking in the name of garden preservation and more.

title: Slide Show: Expert Advice With Alison Dunlap
description: First-time mountain bikers rarely take lessons. But mastering a few fundamentals can make hitting a dirt path or snowy trail a lot more pleasurable.

title: Is Biomet on the Block?
description: Shares of Biomet, which makes artificial hips and knees, rose 9.7 percent Tuesday on speculation that the company might be sold. Speculation began last week after a founder, Dane A. Miller, resigned as chief executive, and it intensified after CNBC reported that Biomet had hired Morgan Stanley to explore strategic alternatives.

title: International Paper Sells Acres of Forest in Record Deal
description: International Paper is raising a record $6.1 billion with the biggest sale of United States forest land ever. North Americas largest paper maker will sell 5.1 million acres, an area larger than the state of Massachusetts, to groups led by Resource Management Service and TimberStar. The buyers agreed to supply wood to International Papers mills for decades, the Stamford, Conn.-based company said Tuesday.

title: Alcatel Buys Thales in Move to Protect French Military Secrets
description: Thales, Europes largest military electronics maker, agreed to buy Alcatels satellite activities in exchange for shares and cash in a transaction valued at about 1.67 billion euros ($2.05 billion) that will help Thales build communications networks for the battlefield.

title: Pulling I.P.O., Fiber Chip Firm Passave Sells to PMC-Sierra
description: Dropping plans for an initial public offering after legal tangles with UTStarcom, fiber-to-the-home chip company Passave has agreed to be acquired by semiconductor giant PMC-Sierra in a $300 million stock deal.

title: After Alienware Buy, Will Dell Go Shopping?
description: When Dell announced plans last month to buy Alienware, a maker of high-end PCs for serious gamers, the deal made big news despite its small size. What made the news shocking is that the words Dell and acquisition are seldom mentioned in the same breath.

title: Maxim-ed Out: Dennis Said to Seek Sale of U.S. Magazines
description: Felix Dennis, the maverick British publisher behind bawdy lad-mag Maxim, is putting the United States unit of Dennis Publishing on the block. Allen & Company won the mandate to sell the firm, which could carry a $250 million price tag.

title: Telco Mergers Could Spur Change, Starting With Siemens
description: The wave of consolidation sweeping the telecommunications sector could clear the way for a rash of upstarts and presage the first round of equipment-gear IPOs in half a decade, writes BusinessWeek.

title: DaimlerChrysler to Cut Stake in Airbus Parent EADS
description: DaimlerChrysler and Lagardere will reduce their stakes in European Aeronautic, Defence & Space, Europes biggest aerospace company, after EADS shares rose more than five-fold in the past three years.

title: Morgan Stanley Shareholders Pull the Cord on Golden Parachutes
description: Expressing their disapproval of ousted chief Philip Purcells $60 million-plus severance package, Morgan Stanley shareholders backed a proposal Tuesday that requires the investment bank to get stockholder approval for so-called golden-parachute pay packages for departing executives.

title: Corus Condo Loans Could Spell Trouble
description: If investors in Corus Bankshares do nothing else, they should read last Sundays San Diego Union-Tribune, advises MarketWatch columnist Herb Greenberg. A headline on the front page screamed, Downtown Downturn? It was a story about the slowdown in downtown San Diegos booming condo market.

title: Computer Sciences Must Be Flexible to Get Deal Done
description: Computer Sciencess adoption of a more determined approach to a potential sale Tuesday, in combination with its restructuring efforts, appears designed to lure private equity firms and other bidders back to the table.

title: Investors Board Airplane Internet Firm
description: CAI Capital Management and other investors are looking to make high-speed Internet in the sky faster and cheaper, investing $30.6 million in AeroSat to help the company develop a system that would do just that. CAI was joined by AeroEquity and North Atlantic Capital in the deal. CAI and AeroEquity are new investors, while North Atlantic upped its stake in the Amherst, N.H.-based company.

title: Rave Wireless Dials Up $12 Million
description: Rave Wireless Inc., a New York-based cell-phone software company developing location-based services for college students, has tapped venture investors for a $12 million second round of funding. New York-based RRE Ventures joined the companys investor syndicate for the new round.

title: Seeking to Repel Mittal, Arcelor  Puts Canadian Unit Into a Trust
description: Plans announced on Tuesday by European steel company Arcelor to repel a $23 billion takeover bid by Mittal Steel left the hostile bidder undeterred. Mittal said that Arcelors plan  which included raising its dividend and putting its steel maker Dofasco into a protective trust  did not change its intention of pursuing the company, adding that its bid was not dependent on the sale of Dofasco. Nothing in this announcement alters our resolve or ability to proceed with our offer, Mittal said.

title: Stealth VC Firm Trilogy Equity Comes Out in the Open
description: New Seattle-based venture capital firm Trilogy Equity Partners, founded by former T-Mobile USA and Western Wirelesss chief executive, John Stanton, has officially begun following a flurry of speculation about its stealthy funding of local start-ups.

title: Goldman Expands Asian Coverage
description: Goldman Sachs has broadened its coverage of Asian stocks, bringing three senior analysts to the firm as executive directors. With immediate effect, Helen Zhu, Jim Hung and Kenneth Whee will join Goldman and be based in Hong Kong, Taipei and Seoul respectively.

title: Fastwebs Dividend Promise Could Break Bank Covenants
description: Fastwebs 300 million euro payout could breach bank covenants. The Italian cable group promised the payout when it abandoned the sale of the business in February. But its not obvious that it can pay it. Maybe Fastweb plans to renegotiate the covenants. But if so, Breakingviews thinks it should tell the market  rather than leaving it guessing.

title: NTLs Virgin Mobile Buy Raises Questions About One-Stop Shopping
description: NTL yesterday billed its 962 million pound takeover of Sir Richard Bransons Virgin Mobile as the creation of a truly national entertainment and communications company that will challenge the might of its closest rivals Sky and BT.

title: Mobile Start-Up Gets $20 Million From MySpace Backers
description: 3Gupload, which wants to become the MySpace of mobile, is announcing that it has landed $20 million in financing from VantagePoint Venture Partners  the Silicon Valley powerhouse that was one of the early backers of the wildly popular social networking site.

title: Icelandic Firm Flies the easyJet Coop
description: Fears over Icelands economy intensified last night when one of the countrys most aggressive investment funds unexpectedly put on sale a 17 percent take in easyJet, the budget airline, to raise an estimated 233 million pounds.

title: Pritzker Family Puts Triton Container Up For Sale
description: Triton Container International., the shipping-container company owned by the Pritzker family, is up for sale and may fetch as much as $2.5 billion, three people familiar with the matter said.

title: Calpine to Sell Power Plants
description: Calpine said Tuesday it plans to sell about one-fifth of its power plants, pare its work force and close some offices in a bid to re-emerge from bankruptcy as a leaner company centered on its profitable operations.

title: Reed Elsevier Puts Educational Library On the Block
description: The Harcourt Education unit of Reed Elsevier is shopping its global elementary library, a collection of elementary reference books and material, to private equity and strategic firms, according to LBO Wire. The company has hired New York investment bank Berkery Noyes & Co. to run a search process for the library. The sale process is expected to be wrapped up by June.

title: Scarletts Big Deal
description: Scarlett Johansson, the actress, paid $1.95 million in January for a duplex condominium on Leonard Street in TriBeCa, according to a deed filed with the city. The apartment was bought in the name of a trust controlled by her mother, Melanie Johansson.

title: Private Equity Fund  Said to Be Considering Bid for Axa Re
description: American private equity group Stone Point Capital is considering a possible takeover of French reinsurer Axa Re, French newspaper La Tribune reported. Axa Re, which La Tribune said was valued at around 1.2 billion euros ($1.5 billion), has previously been linked in newspaper and analyst reports with a possible merger deal with rival French reinsurer Scor.

title: At the Enron Trial, Skilling Then vs. Skilling Now
description: As Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enrons former chief executive, moves from the defense table to the witness stand as soon as today, he will have to be prepared to confront his own past testimony.

title: Europe Weakens Its Proposal on Single Market for Services
description: Bowing to protectionist pressure, the European Commission on Tuesday announced a watered-down version of its plan to create a single European market for a wide range of service industries.

title: NBC Is Poised to Hire Courics Replacement
description: As CBS nears a deal to make Katie Couric the next anchor of its evening news program, NBC has nearly concluded an agreement with Meredith Vieira of ABC to replace Ms. Couric as co-host of the Today morning show.

title: Spitzer Sues Software Company Over Spyware
description: New Yorks attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, has sued Direct Revenue, a software maker, accusing it of surreptitiously installing advertising programs on Internet users computers.

title: Netflix Sues Blockbuster to Shut Down Online Rental Service
description: Online DVD rental company Netflix on Tuesday sued rival Blockbuster , accusing the company of patent infringement. Netflix is asking a federal judge in Northern California to shut down Blockbusters 18-month-old online rental service and award Netflix damages, according to a copy of the filing.

title: Grasso Hands Over Testimony Transcripts to Spitzer
description: Richard Grasso has handed over to the New York attorney generals office transcripts of testimony he gave to SEC investigators looking at trading misdeeds at the New York Stock Exchange.

title: South Korea Antitrust Watchdog Opens Qualcomm Investigation
description: South Koreas antitrust watchdog, the Fair Trade Commission, is investigating U.S. wireless technology company Qualcomm, a senior official at Qualcomm Korea said on Wednesday. Yonhap News cited industry sources as saying the probe was examining whether Qualcomm had breached antitrust rules using its dominant market position in South Korea.

title: S.E.C. Sues Long Island Brokers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit on Tuesday against three brokers at a small Long Island brokerage firm, accusing them of using their account at Refco to run a wide-ranging short-selling scam.

title: Slide Show: Designing Women
description: To their well-heeled clients, the successors to Sister Parish are more like pals than decorating dictators.

title: Couric Leaving the 'Today Show'
description: April 5 - 'Today Show' host Katie Couric announces that she is leaving NBC to join the CBS 'Evening News' and '60 Minutes.'

title: Who Lives in Newark
description: Is it still fair to call Newark an African-American city? How much, if at all, has New Jerseys largest city grown since 1990 or 2000?

title: Vodafone Stock Jumps Amid Talk of Verizon Wireless Deal
description: Shares of Vodafone spiked up more than 2 percent in early afternoon trading in London, a move that some market participants attributed to renewed expectations that an agreement to sell its stake in Verizon Wireless is close at hand.

Selborne Journal: Monday, 5 April 1784: 29 6/10 1/2; 42 1/2; NW, S. Grey & mild, small rain, grey & mild. My crocuss are in full bloom, & make a most gaudy show. Those eaten-off by the hares last year were not injured. Snow melts.

title: Visicu Raises I.P.O. Target, Then Prices Even Higher
description: Visicu priced its initial public offering at $16 a share, less than a day after raising the expected price range to $13 to $15. The company pegged its offering at $11 to $13 last month.

title: Drugmaker QuatRx Files for I.P.O.
description: QuatRx Pharmaceutical may offer up to 6 million shares for between $11 and $13 a share in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

title: Katies Nose for News
description: Tobin Harshaw

title: N.Y.S.E. Names Directors for Regulatory Arm as Split Advances
description: The New York Stock Exchange moved a step closer to distancing itself from its regulatory arm, as it announced the members of a newly created board of directors to oversee the unit.

title: Buyout Firms Pick Up Liberty Globals Swedish Unit
description: Liberty Global, a spinoff of John Malones cable empire, has agreed to sell Swedish cable-television business UPC Sverige to two private equity firms. Carlyle Group and Providence Equity Partners will acquire the assets in a deal that Liberty said has an enterprise value of $247 million.

title: Canada Apologizes for Tax on Chinese
description: The government said it would apologize for imposing a discriminatory tax on Chinese immigrants between 1885 and 1923.

title: Slide Show: Supernatural Colors
description: A well-selected show of paintings affords a welcome opportunity for close study of what Frederic Edwin Church was extraordinarily good at: small landscape studies and sketches.

title: Democrats Fuss About Themselves
description: With Tom DeLays inglorious exit, a White House staff shakeup, continued violence in Iraq and Saddam Husseins trial descending into farce, youd think the Democrats might want to sit out the current news cycle and let the Republicans suffer. Predictably, however, the party is managing to find bane in the bounty. First there was Rep. Cynthia McKinneys altercation with a Capitol police officer, which has even the diehard liberals at Daily Kos calling her an embarrassment. And yesterdays statement of blanket support for same-sex marriage by Democratic presidential hopeful Senator Russ Feingold has the blogosphere speculating on fallout.

title: Where In the World is Hyundais Chairman?
description: How long will it take for Hyundai Motor chairman and patriarch Chung Mong-koo to start appearing on milk cartons?

title: Reports of Hedge Funds Decline Were Greatly Exaggerated
description: George Soros, Bill Gross and other investing luminaries were flat wrong when, about a year ago, they predicted that the hedge fund business was stalling out, writes Bloomberg columnist Matthew Lynn. Hedge funds, he says, are roaring ahead.

title: NYBOT Said to Consider Demutualization as Seat Price Jumps
description: An unnamed source tells Reuters that the New York Board of Trade on Wednesday will discuss demutualizing, or changing from a mutually-owned company to one owned by shareholders. That move could set the stage for an initial public offering of the exchange, which handles futures and options trading for commodities such as cotton and coffee.

title: Should Microsoft Just Buy Apple?
description: Imagine if Coca-Cola agreed to stock Pepsi in its vending machines.

title: Last Blast of Winter
description: April snow fell on Times Square in New York City.    (Producer: Justine Simons)

title: McClatchy Lets Union-Backed Bidder See Newspaper Data
description: Yucaipa  Companies, the private equity firm that has joined with the Newspaper Guild to bid on 12 Knight Ridder newspapers, has succeeded in its push to see detailed financial information on the publications.

title: How Overpriced?
description: BusinessWeek put a table online that describes the characteristics of 30 major markets using 11 different factors, including how overpriced they are. It uses data from Global Insight Inc. and National City Corp., which is determined by comparing personal income to prices.

title: The Constants Among Change
description: Just a month and a half ago, when I first ate in the upstairs dining room at Country, my choice for the first of the four courses (including dessert) on an $85 prix fixe menu was seared squid.

title: Real Estate Rashomon
description: Over at Matrix, Jonathan Miller notes the reaction to the latest Manhattan Market Overview (it hasnt been posted yet) that his company prepares. The market is booming, slumping or steady, depending on what media outlet you read.

title: Dismantling of GMAC May Continue With Rescap Sale
description: The piecemeal amputation of General Motors financing arm may not be over.

title: Open Arms for Immigrants  Sort Of
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans Apr. 5 column, High Fence and Big Gate

title: Mike Gascoyne suspended from Toyota
description: Today Toyota announced that it has suspended Mike Gascoyne, the technical director, for in indefinite period over fundamental differences with the team over ideas about technical procedures. Some people are surprised about that since Ralf Schumacher finished third in his Toyota in Australia last weekend. Others may not be so surprised  like Dennis in Wisconsin, who asked on this blog the day after Toyotas poor results in the first race, How long will it be before Toyota fires a driver? I said they wouldnt fire a driver

title: Newark, U.S.A.: Father Edwin Leahy
description: Residents of Newark know Father Edwin Leahy as the headmaster of St. Benedicts Prep, the 132-year-old school that he resuscitated after its previous administrators decamped for the suburbs following the race riots of 1967.

title: Google Real Estate: You Can Exhale
description: I took a look at the new Google real estate service.

title: Why Stop at Just One House?
description: For more and more people, one home simply isnt enough.

title: Vows: Adam Bye and Vara Lauder
description: April 9 - The couple discuss how a love for Scrabble brought them together. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: BuySide Realty: New Online Tactics
description: The two brothers who created Web Street Securities, an online brokerage that was later sold to E*Trade, are looking at real estate.

title: The VoSky Call Center
description: The VoSky Call Center lets you make Skype calls from regular phones and cell phones.

title: As James Says Goodbye, Newarks Troubles Linger
description: Sharpe James (Associated Press)

title: Arab Life: An Outsiders View
description: Since I have had the opportunity to see a few Arab homes, and to observe and interact at some length with the populace here in Falluja, I thought it might be interesting to point out a few of the similarities and differences between the life we know and that of an Iraqi. Hundreds of customs and courtesies surround the Arab culture. Upon my arrival here, I didnt know what to believe and what to shrug off as nonsense. I quickly realized that most things I had learned from Ustatha Samir during culture time in Arabic class held true in the real world. Its always rather surreal to imagine life drastically different than American culture without actually experiencing it, but after seeing this small part of the Arab world with my own eyes, I know Ill never forget it.

title: Windows on Natural History
description: Times reporter William Hamilton gets an inside look at dioramas from Stephen Quinn, lead curator of the American Museum of Natural History. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

title: A.C.L.U. Says Ethnic Bias Steered Georgia Drug Sting
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is accusing federal prosecutors of ethnic bias in a sting last summer in which South Asian owners of convenience stores in Georgia were charged with selling household ingredients that could be used to make methamphetamine, a highly addictive drug.

title: National Briefing
description: MIDWEST

title: Britain Confirms Bird Flu in Scottish Swan
description: LONDON, April 6  A swan found dead in eastern Scotland has tested positive for the deadly strain of bird flu, government officials said, making it the first recorded case of the disease in a wild bird in Britain.

title: Fossil Called Missing Link From Sea to Land Animals
description: Scientists have discovered fossils of a 375-million-year-old fish, a large scaly creature not seen before, that they say is a long-sought missing link in the evolution of some fishes from water to a life walking on four limbs on land.

title: U.S. Won't Be Candidate for U.N. Rights Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 6  The United States said today that it will not be a candidate for the new Human Rights Council, which was approved overwhelmingly last month by the United Nations General Assembly with Washington in almost lone opposition.

title: World Briefing: Middle East, Americas, Europe, Africa and Asia
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: On Health Care, Massachusetts Leaders Invoke Action, Not Talk
description: BOSTON, April 5  Massachusetts has more than its share of political egos per capita, so one of the most surprising aspects about the measure this week to create near-universal health care coverage is that it involved the cooperation of virtually every political stakeholder in the state.

title: Nepal Makes Mass Arrests of Pro-Democracy Protesters
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 6  A four-day pro-democracy strike began here today in the world's only Hindu kingdom. Most shops and businesses in the capital remained shuttered, but at least 160 people were arrested, apparently in an effort to weaken plans for demonstrations later in the week.

title: Hussein Admits He Ordered the Execution of 148
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 6  Bombarded with questions during the first cross-examination in his trial, Saddam Hussein admitted Wednesday that he had signed an order of execution for 148 men and boys with only a cursory glance at the evidence.

title: Notre Dame's President Allows 'Monologues' and Gay Films
description: The University of Notre Dame will continue to allow a gay film festival and the play "Vagina Monologues" on campus, its president announced yesterday. The decision was a sharp turnaround from a speech that the president, the Rev. John I. Jenkins, gave to faculty members and students in January questioning the appropriateness of such events on a Roman Catholic campus.

title: A Russian 'Wine Blockade' Against Georgia and Moldova
description: MOSCOW, April 5  The wines and spirits section of the Azbuka Vkusa supermarket, one of Moscow's largest, has an utterly new look.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,338 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Opponents Set April 17 Deadline to Rescind French Labor Law
description: PARIS, April 5  French union and student leaders said Wednesday that if the government did not, by April 17, rescind a labor law to which there have been widespread objections, more nationwide strikes and protests would occur.

title: No Surprise but Some Sadness For 'Today' Fans on the Plaza
description: That Katie Couric is leaving her post at the "Today" show to anchor the "CBS Evening News" came as little surprise to many of the screaming, smiling, poster-waving fans who descended early yesterday on Rockefeller Center, where the morning show is broadcast.

title: Article on Bird Flu Criticizes Effort to Monitor Cats and Dogs
description: Five leading European scientists are criticizing officials involved in human and animal health in an article appearing today, saying the officials are not doing enough to monitor cats, dogs and other carnivores for their possible role in transmitting avian influenza.

title: Today's Russian Newspapers
description: Beginning this week, a summary of the top stories in the Russian newspapers will appear Monday through Friday.

title: Bill Strikes at Low-Nutrition Foods in School
description: The days when children consume two orders of French fries in the school cafeteria and call it lunch may be numbered. A bipartisan group in Congress plans to introduce legislation today that would prohibit the sale in school not only of French fries but also of other fatty or sugary foods, including soft drinks.

title: Katherine Anne Couric: Coming Back to Hard News
description: Katie Couric, who for 15 years has chased the slumber from the minds of the biggest portion of the morning television audience, has attributed her success to being "ridiculously normal," a person others see, as she once put it, "as someone they could have gone to high school with or someone who works at the desk next to them."

title: It's Barry Bonds's World, and a Wary Welcome to It
description: Barry Bonds, the San Francisco Giants outfielder, is supremely gifted in at least two areas  hitting baseballs and not hitting them, drawing walks instead. He is not a natural television performer, however, and his appearance on "Bonds on Bonds," the 10-hour ESPN reality show that had its premiere on Tuesday, won't do much to repair his already tarnished image. Bonds makes an effort here to open up and reveal the maligned and misunderstood inner Barry  or he makes a show of making an effort, at any rate  but he whiffs all the same.

title: Amid Banter, Reminders of the Shoes to Be Filled
description: It was impossible not to choke up and grow anxious as Katie Couric announced she was leaving the "Today" show after 15 years  please, Lord, let the next co-host not be Ann Curry.

title: Media Buyers Await Answers on Spending and Audiences
description: When Katie Couric jumps to "CBS Evening News," will advertising dollars follow?

title: Iraqi Says Visit by Two Diplomats Backfired
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 5  A top adviser to Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari said Wednesday that the visit this week by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Foreign Secretary Jack Straw of Britain had backfired, prolonging a deadlock over a new government and strengthening Mr. Jaafari's resolve to keep his post.

title: Program on Vouchers Draws Minority Support
description: WASHINGTON, April 5  As a student at Shaw Junior High School here, Amie Fuwa strained to shut out the distractions of friends cutting up. She struggled through math, and used photocopies or the library when textbooks were scarce.

title: Few Students Seek Free Tutoring or Transfers From Failing Schools
description: Only a small fraction of public school students who were eligible last year for free tutoring or for transfers out of failing schools under federal law received those options, the Department of Education reported yesterday. Education Secretary Margaret Spellings threatened to withhold federal money from states that did not make students aware of their choices.

title: Hussein Admits He Ordered the Execution of 148
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 5  Subjected to cross-examination for the first time in his trial, Saddam Hussein admitted Wednesday that he had signed an order of execution for 148 men and boys with only a cursory glance at the evidence against them.

title: Anchor's Chair Was an Irresistible Lure for Couric
description: In the midst of the widely publicized negotiations over her future career in network television, Katie Couric called a family meeting, with her parents and two young daughters around the dinner table.

title: By Bridging 5,000 Years, China Courts Taiwanese
description: HUANGLING, China, April 5  Heroic opera boomed from huge speakers and white-gloved police officers carried elaborate funeral wreaths as senior Communist officials bowed low Wednesday before the reputed burial mound of a legendary Chinese emperor.

title: In Bid to Rebuild Razed Bridge, Recovery and War Vie in Iraq
description: HUSAYBA, Iraq, April 2  Last August, under daily attack from car bombs and mortars, the Marines took down the only bridge over the Euphrates River for miles around.

title: Bomb Explodes Near Shiite Shrine in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 6  Striking at the heart of Shiite Islam, a car bomb ripped through a crowd of Shiite worshippers and pedestrians near the Imam Ali mosque in Najaf today, killing at least 10 people and wounding 34, according to hospital officials.

title: As a Sea Rises, So Do Hopes for Fish, Jobs and Riches
description: KARATEREN, Kazakhstan  In the blue night haze, Gamin Zhaisanbayev and several dozen other men hauled heavy gear into their trucks as boys sitting on stoops quietly watched their silhouettes.

title: Boycott Threat Roils Guantnamo Hearing
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, April 5  The Pentagon's effort to move forward with military commission trials for people suspected of being terrorists took another chaotic turn on Wednesday when a Canadian teenager accused of murdering an American soldier in Afghanistan threatened to boycott the proceedings.

title: Work it Out, Blair Warns Belfast's Rival Parties
description: DUBLIN, April 6  In a clear statement that his patience had worn thin, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said that if Northern Ireland's rival Protestant and Roman Catholic parties cannot cooperate to make their stalled local government work by this fall, London and Dublin will abandon that political system and find a new way to govern the province. In a joint announcement, Mr. Blair and the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, laid out plans to recall elected officials to the Northern Irish legislature on May 15, in the hopes that they can agree on appointing ministers to its executive branch before the summer. If ministers are not appointed by Nov. 24, the British and Irish governments will take over running the province.

title: 'Gospel of Judas' Surfaces After 1,700 Years
description: An early Christian manuscript, including the only known text of what is known as the Gospel of Judas, has surfaced after 1,700 years. The text gives new insights into the relationship of Jesus and the disciple who betrayed him, scholars reported today. In this version, Jesus asked Judas, as a close friend, to sell him out to the authorities, telling Judas he will "exceed" the other disciples by doing so.

title: Palestinians' Hamas Leader Faces Many Problems
description: GAZA CITY, April 6  Barely a week in office, the Palestinian prime minister from Hamas faces not only diplomatic isolation and a bankrupt treasury but an intense rivalry with Fatah, the longtime Palestinian power, over control of the heavily armed security agencies.

title: At Moussaoui Trial, Giuliani Recalls Horror of 9/11
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 6  With the smiling Al Qaeda member Zacarias Moussaoui sitting only 10 feet from him, former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York recalled today how the sight of people jumping from the burning World Trade Center will stay with him all his life.

title: Second Case of Murder Adds Twist to a Book
description: Joe McGinniss was just grinding away on your average true-crime story: a book about a high-powered American financier in Hong Kong named Robert Kissel, who drank a sedative-laced strawberry milkshake and was bludgeoned to death by his wife. Then his body was wrapped in a piece of carpet that a workman took to a basement storage room.

title: Chinese on Buying Trip in U.S. Seek to Pave Way for Leader
description: BEIJING, April 5  Chinese leaders, eager to improve relations with the United States ahead of the maiden visit there by President Hu Jintao this month, have dispatched a large delegation of business and economic officials to display China's buying power and to cool protectionist sentiment in Congress, Chinese officials said Wednesday.

title: Clashes Steer Kurds and Turkey Back on a Rocky Path
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, April 5  Violent clashes between Kurds and security forces in Turkey over the past week have jolted memories here back to an old conflict that remains a dangerous barrier on the nation's path toward greater prosperity and democracy.

title: Media Buyers Await Answers on Spending and Audiences
description: When Katie Couric jumps to "CBS Evening News," will advertising dollars follow?

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Inquiry Shows Milosevic Died A Natural Death
description: The Dutch inquiry into the death of former President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia concluded that he died a natural death as a result of a heart attack on March 11, dismissing allegations that he was poisoned while in United Nations custody. In a statement, the district attorney's office in The Hague said "there are no indications whatsoever" of foul play. It said that the National Forensic Institute had corroborated earlier results that found traces of Mr. Milosevic's prescribed medicines but said there was no poison or toxic level of any drug that "might have provoked cardiac arrest." The findings were corroborated by the German Forensic Institute.

title: In Connecticut, Bush Talks of Soaring Health Care Costs
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 5 - President Bush visited Connecticut on Wednesday to highlight his prescription for a stubborn national problem certain to play a prominent role in this year's federal and state election campaigns: soaring health care costs.

Briefly: Oil-for-food inquiry targets ex-minister
Coke's Board to Get Bonus or Nothing
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced an innovative plan yesterday for paying outside directors: If earnings per share do not rise fast enough over a three-year period, directors will receive nothing. But they will get a significant raise if earnings perform as expected.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bankruptcy Not an Option for Ford, Chief Says
description: DETROIT, April 5 - Although the American automobile industry is in a precarious state, the chief executive of Ford Motor said Wednesday that he was confident the automaker could solve its financial problems and that a bankruptcy filing was not an option.

title: Armenia Sells Russia Crucial Gas Link in Deal for Cheap Fuel
description: MOSCOW, April 6 A The latest natural gas squabble in the former Soviet Union was settled today, as Armenia negotiated cheap natural gas supplies from Russia with prices well below European averages locked in until 2009. In exchange, the agreement calls for it to surrender to Russia a small but crucial section of pipeline linking it to Iran.

title: U.S. skips candidacy for a UN rights seat
Official Resists Extradition on Charge Involving Internet and Sex
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 - The Department of Homeland Security's deputy press secretary appeared in a Maryland state court on Wednesday and refused extradition to Florida, where he faces charges of using the Internet to seduce someone he thought was a 14-year-old girl.

title: Surprise as European Bank Signals No Rate Raise
description: FRANKFURT, April 6 A Surprising financial markets, and sending the euro and other currencies down against the dollar, the European Central Bank today doused widespread expectations that it would raise interest rates next month, as part of its gradual tightening of monetary policy.

title: Poland Averts Clash With Europe Over Italian Bank Deal
description: FRANKFURT, April 5 - Breaking an impasse that had stained its image and put it on a collision course with the European Union, the Polish government on Wednesday reached an agreement with the giant Italian bank UniCredito that allows two Polish banks to be combined under their Italian owner.

title: The Bullpen Can't Save Bannister's Great Start
description: He walked onto his college baseball team, making it because of a devastating curveball that turned hitters' knees into sawdust. But the Mets drafted Brian Bannister -- in the seventh round, no less -- because they saw a major league pitcher, one who balanced an underdog's temperament with an overachiever's resolve. And he still had that curveball.

title: With the Jury Out, Trivia and Tall Tales Fill the Down Time
description: If every trial is an oceangoing vessel sailing toward a verdict, then the big old heavy schooner of United States v. Louis Eppolito and Stephen Caracappa slipped into still waters yesterday, entering the phase called jury watch.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawyers Criticize Tactics In Drug Case
description: Lawyers for a man who could face the death penalty in a federal murder conspiracy case accused federal prosecutors yesterday of filing sham notices to delay his trial. Lawyers for the defendant, Kenneth McGriff, 46, criticized prosecutors for filing, and then withdrawing, notices seeking the death penalty against Mr. McGriff's four co-defendants, one of whom is a mother of nine children. Prosecutors said they withdrew the notices on Tuesday because Attorney General Alberto Gonzales had authorized them to seek the death penalty only for Mr. McGriff, who prosecutors say is a drug kingpin with ties to the rap music industry. His trial had been scheduled to start on Monday. A spokesman for Mr. Gonzales declined to comment.

title: Roundup:India tops England to clinch series
Briefing: Developing economies in Asia expected to rise
A Sophisticate Conjures a Bygone World
description: When Mary Cleere Haran croons "Blue Room," Rodgers and Hart's pipe-and-slippers fantasy of domestic bliss sustained by "nothing but kisses," the picture of a starry-eyed married couple spooning in their frilly upstairs lair comes into soft focus. For an illusory moment, Ms. Haran sheds the air of a sleek, New York "sophisticate" (a word she frequently drops in a tone of sardonic affection) to evoke the marital daydreams of a bygone era. As her voice curls around the lyrics and a faraway look clouds her eyes, you may think of Myrna Loy as the perfect wife in "The Best Years of Our Lives" or Claudette Colbert tending the home fires in "Since You Went Away."

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about census figures showing the first decline in New York City's black population since the Civil War misstated the proximity of Littleton, N.C., the new home of one black migrant, to Charlotte. Littleton is about 200 miles from Charlotte, not nearby.

title: But Would the Laptop Survive a Trip Over Niagara Falls?
description: Any business traveler who has ever wanted to throw a malfunctioning laptop to the ground and stomp on it can now act on the urge without feeling any regret in the morning -- as long as the laptop is in an OtterBox case.

description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue selected eight N.F.L. owners with diverse views yesterday to lead the search for his successor.

title: Mets Show Plans for New Ballpark in Queens
description: Eight years since they proudly displayed a model of a stadium that echoed the look of Ebbets Field, the Mets showed off today a 21st-century version of that design amid hopes that they can begin construction as early as June.

title: Tough Start for Bonds Reality Show
description: The first episode of "Bonds on Bonds" Tuesday on ESPN2 from 8 to 9 p.m. Eastern posted a 0.4 rating (or 336,000 cable TV households), no better than the average rating in that time period on the network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAKOWER, ELEANOR
description: RAKOWER--Eleanor. Devoted wife of the late Julian. Loving mother of Simon and Beverly. Dearest sister of Leonard Berson. Cherished grandmother of James and Daniel. Services Friday 4PM "Parkside Chapels", Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 6 Muslims Held In Varanasi Blasts
description: The police said they had arrested six Muslims, including a cleric, suspected of involvement in the bombings this month at a temple and a railway station in Varanasi, Hinduism's holiest city, that killed at least 14 people. They described the cleric, Wali Ullah, as the mastermind and said he runs a madrasa with suspected connections to militant Islamist groups. Paraded before television news cameras and shielding his face, Mr. Ullah told journalists he had sought to avenge the demolition of the Babri Masjid, the 16-century mosque in Ayodhya, by a Hindu mob in 1992 and the killing of Muslims in Gujarat in 2002.

title: At Radio City, David Gilmour Delivers Echoes of Pink Floyd
description: When David Gilmour played Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night, he split his concert in half. The first half, which consisted of all the songs from his new album, "On an Island" (Columbia), was the reason he was there. The second half, stocked with favorites from his band, Pink Floyd, was the reason the audience was there.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about General Motors' plans to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, misstated the Standard & Poor's credit rating for G.M. It is B, not BB.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOLD, SIDNEY
description: GOLD--Sidney. April 6, 1972. Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Your loving Daughter & family.

title: Pieces of Bone Are Found on Building at 9/11 Site
description: A crew of demolition workers discovered 74 bone fragments near the World Trade Center site over the weekend, the largest number of remains found since the end of recovery operations nearly three years ago and a sign that significant quantities of human remains may have gone unnoticed in sporadic searches over the years.

title: Torre Plans Tight Rein for Yanks' Setup Men
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 5  There are 6,000 songs on Kyle Farnsworth's iPod, and most days in the Yankees' clubhouse, it seems as if he must listen to them all. Farnsworth, the hulking setup man, is a model of robotic intensity, shifting from the exercise bike to the weight room and back, always with headphones on and music strapped to his left arm.

title: Financial Advice for the 'Mass Affluent'
description: Two years ago, Marty Dragutsky was downsized out of a job selling pharmaceuticals. That startling event forced him to finally take account of his finances. After 30 years in sales, the last 17 years with a division of Abbott Laboratories, Mr. Dragutsky had accumulated a nest egg of nearly half a million dollars in his 401(k) account -- nearly all of it in Abbott Labs stock.

title: Article on Bird Flu Criticizes Effort to Monitor Cats and Dogs
description: Five leading European scientists are criticizing officials involved in human and animal health in an article appearing today, saying the officials are not doing enough to monitor cats, dogs and other carnivores for their possible role in transmitting avian influenza.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Pilot Blamed In Death Of Ex-Rebel Leader
description: An inquiry into the death of John Garang, the former longtime Sudanese rebel leader, blamed pilot error for the helicopter crash that took his life in heavy rain in July, just three weeks after he became Sudan's vice president. Officials told Reuters that foul play and mechanical error were ruled out. Mr. Garang's death has shaken the fragile peace process under way in the south.

title: Delay Likely in Trial Over Grasso's Pay
description: A courtroom showdown over the $190 million in pay received by the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso, set to start in October, will probably be delayed until February because the exchange's lawyers have scheduling conflicts.

title: In 'Quality of Life' the Unraveling Lives of Two Graffiti Artists in San Francisco
description: The Mission District of San Francisco is the kind of place where transgender bike messengers live chockablock with marketing executives, thrift stores brace for the encroachment of Starbucks, and heroin addicts nod off next to Hummers. It is on these slightly mean, thoroughly gentrified streets that two young graffiti artists come of age in "Quality of Life," a minor movie, modestly made, that develops to a counterculture beat but ends with a status quo conundrum: Is selling out the new keeping it real?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINTER, GEORGE
description: PINTER--George, 92. Died Tuesday, April 4 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Judith for 58 years. He will be missed by his sister Kato; his sister-in-law, brother-in-law, numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. A memorial remembrance will be held Monday, April 10 at 3PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

It is where the daughter of Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, was honored in 1995.

title: Fossil Called Missing Link From Sea to Land Animals
description: Scientists have discovered fossils of a 375-million-year-old fish, a large scaly creature not seen before, that they say is a long-sought missing link in the evolution of some fishes from water to a life walking on four limbs on land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEMING, PENNY
description: FLEMING--Penny. A longtime ABC News Producer, died Monday, April 3, 2006 of pancreatic cancer. Penny spent the last 15 years producing stories for 20/20. Before coming to ABC, Penny was a producer at NBC and "The Today Show." She is survived by her daughters, Emma and Abby, stepsons Scott & Craig, grandchildren Colin, Zachary and Joshua. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations be made to Abby and Emma's Education Fund.

title: ECB cool on rate rise, undercutting the euro

Florida would not be the first state to adopt it; South Carolina began a similar program last year requiring high school students to choose a "career cluster."

description: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, plans to present an alternative budget today for the next fiscal year that includes more money than the mayor has proposed for child welfare, day care and public safety, Council officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLANCY, MAIDA
description: GLANCY--Maida. Passed away peacefully at her residence on March 29, 2006. Devoted wife of the late Kenneth. She is also survived by her stepdaughter Suzanne Gallagher. Also survived by her loving cousin Carole Klepper and her devoted friends.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Bring The Troops Home, Voters Say
description: Residents in 24 of 32 municipalities, including the state capital, voted in favor of immediately pulling out troops from Iraq in referendums on Tuesday. About 61 percent of 65,682 voters supported withdrawal in communities where as few as 22 or as many as 35,596 people cast votes. Residents petitioned to get the referendum on the ballot in each community as part of a campaign initiated by the Wisconsin Green Party. The vote brings to 100 the number of cities and towns nationwide that have passed resolutions calling for the return of troops, according to the Institute for Policy Studies in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUICK, REGINA
description: QUICK--Regina. The trustees, faculty and staff of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory are deeply saddened at the passing of Regina (Jean) Clarkson Quick. Mrs. Quick was a generous supporter of the Laboratory, together with her husband, Leslie C. Quick, Jr., during his tenure on our Board of Trustees and after his death as well. Her vision for the future of our work and her kindness and friendship will never be forgotten. To her children, grandchildren, sister and many friends, we express our deepest sympathy. Eduardo Mestre, Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer

title: A Ned Rorem Response to 9/11 at Chamber Music at the Y
description: Chamber Music at the Y can seem staid at times, but Jaime Laredo generally makes a point of including something new, or newish, on its programs. For the closing concerts of the season, on Tuesday and Wednesday, the contemporary offering was Ned Rorem's "Aftermath," a 10-song cycle about war and mortality, drawing on poets from the 16th through 20th centuries.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Man Arrested In Killing
description: A Newark man wanted in connection with the March 23 shooting death of a 38-year-old mother of six was arrested on Tuesday evening, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Travis Burris, 22, is charged with the murder of Linda Carmichael, who was shot in Newark while walking home with two of her sons. Her 18-year-old son, Darnell Carmichael, told the police that he had argued with Mr. Burris and was probably the intended target. Mr. Burris was armed with a handgun and was wearing a bulletproof vest, the police have said.

They are perfectly nice, but they look hurried, like the result of a reality show challenge.

description: BOSTON, April 5 - Massachusetts has more than its share of political egos per capita, so one of the most surprising aspects about the measure this week to create near-universal health care coverage is that it involved the cooperation of virtually every political stakeholder in the state.

She was simultaneously talking at high speed, eating a fried egg and hurling squeaky toys at her 2-year-old Jack Russell terrier, Anchovy, from her seat on a claret-colored corduroy sofa.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 5 - A top adviser to Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari said Wednesday that the visit this week by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Foreign Secretary Jack Straw of Britain had backfired, prolonging a deadlock over a new government and strengthening Mr. Jaafari's resolve to keep his post.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: African Union Checking Rape Charges Against Darfur Force
description: The African Union said it was investigating a report by the British television channel More4 News over the weekend that some members of its peacekeeping force in the Darfur region had raped and abused local girls and women. A spokesman for the 7,000-man force, Moussa Hamani Alzouma, said in a statement that the allegations, while unconfirmed, were "very grave and unacceptable."

description: Sheila Metzner, a fashion and fine art photographer, below right, has created a new line of fabrics for Bernhardt Textiles called String Theory, inspired by her own collections of Native American rugs, African jewelry, Japanese prints and kimonos from the 1940's and 50's. "I wanted the designs to reflect all of these things, but not look like one culture or period," Ms. Metzner said. Working with Teri Figliuzzi, the design director at Bernhardt Textiles, she produced five patterns available in several color combinations (below left, Flow). The patterns, along with recent photographs by Ms. Metzner, are at the John Stevenson Gallery, 338 West 23rd Street (Eighth Avenue), through April 22; www.johnstevenson-gallery.com. title: National Briefing | Washington: Ex-Officials Of FEMA Plead Guilty
description: Two former Federal Emergency Management Agency officials assigned after Hurricane Katrina to supervise a supply base camp in New Orleans have pleaded guilty to charges of trying to bribe a contractor. The former officials, Andrew Rose and Loyd Holliman, were accused of soliciting bribes in return for offering to let the contractor inflate the per-meal headcount upon which its compensation was based, said Jim Letten, United States attorney for the Eastern District of Louisiana. The two, who are to be sentenced in July, face a maximum of 15 years in prison, Mr. Letten said, adding that this was the first Hurricane Katrina-related case he knew of filed against officials of FEMA.

title: Nepal Makes Mass Arrests of Pro-Democracy Protesters
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 6 A A four-day pro-democracy strike began here today in the world's only Hindu kingdom. Most shops and businesses in the capital remained shuttered, but at least 160 people were arrested, apparently in an effort to weaken plans for demonstrations later in the week.

title: Political Chiefs Iron Out Plans For 9/11 Site
description: Gov. George E. Pataki met yesterday with his New Jersey counterpart, Jon S. Corzine, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to work out the details of a unified plan for financing and rebuilding at ground zero.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Friday, about the investigation involving a woman who said she had been raped by three players on the Duke University lacrosse team misstated the nature of the players' cooperation with the authorities. The police in Durham, N.C., said that although most team members had not voluntarily submitted to police interviews and DNA tests, the three residents of the house where the accuser said the incident occurred had done so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, CAROL
description: FELDMAN - Carol. With deepest sadness, I announce the death of my beloved wife, Carol Feldman. She died in Rome on March 18 following unsuccessful surgery to alleviate a long-standing and painful abdominal condition. She was much loved, and she helped create a new field of research relating the development of the human mind to the culture in which it grows. Her loss leaves us all poorer--personally, intellectually, morally. Jerome Bruner

title: Gold Prices Reach 25-Year High
description: The price of gold touched $600 an ounce today, rising to a level not seen in 25 years as investors poured money into precious metals.

title: Arts, Briefly; A Big Entrance For T. I.'s 'King'
description: Finally, 2006 has a genuine blockbuster hit. The Atlanta rapper T. I. made a bold entrance on the Billboard chart this week with 522,000 sales of "King" (Atlantic), by far the most of any new album this year, and the best for a rap album since Kanye West's "Late Registration" in August. The "High School Musical" soundtrack (Disney) has been the year's sleeper success. Its sales have grown for 11 consecutive weeks, and with 165,000 sold last week, its cumulative sales reached 1.1 million, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is at No. 3 on the chart, behind Tim McGraw's new "Greatest Hits Vol. 2: Reflected" (Curb), which sold 242,000. Three other new albums charted in the Top 10: Ghostface Killah's "Fishscale" (Def Jam) is at No. 4, Rob Zombie's "Educated Horses" (Geffen) is No. 5, and Atreyu reached No. 9 with "A Death-Grip on Yesterday" (Victory). The Yeah Yeah Yeahs had their best sales week ever with the new "Show Your Bones" (Interscope), which opened at No. 11 with 56,000. BEN SISARIO

title: Second Case of Murder Adds Twist to a Book
description: Joe McGinniss was just grinding away on your average true-crime story: a book about a high-powered American financier in Hong Kong named Robert Kissel, who drank a sedative-laced strawberry milkshake and was bludgeoned to death by his wife. Then his body was wrapped in a piece of carpet that a workman took to a basement storage room.

title: Upsets at the Championships, and a Tale of a Singleton King
description: DALLAS, April 5 - In the round of 32 of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the Spring North American Bridge Championships here Tuesday, six high-ranked teams lost to lower-seeded opponents. In the biggest upsets, the team of Dan Jacob (Greg Hinze, Nagy Kamel, Robert Lebi, Thomas Peters and John Zilic) had a singular success over the No. 2 seeds led by George Jacobs (Ralph Katz, Zia Mahmood, Michael Rosenberg, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace). And the Dutch team of Sjoert Brink, Bas Dryver, Vincent Ramondt and Berry Westra took out the No. 4 seeds: James Cayne, Robert Levin, Michael Seamon, Steve Weinstein, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness.

title: Resolving the Wiretap Debate
description: Congress seems to lack the backbone to stop President Bush from authorizing wiretaps without court orders, and censuring him would probably not do much to make him follow the law. What could make a real difference would be a Supreme Court ruling that found his domestic surveillance program to be illegal.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon Undergoes Successful Surgery
description: Doctors reattached part of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's skull that had been removed in an earlier operation after his stroke on Jan. 4, officials at Hadassah-Ein Kerem Hospital in Jerusalem said. The procedure was to have been done Tuesday, but was postponed. Mr. Sharon, 78, remains comatose, and the hospital gave no additional details on his condition. Within the next few days, the cabinet is expected to pronounce Mr. Sharon "permanently incapacitated." This would allow Ehud Olmert, the acting prime minister, to formally become the head of the government.

title: Seeking Retail Therapy in a Temple of Fashion

Peering into the cabinet where we keep such things, I saw two choices folded on the shelf. I could send her out onto the street in her Chlo platform shoes with a shiny yellow plastic drawstring bag from Dress Barn. Or I could hand her the Platonic ideal of the chic shopping bag, the Taoist uncarved block of retail therapy: the black, boxy, matte-finish Barneys bag. I debated.

title: 'Gospel of Judas' Surfaces After 1,700 Years
description: An early Christian manuscript, including the only known text of what is known as the Gospel of Judas, has surfaced after 1,700 years. The text gives new insights into the relationship of Jesus and the disciple who betrayed him, scholars reported today. In this version, Jesus asked Judas, as a close friend, to sell him out to the authorities, telling Judas he will "exceed" the other disciples by doing so.

description: Apple to Offer Computers That Can Run Both Macintosh and Windows Systems Two decades after the first Macintosh computer arrived, Apple said that it would offer users of its latest models a simple way to run both the Microsoft Windows operating system and its own. The Art of the Deal
description: Sales offices for condominium developments are usually nondescript, temporary structures. But in the artsy West Queen West neighborhood of Toronto, the London-based architect Will Alsop has created an Urbancorp/Landmark showroom that looks like a speckled red box. Made of marine plywood, it has amoeba-shape windows and an egg-shape conference room. The office will be used to sell apartments in two buildings designed by Baird Sampson Neuert Architects and a tower by Mr. Alsop. Once the apartments are sold, the 3,000-square-foot office will have a second life as an art gallery run by Ben Woolfitt, an artist and art-supply store owner. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, ALBERT
description: ROSENTHAL--Albert. Humanitarian, educator, mentor, leader, influenced the lives of so many people. Loving and devoted husband of Mildred. Dear father of Ellen Rosenthal-Gelband and Barbara J. Brady. Proud grandfather of Lauren and Steven Brady. Caring father-in-law of Donald Brady & Stuart Gelband. Passed away on April 3, 2006. Al and Mil were married for over 62 years, sharing their love of family, friends and world travel. He served as a Chief Petty Officer in the U.S. Navy, training men in physical education in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He was a graduate of James Monroe High School in the Bronx, City College, New York University and Columbia University. Al began his teaching career in elementary school and then moved through the ranks to junior high school, high school and college. His passion for teaching led him to become Chairman of Health and Physical Education. For over 20 years "Uncle Al" was director of Masonic Camp Seven, providing campers and counsellors with unforgetable life experiences. Throughout his 88 years he worked tirelessly to make this world a better place. As an active member of the Plainview Jewish Center, the Plainview Library, the RSSA and numerous other organizations, he was determined to assist people in making their lives better. Al defined the term gentleman, and was a unique character in so many ways. He will be profoundly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEEN, WILLIAM J.
description: GEEN--William J. A former longtime resident of Pelham Manor and member & Elder of The Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church, passed away on April 1, 2006 after a long illness. Born May 30, 1930, Bill was the son of the late William John and Annie (Jones) Geen. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Ruth Parker Geen, and his five children: Barbara LeMaster, David, Elizabeth Gallagher, Robert and Christopher. Bill was an alumnus of Drexel University, and the University of Pennsylvania law school. He was partner of Chadbourne & Parke, LLP from 1971-95, where he was said to combine "meticulous fairness, intellectual honesty and the fearlessness of a pirate." Upon retirement, Bill and Ruth moved to Easton, MD, where he enjoyed sailing, skiing, trumpet and piano playing. Bill's greatest joy was his 12 grandchildren: Kate, Sam, Tom, Rachel, Josh, Liza, Anne, Peter, William, Lucy, Georgia, and Henry. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 8 at 1:00PM at the family home in Easton. For information, call Liz Gallagher at 410.822.1257.

title: Arts, Briefly; Mixup in Beatles Mixes
description: The first run of "The Capitol Albums, Vol. 2," the collection of the Beatles' American albums to be released on Tuesday, uses incorrect mixes on two of the four discs. The error, spotted by collectors who received advance copies, was acknowledged by Capitol Records yesterday. The company said consumers would be able to exchange the mispressed discs for corrected versions. Like the first volume, the set includes four albums as they were released in the United States in the 1960's, in formats that differed notably from their British counterparts. Each disc -- in this case, "The Early Beatles," "Beatles VI," "Help!" and "Rubber Soul" -- was meant to include both the stereo and mono mixes, which in many cases are noticeably different. For "The Early Beatles" and "Help!" Capitol's engineers in the 1960's chose to assemble a stereo master, and to fold down (or reduce) the stereo mixes to mono for the mono releases, instead of using the British mono mixes. But the mono tracks on the original LP releases of "Beatles VI" and "Rubber Soul" are distinct mixes. On the "Vol. 2" CD's, Capitol used reduced mono mixes on all four albums. The company attributed the error to a mastering house, which apparently sent the incorrect mixes to Capitol's pressing plant. The mistake is most easily spotted on "Rubber Soul." The stereo version of the song "I'm Looking Through You" includes a false start that did not appear on the mono version. On the mispressed CD's, the mono "I'm Looking Through You" has the false start. ALLAN KOZINN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NUSIM, JOSEPH
description: NUSIM - Joseph. Whose career as a leader in retailing spanned over 50 years, and a turnaround specialist for troubled companies died of complications from lymphoma at his home in Wayne, New Jersey on April 3 at the age of 72. Attending the Baruch School at night he took his first job with Robert Hall Clothes as a buyer of Women's apparel, and in 1959 moved on to become VP and General Merchandise Manager of Spartan Industries Department stores. In the early 1970's he became Executive VP of the Jamesway Corporation a major mass merchandise retailer. He left Jamesway in 1985 to become Chairman, CEO and Managing Director of Makro, a division of Dutch giant SHV when SHV expanded its European operations to the US, bringing one of the first warehouse clubs to these shores. After overseeing the acquisition of Makro by K Mart in 1990, Nusim took on the challenge of turning around the troubled Channel Home Centers as President and CEO. When Channel was acquired by Rickel Home Centers in 1996 he bcame Chairman and Pre sident until 1998. Most recently he was Co-Chairman of the Board of Loehmanns. In 1998 Nusim started the Nusim Consulting Group. An expert in turn-around issues facing retailers he was a frequent advisor and speaker on the subject. He served on the Board of Directors of Frank's Nursery, Scotty's Home Centers, Frankel's Home Furnishings, Herman's Sporting Goods, Woodworkers Warehouse, Lions Brand, and Kimco Realty Corporation. He served on the Advisory Board of Wells Fargo Bank Retail Division and DJM As1as a consultant to GE Capitol and the Blackstone Group. A founder of the International Mass Retail Association (IMRA) he was on the Board and was a frequent speaker on retailing and turnaround issues. Nusim is survived by his second wife Rosemary, his son, Steven Nusim of Montclair, NJ a daughter Zina Numim of East Brunswick, NHJ a stepdaughter Kim Wood, three grandchildren and a brother Stanley Nusim and a sister Roberta Nusim, both of New York City. Contributions can be made to the Joseph Nusim Fund for Mantle Cell Lymphoma, 20 Stoney Ridge Lane, Riverside, CT. 06878

title: Arts, Briefly; A Night of Pain For Simon Cowell
description: Every season of Fox's "American Idol," Simon Cowell, below, says he hates country music. And every season, there is a country music theme night that flummoxes him. This year, it was Tuesday night, and Mr. Cowell seemed as if he were being tortured before the show's estimated 28 million viewers. After that on Fox, the medical drama "House" drew its best ratings ever, with an audience of 22.63 million. It drew more viewers in its second half-hour than it did in its first, a ratings feat no hourlong series following "Idol" has ever accomplished. Needless to say, Fox made mincemeat of its network competition. Among the carnage was the debut of the WB's "Pepper Dennis" (2.92 million), which lost a significant portion of the "Gilmore Girls" audience (4.29 million). At 10 p.m., NBC's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" delivered 14.81 million viewers and easily won the hour. The episode ended with Olivia, played by the maternity-leave-bound Mariska Hargitay, asking for a new partner to get away from her intense relationship with Elliot (Christopher Meloni). KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tentative Approval For Javits Center
description: State officials tentatively approved plans yesterday for a $1.7 billion expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The project would add 1.3 million square feet of exhibition and meeting room space and a ballroom, while renovating the center on 11th Avenue, according to the Javits Development Corporation. Plans also call for a glass-enclosed concourse, a convention hotel and a new park. There will be a public hearing on the project next month. The Javits Operating Corporation and another state board must approve the plans before the groundbreaking, which is scheduled for late this summer.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Applications For Medical Marijuana
description: Chronically ill patients who want to use medicinal marijuana began submitting applications under a new state law. In January, Rhode Island became the first state to sanction the use of medical marijuana since the Supreme Court ruled that the authorities could prosecute marijuana users, even in states that allow it to be used medicinally. Four people submitted applications, and 51 others are being completed, said Maria Wah-Fitta, a spokeswoman for the Rhode Island Department of Health. The state has 30 days to verify with a physician that the patient is eligible for the program. A patient and a caretaker can possess up to 2.5 ounces of marijuana or up to 12 plants. The patient and caretaker must carry cards that identify them as part of the program at all times.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man In Hospital After Standoff
description: A 20-year-old Long Island man who was holding what turned out to be a fake handgun was disarmed by the police yesterday as he stood on the balcony of an apartment building on the Upper West Side. The man, whose name was not released, went to 101 West End Avenue to look at an apartment on the 30th floor. He told the real estate agent that he had a gun and ordered her to leave the apartment, the police said. When Sgt. David Schimschi entered the building, he found the man on the edge of the balcony, pointing what appeared to be a 9-millimeter handgun in his direction. After a brief standoff, during which the man threatened to leap off the building, Sergeant Schimschi and other officers rushed and tackled him. The man was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center for observation.

title: The Listings: April 7 - April 13; CHICK COREA: FOREVER RETURNS
description: Before its spangled reign as one of the better bombastic fusion bands, Return to Forever was a sprightly chamber-jazz outfit inspired especially by the music of Brazil. The group originated in 1971 as an outgrowth of the keyboardist Chick Corea's work with the tenor saxophonist Stan Getz; its first iteration included Mr. Corea and two other Getz sidemen, the bassist Stanley Clarke and the percussionist Airto Moreira. By the time it disbanded at the close of 1977, Return to Forever had etched a place in popular culture, complete with arena tours and Top 40 albums (one of which, "Romantic Warrior" on Columbia, would eventually be certified gold). Moving away from the band, Mr. Corea, above, briefly reconnected with its fluttering early sound; in 1978 he recorded a pair of solo albums with the former Return to Forever members Joe Farrell (reeds) and Steve Gadd (drums) and a sharp new bassist, Eddie Gomez. An array of projects have preoccupied Mr. Corea in the years since -- for a crash course, splurge on "Rendezvous in New York" (Image Entertainment), which chronicles a reunion-heavy 2001 Blue Note residency on 10 DVD's -- but Return to Forever has rarely re-entered the picture. That's changing now, somewhat: Mr. Corea's most recent album, "The Ultimate Adventure" (Stretch), pointedly evokes his early-70's sound. And next week at the Blue Note, he introduces something called Forever Returns, with Mr. Moreira and Mr. Gomez. The absence of Mr. Clarke undercuts the premise a bit, but the music should soar nonetheless. (Tuesday through April 16 at 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592; cover, $45 at tables, $35 at the bar, with a $5 minimum.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEEN, WILLIAM J.
description: GEEN--William J. A former longtime resident of Pelham Manor and member & Elder of The Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church, passed away on April 1, 2006 after a long illness. Born May 30, 1930, Bill was the son of the late William John and Annie (Jones) Geen. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Ruth Parker Geen, and his five children: Barbara LeMaster, David, Elizabeth Gallagher, Robert and Christopher. Bill was an alumnus of Drexel University, and the University of Pennsylvania law school. He was partner of Chadbourne & Parke, LLP from 1971-95, where he was said to combine "meticulous fairness, intellectual honesty and the fearlessness of a pirate." Upon retirement, Bill and Ruth moved to Easton, MD, where he enjoyed sailing, skiing, trumpet and piano playing. Bill's greatest joy was his 12 grandchildren: Kate, Sam, Tom, Rachel, Josh, Liza, Anne, Peter, William, Lucy, Georgia, and Henry. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 8 at 1:00PM at the family home in Easton. For information, call Liz Gallagher at 410.822.1257.

description: If you happen to be near the Rialto Theater in June, you can catch "Still Smoking," the newest work by Maria Hassabi, who has been invited to perform there by the Cyprus government. Or, swing by the Kitchen this week. Ms. Hassabi's dance, created with her co-performers David Adamo, Caitlin Cook, Ori Flomin, Jessie Gold and Hristoula Harakas, was commissioned by the Kitchen and boasts, as curator, the downtown favorite Sarah Michelson. Ms. Hassabi, who earned her B.F.A. from California Institute of the Arts, has also designed the set for "Still Smoking" (above, with Ms. Hassabi third from left). The news release describes it as "a rich theatrical environment" full of "stylized visual elements," including Joel Fitzpatrick's lighting and costumes designed by ThreeAsFour. Ms. Hassabi describes it as a world for "six performers, submerged in their melancholia and indefinable desires," who "create an architectural form that examines the extreme dichotomy of a frenetic urban life and exposes a raw interior landscape." The abstract work doesn't focus on personalities like some of Ms. Hassabi's previous efforts, but gains its rhythm and energy from, as she put it, a constant urban "overflow of information and interactivity." (Thursday at 8 p.m., next Friday at 7 and 9:30 p.m., and April 15 at 8 p.m., 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org; $12.)
