But the gospel-influenced singer did not shine on Tuesday's country music night, and an estimated audience of 25.4 million watched her shown the "Idol" door. The ratings for that half-hour lifted Fox to first place for the night, but its criminal procedural "Bones" (9.9 million) and its "No Exit"-like reality series "Unan1mous" (13.74 million) also fared well. ABC was No. 2 for the night among adults 18 to 49 on the strength of "Lost" (15.76 million). title: The Listings: April 7 - April 13; GALLERY PLAYERS
description: Sadly, you can't TiVo Broadway shows (imagine how wonderful it would be to fast-forward through the labored scenes of jukebox musicals), so if you don't catch any performances of the run of, say, "The History Boys," you'll have to wait at least a decade or two for a major revival, if it ever arrives. But for some fans, there is another option -- and it can be found in, of all places, Park Slope, Brooklyn, less known for its Broadway babies than for the regular kind. The Gallery Players, located on 14th Street for the last 16 years, have developed a reputation for reviving commercial hits whose original productions still vividly linger in memories. Among the offerings over the past few years have been "The Full Monty" (closed on Broadway September 2002), "Side Show" (closed on Broadway January 1998) and "The Fantasticks," a show that only four years ago finished its downtown run of more than 41 years, enough time, you would think, to exhaust its demand for at least a generation. But part of the fun of these quickie revivals is the comparisons. The broadly comic current version of "Take Me Out" (closed 2004), above, for example, is a solidly entertaining production with actors who look a few sizes too small to be major leaguers. "I thought I would never want to see anyone but Denis O'Hare," said the man sitting next to me, referring to the actor who won a Tony Award for his role as the accountant who falls in love with the game. But here he was, chuckling at Scott McGowan's version of the same character, which hinted at the original (he also hugged himself nervously) but pursued laughs more shamelessly. (Though April 16, "Take Me Out" is playing at the Gallery Players, 199 14th Street, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues, Park Slope, (212) 352-3101, theatermania.com; $15; students and 62+, $12.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cyclists Sue Over Duck Boats
description: A group of advocates for bicyclists and pedestrians filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to block the construction of a ramp for amphibious tour buses in the Hudson River at West 38th Street. Port Imperial Duck Charterers, a company run by owners of the New York Waterway ferry service, received state approval to build the ramp in December. In its suit, which names the State Department of Environmental Conservation and Port Imperial, the advocacy group, Transportation Alternatives, contends that the state review did not consider the dangers the buses would pose to people using the bike path along the Hudson River. Pat Smith, a spokesman for the company, responded, "The impacts are negligible and the claim is without merit." A decision from the Army Corps of Engineers on the ramp proposal is pending.

title: A Russian Noir, '4,' Is Bleak and Brooding, Naked and Sweating
description: The terminally bleak meets the hypnotically beautiful in the Russian cryptogram "4." Directed by the newcomer Ilya Khrzhanovsky, the film opens with four dogs carefully positioned on a city street at night. Nearby, a mounted light pulses an agitated rhythm, as does a loudly chugging machine. To the rear of this strange tableau, cutting across the frame like a theatrical backdrop, is a large shop window from which four dolls stare blankly into the street. A similar emptiness fills the faces of some of the men and women who will later catch Mr. Khrzhanovsky's pitiless interest, but for now, the night belongs to these barking, whimpering, torturously symbolic harbingers of social unease and untrammeled aesthetic ambition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAGNER, SIMA
description: WAGNER--Sima. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Sima Wagner. For sixty-six years Sima was the devoted wife of Rubin Wagner, who survives her, the loving mother of Harry and Myra, Leon and Marsha and grandmother of Elliot, Lauren, Gabriel and Daniel. Born in Vilna, now Vilnius, Lithuania, daughter of Leah and Yisroel Benosher, Sima was the devoted older sister of Fania, Sharon and Merele of whom only Fania and Sharon survived the Holocaust. Young and in love Sima and Ruby eloped in February 1940 as the world erupted into war. Their daughter, Sheyna, born in 1941, was taken from Sima during a concentration camp selection. Separated during the war and imprisoned in numerous concentration camps Sima miraculously reunited with her husband after the war living in a displaced persons camp in Heidenheim, Germany between 1945 and 1949. They landed in New York with $8 to their name, lived in Brooklyn whereupon Sima became a member of the International Ladies Garment Worker's Union in order to help support her family. She reared her family in Jewish homes in Huntington, Roslyn and Aventura, Florida and always carried herself with elegance, dignity and discipline and was widely respected and loved in the community of survivors. Throughout her life Sima Wagner gave comfort and care to her sisters, niece, nephews, and cousins living a life devoted to family, friends, charity, Holocaust Remembrance and Am Yisrael Chai. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to: Ella Levine, YIVO Institute, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011 In memory of Sima Wagner or Dr. Amir Baron, Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center, 20400 North East 30th Avenue, Aventura, FL 33180 In memory of Sima Wagner. The Wagner Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CREGAN, DORIS JEAN ROY
description: CREGAN--Doris Jean Roy. Of Pawleys Island, S.C. passed away on April 5, 2006 at her home surrounded by her family and friends. Mrs. Cregan was born in Sheepshead Bay, NY to the late Helen Casey Roy and Frederick Patrick Roy on September 14, 1930. Mrs. Cregan raised her family with her devoted husband of 57 years, William John Cregan, in Huntington, NY. A lifelong volunteer, Mrs. Cregan ministered to the sick and homebound. Her warm contagious smile, outgoing personality and giving heart endeared her to all those whose lives she touched. She was especially gifted in easing the burden of those who suffered from illness, loneliness and isolation. Mrs. Cregan was an active member of the Precious Blood of Christ during her entire 12-year residence in Pawleys Island. She was a Eucharist Minister, an active member of the Community Outreach Program and contributed to numerous Church Committees. Mrs. Cregan is survived by her devoted and loving husband, William John Cregan, her seven children; Donna Lambert and husband Matthew of River Forest, IL; William Cregan and wife Beth of Jamestown, RI; Ellen Kitchen and husband John of Westwood, MA; Carol Reynolds and husband James of Charlotte, NC; Robert Cregan of Tampa, FL; Timothy Cregan of Statesville, NC; Eric Cregan and wife Martha of North Reading, MA and 19 grandchildren and one great grandchild. A celebration of her life will take place at the Precious Blood of Christ at 1633 Waverly Road in Pawleys Island, SC on April 8, 2006. Memorial contributions may be made to the Outreach Programs at the Precious Blood of Christ and the Tidelands Community Hospice Incorporated.

title: The Listings: April 7 - April 13; KAREN AKERS
description: Ms. Akers admits that the pairing did not at first seem auspicious. "I'm not a Broadway baby, a belter, a razzle-dazzle kind of kid," she explained. Indeed, in her early cabaret performances, and on Broadway in "Nine" and "Grand Hotel," Ms. Akers, above, honed her regal bearing and nonindulgent way with a tune to such a degree that you could hardly imagine her coming within a mile of a sequin or a shout. So the news that her new gig at the Oak Room would consist of songs by John Kander and Fred Ebb -- they of "New York, New York" and "Cabaret," of the streetwise insouciance and ha-cha-cha dissipation -- seemed to suggest a misalliance. But two things conspire to predict a good match. One is that Ms. Akers's style has become less Olympian, more personal; beneath the perfect diction and lucid phrasing you can hear her heartbeat. It's also true that the Kander and Ebb catalog is more varied, and frequently much darker, than their most Lizafied songs might indicate at first glance. "I went to the music and found that it offered me a lot more latitude than I expected," Ms. Akers said. "It opened itself up to me." That's because the songs were written for complex theatrical situations; the balance between hopefulness and the implied despair that makes hopefulness necessary is always being negotiated. Still, she "sidestepped" most of the flashier numbers in favor of actorly songs from lesser-known shows like "The Happy Time," "The Rink," "70, Girls, 70," "The Act" and "Steel Pier." But "Cabaret" is not entirely shut out. From that show Ms. Akers will sing the relentlessly conditional "Maybe This Time" and, most fittingly, "Married": a perfect ode to mismatches that aren't. (Tuesdays to Saturdays through May 13 at 9 p.m., with late shows on Fridays and Saturdays at 11:30, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 419-9331; $60 cover, with a $20 minimum; $60 prix fixe dinner required on Thursdays and at the early shows on Fridays and Saturdays.)

description: The listing of lottery results yesterday omitted the winning bonus number for New York Lotto. The numbers were 18, 27, 30, 34, 35 and 39, with a bonus number of 14.

title: A Juror's Question That Went Unanswered: 'How Dare You Violate That Oath?'
description: There were several reasons it took jurors more than 11 hours to reach guilty verdicts in the federal racketeering trial of Louis Eppolito and Steven Caracappa, the former police detectives accused of taking part in eight murders for the mob.

title: Moscow issues West a warning
Colleagues of Police Chief Cite His Bond With Jews
description: Joseph J. Esposito enjoys, among the rank and file of the New York Police Department, a reputation as a "cop's cop," as much a product of the department as any school or neighborhood, joining at age 18 in the bygone days of officer trainees.

title: Rights of Ex-Felons
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke Grappling With Impact of Scandal on Its Reputation
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 6 - Duke University is widely considered one of the great success stories in higher education, having transformed itself from a respected regional university with a history of segregation into a selective research university on a par with the country's most elite institutions.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about efforts by Jewish organizations nationwide to market Judaism referred imprecisely to one organization, the National Jewish Outreach Program. Although its founder and director is an Orthodox rabbi and it encourages "traditional" observance, it is not officially affiliated with the Orthodox branch of Judaism.

title: Slogging through the Soviet facts of war
Reptile Events: Up Close, a Creepy, Crawly World
description: CHILDREN love dinosaurs, but barring the development of a real-life Jurassic Park, they are a few million years too late to see Tyrannosaurus rex. Prowling about in the 21st century, however, and satisfyingly huge, alien and scary in their own right, are some relatives of those distant dinosaurs -- the oversize living lizards called monitors.

title: Biomet Won't Say So, but Investors Expect a Sale
description: Biomet will not say the company is for sale. In fact, the company -- one of the nation's largest manufacturers of artificial hips, knees and other orthopedic devices -- refused until yesterday afternoon to confirm a CNBC report Tuesday that it had hired Morgan Stanley to help it explore its strategic options.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fort Lee: Body Found By River
description: The skeletal remains of a body were discovered by hikers on a steep slope in Fort Lee overlooking the Hudson River yesterday around 4:30 p.m., the police said. Investigators were trying to retrieve the remains, which were discovered near Ross's Boat Basin. As of last night, the sex, age and identity of the victim were unknown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUICK, REGINA
description: QUICK--Regina. The passing of Regina (Jean) Quick saddens the Trustees and staff of the Inner-City Scholarship Fund (ICSF). Mother of board members Thomas C. Quick and Patricia A. deVisscher, Jean was a tireless supporter of the students and schools served by ICSF. We will always remember her kindness and compassion for those less fortunate. Our hearts go out to Tom, Tricia and all the Quick family at this time. Peter T. Grauer, President Susan George, Exec. Director

title: For Venice Biennale: Felix Gonzalez-Torres
description: For Venice Biennale: Felix Gonzalez-Torres

title: A new gas war looms, with Belarus the loser
Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, HARRY
description: LEVY--Harry. Former General Counsel to New York City Housing Authority and pioneer of the public housing movement, passed away at age 97 on April 5, 2006. He was instrumental in the original movement to create the concept of low income public housing in the City of New York and in the nation, and in effecting passage of the first national Public Housing Law in 1937. He is survived by his wife Hilda (nee Jonas), by his children, David Levy (Zari Weiss) of Seattle, WA, Elena Levy (Daniel Leonard) of Norwalk, CT, and Lester Levy (Mary Tilbury) of San Anselmo, CA, by his brother Jacob Usadi of White Plains, NY, and by his loving grandchildren, Simon, Rick, Jane and Sarah. Services will be held at 11:30 A.M. April 7 at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue.

title: Other views: Irish Times, Baltimore Sun, Montreal Gazette
The plight in Iraq
Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 9 about the military's recruitment of Hispanics referred incompletely to the belief of some critics that Hispanics in the Iraq war and blacks in the Vietnam War accounted for a disproportionate number of casualties. Statistics do not support the belief. Hispanics, who are about 14 percent of the population, accounted for about 11 percent of the military deaths in Iraq through Dec. 3, 2005. About 12.5 percent of the military dead in Vietnam were African-Americans, who made up about 13. 5 percent of the general population during the war years. The error was pointed out in an e-mail in February; the correction was delayed for research after a lapse at The Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, WILLIAM R.
description: RYAN--William R. 94, of Vero Beach, FL died April 3rd in Holland, MI. A graduate of Stevens Institute and former resident of Riverside, CT. He retired in 1994 as Chairman and CEO of EDO Corporation. He is survived by his wife Joan, his children Susan Mimnaugh, Christine Walworth and Richard. Eleven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren, and preceded in death by his first wife Nancy. Celebration of life memorial services are planned for August 5th at Little Point Sable, MI and August 19th at Saint Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, CT. Tax deductable donations may be made to Memorial Nature Preserve, c/o Paul Thompson (Treasurer), 805 Glen Road, Shelby, MI 49455.

title: Neglected Diseases
description: To the Editor:

title: Couric Says Jump, and Fans Reach for Their Remotes
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 6 - Three nights a week, Ann Viele usually sits down to watch at least part of the evening news, and when she does, she chooses the newscast of Brian Williams on NBC, just as she did Tom Brokaw's before him.

title: In a Canyon, a Different Mexico
description: THE view from a cozy car on the Copper Canyon Railroad in Mexico is dazzling: mossy, emerald hills and slate-blue lakes slowly give way to red canyon walls that rise below and above the train tracks to dizzying depths and heights. Go stand between cars, where you can lean out of an open-windowed vestibule, and the experience gets even better -- sweet mountain winds rushing over your face like water, the air warm and cool, fresh and dusty all at once.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KIRKLIN, JOHN E.
description: KIRKLIN--John E. April 6, 2000. I mourned, and yet shall mourn with ever-returning spring

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOWELL, GILBERTE CAZES
description: YOWELL--Gilberte Cazes. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Yowell. Loving mother of Linda, Debora, Alan and Robert; loving mother-inlaw of Richard Zuckerman, Richard Alberts and Mara Mikialian. Adored grandmother of Julia, Emily, Jackson, Marguerite, and Henry. Her family will always be inspired by her courageous journey and indomitable spirit. Services Sunday, April 9 at 10 AM at Temple Sholom, Greenwich, CT. Burial to follow at King Solomon Cemetery in Clifton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday, about plagiarism in novels, gave the wrong name for a pope who 19th-century con artists said had been kidnapped. It was Leo XIII, not Leo VIII.

title: Conglomerates: When synergies collide
Sondheim's 'Company' Is Coming to Broadway Next Season
description: The marriage between Stephen Sondheim's music and John Doyle's directing is proving to be fruitful. Mr. Doyle's acclaimed production of "Company," now playing in Cincinnati, is headed for Broadway by the end of the year, its New York producers said. There it will join the hit revival of "Sweeney Todd," by Mr. Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler, which is also directed by Mr. Doyle.

title: Police Chief Apologizes for Remarks During Brooklyn Protest
description: A top police official accused of making a derogatory comment about Jews during a clash between police officers and residents in Brooklyn sent a letter of apology last night to the city councilman who made the accusation and a state assemblyman who backed him.

title: An Unlikely Friendship Alters Two Lives in 'Simon'
description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Eddy Terstall Not rated; 102 minutes

title: Photographs: Pro-Life Nation
description: What happens when you completely criminalize abortion? El Salvador has found out.

title: Slide Show: Day 2 at Augusta National
description: After a calm first round at the Masters, wind gusts greeted the players on Friday.

title: Average Joes on Hidden C.E.O. Pay
description: Plenty of academics, experts and respected pundits have weighed in on the proposed changes to the rules on disclosing executive pay. But why read such serious stuff on a Friday?

title: Slide Show: Pulse
description: Growing animals in the garden, what the 'tween queen is wearing now, bringing in the crops and the sands of time turn back.

title: Biomet Wont Say So, but Investors Expect a Sale
description: Biomet will not say the company is for sale. But movement of the companys stock indicates some investors think a sale could be in the offing. And analysts who follow the company and its competitors in the $20 billion orthopedics industry have little doubt that Biomets independence is in play and that its predicament spotlights broader trends as well as the companys particular problems.

title: What to do With Old Newspapers?
description: Old newspapers are often used for some rather unpleasant tasks. You can wrap stinky fish in them. You can use them to line the bottom of a bird cage. Or you can bring a paper along with you when youre walking your dog and use it as a makeshift pooper scooper.

title: Executive Search Firms Merge
description: One of the more colorful mergers in recent times has been announced in Hong Kong, with the Green Orange executive search firm and the U.S.-based Search Pacific joining forces. The Hong Kong-based firm will be bolstered by the return of Mark Jones, managing director of Search Pacific, to the region after a two-year absence.

title: Pfizer to Buy Rinat, a Biotechnology Drug Maker
description: Pfizer said yesterday that it would acquire Rinat Neuroscience, a privately held company developing drugs for pain, Alzheimers disease and other neurological disorders, to move further into biotechnology. Terms of the deal were not announced, though Pfizer is believed to be paying several hundred million dollars.

title: Getty Images Snaps Up Image Partner
description: Getty Images, a Seattle-based supplier of stock images for businesses and consumers, said Thursday that it has acquired Ireland-based Pixel Images Holdings for $135 million in cash. Pixel owns Stockdisc and Stockbyte, Gettys largest image partner. Getty said owning the content it is already distributing will give it more flexibility and higher margins.

title: Lehman Sets Stock Split
description: Hot on the heels of a record earnings report and following an approximately 60 percent rise in its shares over the last year, Lehman Brothers Holdings management issued another vote of confidence in the firms outlook Thursday in announcing a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: LSI Logic to Sell Production Facility
description: LSI Logic said Thursday it will sell an Oregon production facility to ON Semiconductor for $105 million in cash, as part of a strategy to stop manufacturing chips.

title: Post Gossip Writer Investigated for Burkle Blackmail
description: A gossip writer for the New York Post has been suspended pending the outcome of a federal investigation into whether he tried to extort money from billionaire financier Ron Burkle, the newspaper said Thursday. Jared Paul Stern, who worked as a freelancer for the newspapers Page Six column, is suspected of demanding $100,000 and an annual $10,000 stipend from Burkle in exchange for not writing negative stories about him.

title: EDS makes Formal Offer for Indian Outsourcer
description: EDS has made a $380 million offer to buy a majority stake in an Indian business-process outsourcing company. EDS has made the offer for a 52 percent stake in Bangalore, India-based Mphasis, which has around 12,000 employees.

title: Oil Refinery Barrels Toward Sale
description: The refinery jointly owned by Lyondell Chemical and Citgo Petroleum appears headed for the sales block. The partnership, Lyondell-Citgo Refining, said Thursday it has signed a letter of intent to jointly explore the sale of the refinery in Houston capable of refining 268,000 barrels a day of crude, which an analyst said could fetch around $3 billion.

title: Icahn Still Wont Stand Up for Lexars Micron Marriage
description: Lexar Media Inc., the flash-card memory maker, has yet to win the support of one of its biggest shareholders for its pending merger with Micron Technology. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing late Thursday, the investment group of billionaire Carl Icahn said Lexar officials tried to persuade them in an April 5 meeting to support Microns offer of roughly $680 million.

title: Goldman Struggling to Find Buyer for German Drug Maker
description: Goldman Sachs is struggling to find a buyer for the German drugs company Altana, marking the investment banks second flop in the pharmaceuticals sector after it also failed to sell the Swiss company Serono. There is speculation that Goldman may now try to organize a marriage between Altana and Merck, which lost out to its larger rival Bayer in a battle for Schering last month.

title: Is Paulson Going Public?
description: For several decades, senior partners at Goldman Sachs have pursued second careers in politics. Now, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the firms chief executive, must decide if he will continue what has become a Wall Street tradition. As speculation builds in Washington that President Bush will move to replace his Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, Mr. Paulsons name has cropped up as a possible choice.

title: Ports Debacle Leads to Fears of Bad Case, Bad Law
description: Congress has begun to overhaul the obscure legal process by which the White House reviews mergers and acquisitions by foreigners of American companies  from rocket manufacturers to software makers  that are vital to the national security.

title: Singapore Exchange Denies Nasdaq Merger Rumors
description: The Singapore Exchange on Friday denied speculation it was in talks with Nasdaq Stock Market about a merger but confirmed it was open to tie-ups with others, including other stock exchanges.

title: Next Industry to Ride the M&A Wave: Nonprofits
description: The wave of mergers rippling through the corporate world is also washing into the nonprofit sector. Interest in mergers and alliances among nonprofits has become so hot nationally that a California firm specializing in the issue, La Piana Associates, Inc., has seen inquiries on the topic increase more than 50 percent over the last two years.

title: Street All Wound Up Over Morgan Stanley Funds
description: Morgan Stanleys ability to stay calm on the topic of its struggling asset-management unit is making Wall Street hyper.

title: Armenia Sells Russia Crucial Gas Link in Deal for Cheap Fuel
description: The latest natural gas squabble in the former Soviet Union was settled today, as Armenia negotiated cheap natural gas supplies from Russia with prices well below European averages locked in until 2009. In exchange, the agreement calls for it to surrender to Russia a small but crucial section of pipeline linking it to Iran.

title: Canada Telecoms Want Deregulation
description: As the U.S. telecommunications firms consolidate at a rapid pace, Canadas phone companies are concerned with deregulation. The coutrys biggest telephone companies must lose 25 percent of their market share in the local phone sector before Canadas federal regulator will loosen their regulatory chains.

title: Citigroup Pays University to Settle WorldCom Allegations
description: Citigroup will pay $13.25 million to the University of California to settle allegations linking the financial services company to the accounting fiasco that toppled WorldCom nearly four years ago.

title: Smith Barney Pays to Settle Class Action Suit
description: Smith Barney has agreed to pay $50 million to investors to settle a class action alleging that the firm placed stocks of investment banking clients in broker-managed fee-based accounts

title: UBS  to Pay $85 Million to Settle Sumitomo Copper Suit
description: UBS, Europes largest bank by assets, agreed to pay Sumitomo 10 billion yen ($85 million) to settle litigation concerning market-roiling transactions a decade ago by a rogue trader known as Mr. Copper.

title: After a Good Nights Sleep, Sealy Will Wake Up Public
description: Mattress giant Sealy plans to wake up as a public company Friday some 17 years after the 125-year-old company was taken private. The Trinity, N.C., company plans to offer 23.33 million shares at a price range of $14 to $16 a share in a bid to raise about $350 million. Underwriters are Citigroup and Goldman Sachs.

title: Dyno Nobel of Australia Prices I.P.O.
description: Co-lead managers Macquarie Bank and Credit Suisse met investor demand for Dyno Nobel stock by raising the price of the initial public offering to A$2.37 per share, 10 cents above the top end of the bookbuild range.

title: Canada Sees Uptick in I.P.O.s
description: Despite a slow start and a lingering sense of caution among issuers, Canadas initial public offering market picked up through the first quarter, and by the time the quarter was over, the number and value of offerings were sharply higher than a year earlier.

title: Massachusetts Venture Capitalist Joins Race for Governor
description: Venture capitalist Christopher Gabrieli formally announced he is running for governor, becoming the third Democrat to join the race. Gabrieli announced his run Thursday morning in a 10-minute speech at his campaign headquarters on Canal Street in Boston.

title: Cerberus Dishes Out GMAC Equity Like Candy
description: Cerberus $7.4 billion acquisition of GMAC is a triumph of financial engineering. Up to 50 co-investors are clamoring for a nibble of the biggest equity investment ever by a leveraged buyout firm. Thats because the record-breaking deal for a stake in the General Motors finance unit is so sweet. Cerberus is paying less than book value.

title: Seattle Venture Firm Brings Media Analyst On Board
description: The media and telecommunications industries are undergoing radical transformations. And now Maveron, the Seattle venture capital firm with about $600 million under management, is adding some horsepower to take advantage of the changes.

title: Bidders Circle Parisian and Lord & Taylor
description: The mergers and acquisitions activity around Parisian and Lord & Taylor is heating up.

title: British Retailer Gets Dawn Raid from Icelandic Investor
description: Baugur, the ambitious Icelandic investor, has conducted a dawn raid on House of Fraser, snapping up 9.5 percent of the department store groups shares. The move is a clear signal from Baugur that it will not be deterred either by the meltdown in Icelands economy or by the fact that its chief executive, Jon Asgeir Johannesson, was landed this week with another possible court case.

title: Private Equity Players Lead the Pack on REITs
description: Private equity firms have jumped to the forefront of the REIT privatization wave, and major industry players say the firms will stick around as buyers so long as cheap debt remains plentiful. Since the beginning of 2004, there have been 15 REIT privatizations, and all of the buyers were private equity firms or other institutional investors. Their common trait is that they can employ large amounts of debt and are able to flip properties quickly  two things public REITs cant do.

title: LVMHs Arnault Luxuriates in Jewelry Chain Sale
description: Bernard Arnault has pocketed a handsome profit via his L Capital investment fund. The LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton chiefs investment firm sold Italys Stroili jewelry chain to Investindustrial, a fund linked to the Benetton family, for 216 million euros, or $264.6 million at current exchange, according to a spokesman.

title: AXA Receives Private Equity Bid
description: French insurance group AXA said Friday it has received a binding offer for its reinsurance business from a private-equity consortium led by Stone Point Capital. The offer, which is for 120 million euros ($147 million) above the net assets of AXA, comes as the insurer has been reviewing the future of the reinsurance unit.

title: Seattles First Skyscraper Sold
description: Seattles first skyscraper was sold Thursday in a $47 million deal adding the 42-story Smith Tower and the adjacent two-story Florence Building to the holdings of a Chicago investment trust.

title: N.Y.S.E. Executive Describes Moves to Hide Grassos Full Payout
description: A senior human resources executive at the New York Stock Exchange has told lawyers that she altered documents, at the request of her boss, to hide the full amount of compensation earned by Richard A. Grasso, the former chief executive of the exchange, a transcript of her deposition says.

title: President of Ford Motor Will Retire
description: The Ford Motor Company said Thursday that its president, James J. Padilla, would retire July 1. His duties will be assumed by the chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., who is forming an executive operating committee to help him run the company.

title: Prosecutors Poised to Charge Milberg Partners
description: After six years of wide-ranging inquiries, stop-and-go grand jury activity and peripheral indictments, L.A. federal prosecutors are close to charging two partners from the massive plaintiff firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman  and possibly the firm itself  with paying illegal kickbacks, said several lawyers connected to the case.

title: Vodafone : It Restructures, It Reshuffles
description: After recent upheavals that have seen it sell off its Japanese business and cut up to $48.7 billion from the companys value, Vodafone is reshuffling its management and structure.

title: Before the Drama of Skilling, the Boredom of Details
description: Even if youre an Enron junkie  meaning that while most in the courtroom are groaning about endless accounting detail, youre sitting on the edge of your wooden bench, rapt  you would have found Wednesdays testimony trying.

title: Thrilling Da Vinci Trial nears End
description: Like a good thriller, The Da Vinci Code trial has had drama, controversy and conflict. And its ending with a cliffhanger  which way will a judge rule in the copyright infringement case against the publisher of Dan Browns world-conquering novel?

title: Blockbuster Finds Silver Lining in Patent Fight
description: If there is a bright side to being sued, movie-rental giant Blockbuster claims to have found it in its battle with Netflix. Blockbuster initially declined to comment when Los Gatos, Calif.-based Netflix sued the chain this week for patent infringement.

title: Dynegy Executive Asks for Release Pending Resentencing
description: Attorneys for former Dynegy employee Jamie Olis argued before an appeals court Thursday for his release on bond while he awaits resentencing. Olis has served two years of a 24-year sentence for his role in Project Alpha, a transaction that helped Dynegy inflate its reported cash flow by as much as $300 million.

title: S.E.C. Names Head of Boston Office
description: After overseeing investigations into several high-profile cases involving Massachusetts companies, David Bergers was named head of the Boston office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Bergers replaces Walter Ricciardi, who is now deputy director of the SECs division of enforcement in Washington, D.C.

title: Rap Producer Said to Be Near New Arrangement With Universal
description: Irving Lorenzo, the rap music impresario who lost much of his domain as he battled federal money-laundering charges, is on the verge of reviving his music label with private financial backing and re-establishing his alliance with Universal Music Group, according to press reports.

title: Independent Research Not Really Working Out
description: When Wall Streets top investment banks formalized their $1.4 billion global research settlement with the SEC in April 2003, in addition to making numerous reforms, they agreed to pay $450 million over five years to provide clients with independent equity research alongside their own. The idea was to create a new model for the industry that would avoid the conflicts of the old investment banking-driven one, while still producing a high-quality product. But in practice, it doesnt seem to be working for much of anyone.

title: BAE  in Talks to Sell Airbus Stake
description: BAE Systems could raise more than 3 billion pounds($4.3 billion) by selling its 20 percent stake in Airbus to EADS, the French-German defense company that already owns 80 percent of the aircraft maker. BAE said Friday that it was in talks with EADS to sell the stake. Analysts expect BAE to use the proceeds to expand in the United States.

title: NBC Universal Has a Crush on ProSieben
description: NBC Universal is looking at acquisition possibilities in Europe and considers German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 to be an attractive company, its distribution chief told The Financial Times Deutscheland.

title: Private Equity Bid for VNU Dealt Fresh Blow
description: A private equity groups plan to buy Dutch media giant VNU, owner of Billboard magazine and the Nielsen television ratings service, was dealt a serious blow yesterday after a powerful advisory firm told shareholders to vote against several key provisions of the deal.

title: Fantastic Fossil
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: No Fisticuffs
description: I met Pakistani Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz Thursday afternoon, during his visit to New York. Wow, hes got tight security, from the U.S. side. Presumably the U.S. is worried that Al Qaeda will try to blow him up while hes at the U.N.

title: The Livestock in the Walls
description: Selborne Journal: Wednesday, 7 April 1784: 29 7/10; 41; NE; 40. Snow melted, sun & clouds, dry & cold. Apricot begins to blow. Cucumber blows, female bloom without male. Ever-greens little injured: about London several sorts are destroyed. A farmer told Mr. Yalden that he saw two swallows on this day at Hawkley!!

title: The Elusive Mr. Rice
description: Ronald L. Rice (Keith Meyers/The NewYork Times)

title: Burger King Chief Steps Down on Eve of I.P.O.
description: As it prepares to go public for the first time in its 52-year history, Burger King has announced that its chairman and C.E.O. will step down and return to his private equity firm.

title: Saving a Church to Save the Town
description: In the isolated hamlet of Ruidosa, Tex., an effort to attract visitors and revive the town is hinged on its weather-beaten church.

title: What Would Judas Do?
description: Tobin Harshaw

title: Ferrovial Makes Formal BAA Bid (But It Doesnt Fly)
description: Ferrovial unveiled its latest proposal to acquire British airport operator BAA   but the price was no higher than the old one. The formal offer of 810 pence per share, or about 8.75 billion pounds ($15.4 billion), was essentially just a repeat of its previous non-binding offer of March 17, which BAA flatly rejected.

title: Roundup: Conspiracy Theories
description: This wont do anything to calm the conspiracy theories .

title: Da Vinci Code Author Cleared in Copyright Suit
description: All good thrillers must end eventually. And so a London judge found Friday that Dan Brown, author of the bestseller The Da Vinci Code, did not steal ideas from a nonfiction book.

title: Sealys Stock Offering Rises and Shines
description: Friday was a glorious morning for Sealy and its private equity owner, as the mattress makers initial public offering performed well on several fronts.

title: Pioneering Patent Auction Draws Sighs, Not Much Cash
description: Patents are generally sold via a loose network of brokers and lawyers who connect sellers with potential buyers. It often takes months to sell a patent.

title: It All Depends What You Mean by Tactical
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans Apr. 7 column, Condi and Rummy

title: Threats from Pakistan
description: The Daily Times of Pakistan has picked up my reporting on the threat from Brigadier Ijaz Shah to kill Dr. Amna Buttar and Mukhtar Mai on the streets of New York. Heres the latest article. Note that the Daily Times doesnt mention Ijaz Shahs name (though hints at it in Amnas quote), presumably to avoid offending him too much. But remember that Ijaz Shah is head of Pakistans Intelligence Bureau and a very close buddy of President Musharraf.

title: What To Make Of Libbys Testimony
description: Once upon a time an investigation into a shady Arkansas land deal led to the impeachment of a president on grounds that had little do with real estate. Today an investigation into the shady disclosure of a C.I.A. officers name has led to calls for impeachment of a president on grounds that have little to do with the identity leak. O.K., its obvious that Monica Lewinsky was far more tangential to Whitewater than Valerie Plame Wilson is to the news that the White House may have leaked classified material to discredit critics, including her husband, Ambassador Joseph Wilson.

title: Slide Show: Industry Insiders
Pedro Martnez's Opening Night
description: Highlights from the first game of the season that Pedro Martnez has pitched for the Mets.

title: Lucent-Alcatel Merger Gets Lost in Translation
description: It was a small detail, but one that speaks volumes about the cultural challenges ahead for Lucent Technologies and its French merger partner, Alcatel.

title: Director Pay Sees Double-Digit Gains, Again
description: Directors love to complain about the additional headaches and potential liabilities they are encountering in the post-Enron, post-Sarbanes-Oxley era. They can take some comfort, though, in their steadily increasing pay checks.

title: Oil Explorer Pioneer May Draw Suitor, Analyst Says
description: One analyst is seeing a potential takeover target in Pioneer Natural Resources, the independent oil-and-gas exploration company, BusinessWeeks Gene Marcial writes.

title: Grand Central Terminal
description: David Frank, deputy director of photography at The Times, talks about videotaping the restoration of Grand Central Terminal's facade. (Video: David Frank and Erik Olsen)

title: Nortel Chief Hints at Acquisitions Ahead
description: Nortel Networks may soon be in acquisition mode, the companys chief executive, Mike Zafiroski, said Thursday during a speech at a convention in Las Vegas.

title: Morgan Stanley Tends to Bruised Asset Management Arm
description: Other Wall Street firms have been selling their troublesome asset management businesses , but Morgan Stanley continues to hope for an in-house solution. Reuters on Friday reported that the firm has outlined its plans for the flagging division in a internal memo, which indicated that it still wants to acquire money management firms and hire teams of managers.

title: The Hate Resurfaces
description: Four years after Mayor Sharpe James falsely asserted on the Today show that Cory Booker was Jewish  and four years after Mr. Booker, an African-American Christian, was attacked with anonymous fliers portraying him with a hooked-nose  another round of anti-Semitic, race-baiting nastiness has begun.

title: Google Finance: Where Sealy Meets ZZ Top
description: Picky, picky, picky. Equity Private and DealBreaker.com are reporting that as of Friday afternoon, Google Finance remained oblivious to the existence of Sealys adorable new ticker symbol, ZZ. (But we noticed that a search on the symbol does turn up a company called High End Systems, which we are told made lighting systems for ZZ Top concerts.)

title: Exercise Evolution for Baby Boomers
description: Baby Boomers are the first generation that grew up exercising.  How are they faring as they hit middle age?

title: Pogues List, the Software Edition
description: From a reader:

title: Memories of Hamburg, Enough to Build a Dream On
description: HAMBURG, Germany

title: Found Footage, and a View Through the Eyes of a Mentor
description: In his career as a documentary filmmaker, Richard P. Rogers, director of the Film Study Center at Harvard, produced works on topics as varied as the Nicaraguan revolution and the poet Wallace Stevens. But Mr. Rogers's recurring fear of being self-indulgent kept him from finishing his long-planned autobiographical film, "Windmill."

title: Chief of U.N. Monitoring Agency to Conduct Nuclear Talks in Iran
description: PARIS, April 7  Mohamed ElBaradei, the director of the United Nations' nuclear monitoring agency in Vienna, will visit Iran next week to conduct talks on the country's nuclear program, his agency announced Friday.

title: Israeli Attack in Gaza Strip Kills 4 Militants and a Child
description: JERUSALEM, April 7  An Israeli airstrike Friday on a car carrying Palestinian militants in the southern Gaza Strip killed six people and wounded about a dozen, Palestinian security officials and medical workers said.

title: Julia Child's Memoir of When Cuisine Was French for Scary
Archdiocese Is Hamstrung in Reform, Report Says
description: BOSTON, April 7  Efforts to change the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston in the aftermath of the crisis of sexual abuse by clergymen have been hampered by diminished resources, according to a report issued Friday.

title: Asia, Europe, Africa and Americas
description: ASIA

title: U.S. and Europe Halt Aid to Palestinian Government

title: Arts, Briefly; Russia Joins Forces With Germany
description: Last year a large exhibition at the State Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow featuring antiquities that had been seized in Berlin by Soviet troops at the end of World War II caused sore feelings in Germany. But after an agreement yesterday between Russian and German museums promising cooperation on future exhibitions, the Pushkin will open an even bigger show in February, the Prussian Cultural Heritage Foundation announced. German war booty will again be on display -- with 900 pieces from ancient and medieval Germanic cultures -- but this time German specialists were invited to study the items, many unseen since the end of the war. The agreement, made in Berlin by the State Museums of Berlin, the Pushkin and the Hermitage, was praised by the Prussian foundation, a government-financed institution that runs the Berlin state museums, as "sensational" because the cooperation will offer new perspectives on the long-simmering debate between Russia and Germany about stolen art. After being shown at the Pushkin, the exhibition is to move to the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg. SARAH PLASS

And "CSI" (22.91 million) drew its lowest 18-to-49 rating for an original episode since October 2001 (not counting its broadcast opposite the "Friends" series finale two years ago). Fox, which has a solid schedule from Sunday through Wednesday, finished fourth for the night. Its once-dominant "O.C." delivered a mere 5.03 million viewers, who watched Summer and Seth break up for the umpteenth time; the series's audience was the lowest it has ever had for an original episode among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAGNER, SIMA
description: WAGNER--Sima. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Sima Wagner. For sixty-six years Sima was the devoted wife of Rubin Wagner, who survives her, the loving mother of Harry and Myra, Leon and Marsha and grandmother of Elliot, Lauren, Gabriel and Daniel. Born in Vilna, now Vilnius, Lithuania, daughter of Leah and Yisroel Benosher, Sima was the devoted older sister of Fania, Sharon and Merele of whom only Fania and Sharon survived the Holocaust. Young and in love Sima and Ruby eloped in February 1940 as the world erupted into war. Their daughter, Sheyna, born in 1941, was taken from Sima during a concentration camp selection. Separated during the war and imprisoned in numerous concentration camps Sima miraculously reunited with her husband after the war living in a displaced persons camp in Heidenheim, Germany between 1945 and 1949. They landed in New York with $8 to their name, lived in Brooklyn whereupon Sima became a member of the International Ladies Garment Worker's Union in order to help support her family. She reared her family in Jewish homes in Huntington, Roslyn and Aventura, Florida and always carried herself with elegance, dignity and discipline and was widely respected and loved in the community of survivors. Throughout her life Sima Wagner gave comfort and care to her sisters, niece, nephews, and cousins living a life devoted to family, friends, charity, Holocaust Remembrance and Am Yisrael Chai. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to: Ella Levine, YIVO Institute, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011 In memory of Sima Wagner or Dr. Amir Baron, Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center, 20400 North East 30th Avenue, Aventura, FL 33180 In memory of Sima Wagner. The Wagner Family

title: Arts, Briefly; Calling All Conceptual Artists
description: Sometime around noon on Wednesday, a wounded phone booth showed up in the Soho district of London. Knocked over, sawed in half and stuck back together at an odd angle, it had a pickax stuck in its side and dripped blood-red paint as if it were hunted game. Apparently a protest against the disappearance of the iconic British red phone booths, it was quickly removed by the authorities, but not before Banksy, the British art prankster known for placing his own works on the walls of major museums, took credit for it. In a rare public acknowledgment, he issued a statement through a spokeswoman: "GRAFFITI ARTIST VANDALISES PHONEBOX SHOCK. Banksy makes use of a pickaxe in soho square london." A spokesman for the Westminster Council, which regulates some of central London, said yesterday that "although it's a work of art, it is like anything else -- it has to be removed to keep the footpaths clear," and added that the piece had been taken to a storage depot, where it could be retrieved by the artist. BT, the telephone company, was amused. "This is a stunning visual comment on BT's transformation from an old-fashioned telecoms company into a modern communications services provider," the company said in a statement, adding that it might want a Banksy phone booth for the office. PAM KENT

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KROLL, DOUGLAS
description: KROLL--Douglas. July 7, 1967--April 8, 2002. There is not a moment when you are not overwhelmingly missed. Your love, compassion and spirit live on in everyone who was fortunate enough to know you. We'll love you forever. Mom

title: Israeli Attack in Gaza Strip Kills 4 Militants and a Child
description: JERUSALEM, April 7 - An Israeli airstrike Friday on a car carrying Palestinian militants in the southern Gaza Strip killed six people and wounded about a dozen, Palestinian security officials and medical workers said.

title: Who Paid $35.8 Million for J. M. W. Turner's View of Venice?
description: Despite tight lips on Christie's executives, the secret was out within hours after J. M. W. Turner's "Giudecca, La Donna Della Salute and San Giorgio" sold to a mystery telephone bidder on Thursday for $35.8 million.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Rudolf Vrba, who escaped from Auschwitz as a young man and later provided evidence both of the tragedy there and of the mechanics of Nazi mass slaughter, misstated his age in some copies. He was 81, not 82. (Go to Article)

title: In Swirling Winds, Woods Keeps Appointed Rounds
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 - Tiger Woods wore his cap a little higher than usual, like a man after an afternoon of raking the leaves in the garden. He had made it through Friday with a one-under-par 71, but Augusta National had made him work and think and work some more.

title: Spitzer Said to Try to Woo Golisano Away From Fight
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, a Democratic candidate for governor, met last week with a Republican nemesis, Thomas Golisano, in what Democrats described as a Spitzer attempt to woo Mr. Golisano after a disastrous meeting between the two men last summer.

title: Canada's Jobless Rate Falls to 32-Year Low
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell by 0.1 percentage point in March, reaching 6.3 percent, its lowest level in 32 years. Statistics Canada, a government agency, also reported yesterday that an additional 51,000 jobs created during the month brought Canada's employment rate, the percentage of the working-age population that has jobs, to a record 62.9 percent. The bulk of the new jobs were full time. Despite concerns that the high value of the Canadian dollar was harming manufacturers because of reduced exports, most of the new jobs came in Ontario, the most populous and industrial province. The agency said that the new jobs there were mostly in the construction and service industries. In the resource-rich province of Alberta, which is in the middle of an upswing because of high oil prices, hourly wages rose by 7 percent, the largest increase in the country. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Corzine Wants Poor Schools to Make Do With Less Aid
description: TRENTON, April 7 - Signaling a willingness to tackle one of the most contentious issues in New Jersey politics, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced Friday that he would ask the State Supreme Court to freeze financing for the poorest school districts because of budgetary constraints.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. and Europeans Cut Aid To Hamas-Led Government The United States and the European Union announced that they would halt payments to the Hamas-led Palestinian government but that some aid would flow to the Palestinian people through the United Nations and other independent organizations. PAGE A6

title: Diet Drug Moves Closer to Being Sold Over Counter
description: GlaxoSmithKline's plan to market an over-the-counter version of the prescription diet drug Xenical received an "approvable" letter from the Food and Drug Administration, the company said yesterday, meaning it can be marketed once the company addresses additional questions from regulators.

title: Daniels Plans to Drop Out of Governor's Race
description: The Republican race for governor of New York is set for a shake-up on Monday with one of the three candidates, Randy A. Daniels, planning to drop out and throw his conservative and upstate political coalition to a rival, John Faso, both men said today.

title: Chase Led Man Into Car's Path
description: A 20-year-old college student who was struck and killed by a car last week in Harlem was chased into a busy road while fleeing a group of young men during what may have been a bias attack, the authorities said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Merger of FPL and Constellation Threatened By Dispute in Maryland Over Utility Rates Executives of the FPL Group and the Constellation Energy Group said their planned merger could fail as a result of Constellation's regulatory problems in Maryland. In letters to shareholders, the chief executives of both companies said Constellation's dispute with Maryland legislators over a proposed rate increase poses serious implications for the deal. Later yesterday, however, Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. of Maryland was more optimistic about a possible settlement of the dispute, a spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Shareese DeLeaver, said the governor met with the Senate president and the speaker of the House of Delegates and made progress toward a resolution. FPL, which is based in Juno Beach, Fla., agreed to acquire Constellation, based in Baltimore, in December in a deal then valued at about $11 billion. (REUTERS)

description: Correction Appended

title: Drug Plan's Side Effect Is Severe
description: YEADON, Pa. - As a result of the new Medicare drug program, thousands of people who take pills to fight cancer have suddenly found themselves with new bills to pay for their essential medicines. Frances Blue is one of them.

title: Blame and Uncertainty as Immigration Deal Fails
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 - The Senate's effort to pass immigration legislation collapsed on Friday, and lawmakers went home for a two-week recess to face voters who are as deeply and passionately divided on the issue as Congress has proven to be.

title: Iraqis Mourn Victims of Mosque Bombing
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 7 - Three suicide bombers, including at least one who appeared to be a woman, exploded in a sea of Friday worshipers at the main mosque of the most powerful Shiite political party in Iraq, killing at least 71 people and wounding at least 140.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUBIN, SHIRLEY
description: GRUBIN -- Shirley. Beloved wife of Saul; mother of Neil, Jeffrey and Alan; mother-inlaw of Tobi, Melody and Sue; grandmother of Ronnie, Andrew, Jonathan, Gillian, Allison and Erica, and great grandmother of Danielle, Ryan and Jake. He is the Rev. Christian Scharen, not Sharen.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Europe Halt Aid to Palestinian Government
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 - The United States and the European Union announced Friday that they would halt payments to the Hamas-led Palestinian government but that aid would flow to Palestinians through the United Nations and other independent organizations.

title: Setback for 2 Rules on Mutual Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 - A federal appeals court threatened Friday to strike down two important regulatory changes in the mutual fund industry that the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved after a series of industry scandals shook investors and several of the largest funds.

title: 'MacRune's Guevara' at St. Clement's: Revolution and Blather
description: It's hard to imagine a world where pretentious art criticism and revolutionary guerrilla movements intersect, but the playwright John Spurling created one more than 35 years ago, and Young Mirror, the youthful arm of the Mirror Repertory Company, is resurrecting it in a funny though frustrating production at the Theater at St. Clement's.

title: In Drug-Aid Foundations, a Web of Corporate Interests
description: The mission of the HealthWell Foundation sounds unassailable. Founded two years ago, HealthWell offers financial assistance to patients who need help paying for medical care to treat cancer, rheumatoid arthritis and other diseases.

title: Divine Right of Bushes
description: WASHINGTON - So the aide turns out to have been loyally following his leader's dictates, rather than going around the boss's back to peddle secret information.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the implications of the discovery of an early Christian manuscript that portrays Judas Iscariot in an unconventional light misidentified the material of which the manuscript was made. It is papyrus, not parchment.

title: For President, First a Leak; Now, a Jam
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 - That President Bush authorized an aide to disclose classified intelligence on Iraqi weapons, as asserted in court papers, comes as no shock to official Washington. The leaking of secrets has long been a favored tool of policy debate, political combat and diplomatic one-upmanship.

title: Mayweather Tries to Win Fourth Title
description: LAS VEGAS, April 7 - Floyd Mayweather Jr. often works out at 2 a.m., believing that it gives him a psychological edge to train while his opponent is probably sleeping. He has been known to leave dinner or a movie, abandon friends and family in a parking lot and jog several miles in street clothes to his home here.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend yesterday about paintings by Jeff Elrod at the Fredericks & Freiser gallery in Chelsea included an outdated closing schedule. The exhibition has been extended to April 22; it does not close today.

title: Hyundai Chief Arrives Home to Face Inquiry
description: INCHEON, South Korea, Saturday, April 8 - The chairman of the Hyundai Motor Company, Chung Mong Koo, returned Saturday from a six-day business trip to the United States, after prosecutors repeatedly called for his return to answer questions in an investigation into accusations of bribes for government favors.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: No Big Breakthroughs In Oil Talks
description: Senior officials from the World Bank and Chad held talks this week in Ndjamena, the capital, to resolve an impasse over the nation's oil profits that has dragged on for months. In January the bank's president, Paul D. Wolfowitz, suspended all loans to the country after Chad weakened a law dedicating most of the revenues from a $4.2 billion oil pipeline to reducing poverty. "We're inching forward," said Tim Carrington, a bank spokesman. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

title: A Ground Zero Summit
description: The governors of New York and New Jersey and the mayor of New York City finally sat down face to face on Wednesday to talk about the problems at the World Trade Center site. It was the kind of meeting that should have been happening regularly over the last three and a half years, especially as progress at ground zero has wobbled to a standstill.

title: E-Mail Message Sent in Error Turns Campaign Psst to Oops
description: The mistakenly sent e-mail message is the trapdoor of the Internet age, alerting co-workers or friends to private thoughts and, sometimes, behind-the-scenes plotting.

title: A Murder Victim's Daughter Disputes Sebastian Junger Book
description: In a new book, "A Death in Belmont," Sebastian Junger, author of the best seller "The Perfect Storm," turns his attention to a brutal strangling that took place in his hometown, Belmont, Mass., in 1963. In it he asks whether the man convicted of the crime, a laborer named Roy Smith, was, in fact, innocent, and whether Albert DeSalvo, the man who confessed to being the Boston Strangler, could have committed the crime instead.

title: Worker Is Killed in a Fall
description: A 60-year-old construction worker was killed yesterday when he fell from scaffolding attached to a Queens building and landed on the roof of a parking garage six stories below, the police said.

title: Another Picasso Sold by Costco Is Called Inauthentic
description: Maya Widmaier-Picasso, a daughter of Picasso who authenticates works attributed to him, said this week that a drawing of a faun bought in 2004 by a San Francisco doctor through Costco, the warehouse-club wholesaler, was not made by her father, and that a certificate accompanying it had been forged.

title: Gonzalez's Approach Is Change for Seton Hall
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 7 - As he took rapid-fire swigs from a water bottle while waiting to be introduced as the new basketball coach at Seton Hall, Bobby Gonzalez scanned Walsh Gym with darting eyes. That is apparently why he got the job.

title: Kerry Sharply Criticizes Bush on Several Fronts
description: Senator John Kerry made a slashing attack on the Bush administration yesterday, comparing it to the faltering government in Iraq and equating its war strategy with its planning for Hurricane Katrina, while also invoking Jesus as he criticized federal Medicaid policy.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of House & Home on Thursday about a sale at Kilim, a carpet store in SoHo, misstated the telephone number. It is (917) 287-7956.

title: ngels in America
description: CHICAGO - ngel Espinoza doesn't understand why Republicans on Capitol Hill are determined to deport Mexicans like him. I don't get it, either. He makes me think of my Irish grandfather.

title: A California Billionaire Who Avoided the Spotlight Suddenly Finds Himself in It
description: Ronald W. Burkle, one of California's richest men, has quietly amassed billions of dollars over the years, along with a collection of houses -- including the silent film star Harold Lloyd's former Beverly Hills estate -- and a prized art collection. He has also gathered a flock of powerful friends from Hollywood, Wall Street and Washington that numbers former President Bill Clinton in its ranks.

title: Consortium Bids for British Airport Concern
description: A consortium led by a Spanish builder, Grupo Ferrovial, made a formal 8.75 billion ($15.3 billion) bid for the British airport company BAA yesterday, three weeks after BAA's management rejected a similar proposal. BAA, which runs Heathrow Airport in London, turned down an informal bid on March 17, saying it undervalued the company. By making a formal offer, Grupo Ferrovial will have access to BAA's books, which BAA would not allow earlier. Grupo Ferrovial was joined by a Canadian fund manager, Caisse de Dpt et Placement du Qubec, and GIC Special Investments of Singapore, in the consortium making the bid. Heather Timmons (NYT) BUSINESS BRIEFS

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Car Rams Protesters
description: A car drove into students demonstrating in Paris against a new labor law, injuring 12, the police said. They said the driver seemed to hit the students on purpose, knocking down several people and dragging one. Students also protested in other cities, and the majority leader of the governing party in the National Assembly, Bernard Accoyer, said the government was working to rewrite the law. KATRIN BENNHOLD (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHBART, JOSEPH
description: ROTHBART--Joseph, whose life spanned close to a century died peacefully on April 6, 2006 at the age of 98. He leaves behind a family who loved him deeply and a legacy of friendship. For 35 years he was a Physical Education Teacher at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, NY and for 25 years an Owner/Director of Camp Oxford and Guilford in Guilford, NY. He retired in Hallandale, FL and was the devoted husband to the late Betty Rothbart. He was a loving father to Michael J. Rothbart, and cherished grandfather to Heather Rothbart. He was a beloved brother to Ida, and the late Sol and Murry Rodbart. He was a loving father-in-law to Marilyn Goldberg and beloved companion to Sally Levitt and to his caretaker Steven Grobstein.

title: Blake Falls, but Roddick Wins to Pull U.S. Even
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., April 7 - James Blake will have to wait until another day to collect the first victory of his career in a five-set match.

title: Rat Poison Cited in Coyote's Death
description: Hal, the year-old coyote who died in custody after leading the authorities on a gripping chase through Central Park last month, was seriously ill from a heartworm infestation and internal hemorrhaging caused by rat poison, according to the results of a necropsy released yesterday by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Court Approves Delphi Early-Retirement Plan
description: The Delphi Corporation, the auto parts company, received bankruptcy court approval yesterday to offer early retirement incentives to 13,000 employees as part of a plan to cut labor costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MIRKIN, JULIAN
description: MIRKIN--Julian, 77, April 5, 2006 from Myositis. Grew up in Brooklyn, Korean War vet, Master Mason of the Victoria Seagate Masonic Lodge in Brooklyn. Survived by his wife of 52 years, Florence; daughters, Cheryl (Alan) Fink, Marcy (Adam Schutz); 3 granddaughters, Jana, Deena and Leah; and sister, Myra Raykoff. title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: New Attacks Threaten Peace Accord
description: Unidentified gunmen killed a pro-rebel Tamil leader and suspected rebels shot dead two security officials, police and military officials said. The violence came despite cease-fire talks in February that resuscitated a frayed accord. Another round of talks is scheduled this month. SHIMALI SENANAYAKE (NYT)

title: J.P. Morgan and Bank of New York to Swap Units
description: J.P. Morgan Chase, New YorkAs biggest lender, said it had agreed to swap its corporate-trust unit for the Bank of New YorkAs consumer and small-business banking unit in a transaction valued at about $3.1 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, THE REV. CANON FREDERICK B.
description: WILLIAMS--The Rev. Canon Frederick B., Rector Emeritus of the Church of the Intercession in New York City, died suddenly at his home on April 4. At the time of his death, Canon Williams was a Trustee of the Rockefeller Foundation and Chairman of the Board of Harlem Churches for Community Improvement; he was also a leader of Shared Interest, A Balm In Gilead and PeaceJam. There will be a Vigil for Canon Williams at the Church of the Intercession from 4 to 8 PM on Sunday, April 9; the Bishop of New York will celebrate a Mass of the Resurrection on Monday, April 10, at The Church of the Intercession, 550 West 155th Street (at Broadway) at 11AM. Donations may be made to The Church of The Intercession.

title: Bush's Interior Nominee: Comfort in Consensus
description: EAGLE, Idaho, April 6 - Eagle Island State Park here has horse-riding trails, picnic tables and a water slide. Under a recent compromise between the Idaho Legislature and Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, President Bush's nominee to oversee the nation's public lands as secretary of the interior, the park may one day get its own gravel mine, too.

title: UBS Will Pay $85 Million to Resolve Copper Suit
description: UBS, the Swiss-based bank, agreed yesterday to pay the Sumitomo Corporation 10 billion yen ($85 million) to settle a lawsuit related to losses a decade ago by a rogue Sumitomo copper trader who became known as Mr. Copper.

title: Sealy Rises 9.4% in First Day of Trading
description: Shares in the Sealy Corporation, the mattress maker, climbed yesterday in their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Sex, drunkenness, treachery, murder. Not bad for a nature program about a fig tree.

description: As lawmakers have increasingly slipped pet projects into federal spending bills over the past decade, one lawmaker has used his powerful perch on the House Appropriations Committee to funnel $250 million into five nonprofit organizations that he set up.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Election Rules Are Eased
description: The Federal Election Commission relaxed rules that restrict coordination between outside groups or political parties and candidates for the House and the Senate. Citing analyses that showed that most campaign advertisements for House and Senate races fell within two months of an election, the panel decided that certain advertisements by outside groups would be considered in-kind candidate donations only if they appeared within 90 days of a primary or election, rather than within the 120-day limit it had set. That limit remains in place for presidential campaigns, said George Smaragdis, a commission spokesman. KATE PHILLIPS (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Transactions column in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday reversed the roles of the brokers involved in the recent lease of 131 Greene Street, in Manhattan. Christopher Owles of the Sinvin Realty Corporation represented the tenant; Cynthia Chapin, an independent broker, and Jon Chodosh and Sarah Cassell of Chodosh Realty Services represented the landlord.

title: Aguirre-Sacasa: Playwright's Path Is via Comic Books
description: At the New York Comic-Con in February, Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa was treated to an object lesson in fame and anonymity. This 33-year-old comic-book writer went to the Comic-Con, a frenetic three-day orgy of comic books, video games and an appearance by the actress Milla Jovovich, to autograph his recent books for Marvel. But Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa, a relative newcomer, found himself seated next to Brian Michael Bendis, the prolific superstar behind "Daredevil" and the "New Avengers."

title: Corrections

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Spying Investigation Approved
description: Germany's three opposition parties voted to conduct a formal parliamentary investigation into the role the German intelligence service has played in the Iraq war. The inquiry will focus on whether German agents helped the American military during its invasion, whether the government had information regarding clandestine C.I.A. flights over Germany and whether Germany took part in the C.I.A. abduction of Khaled el-Masri, a German citizen who says he was taken to an American prison in Afghanistan and tortured. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

title: In 'Avenger,' Sam Elliott Stars as a Gun for Hire
description: For a long time Sam Elliott has seemed like one of those actors who can do no wrong. Even when he found himself in less than masterpiece-quality films or television projects, Mr. Elliott, when he appeared, lent them some dignity by his presence -- strong, quiet, proudly craggy, noble, unflappable and possibly immortal.

title: One Catholic School's Fervent Plea to Stay Open
description: Mary George, the principal of Our Lady of Sorrows School, woke up early Thursday morning after a restless night in the guest bedroom of the friary next to her school.

title: Now in the Rearview Mirror: Low Gasoline Prices
description: This weekend, Maria Bland says she will be driving around in a pristine Ford F-150 truck, picking up her dryer and dishwasher from the repair store and enjoying a smooth ride in Miami's sunny weather.

title: Idea for 'Da Vinci Code' Was Not Stolen, Judge Says
description: LONDON, April 7 - A High Court judge ruled on Friday that Dan Brown did not steal the idea for his stratospherically successful thriller, "The Da Vinci Code," from an earlier book, and he cleared Mr. Brown's publisher, Random House, of accusations of copyright infringement.

title: Frederick B. Williams, 66, Bold Moral Voice in Harlem, Dies
description: Canon Frederick B. Williams, whose ministry of a historic Episcopal church extended to the pressing needs of its Harlem neighborhood, and who spoke eloquently to national and international issues, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: New York Philharmonic Highlights Soloists at Avery Fisher Hall
description: A couple of years ago, the New York Philharmonic introduced a June series of what might be called "B" fare, "Summertime Classics," led by Bramwell Tovey, a British conductor able to intersperse his performances with humorous patter in a fond, avuncular mode. Mr. Tovey has now made it onto the orchestra's regular season calendar, bringing with him a certain number of admirers and a sense of the "B" level. On Thursday night he conducted a staid, unobjectionable program that showed the orchestra at its most average.

title: A Museum Clad in Billboards? The Critics Are Not Pleased
description: When the Museum of Arts and Design bought 2 Columbus Circle last year, its director, Holly Hotchner, defended the decision to reconstruct it, saying, "I think nearly everyone would agree 2 Columbus Circle is a tremendous eyesore."

title: Wu Man, a Pipa Player in Search of the Common Chord
description: Just because Wu Man plays the pipa, an ancient Chinese lute, there was no reason to suppose that her program on Thursday evening at Zankel Hall would focus on traditional Chinese music. The concert was, after all, part of the Kronos Quartet's "Live Mix" series, and when Kronos is involved, anything goes -- especially anything that involves demolishing musical boundaries or practicing stylistic alchemy. And Ms. Wu has been known to mix things up on her own.

title: Memories of Hamburg, Enough to Build a Dream On
description: HAMBURG, Germany - IT is close to half a century since Horst Fascher was the flyweight boxing champion of Germany, a gold medal prospect in the 1960 Rome Olympics and a young man who knew his way around this wealthy, rough-and-ready port city.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 11:30 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE -- Antonio Banderas (left), whose new ballroom-dancing-meets-hiphop movie, "Take the Lead," opened yesterday, is the host. Mary J. Blige is the musical guest. And this is the 600th live broadcast of "S.N.L.," which began on Oct. 11, 1975, with George Carlin, then a youthful 39, as host.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINTER, MARTIN
description: WINTER--Martin. April 6, 2006. Beloved husband of the late Jessica Winter. Devoted brother of the late Dr. Eugene Winter. Loving uncle of Randy Winter, Dr. Lee Winter, Dr. Margarita CamachoWinter, Marvin and Diane Bernstein, Philip and Beverly Sklover, William and Sharon Friedheim, Jennifer Kouvant and David Kouvant. His love of life and sense of humor will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. For funeral information please call Frank E. Campbell at 212288-3500.

title: Give Rebuilding Lower Priority in Future Wars
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 - As factions in the Bush administration continue their bitter infighting over the reconstruction program in Iraq, the State Department has produced a draft planning document saying that after any future conflicts, the United States should not immediately begin a major rebuilding program.

title: Joe Chambers Leads a Quartet at Iridium
description: Joe Chambers is best known within jazz circles for his drumming, a quietly commanding force in hard bop for more than 40 years. He is also held in high esteem for his compositions, which often weigh harmonic intricacies against the subtleties of groove. Recently he has placed emphasis on a third aspect of his artistry, mallet percussion: he plays vibraphone and marimba throughout "The Outlaw" (Savant), his latest album. There's a good chance he'll earn respect in that endeavor, too.

title: Of champs and chumps
description: The unfortunately-named Champ Car series  always makes me think of chump or chimp  begins its first race this weekend, and for the moment, Sebastien Bourdais is picking up where he left off. The Frenchman who became rookie of the year three years ago, then champion for the last two seasons has taken the first available point by turning the fastest lap of Friday qualifying. So while Formula One continues to keep its eyes focused on Schumachers future, the sport continues to ignore a driver I have always believed had most of the qualities that made Schumacher the complete driver: natural talent, massive drive, a much higher level of intelligence than the average driver and a superb ability to give engineers the technical feedback they need to improve the car.

description: Lymphatic filariasis, which causes lymph nodes to swell painfully, is not curable, but health experts hope to eliminate the disease within a generation.

description: Incumbent Councilwoman Gayle Chaneyfield Jenkins has a theory:

description: Many employers and legal and illegal workers said the Senate's failed immigration plan would have been an improvement.

title: That 15% Fee
description: Once they have found someone an apartment, rental brokers in Manhattan typically charge a standard fee: 15 percent of a years rent.

Selborne Journal: Thursday, 8 April 1784: 29 7/10 1/4; 41; N. Grey, sun & pleasant, red even. Men open the hills, & cut their hops. Many lettuces, both Coss, & Dutch, have stood-out the winter under the fruit-wall. They were covered with straw in the hard weather, for many weeks.

title: A Disease's Hidden Agony
description: Times reporter Donald G. McNeil Jr. discusses the eradication efforts for lymphatic filariasis. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

description: Today, I will venture to give you some description of my temporary home in the deserts of western Iraq  the weather, the surrounding area, and the general feel of living in Ramadi, where I have been stationed for the past 9 months.

title: On a High Andean Lake, an Island of the Incas
description: THE bantam motor coughs, and our boat creeps through green water. A couple of men sporting the floppy wool stocking cap called a chuyo are perched in the rear chewing coca. Women cooing in Quechua tent little ones beneath long black shawls, and we crane our necks to peek inside their secret world.

title: Classic Beat
description: A "HOWL" photograph, taken at the Virginia Military Institute in 1991 by Gordon Ball: a row of uniformed cadets, their heads shaved, each with an identical blank notebook, each holding a copy of the City Lights Books Pocket Poets Series edition of Allen Ginsberg's "Howl and Other Poems," published in San Francisco in 1956, subject to an obscenity trial soon after, cleared by Judge Clayton Horn in a ringing affirmation of individual liberty and creative expression  and a flag of revolt, a blow against conformity, a hallowed relic, ever since.

title: An Iowa Town's Story Told in Portraits 21 Years Apart
description: OXFORD, Iowa  Ben Stoker was only a few weeks old when Peter Feldstein took his picture in 1984, so tiny that his father held him aloft, head cradled in one palm. In another portrait by Mr. Feldstein, taken last year, Ben stands at more than six feet tall, a lanky man in long, baggy shorts, a T-shirt and a backward baseball cap.
