title: As France Burned
description: THIS stunning book contains two narratives, one fictional and the other a fragmentary, factual account of how the fiction came into being. "Suite Franaise" itself consists of two novellas portraying life in France from June 4, 1940, as German forces prepare to invade Paris, through July 1, 1941, when some of Hitler's occupying troops leave France to join the assault on the Soviet Union. At the end of the volume, a series of appendices and a biographical sketch provide, among other things, information about the author of the novellas. Born in Ukraine, Irne Nmirovsky had lived in France since 1919 and had established herself in her adopted country's literary community, publishing nine novels and a biography of Chekhov. She composed "Suite Franaise" in the village of Issy-l'Evque, where she, her husband and two young daughters had settled after fleeing Paris. On July 13, 1942, French policemen, enforcing the German race laws, arrested Nmirovsky as "a stateless person of Jewish descent." She was transported to Auschwitz, where she died in the infirmary on Aug. 17.

title: TBR: Inside the List
description: BETA MALES: It's been nearly 30 years since the publication of Bruce Jay Friedman's sad-sack classic, "The Lonely Guy's Book of Life," a copy of which, in a better world, would be given to every male college graduate, or at least the ones who cringed at the idea of playing varsity sports. In Christopher Moore's new novel, "A Dirty Job" (Morrow), the hero -- if that's the right word -- is a variant of the lonely guy: the Beta Male. The term isn't new: in The Times's Sunday Styles section a few years ago, Rick Marin wrote a column with that title. But in Moore's novel, his taxonomy of the breed includes this observation: "Many Beta Males, contrary to any empirical evidence, actually believe that they are Alpha Males, and have been endowed by their creator with advanced stealth charisma, which, although awesome in concept, is totally undetectable by women." Moore's novel, his ninth, is his first to hit the Times list -- it makes its debut this week at No. 9. The book is about a guy named Charlie who becomes, more or less by accident, Death's assistant. (Death here is "a very tall black man dressed in mint green.") Moore's cheerfully goofball prose has led critics to compare him with Tom Robbins, and these comparisons aren't wildly off base. But there was a time in Robbins's career, when he was hang-gliding over the late-hippie zeitgeist, that it seemed as if he might mature into a major writer. (Remember when Thomas Pynchon gave him a blurb? "Robbins has a grasp on things that dazzles the brain and he's also a world-class storyteller.") Reading a Moore novel, you don't feel impending genius. But he's O.K. with that. As he put it in an interview on his Web site: "People, even really stupid people, are very complex. If you try to make a character as complex as a real person then that's all your book will be about. They call that literary fiction. Hardly anything gets blowed up in literary fiction, so I don't write it."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEFTER, HARRY
description: SHEFTER--Harry. Born July 16, 1910, and passed on April 7th, of natural causes at age 95. Professor Harry Shefter had numerous accomplishments throughout his life. He was an English teacher and basketball coach at Gompers High School early in his career. He went on to become the Dean of Boys and the Assistant Principal of William Howard Taft High School. Mr. Shefter was a Professor of English at New York University and was one of the first English teachers to be on Public Television. He authored several best selling grammar and educational books that many schools used as supplements to their textbooks. He edited and compiled the Readers Enrichment series of famous stories that was widely used throughout the country. Harry Shefter was the loving husband of the late Dr. Evelyn Shefter. He was the beloved father of Barbara Ginsberg and Sharon Briskman. Adored grandfather of Dr. Randi Brown, Bonni Ginsberg Robinson, Lauren Bilotti and James Rapp. Devoted and adored great-grandfather of Jordan, Samantha, Daniella, Kevin, Jack, Samuel and Jacob. He will be forever in our hearts and profoundly missed by all who knew and loved him. Graveside funeral services will be held at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla on Monday. For information contact Zion Memorial Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIAMBELLI, FRANCESCO ''FRANK''
description: GIAMBELLI -- Francesco "Frank". Famed restauranteur, owner and founder of Giambelli 50th Ristaronte, died peacefully at his home on April 7th at the age of 90. Loving and devoted husband of more than 50 years to Mary Giambelli. Born in 1915 in Voghera, outside Milan, Italy. Francesco worked in some of the most renowned restaurants in Europe before coming to the US in 1954 to open Giambelli's Ristorante, originally located on Madison Avenue and 37th Street in Manhattan. Giambelli's 50th Ristorante opened at its present location on 50th and Madison Avenue in 1960 and has boasted many distinguished personalities, including presidents of the United States, kings, queens and other royalty, media celebrities, politicians and business executives. His proudest moment came in October, 1995, during Pope John Paul II's historic trip to New York, when he and his wife had the honor to serve the Holy Father and fifty Cardinals who were his guests at the Cardinal's residence in New York City. Francesco has been honored by his peers in the restaurant industry, including the Association of Italian Restauranteurs of New York and the Culinary Institute of America, and is the recipient of many honors as Commandatore of the Italian Republic by the President of Italy, the 2003 Angelus Awardee for St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, as well as being active as a member of the Columbus Citizen Foundation, Legion of Merit, rank of Commandatore. He has generously contributed to the Archdioces of New York, St. Patrick's Cathedral, St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, Boys Town of Italy, Culinary Institute of America, Columbus Citizens Scholarship Fund, St. Virgilius School in Broad Channel, NY, and the Jewish Communal Fund. The family will receive friends on Sunday and Monday 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday April 11th at 10 AM St. Patricks Cathedral, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital, Manhattan, SVCMC Foundation, 130 West 12th Street, 1-G, New York, NY 10011.

title: Children's Books
description: Though untrained as an artist, Esther Nisenthal Krinitz (1927-2001) spent the last 25 years of her life recording her Polish childhood using an unusual medium: embroidery and fabric collage. The result is Memories of Survival, by Krinitz and her daughter Bernice Steinhardt (Hyperion, $15.99; ages 5 to 9), which depicts life before Nazi soldiers came in 1939 and began taking villagers away, including Krinitz's parents and all but one of her siblings. The effect is eerie, as precise renderings of orchards, geese and children's games give way to images of soldiers and barbed wire in gunmetal gray.

title: Is There Life After 'American Idol'?
description: LEVITTOWN, N.Y. - KEVIN COVAIS, known to millions of television viewers as Chicken Little, was anxiously pacing a high school office here, wringing his hands in anticipation. In the preceding week he was voted out of "American Idol," traded barbs with the judge Simon Cowell, bantered with Regis Philbin on "Live With Regis and Kelly," joked with Jimmy Kimmel on his late-night show and belted out his signature song, a warbling rendition of the pop standard "When I Fall in Love," on "Today." Now Mr. Covais, a geeky 16-year-old junior at Island Trees High School was about to face a hometown crowd of classmates and friends he hadn't seen in nearly three months of competition on "American Idol," and he was trying to play it cool. With banners, balloons and handmade signs, hundreds of his schoolmates, along with relatives, friends and national television cameras were gathered in the school's gym for a welcome-back celebration.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE END OF POVERTY: Economic Possibilities for Our Time, by Jeffrey D. Sachs. (Penguin, $16.) Sachs makes a bold declaration: If wealthy countries increased their combined foreign aid budgets to between $135 billion and $195 billion for the next decade, that money could eliminate extreme global poverty by 2025. Too many countries, he argues, are caught in a "poverty trap," a combination of poor geography, poor infrastructure and poor health care. Sachs, the director of the Earth Institute at Columbia University and a special adviser on global poverty to the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, also recounts his experiences as an adviser to distressed and developing nations, including Bolivia, Poland and Russia.

As a matter of cultural history, it's the dog that didn't bark, or, anyway, the dog that didn't yearn for more kibble than its littermates.

title: COMINGS & GOINGS
description: At the Hotel Ostfriesland (www.hotel-ostfriesland.de), a family-run hotel in Norden, Germany, near the North Sea, guests are charged by weight -- theirs. They pay a half a euro per kilogram (2.2 pounds) at check-in but no more than 39 euros (about $48, at $1.23 to the euro) for a single room and 74 euros ($91) for a double. Guests can take off their shoes to save weight and money. The promotion, which runs through the end of the month, is designed to reward fit guests, the owner, Jrgen Heckrodt, said in an e-mail message. Besides, he wrote: "Healthy guests do live longer. Which means: They can check in at Hotel Ostfriesland more often -- which also is not bad for us." On Monday, Lufthansa is starting a Web site aimed at the United States student travel market. The site, GenerationFly.com, will offer destination information, travel tips and low student fares. But only travelers with valid school e-mail addresses ending in .edu can access the site. Fliers will need to show a valid student ID at check-in. Mickey Mouse is heading to the Mediterranean. Next year, Disney Cruise Line will sail in Europe for the first time. The company plans to reposition the Disney Magic for the summer of 2007 to Barcelona, Spain, and offer alternating 10- and 11-night Mediterranean cruise vacations. Rates start at $2,399 based on double occupancy. Given the choice, travelers would be willing to pay extra for amenities that would make their flight more comfortable or convenient, according to a recent survey from Amadeus, a travel technology provider. About 40 percent would be willing to pay more for in-flight entertainment choices, 31 percent would pay for guaranteed overhead luggage storage and 25 percent would pay more for priority baggage handling.

title: Jagr Scores To Set Record And Sets Up Winning Goal

title: Up Front
description: IN this week's issue, the writer and cultural critic Greil Marcus -- his books include "Mystery Train" and "Lipstick Traces" -- reviews a new collection of essays devoted to Allen Ginsberg's "Howl." Marcus recalls meeting Ginsberg at Chez Panisse in Berkeley in 1996, one year before the poet's death. "He spent a great deal of time," Marcus said by e-mail, "working on a drawing and dedication in a copy of his 'Selected Poems.' He was putting in date and place and couldn't remember how many e's there were in 'Berkeley.' For the moment, no doubt because I was so happy to meet him, I couldn't either. It came out 'Berkely.' Most of the evening was devoted to Ginsberg pounding on me, in the most gentle, friendly, relentless way, for having once called Jack Kerouac a phony (for his unbearable recording of 'October in the Railroad Earth')."

title: C.E.O. Pay Keeps Rising, And Bigger Rises Faster

title: 'A Dirty Job'

Blessed with the Beta Male imagination, he spent much of his life squinting into the future so he might spot ways in which the world was conspiring to kill him - him; his wife, Rachel; and now, newborn Sophie. But despite his attention, his paranoia, his ceaseless fretting from the moment Rachel peed a blue stripe on the pregnancy stick to the time they wheeled her into recovery at St. Francis Memorial, Death slipped in.

title: Like a Bordeaux, via Local Vines

Their 2005 First Fruit, a bright blend of sauvignon blanc and smillon, resembles a Bordeaux blanc. Dry and crisp, it has the refreshing flavors of a citrus mlange.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: GIRLBOMB: A Halfway Homeless Memoir. By Janice Erlbaum. (Villard, $21.95.) As Erlbaum learns, problems don't go away -- even when you do. A furniture-breaking, leering stepfather drove 15-year-old Erlbaum out of her home and into a Hell's Kitchen shelter. There, she writes, she was called "white bitch" and singled out for more abuse. One occupant, Sherri, heavily pregnant and furious ("When the nuns weren't looking, she'd take a flying leap at the arm of the sofa or smash her belly into the stair banister"), charged her with a small knife. Erlbaum, now a columnist for Bust magazine, describes the failures of a system designed to help young people: shelter residents were one missed curfew away from being thrown on the streets -- where, she discovered, you might end up, as one girl did, "hanging around the men's bathroom at the Port Authority with some pit-faced guy in zebra-striped weight lifter's pants." At a group home on the Upper West Side, she was threatened with "Treatment," which sometimes involved wearing a sign (for example, one that said baby) around your neck. School "functioned mostly as a clearinghouse for drumming up drugs, sex or shelter." At one point she worried, needlessly, that people thought she was "a Goody Two-Shoes." "Not at all," a friend assured her. "Maybe, like, a Slutty Two-Shoes." Erlbaum was hard to help. And everywhere she went, adults failed her: counselors seemed psychotic; teachers were indifferent; her mom floundered. How satisfying to watch Erlbaum survive adolescence and produce a smart, engaging book -- "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Pothead," you might say -- that indicts those who wronged her yet never dissolves into tears or tantrums. Eventually, she did what many adults never manage: she grew up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RULE, DR. COLTER
description: RULE--Dr. Colter, a prominent New York psychiatrist and the author of "Uncovering The Sources of Love and Hate: A Theory of Human Behavior", died Tuesday afer a short illness at his home on Park Avenue according to his wife, Dr. Elizabeth Goessel. He was 94 and was stricken with polio before the age of 2. A graduate of Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and a research fellow at the Rockefeller Institute (now Rockefeller University) he was active in research for the government during WWII. An authority in improving the function of pilots at high altitudes he suffered a lung injury during a hazardous experiment requiring a year's hospitalization to recover. He was hailed widely by the media as a civilian war hero. Dr. Rule was also the author of "Limping Through the Twentieth Century" and co-author with Cartoonist Irwin Hasen of "Herstory of the World". He is survived by his wife, Dr. Elizabeth A. Goessel; three children, Marguerite Giordano, Jeanette Rule, Colter Rule III; four grandchildren, Katherine and Rule Johnstone, Phoebe Rule and Colter Rule IV; three sisters, Marguerite Wickemeyer, Alis Robinson and Jeannette Hodgson. The show has a relaxed, at-home atmosphere, with living room lamps made from Tang sculptures, and rugs that once covered Rockefeller floors hung on the walls. It also has some great stand-alone art.

And that's not just Mozart -- he has a jazz group, he performs with dancers, and he's an active composer for the concert stage and film. Still, the classics remain a cornerstone of his solo repertory. Long lauded for his Mozart, he recently released a CD of Beethoven, but he moves farther into the past for his Metropolitan Museum of Art recital on Friday: the program, part of the museum's "Piano Forte" series, focuses on Bach, including some more recent transcriptions (one is by Mr. Say himself), and concludes with Brahms (Intermezzi, Op. 117). 8 p.m., Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, (212) 570-3949; $40.

title: The Modern Hunter-Gatherer
description: I found myself sucked into Michael Pollan's article (March 26) over a breakfast of bread, eggs and meatless sausage that I had not kneaded, collected or killed, in contrast to the meal Pollan so painstakingly prepared. Although I have been a vegetarian (more or less) for some 10 years, I have been grappling with the issues raised by his article ever since interning a couple of summers back at a local organic farm. The farm experience was a cold slap in the face to my urban fantasies of a karmically clean vegetarian diet. Farmers use animal manure, blood meal and crushed bone to fertilize the fields that produce the "vegetarian" plants. The truth is that it is difficult and impractical to grow organic produce without relying on the slaughterhouse.

Pinned on the walls of his office in Seoul, among the movie posters and postcards, are photographs of his wife and 12-year-old daughter. His wife, whom he met at a university film club in the 1980's, reads all his scripts and is his most trusted adviser. Their daughter has seen most of his films. title: Brookland
description: At the close of the workday on Thursday the twenty-fourth of January, 1822, Prue Winship sat down at the large desk in the countinghouse of Winship Daughters Gin to write a letter to her daughter, Recompense. The power train had been sprung free of the windmill for the night, and the machines of the distillery sat quiet, the embers of its great fires still smoldering. Prue could hear the low horn of the steam ferry as it approached the Brooklyn landing. Her sister, Tem, with whom she ran the distillery, had retired an hour since to the Liberty Tavern, and had said she'd be home for supper; their overseer, Isaiah Horsfield, had gone home to his family. He'd left a stack of papers on his section of the desk, and would no doubt see to them first thing in the morning.

title: Pro-Life Nation
description: It was a sunny midafternoon in a shiny new global-economy mall in San Salvador, the capital city of El Salvador, and a young woman I was hoping to meet appeared to be getting cold feet. She had agreed to rendezvous with a go-between not far from the Payless shoe store and then come to a nearby hotel to talk to me. She was an hour late. Alone in the hotel lobby, I was feeling nervous; I was stood up the day before by another woman in a similar situation. I had been warned that interviewing anyone who had had an abortion in El Salvador would be difficult. The problem was not simply that in this very Catholic country a shy 24-year-old unmarried woman might feel shame telling her story to an older man. There was also the criminal stigma. And this was why I had come to El Salvador: Abortion is a serious felony here for everyone involved, including the woman who has the abortion. Some young women are now serving prison sentences, a few as long as 30 years.

title: Suite Franaise
description: Hot, thought the Parisians. The warm air of spring. It was night, they were at war and there was an air raid. But dawn was near and the war far away. The first to hear the hum of the siren were those who couldn't sleep-the ill and bedridden, mothers with sons at the front, women crying for the men they loved. To them it began as a long breath, like air being forced into a deep sigh. It wasn't long before its wailing filled the sky. It came from afar, from beyond the horizon, slowly, almost lazily. Those still asleep dreamed of waves breaking over pebbles, a March storm whipping the woods, a herd of cows trampling the ground with their hooves, until finally sleep was shaken off and they struggled to open their eyes, murmuring, "Is it an air raid?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOHMER, MILLIE (NEE BRAUNSTEIN)
description: SOHMER--Millie (nee Braunstein), widow of Dr. Abram Sohmer of Jamaica, N.Y. died April 6, 2006 in Los Angeles. She was 90 years of age. An immigrant girl who lived an American dream, Millie and her parents arrived from England penniless. Hardworking and industrious, Millie determined to educate herself. After high school, she attended college and nursing schooland became a graduate Registered Nurse. She was Chief Obstetrical Nurse and Night Supervisor at Beth Israel Hospital where she met and fell in love with a dashing, young intern named Abram Sohmer. They married in 1940. A first child, Stephen, was born in December 1941. Abram was then a flight surgeon with the USAF. When he volunteered for overseas duty, Millie and her son moved to New York, where they lived for the duration of the war with Abram's parents, David and Rose Sohmer. Abram rose to the rank of Colonel and was awarded a Bronze Star medal. After the war, the couple settled in Jamaica, where a second son, Paul, was born in 1948. Abram practiced family medicine for more than 50 years. In addition to raising her sons, Millie worked sideby-side with her husband during many of those years. They were loved and respected by the community they cared for. A happy and contented couple, they traveled widely and enjoyed theatre, music, and books. They were married 63 years. Millie is survived by her sons, six grandchildren and a loving extended family. Each year an endowment in Millie's honor at Beth Israel School of Nursing provides scholarships for two immigrant students. Condolences and reminiscences welcome at drsohmer@aol.com.

The race is on an interconnected lake system which widens and narrows and undulates. There are trees and farmhouses and you pass small villages. It's a route that the Vikings used in earlier days. I was No. 33, in a time of 3 hours, 28 minutes. The basic thing that appeals to me in skating? It feels like the closest thing to flying. title: 'The Man on Whom Nothing Was Lost'
description: The genius of Charles Hill is his silence. In books and in school we had encountered the far-off places and the Great Men whom he served: Hong Kong, Vietnam, and Israel; Ellsworth Bunker and Henry Kissinger, George Shultz and Boutros Boutros-Ghali. But he never mentioned them in class, and as artless freshmen we had yet to pick up on the gossip that the upperclassmen traded after his lectures. Most of us were too young to remember the Iran-Contra affair, at the time preferring Saturday morning cartoons to Oliver North. We did not know that our professor's notebooks helped to break open the investigation. Our ignorance was for the best. His presence, his hold on the class, was enough to make us freeze in our seats. Filled at first with the happy murmur of weekend gossip, the room snapped silent at nine o'clock when Professor Hill walked in. He wore a stone-colored suit, and he did not speak or look at us until he had taken his seat at the head of the table and pulled his yellow legal pad from his backpack. The backpack, please note, was made of dignified brown leather and detracted only slightly from the overall gravity of his image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WAGNER, SIMA
description: WAGNER--Sima. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Sima Wagner. For sixty-six years Sima was the devoted wife of Rubin Wagner, who survives her, the loving mother of Harry and Myra, Leon and Marsha and grandmother of Elliot, Lauren, Gabriel and Daniel. Born in Vilna, now Vilnius, Lithuania, daughter of Leah and Yisroel Benosher, Sima was the devoted older sister of Fania, Sharon and Merele of whom only Fania and Sharon survived the Holocaust. Young and in love Sima and Ruby eloped in February 1940 as the world erupted into war. Their daughter, Sheyna, born in 1941, was taken from Sima during a concentration camp selection. Separated during the war and imprisoned in numerous concentration camps Sima miraculously reunited with her husband after the war living in a displaced persons camp in Heidenheim, Germany between 1945 and 1949. They landed in New York with $8 to their name, lived in Brooklyn whereupon Sima became a member of the International Ladies Garment Worker's Union in order to help support her family. She reared her family in Jewish homes in Huntington, Roslyn and Aventura, Florida and always carried herself with elegance, dignity and discipline and was widely respected and loved in the community of survivors. Throughout her life Sima Wagner gave comfort and care to her sisters, niece, nephews, and cousins living a life devoted to family, friends, charity, Holocaust Remembrance and Am Yisrael Chai. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to: Ella Levine, YIVO Institute, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011 In memory of Sima Wagner or Dr. Amir Baron, Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center, 20400 North East 30th Avenue, Aventura, FL 33180 In memory of Sima Wagner. The Wagner Family

title: Movies on TV
description: THE END OF VIOLENCE (1997) Tuesday at 9:45 p.m. and Saturday at 10 p.m. on Flix At one point in Wim Wenders's intriguing puzzle of a film, Bill Pullman (above right), playing a high-powered Hollywood producer, tries to explain what "perversely" means. "It's when things are upside down and you start to like them that way," he says. Which pretty much describes what happens to his character, Mike Max, who at the start of the film is ordering people around from poolside and ignoring his wife, but by the end is looking from the outside in at his old life. In between, an attempt is made on his life, some immigrant gardeners take him in and a mysterious F.B.I. file is sent to his computer. The file involves a plan for a high-tech surveillance system that will keep an eye on the streets, bringing "the end of violence" (and, yes, calling to mind some recent government eavesdropping). It's all left tantalizingly understated and a bit creepy.

title: Reverse the Nurse

They said that without it, she would have had no hope and nothing to live for. Were these lies ethical?

But the focus of late is becoming narrower, limited to the fighting within Iraq: some call it sectarian violence or its synonym Sunni-Shiite fighting; others who see it as more political than religious call it an insurgency or an internecine (in-ter-NEE-sin) struggle.

They come from obscure little villages like Lisaleen and Closutton, Coolagh and Moone, dozing and possibly dreaming on the long, dark ferry ride from Dun Laoghaire across the Irish Sea to Wales. They are Ireland's pride, the finest jumpers in a country obsessed with jumping, with grand historical leaps over daunting obstacles, so they've been prepared for the trip with the utmost care. Some have IV drips to balance their electrolytes, others have been fed exotic Chinese herbs for an energy boost, and almost all have had their lungs checked for infections, their blood tested, and their weight recorded precisely, down to the last ounce, to be sure they have reached a peak of fitness for their annual tilt against the British at the Cheltenham Festival in England.

Lives; Reading a Death Warrant in Tehran

The government had admitted partial complicity in a few of the dozens of murders of intellectuals during the 1990's. Some were strangled while running errands, others hacked to death at home. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEGLEITER, HENRI
description: BEGLEITER - Henri. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Henri Begleiter, PhD, Distinguished Professor of Psychiatry and Director of the Neurodynamics Laboratory at SUNY Downstate. Highlights of Dr. Begleiter's extraordinary career include being the first to characterize brain dysfunction in alcoholics; assembling an internationally renowned project that successfully identified several genes involved in the predisposition toward alcoholism and related disorders; inception of the federally-funded, multi-center Collaborative Study of the Genetics of Alcoholism (COGA); and the introduction of the use of endophenotypes, or biological markers, to study the genetics of complex disorders in patients and their offspring. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife, Esther; his son, David; his daughter, Alison; his sonin-law Noah Siegel; his grandchildren; and to his numerous friends and colleagues throughout the world. John C. LaRosa, MD, Pres Eugene B. Feigelson, MD Senior Vice President for Biomedical Education and Research Stephen M. Goldfinger, MD, Chairman of Psychiatry

title: Suite Franaise
description: Hot, thought the Parisians. The warm air of spring. It was night, they were at war and there was an air raid. But dawn was near and the war far away. The first to hear the hum of the siren were those who couldn't sleep-the ill and bedridden, mothers with sons at the front, women crying for the men they loved. To them it began as a long breath, like air being forced into a deep sigh. It wasn't long before its wailing filled the sky. It came from afar, from beyond the horizon, slowly, almost lazily. Those still asleep dreamed of waves breaking over pebbles, a March storm whipping the woods, a herd of cows trampling the ground with their hooves, until finally sleep was shaken off and they struggled to open their eyes, murmuring, "Is it an air raid?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIG, MARTHA K.
description: SELIG--Martha K. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Martha K. Selig. She was 93 years old and died of heart failure on April 8th, at home, peacefully in her sleep. She was known for her pioneering leadership in the field of social work, but the passion closest to her heart was her family, especially Kal, her adored late husband. Martha deeply loved her daughters and sons-in-laws, Judith and Howard Rubenstein, and Elaine and David Gould, and her grandchildren Emily Rubenstein, Adam Rubenstein, Jennifer Rubenstein, and John Rubenstein, Dina and Adrian Halme, Talya Gould and Sara Gould, and Jennifer's fiance, Benjamin Zigun. Martha took great pride in all of their accomplishments. Her family in turn was very proud of Martha's professional achievements and unstinting dedication to Jewish communal service. She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, friend, mentor and teacher. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Martha K. Selig Institute of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, 120 West 57th Street, Room 921, NY, NY 10019. Named for her by her admirers, the Institute remains among her greatest honors and most significant accomplishments in advancing the education and training of social work professionals. She will be greatly missed, but the world will continue to benefit from her good works.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fines For Gun Dealers

Mr. Yassky's proposal is the most recent attempt to combat illegal gun sales in the city. A federal lawsuit that the city filed against gun makers in 2000 is pending. Last year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed another bill by Mr. Yassky that holds gun makers and dealers liable in civil lawsuits for selling guns that end up in the hands of criminals. It is debatable, however, whether the city has the authority to enact a product-liability law, and a federal law enacted last year gives gun manufacturers broad immunity from civil suits. Mr. Yassky's new bill, which seeks to establish civil penalties, may also be unenforceable, because very few gun makers and gun dealers are based in the city and state courts might lack jurisdiction.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEAR, STANLEY
description: SCHEAR--Stanley. 77. Died peacefully at home at the Schear farmhouse in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on Saturday, April 8, of esophageal cancer. Since 2001, Stanley dedicated himself to the low-income elderly residents of Westchester County as the Director of the LIFE Program (Living Independently for the Frail Elderly) of Family Service of Westchester. For the preceding decade, Stanley directed the Bridge Fund of Westchester, a program that prevents homelessness by making it possible for at-risk individuals and families to stay in their homes and apartments. Before becoming a full time advocate for affordable housing, Stanley was renowned for twenty-five years as the owner and operator of Jespersen's Pastry Shop in Scarsdale Village, where his famed chocolate pastry, named for Sarah Bernhardt, brought joy to countless fans. Stanley was also well known as a community activist who believed that all people deserve the dignity of a roof over thier heads, regardless of their race, income, age, or mental health status. An avid defender of the U.S. Bill of Rights, Stanley served on the boards of the Westchester County and New York State Civil Liberties Unions, as well as the Paul Robeson Foundation. Stanley founded and organized the annual Bill of Rights Day Celebration for high school students, which takes place at St. Paul's Church in Mt. Vernon, the site of the trial of Peter Zenger, which established freedom of the press. Stanley is survived by by Doris Schear, his loving wife and life partner of 58 years, his daughter Rose Anne and sons Stuart and Mitchell, and their families. Stanley leaves behind many friends, admiring colleagues, and fellow activists who believe in the full promise of the American dream for all. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Stanley's honor to the Sunshine Fund of Famliy Service of Westchester, which meets critical needs of the low-income frail elderly, so they may live with dignity. Donations to the Sunshine Fund may be sent c/o FSW, One Gateway Plaza, Port Chester, NY 10573. Burial will be private, and a public memorial Service will take place at the Westchester Society for Ethical Culture on Saturday, April 29, at 1 PM. For more information, please write sschear@nyc.rr.com. The family will be receiving guests on Monday, April 10, and Tuesday, April 11, starting at 5 PM, and on Sunday, April 16, starting at 2 PM, at 230 South State Road in Briarcliff Manor, NY.

Arts, Briefly; Who Reads Poetry?
description: African-American readers are more likely to read poetry than white readers, according to a study to be released tomorrow by the Poetry Foundation. The study, conducted by the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago, surveyed 1,023 people who declared themselves readers. The group was then questioned about its poetry reading habits. Seventy-six percent of the total said they read poetry. Overall, the highest percentage of people who read poetry are educated white women. "But if you look just at the percentage of African-Americans," said Norman Bradburn, a senior fellow at the center and a professor emeritus at the University of Chicago, who supervised the study, "as compared to the percentage of whites, a higher percentage of African-Americans -- 85 percent of those sampled -- are likely to read poetry than of whites." Among the most surprising results: if you like poetry, according to the study, no matter what your race, there is a better chance that you're athletic, too, and enjoy the company of others. And there isn't necessarily a correlation between having a college degree and being a poetry reader. "Fifty-six percent of poetry readers have less than a college degree," Mr. Bradburn noted. As for more women seeming to read poetry than men, "I have a theory," he said. "Maybe a lot more men read poetry than talk about it. It's not viewed as a very masculine thing. It's a kind of secret sin." DINITIA SMITH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIAMBELLI, FRANCESCO ''FRANK''
description: GIAMBELLI -- Francesco "Frank". Famed restauranteur, owner and founder of Giambelli 50th Ristaronte, died peacefully at his home on April 7th at the age of 90. Loving and devoted husband of more than 50 years to Mary Giambelli. Born in 1915 in Voghera, outside Milan, Italy. Francesco worked in some of the most renowned restaurants in Europe before coming to the US in 1954 to open Giambelli's Ristorante, originally located on Madison Avenue and 37th Street in Manhattan. Giambelli's 50th Ristorante opened at its present location on 50th and Madison Avenue in 1960 and has boasted many distinguished personalities, including presidents of the United States, kings, queens and other royalty, media celebrities, politicians and business executives. His proudest moment came in October, 1995, during Pope John Paul II's historic trip to New York, when he and his wife had the honor to serve the Holy Father and fifty Cardinals who were his guests at the Cardinal's residence in New York City. Francesco has been honored by his peers in the restaurant industry, including the Association of Italian Restauranteurs of New York and the Culinary Institute of America, and is the recipient of many honors as Commandatore of the Italian Republic by the President of Italy, the 2003 Angelus Awardee for St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, as well as being active as a member of the Columbus Citizen Foundation, Legion of Merit, rank of Commandatore. He has generously contributed to the Archdioces of New York, St. Patrick's Cathedral, St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, Boys Town of Italy, Culinary Institute of America, Columbus Citizens Scholarship Fund, St. Virgilius School in Broad Channel, NY, and the Jewish Communal Fund. The family will receive friends on Sunday and Monday 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday April 11th at 10 AM St. Patricks Cathedral, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital, Manhattan, SVCMC Foundation, 130 West 12th Street, 1-G, New York, NY 10011.

description: WASHINGTON, April 9 - A vast program to replace the voice and data lines that link the Federal Aviation Administration's air traffic control system has caused at least three major failures in the system recently, resulting in the grounding of scores of airliners, government officials say.

title: Barry Harris and Regina Carter at Jazz at Lincoln Center: New Work From Two Detroit Natives
description: Two initiatives of Jazz at Lincoln Center intersected over the weekend at Rose Theater. The first was As of Now, a series that has sponsored new music from a pair of jazz composers -- an accomplished veteran and an estimable younger talent -- for each of the last eight seasons. The second was Jazz From Coast to Coast, the title and mission of the current season.

title: Arts, Briefly; Slime Pays
description: Nickelodeon's annual "Kids' Choice Awards," which honored Will Smith, below, and Lindsay Lohan, among others, was the most-watched program on advertiser-supported cable for the week that ended on April 2. Jack Black was the host, and he covered Robin Williams and members of the audience with the show's signature slime. The festivities drew 5.94 million viewers, and the award show was No. 1 in all children's demographics. Among 12-to-34-year-olds, the finale of the "Real World/Road Rules Challenge" (3.6 million) was the week's most popular show. Viewers who tuned in to this edition of the competition -- in which former cast members of this flagship reality series on MTV compete for money and prizes -- saw the rookie players beat the veterans, along with the show's requisite alcohol-fueled fights and hookups. Over all for the week, USA Network ranked first in primetime. KATE AURTHUR

title: Allan Kaprow, Creator of Artistic 'Happenings,' Dies at 78
description: Allan Kaprow, an artist who coined the term "happenings" in the late 1950's and whose anti-art, audience-participation works contributed to radical changes in the course of late-20th-century art, died on Wednesday at his home in Encinitas, Calif., near San Diego. He was 78.

title: Duke Case Could Turn on Players' DNA Tests
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 9 - The test results of the DNA samples taken from 46 members of the Duke University lacrosse team are expected back as soon as Monday, providing what could be a turning point in the rape case that has divided this college town.

description: Rascal Flatts"Me and My Gang"(Lyric Street/Hollywood)

William A. Barnes, 94, Surgeon Who Improved Tube Feeding, Dies
description: Dr. William A. Barnes, a New York surgeon and stomach specialist who developed an early device that improved the catheterized feeding of patients with a blockage of the esophagus, died on March 26 at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 94.

title: Other Views: The Guardian, New Straits Times, Toronto Star
As 'Kids' Lead Way, Knicks Look to Future
description: BOSTON, April 9 - The wait-till-next-year party is officially in full swing, and the Knicks will have to be forgiven if they blow their noisemakers a little in the enjoyable final days of an otherwise sorry season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PACKARD, SIDNEY
description: PACKARD--Sidney. On Friday April 7, 2006, Sidney Packard of Potomac, MD. Husband of the late Sylvia Packard. Father of Margery, Thomas and Beverly (Akira Komoriya) Packard. Brother of Helen (Sandy) Elfenbein, Sylvia Sanders and Clarence (Lucille) Shapiro. Grandfather of Samantha (Jim) Kreindler, Lauren Thomas (fiance Ari Holtzblatt) and Vanessa Thomas. Great grandfather of Jordan and Benjamin Kreindler. Funeral services were held in Washington, DC. Shiva will be observed on Monday and Tuesday at the home of Margery Thomas. Contributions may be made to Hoop Dreams Scholarship Fund or to American Jewish World Service. For information, Torchinsky Hebrew Funeral Home, Washington, DC, 800-500-5401.

title: Critics' Choice: New CD's
description: LL Cool J "Todd Smith" (Island Def Jam)

title: Running out of Patience in Iraq
Spacecraft Will Be Sent to Seek Water on Moon
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 A A previously planned lunar orbiter mission will be accompanied by a secondary spacecraft designed to crash into the moon in search of water that might be lurking in dark craters, NASA officials announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLOGG, HON. FRANCIS L.
description: KELLOGG--Hon. Francis L. Passed away peacefully at his residence on April 6. Born in NYC 1917, he is survived by his children Christopher Gage Kellogg and Fernanda Kellogg Henckels, three grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Among his many accomplishments he was Executive Vice-President of John Wanamaker, represented the State Department as Ambassador for Refugees and Migration Affairs, Director of UNICEF Children of The World Coin Program, Chief of Protocol for NY Mission to United Nations and President of World Wildlife Fund. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, April 25, at St. Thomas Church in NYC at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to World Wildlife Fund, 1250 Twenty-Fourth St., N.W., POB 97180, Washington, DC 20037.

title: A Victory for California
description: California took a leap of faith six years ago when it decided to offer nonviolent drug offenders the choice of going to jail or accepting probation and community-based drug treatment. Critics of the initiative predicted dire consequences if petty drug criminals were allowed to escape incarceration. But the data collected in California is beginning to show that nonviolent drug offenders are more effectively -- and less expensively -- dealt with when they are diverted into treatment.

title: Prosecution Sees Setback at Terror Trial in California
description: SACRAMENTO, April 6 - The federal terrorism trial that has been going on here for the past several weeks has not lacked for surprises. Its shockers have included word of a sighting of one of the world's most sought-after terror suspects in a town not far away and the last-minute discovery of a surreptitiously recorded tape.

title: Italians Go to Polls, in Referendum on Berlusconi's Five-Year Record
description: ROME, April 9 - Italy began voting on Sunday for 945 members of Parliament, but as has been the case here for years, the day was about one man alone: Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Blasting of Kidney Stones Has Risks, Study Reports
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 - The use of shock waves to pulverize kidney stones into sand-like material significantly increases the risk for diabetes and high blood pressure later in life, according to the longest follow-up study of the popular therapy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENTHALER, ROBERT WOERNER
description: SCHOENTHALER -- Robert Woerner, a White Plains resident and former longtime Scarsdale, NY resident died April 8, 2006. He was 64. He was born October 13, 1941 to the late Woerner Frederick and Dorothy Lakin Schoenthaler. On November 3, 1978 he married Linda Karsh. Besides his wife Linda of White Plains, Robert is survived by his children, Robert C. (Lauren Knudsen) Schoenthaler of Portola Valley, CA, Diane Gutwillig (Jeffrey Diamond) of Great Barrington, MA, Kenneth (Jill Cooper) Gutwillig of Yorktown Heights, NY and Lisa Gutwillig (Brian Fee) of White Plains, NY. Also surviving are his grandchildren, Shane, Kelsey, Makayla and Trey Fee, Jake and Matthew Diamond, and Jack and Brad Schoenthaler. A brother John (Suzanne) Schoenthaler of Addison, TX and his nephews John and Peter Schoenthaler also survive. Mr. Schoenthaler was a retired energy executive. Visiting hours will be Monday and Tuesday, 6-9pm, at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home 491, Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY (914) 949-7777. Funeral service will be Wednesday, April 12, 2006 at 10:30 am at St. James the Less Church, Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 30 Glenn St., White Plains, NY 10603

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEFTER, HARRY
description: SHEFTER--Harry. We mourn the passing of a great and loving gentleman who always saw the positive side of life in his 95 years. He will be missed by everyone he touched. The Briskman Family

title: Until Putter Faltered, Couples Was All Smiles
description: AUGUSTA, Ga. - PHIL MICKELSON and Fred Couples were each trying to win the Masters, but as they strolled around Augusta National yesterday, talking and smiling, it was as if they were college teammates in a practice round.

description: A week into the season, David Wright does not consider the M.V.P. chants premature. They are, he said in his aw-shucks sort of way, completely ludicrous.

title: Some Parents Let Children Choose College, and Pay
description: Alexandra Baldari and her parents have talked a good deal over the past year about how to pay for her college education, and the upshot is this: If she enrolls at the University of Miami in the fall, she will bear much of the cost, which could total $40,000 or more a year, on her own.

description: Dontrelle Willis had a running commentary, mostly with himself, in the Florida Marlins' clubhouse before he tossed a pitch against the Mets yesterday. It was the Dontrelle Show, unscripted and unplugged.

Iran Doesn't Spring Forward. Time to Get Mad.
description: TEHRAN, April 9 - A decision by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's government not to move the clocks ahead at the beginning of spring this year has caused immense problems and irritations for Iranians.

title: The Saddam Hussein Trials
description: The crimes committed against the Iraqi people by Saddam Hussein's dictatorship are so numerous that there is no realistic possibility of trying Mr. Hussein for all of them. But if there is one particular case for which he must be made to answer, it is the gruesome military campaign he waged against Iraqi Kurdish civilians 18 years ago. At least 50,000 civilians were killed and 2,000 villages destroyed.

description: ALBANY, April 9 - Gov. George E. Pataki is preparing to block roughly $2 billion worth of spending and proposed tax cuts in the budget that the State Legislature passed last month, vetoing some items and declaring that several major programs were passed unconstitutionally, a senior aide to the governor said on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHAN, WALTER I.
description: NATHAN--Walter I. on April 6, 2006. Beloved son of the late Philip J. and Sylvia L. Nathan. Loving brother of Helen.

title: At the Four A's, Jokes, Proposals and a Tribute
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. - HERE is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the 2006 management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A's, which was held here last week.

title: Early Results Show Italian Election Is Too Close to Call
description: ROME, April 10 A Italy's elections narrowed this evening to a race too close to call, as projections showed Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi winning the upper chamber of parliament and in a tight race for the lower chamber.

Lawyers for Duke Players Say DNA Doesn't Match
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 10 A DNA evidence released today cleared 46 Duke lacrosse players from an accusation that three of them raped a dancer at a party four weeks ago, the players' defense lawyers said.

title: Day After Streak Ends, Nets Start a New One
description: MILWAUKEE, April 9 - By Coach Lawrence Frank's reckoning, this would have been the perfect day for the Nets to mail one in. After a tough crunch-time loss to LeBron James and Cleveland on Saturday -- the first time in 37 games that the Nets led entering the fourth quarter and did not win -- the Nets flew here to face a Bucks team with much more at stake. Milwaukee is jockeying with three other teams for the fifth seeding in the Eastern Conference.

title: Bush admits declassifying Iraq report
Heading off fears of a resurgent China
Moussaoui Jury Hears From Families of Victims
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va. April 10 A The jurors who will soon decide whether Zacarias Moussaoui is to be executed or spend the rest of his life in prison heard a steady stream of accounts today of the grief and pain felt by the families of those killed on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Mickelson Works Magic for Second Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 - Phil Mickelson walked with his golf glove dangling from his back pocket, his reputation evolving in the soft light of spring. His grandfather Al Santos once predicted magical things for him at Augusta National Golf Club, and once more it was happening at the Masters.

title: Renzo Piano's Expansion of the Morgan Library Transforms a World of Robber Barons and Scholars
description: If some architects feel a twinge of envy at the mention of Renzo Piano, who can blame them? In the United States alone, the Italian architect is working on or has just finished major museum projects in New York, Los Angeles, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago and San Francisco. And two decades after its completion, the art world still speaks reverently of the serene, muted light in his Menil Collection building in Houston.

description: Hundreds of Thousands March for Immigrants Demonstrators marched in cities across the nation, calling for citizenship for illegal immigrants. The police estimated that as many as 500,000 marched in downtown Dallas in the largest of the protests. PAGE A14

description: The Connections column in The Arts on March 20, about the art of conversation, misspelled the name of an 18th-century journal that Samuel Johnson said had "adjusted" conversation with their "propriety and politeness." It was The Tatler, not The Tattler.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Barrons: Goldman Is No Gambler, Its the House
description: When Goldman Sachs reported blow-out first-quarter earnings earlier this year, many contrarians groused about the securities firms increasing exposure to trading risk and its hard-to-understand inner workings (often called Goldmans black box.)

description: Gilbert Whites Selborne Journal: Saturday, 10 April 1784: 29 3/10; 42; NE, N. Rain, rain, rain. Gentle rain.

title: Slide Show: On Their Own
description: Many well-off members of Generation X may actually end up better prepared for retirement. Yet most young families are saving almost nothing.

title: Consortium May Be Considering Mammoth Vodafone Bid
description: A consortium of telecoms giants and private-equity firms are said to be mulling a bid for Vodafone Group, according to The Daily Mail of London. The report said that Verizon Communications, Telefonica of Spain and private-equity firm Blackstone Group are looking to fund a 160 pence-a-share offer for the worlds largest mobile-phone carrier. Such an offer would value Vodafone at 96 billion pounds ($168 billion). J.P. Morgan Cazenove is thought to be masterminding the plan, according to the report.

title: Spanish Suitor Takes Offer to Shareholders of British Airport Operator
description: Grupo Ferrovial , Spains second- biggest builder, offered 8.75 billion pounds ($15 billion) for BAA, taking its bid directly to investors after the owner of Heathrow airport spurned the proposal.

title: Energy Merger May Go Dark Over States Rate Increase
description: The chief executives of FPL Group and Constellation Energy Group warned shareholders Friday that the actions of Maryland state lawmakers could short-circuit the companies proposed $11.4 billion merger.

title: Inco May Unload Falconbridge Unit to Win European Approval
description: Inco, seeking to win European approval for a takeover of Falconbridge , offered to sell a unit that acquires metal for refining, The Globe and Mail reported. Inco is planning to buy Falconbridge for $13.2-billion, which would see it overtake Russias OAO GMK Norilsk Nickel as the worlds biggest producer of nickel.

title: Private Equity Group Gets a Look at McClatchys Books, Too
description: A group of private-equity investors has joined the bidding for The Inquirer and Philadelphia Daily News, a member of the group said yesterday. Their addition brings to at least four the number of bidders with permission from McClatchy to review financial records at The Inquirer and Daily News in preparation for final bidding on the papers.

title: Guidants Legal Woes Cast A Pall Over Deal
description: A large amount of debt is one thing, but a bunch of sticky and potentially expensive lawsuits is another. In agreeing to spend $27 billion in a cash-and-stock deal to acquire heart device-maker Guidant, Boston Scientific has inherited both. Guidant defibrillators have brought the company buckets of bad news as well as dozens of lawsuits. The tangled legal situation is keeping investors on the fence about the merger.

title: Turbulence Ahead for BAEs Airbus Sale
description: The announcement by BAE Systems last week that it planned to sell its stake in the aircraft maker Airbus to its partner European Aerospace Defense & Space has sparked fears of job losses in Britain. Despite reassurances from the British government and the management of Airbus, unions and staff members at the aircraft makers two British factories said over the weekend that they feared that jobs would be lost.

title: VeriFone Rings Up Lipman Deal
description: VeriFone Holdings said on Monday it reached a cash and stock deal worth $793 million to acquire rival electronic payment systems maker Lipman Electronic Engineering.

title: A White Elephant, Whiff of Scandal Included
description: No. 10 Toronto Street, an elegant three-story Greek Revival building, is arguably one of Canadas best-known business addresses. Since 1978, when he took over Argus, it has been known as both the personal office of Conrad M. Black and the hub of his business empire. Now Hollinger, one of the corporations that succeeded Argus as Lord Blacks main corporate vehicles, has put the 153-year-old building up for sale after evicting its former chairman.

title: Law Firms Debate Merger
description: Cincinnatis largest law firm, Dinsmore & Shohl, is in merger talks with Thorp Reed & Armstrong, Pittsburghs seventh largest law firm. Douglas Gilbert, Thorp Reed managing partner, confirmed that the discussions were initiated by Dinsmore managing partner Clifford Roe. But he also stressed that a deal isnt imminent with the Cincinnati firm, which is more than twice Thorp Reeds size.

title: Goldman Back on Top of the Underwriting World
description: When Google, the twenty-first centurys hottest company, selected underwriters for its $1.9 billion initial public offering in August 2004, Goldman Sachs Group didnt make the cut. For Goldman, losing the Google IPO wasnt acceptable  which is why 10 days ago the most profitable securities firm arranged a $2.1 billion stock sale for Google that paid almost no concession.

title: Citigroup Branches Out in Philadelphia
description: Citigroup is the latest international giant making plans to break into Philadelphias established branch-banking market.

title: Sealy I.P.O. No Snooze
description: Shares of mattress maker Sealy shot higher Friday in their debut on the New York Stock Exchange following the companys initial public offering. Sealys stock closed at $17.50, or up 9.4 percent. VDM Specialists, the specialist firm that manages Sealy trading on the NYSE floor, said that at $16 per share the I.P.O. raised $448 million.

title: Japanese Bank Makes Pretty With Apple Before I.P.O.
description: Aozora Bank, a Japanese lender majority-owned by U.S. buyout fund Cerberus, is sprucing up ahead of a widely expected share listing, and it has asked Apple Computer to outfit 2,500 work stations at its main office, data center and 17 branches. And Aozoras makeover goes so deep that it has made it the iPod-makers biggest financial industry client worldwide

title: Baidu.com Out of Sync
description: If Baidu.com were a band, it would be N Sync. If it were a fashion item, it would be leg warmers. If it were home decor, it would be avocado-green shag carpeting.

title: XL Capital Readies Security Capital for I.P.O.
description: XL Capital said on Friday its holding company, Security Capital Assurance, has filed a registration statement to sell some of its common shares to the public in an initial public offering. Security Capital is a holding company for XLs financial guaranty insurance and reinsurance businesses conducted through XL Capital Assurance and XL Financial Assurance.

title: Keeping Up With the MySpaces
description: Social-networking sites like MySpace are growing at an astonishing rate. Facebook, a site for students, is now the seventh-busiest spot on the Web.

title: U.S. Research Funds Often Lead to Start-Ups, Study Says
description: A new study of university scientists who received federal financing from the National Cancer Institute found that they generated patents at a rapid pace and started companies in surprisingly high numbers. The study, the authors say, suggests that the commercial payoff for the governments support for basic research and development in the life sciences is greater than previously thought.

title: Endoart Raises $10.5 Million
description: Endoart, a company that started out targeting arterial disease but changed direction to develop an implantable device to combat obesity, said that it has raised CHF 13.5 million ($10.5 million) in Series C financing. The new money will fund sales of Endoarts device in Europe, where marketing began this year, as well as the process of getting the device approved in the U.S.

title: Investors Get a Compass to Guide Them in the Travel Services Industry
description: Compass Group, the worlds largest caterer, agreed to sell its travel-services business to investors led by Swedens billionaire Wallenberg family and Macquarie Bank for 1.82 billion pounds ($3.2 billion). EQT Partners, a private equity business controlled by the Wallenbergs, will buy the airport and railway food operations of Compasss Select Service Partner unit, Chertsey.

title: Yard House Wants Private Equity to Come Over and Play
description: Yard House USA, a 13-unit bar and restaurant chain, is looking for private equity capital as it seeks to expand into a 100-unit chain with locations worldwide. Steele Platt, owner and founder of the Irvine, Calif.-based chain, told LBO Wire that he is speaking to a handful of buyout firms about selling a majority stake of the company for north of $100 million.

title: Austin Ventures Partners Up
description: Continuing to look at middle-market buyout deals, Austin Ventures has partnered with Elisabeth DeMarse, the former head of publicly traded Bankrate, to acquire or develop a company in the information services market.

title: S.E.C. Must Review Mutual Fund Rules, Court says
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission must for a second time review mutual fund governance rules pushed through by outgoing SEC Chairman William Donaldson, giving successor Christopher Cox a chance to revisit regulation of the $8.6 trillion industry, a federal appeals court held.

title: Photographs: Searching for Bodies in New Orleans
description: The bodies of storm victims are still being discovered in New Orleans. In March alone there were nine, plus one skull.

title: Boeing Pays Record Fine for Violating Export Act
description: Boeing has paid the largest fine ever levied on a company for violation of the Arms Export Control Act, settling a dispute with the State Department over the unlicensed foreign sales of commercial airplanes carrying a small gyrochip with military applications.

title: Mediaset Threatened by Italian Elections
description: Italian broadcaster Mediasets future hangs in the balance as it waits to see if its controlling shareholder, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, wins national general elections on Monday. Berlusconis control of Italys leading private television network has dominated the election campaign and the center-left opposition, who are leading in the latest opinion polls, has pledged to loosen Mediasets grip should it gain power.

title: Time Warner Settlement Approved
description: A federal judge has approved a settlement that calls for Time Warner, the worlds largest media company, to pay $2.65 billion to settle charges it overstated revenue to gain approval for its merger with AOL. Time Warner agreed last August to the settlement with a lead group of shareholders who accused AOL of inflating its revenue by $1.7 billion between January 1999 and August 2002.

title: Wal-Mart Resists Pressure in Brokeback DVD Sales
description: The culture war surrounding Brokeback Mountain may be nearing an end, but as the film was released on DVD last week, it found an unusual ally: Wal-Mart Stores. On Tuesday, the retailer began selling Brokeback Mountain on DVD, over the objection of the American Family Association, a conservative religious organization based in Tupelo, Miss.

title: Not So Boffo: Hollywood Hopping Mad Over Disclosure Rules
description: Media companies, worried that some of their most closely guarded Hollywood secrets could be exposed, are rallying to fight a proposed change to corporate-disclosure rules.

title: Some Worries as San Francisco Goes Wireless
description: Days after announcing it had selected Google and EarthLink to build public wireless network, San Francisco has found itself at the center of debate about the role of advertising, the implications of the network on consumer privacy and the effect on telecommunications companies that today sell Internet access in the city.

title: Would Stolichnaya Taste So Sweet Under Any Other Name?
description: Whats in a name? Well, quite a lot actually, if the name happens to be Stolichnaya, the worlds best-selling vodka. To be precise, some $2 billion in annual sales, including $400 million in the U.S.

title: Spitzers Music Inquiry Not Such Sweet Music for New Bands
description: New York attorney general Eliot Spitzers inquiry into the music industry over allegations of illegal payments for airplay was intended to make the airwaves more of a meritocracy. Without such pay for play, Spitzer argued, consumers would hear the music that programmers liked best, rather than tunes that the major record labels bribed deejays to air.

title: Trumps Mortgage Move May Be Ill-Timed
description: Donald Trump wants to become a mortgage broker. His new company, unsurprisingly named Trump Mortgage, has taken out broker licenses in several U.S. states and is applying to become a nationwide home lender.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Palo Alto Firm for Insider Trading
description: A week after federal regulators accused a former executive of Palo Alto-based Connetics of illegal insider trading, they have begun a formal investigation into whether the biotech firm or its employees broke U.S. securities laws, the company said Friday.

title: Telecoms Want a Little TV Help from Their Friends in Washington
description: Having invested billions of dollars to upgrade their communications networks so that they are capable of offering TV service, phone giants now want laws making it easier to actually offer it. For all the talk about broadband technology and video-content agreements, the biggest hurdle to phone companies sending TV into homes has been getting local government approval.

title: Airlines Communication Firm Turns On the For Sale Sign
description: ARINC, a 77-year-old military and aviation communications company owned primarily by the nations largest airlines, is up for sale after more than a year of deliberations about how to raise the capital necessary to grow. The Annapolis, Md., company, which had $890 million in revenue in 2005, derives two-thirds of its business from the U.S. military, for which it provides wireless systems that allow all branches to communicate over multiple devices.

title: Limited Partners Keep Writing Checks
description: Limited partners continued to pile into private equity funds  especially buyout funds  in the first quarter, nearly doubling the amount of capital they committed to the asset class from the same quarter a year ago. According to data compiled by The Private Equity Analyst, private equity funds raised $26.93 billion in the quarter, up from $13.71 billion in the same period a year ago.

title: Another Twist in the Biovail Tale
description: Controversial Canadian pharmaceutical company Biovails purchase of Pharmaceutical Technologies has been included as a subject of the continuing Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into Biovail, according to company filings. The $22 million purchase of the research company in 2002 continues to baffle regulators on both sides of the border, who are questioning the validity of the transaction.

title: Hedge Fund Digs Its Heels in Over Sears Canada Bid
description: Hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management has refused to tender its Sears Canada shares in a takeover bid by parent Sears Holdings and might go to court to force the retailer to raise the price.

title: With No Buyer in Sight, Serono Hunts for Deals of Its Own
description: Seronos billionaire Bertarelli family ended its five-month search for a buyer because the offers it received for Europes largest biotechnology company were too low.

title: The Serial Monogamists: Exchanges Cant Stop Proposing
description: Strong growth in trading volume reported last week by the big Chicago exchanges, coming on the heels of a visit here several weeks ago by New York Stock Exchange chief executive John Thain, has cranked up speculation about other possible New York-Chicago exchange marriages.

title: In California, Politics Is a Family Business
JBoss Ends Takeover Speculation with Red Hat Deal
description: A few months after being pegged as potential takeover bait for Oracle, software company JBoss has agreed to be bought by someone else: Red Hat.

title: Law Firm Paul Hastings Sued Over Role in Alleged Memo Destruction
description: The collapse of a billboard-selling business has led to a lawsuit against prominent law firm Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, alleging that it directed its client to destroy a legal memorandum, The Wall Street Journal reports.

title: Roundup: School Cuts Proposed
description: In a decision that could have a profound effect on Newarks public education system, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced late Friday that he would be asking the states poorer school districts to make do with less.

title: Is Chivalry Dead, or Did It Ever Exist?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Apr. 9 column, Virtues and Victims:

description: Everytime I hear one of those radio ads from the Beringer Vineyards How to Get to Napa Valley campaign (click here to hear it; mp3 format), I start feeling very cranky. I dont normally gravitate to a grumpy Andy Rooney persona, but they drive me crazy. If you havent hear it, or cant hear it through this link, heres a crude approximation:

title: Fidelity Said to Sell Stake in London Stock Exchange
description: As speculation about the fate of the London Stock Exchange continues to swirl, Reuters is reporting that fund manager Fidelity International, once the London exchanges largest shareholder, cashed out its remaining shares of the L.S.E. last week.

title: Stung By Locusts Tag, Buyout Titans May Join Forces
description: In a sign of the rising hostilities directed at their industry, four of the biggest private equity firms may form a trade group to represent their interests, The Financial Times reports.

title: You Can Leave Your Hat On
description: Gilt, at the New York Palace Hotel, is one of the few New York restaurants to retain a jackets required policy  at least in theory.(Shannon Greer for The New York Times)

title: The Rise of the Theocons
description: Are liberals wrong to spend so much time worrying about the bogeyman of religious conservatism? In a Wall Street Journal op-ed that was published last week and posted on the Journals free OpinionJournal site over the weekend, Ross Douthat, an associate editor at The Atlantic, suggests that so-called theoconservatism is the closest thing to a credible public philosophy the G.O.P. has to offer. title: Memo Pad
description: IMPROVING HOTEL LOYALTY -- As faith declines in the airlines' frequent-flier mileage programs, business travelers are giving high marks to frequent-stay programs at hotels, according to a new survey by the management consulting company Accenture. In a survey of business travelers belonging to frequent-stay programs, 31 percent said that hotels now recognized them as loyal customers and tailored reservations to fit their stated preferences. When Accenture last surveyed business travelers on the subject last October, only 18 percent said that hotel loyalty programs were providing personalized services like choices of floors and pillows. Paul Chiu, managing partner in Accenture's travel services sector, said that the change partly reflected improvements that hotels made in technology to process loyalty program reservations. On the other hand, accumulation of points in a hotel loyalty program is the least important factor business travelers cite in choosing a hotel. Proximity to business meetings is the top factor.

The platform, which should have been connected to a crane, was rendered unstable and collapsed onto the street, killing two construction workers and a man driving by. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGAN, DENISE
description: MORGAN -- Denise. The trustees, dean, faculty, students, staff and alumni of New York Law School mourn the death of our beloved colleague, teacher, and friend, Professor Denise Morgan in Chicago on April 8 at the age of 41. She was an extraordinary colleague. Her passing leaves a huge void in the institution that is impossible to replace. Denise wrote extensively about civil rights and equal educational opportunity. Her most recent scholarly work focused on the role of the federal government in protecting individual rights, which she explored as principal editor of "Awakening from the Dream: Civil Rights Under Siege and the New Struggle for Equal Justice" (2005). Denise taught federal courts, civil procedure, evidence, a seminar on race and American history and a course on education policy and the law. Her passionate concern for educational inequality in America turned to advocacy with her involvement in the landmark litigation, Campaign for Fiscal Equity, Inc. v. New York State, in which she represented the Black, Puerto Rican and Hispanic Legislative Caucus. Denise received her BA and her JD from Yale University. Before joining the New York Law School faculty in 1995, she clerked for the Honorable Marilyn Hall Patel, US District Court, Northern District of California, and worked as an associate at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Eric Wold, their daughter Sylvan, and her mother and father, Coralee and John Morgan. A memorial service will be held in New York City. Details about the memorial, and an educational trust fund to be established for her daughter Sylvan will be available by email to jfishman@nyls.edu. Arthur N. Abbey, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Richard A. Matasar, Dean and President

title: Letter From Ed Smith to His Son, Army Cpt. Will Smith
description: I enlisted in the Marines on May 9,1964, prior to graduating high school. On June 21,1964, I took the long bus ride to Charleston, W.V., to start my journey. We arrived at P.I. in the early morning hours and were promised beds as soon as they were ready. It didnAt take long for reality to set in. I wasnAt in W.V. anymore. Boot camp in the 1960As was nothing like it is now. Vietnam was not a big topic at that time. It was just getting started. Advisors had been sent to help the Vietnamese army. After getting to Camp Pendelton (California) it seemed like more troops were starting to be sent over, beginning the buildup. I had no idea at that time that I might be sent to war. Mid-1965 there were more rumors that we might go. I had no clue what we would be facing.

description: Three teenagers accused of chasing a New York University student into traffic at 125th Street and Park Avenue, where he was fatally injured by a car, were arraigned yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court. The teenagers -- Humberto Guzman, 13, Denzell Fell, 13, and Hassan Mayfield, 15 -- were charged with second-degree murder in the death of the student, Broderick J. Hehman. A fourth teenager, Andre Johnson, 15, was arraigned on Sunday on the same charge. A prosecutor, Joel J. Seidemann, said the defendants had implicated a fifth youth, who had not been arrested by last evening, who they said had instigated the robbery attempt on April 1. Mr. Mayfield told the police that the group had followed Mr. Hehman to rob him of his cellphone, prosecutors said. Service Tuesday, April 11, 10:30AM at King Solomon Cemetery, Dwas Line Rd and Allwood Rd, Clifton. Friends may visit at the home of Lisa and Perry Schaffer, 17 Marquette Rd, Upper Montclair following services until 8PM and Wednesday, 11-4PM.
