description: To the Editor:

title: Now, Winning It All Is the Only Thing
description: It was 10 years ago this week, against the Kansas City Royals, that Joe Torre managed for the first time at Yankee Stadium.

title: It's Crowded. It's Chaotic. And It's Not Even Summer.
description: PHOENIX - I FELT like a hostage in the studio of the Home Shopping Network, but it was only the departure area for the newly merged US Airways and America West Airlines at the Phoenix airport.

title: Save Yourself
description: WHEN my wife and I talk about paying for our retirement, we assume that we will be pretty much on our own. We are both 33, and it's hard to have a lot of confidence that Social Security and traditional pensions will do for us what they did for our grandparents.

title: Surge in Metal Prices Lifts Alcoa's Profit
description: Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit more than doubled, to $608 million, beating analysts' estimates, as metals prices surged.

title: World outlook rosy, but risky
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Kushner Executive Is Indicted
description: An executive at a real estate partnership controlled by Charles Kushner, a developer and Democratic contributor, was indicted yesterday on federal tax charges, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Prosecutors said the executive, Richard Stadtmauer, 47, managing director of the Kushner Companies, was charged with conspiring to mischaracterize $5 million in charitable and political contributions and other items as business expenses. Three members of an outside accounting company have also been charged, prosecutors said. Mr. Stadtmauer's lawyer, Robert S. Fink, said the deductions were proper. "They are accounting disputes," Mr. Fink said.

title: Senses: A Whiff of Fear Can Sharpen a Woman's Thinking
description: Women can unconsciously detect the smell of fear, new research suggests, and the smell improves their performance on mental tasks.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Blast kills 47 at religious rally in Karachi
In France, a Bullet Goes Unbitten
description: Nearly two years ago, the chief executive of one of the largest international companies based in France described what he viewed as the best chance for needed economic reform that would open up European economies by making it much easier to hire and fire workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIVIN, BARRY S.
description: TIVIN--Barry S. The Queens County Bar Association records with deep sorrow the passing of its distinguished member and Past President 2004-2005 on April 9, 2006. Funeral service is Tuesday, April 11, 2006 at 1 PM and will be held at Schwartz Bros. Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. George J. Nashak, Jr. President

title: Corrections
description: The "On the Road" column in the Itineraries pages of Business Day on April 4 about meals during travel misstated the location of a lunch at the Radisson Lexington Hotel in Manhattan. It was in the hotel's Latin Quarter club, not the Alma Grill. The article also misstated the availability of the new Radisson "Tasteful Choices" menu. While it can be found at many Radisson Hotel restaurants, it is available at the Lexington through room service only.

title: Blast in Pakistan Kills at Least 47
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 11 A A powerful explosion ripped through a religious congregation in the southern port city of Karachi this evening, leaving at least 47 dead and more than 80 wounded, officials said.

title: They Said Immigration Could Be Fixed
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about campaign finance legislation referred incorrectly to the legal status of the political advocacy arm of the liberal group MoveOn.org. It operates as a political action committee, not as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code.

title: Stabilizing 'Today,' Matt Lauer Extends Contract to 2011
description: Just as Katie Couric of the "Today" show was agreeing to go to CBS last week, and Meredith Vieira of "The View" was agreeing to replace her, Ms. Couric's low-key co-host, Matt Lauer, made a decision securing his own future.

title: First the Pork, Governor
description: Sometime in the next few days, Gov. George Pataki will try to put his final imprint on his final New York State budget. Passed by the Legislature hours before the April 1 deadline, this $112 billion to $116 billion budget proposal should offer the governor some easy vetoes. For example, he has indicated that he plans to pluck out the large vats of money that state leaders divvy up among their followers for unidentified pet projects. If the budget has pork, it should at least be public pork.

title: Capitulation in France
A site to help bloggers unite - and profit
It's Early, but the Mets' Glass Is at Least Half Full
description: A pessimist could attribute the Mets' 4-1 start to a forgiving schedule that included a string of home games against what are presumed to be the lesser teams in the National League East. An optimist could consider the same evidence and start envisioning chilly October nights at Shea Stadium.

title: Military Fantasies on Iran
description: Iraq shows just how badly things can go wrong when an administration rashly embraces simple military solutions to complicated problems, shutting its ears to military and intelligence professionals who turn out to be tragically prescient. That lesson has yet to be absorbed by the Bush administration, which is now reportedly honing plans for airstrikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

title: Lawyers for Duke Players Say DNA Clears Team
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 10 - Results of DNA tests on 46 Duke lacrosse players were released Monday, and lawyers for the players said the tests failed to link them to the woman who accused three of them of raping her at an off-campus party last month.

title: Judaism for the Cool?
description: To the Editor:

title: From hotel hell to heaven in Kiev
Experts See Peril in Reduced Monitoring of Nation's Streams and Rivers
description: When Michael Griffin thinks about the stream gauge on the Licking River at Catawba, Ky., he says he has an uncomfortable sense that history may repeat itself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOROWITZ, HENRY
description: HOROWITZ--Henry. April 11, 1994. Missing you and loving you every day. Linda and Family

title: Hazardous to Your Health
description: Our government needs to do much more to control potentially deadly substances -- plutonium, anthrax and high-fructose corn syrup.

title: Sunnis and Kurds Stand Firm on Opposition to Jaafari as Iraqi Prime Minister
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 10 - Sunni Arab and Kurdish political leaders on Monday rejected a last-ditch attempt by Shiite leaders to corral support for Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari and urged them to settle on another nominee to lead the next government, officials said.

title: In Stock Market, the Bears Gnaw at Iraq's Confidence
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 10 - Falah al-Ogaidy squinted through his glasses at the numbers scrawled across white boards at the Iraq Stock Exchange.

title: Content to Watch Bananas Grow, More Retirees Relocate to Panama
description: MIGRATORY retirees have lent more than a touch of gray to Florida, Arizona and Southern California. Next stop on the aging boomer bandwagon: Panama.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the rivalry between The New York Post and The Daily News misstated the role of Jared Paul Stern, a contributor to The Post's Page Six gossip column, in the criminal investigation of assertions that he tried to extort money from a businessman. While The Post is cooperating with the investigation, Mr. Stern is not. He said he had not been approached by the authorities.

title: They Said Immigration Could Be Fixed
description: To the Editor:

title: Australia foreign minister dismisses reports of Saddam kickbacks
Punitive damage award in Vioxx case
'Sickle,' a Tale of Russia by Sophia Romma
description: A few too many theatrical experiments are being conducted simultaneously in "Sickle," a drama by Sophia Romma that would be more powerful if it were less clever. The play jumps around in time, switches between real and imagined conversation, and gives one central character a distracting speech impediment that serves little purpose. Also, it's written, not very elegantly, in verse.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer at Merrill to Head S.E.C. Fund Unit
description: Andrew J. Donohue, a lawyer at Merrill Lynch, will lead the division of the Securities and Exchange Commission that regulates mutual funds and investment advisers, the S.E.C.'s chairman, Christopher Cox, said yesterday.

title: London Bombers Tied to Internet, Not Al Qaeda, Newspaper Says
description: LONDON, April 10 - A forthcoming government report concludes that the July 7 bombings in London were a low-budget operation carried out by four men who had no connection to Al Qaeda and who obtained all the information they needed from the Internet, The Observer reported Sunday.

title: Saying No Is a Patient's Choice, However Risky
description: The beep came between turkey and dessert on Thanksgiving. When I returned the call, I learned that my 81-year-old patient named Jeanette had briefly passed out.

title: Italy appears headed toward split parliament
Micron Profit Rises by 64%, Aided by Deal With Intel
description: Micron Technology, the maker of computer-memory chips, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 64 percent, helped by a gain from the sale of semiconductor designs and technology to the Intel Corporation. Net income increased to $193.2 million, or 27 cents a share, from $117.9 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier, the company, based in Boise, Idaho, said yesterday in a regulatory filing. Sales fell 6.3 percent, to $1.23 billion.

title: Rocket kills 6 Afghan children
Slide Show: More Than Words
description: A look at some of the children's shows produced by the National Theater of the Deaf.

title: Slide Show: Opening Day at Yankee Stadium
description: After a week on the West Coast, the Yankees finally came home to a sellout crowd in the Bronx.

title: Whither the New Viacom?
description: Tom Freston, the new chief executive of Viacom, seems unfazed by his new job, which is to steer the slimmed-down company into an unpredictable media future. Freston is confident that investors will learn to love the new Viacom.

title: Rating Skillings Court Debut
description: The trial of two former Enron executives entered an important new phase as Jeffrey Skilling, the energy companys former chief executive, took the stand in his own defense this week. He was nothing if not emphatic, declaring that he was absolutely innocent of charges that he conspired to defraud Enron and vowed that he would fight the charges until the day I die.

title: Fidelity Nearly Doubles Stake in Parent of American Airlines
description: Fidelity Investments, the worlds largest mutual fund company, has almost doubled its holdings in AMR since year-end to become the biggest shareholder in the parent of American Airlines. The 24.1 million shares of AMR, based in Fort Worth, represent almost 13 percent of the companys stock, Fidelity said yesterday in a regulatory filing.

title: Televisa Plays Starring Role in Univision Sale
description: Mexicos media colossus, Grupo Televisa, has long been looking for a way to increase its 10.8 percent stake in Univision, the dominant Spanish-language media company in the U.S. Now Televisa is working with investment banking firm Allen & Co. to structure a bid. At the same time, several private equity firms have been wooing Televisa to join with them in their bids.

title: French Banks May Try to Derail Bid for Euronext
description: A group of French banks is considering raising its stake in pan-European stock exchange Euronext in a bid to support embattled chief executive Jean-Francois Theodore, the Telegraph reported. The banks, believed to include BNP Paribas, are looking at making the move to defend their position and ensure that Mr. Theodore is not railroaded into a merger with Deutsche Brse.

title: Time Warner Making Moves to Boost Main Businesses
description: Time Warner, the worlds largest media company, may get rid of smaller units to help fund an expansion of its main businesses, CEO Richard Parsons said. Parsons, who will already reap more than $1.5 billion by selling a book-publishing unit and a stake in the AOL Web division, said he wants Time Warners larger units to remain in the No. 1 or No. 2 spots in their respective industries.

title: JBoss Buy Propels Red Hat into Prime Time
description: Red Hats announcement that it would buy JBoss for up to $420 million came as a surprise to many in the software industry. It wasnt because JBoss got sold. The surprise? That penny-pinching Red Hat was willing to pony up what some saw as a steep premium for a company that did $16 million in revenue in the last year.

title: Pipeline Giant Hooks Oil Field
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, the worlds largest publicly traded pipeline partnership, will spend as much as $115 million to buy and develop an oil field in West Texas from two closely held partnerships. Kinder Morgan is one of the biggest oil producers in Texas, averaging 53,600 barrels daily last year from its Sacroc and Yates projects in the state.

title: Frances Axa Plays Down Prudential Bid Chatter
description: French insurer Axa moved on Tuesday to quash market speculation it could bid for rival Prudential, saying it was not in talks with Britains second-largest life insurer on any tie-up.

title: Plastic Maker Royal Group to Sell More Assets
description: Royal Group Technologies will put more assets on the block, saying Monday it now expects proceeds from non-core asset sales of between $260-million and $300-million this year. The maker of plastic products used in home-building, which is being reviewed by the Securities Exchange Commission, said proceeds from sales so far this year were about $120-million.

title: Canadas Descartes Systems Buys Security Firm
description: The Descartes Systems Group, a provider of business software, has acquired Ottawa-based ViaSafe, a private company that develops secure electronic logistics services for global traders.

title: A Rule at eBay: No Human Skin Suits
description: Looking for a killer land deal? Better look somewhere other than eBay. The online auction giant recently halted an auction on land in Wisconsin that was once owned by Ed Gein, the murderer who inspired the classic Alfred Hitchcock movie Psycho.

title: After Asset Swap, J.P. Morgan Sitting Pretty
description: Breakingviews gives Jamie Dimons first deal as J.P. Morgan boss a thumbs-up:

title: Stars May Be Aligning for JMP Securities I.P.O.
description: JMP Securities is considering selling shares in an initial public offering, lured by the soaring shares of rival investment-banking boutiques such as Greenhill, Lazard and Thomas Weisel Partners.

title: Personalized Medicine Company Files for I.P.O.
description: Affymetrixs spinoff Perlegen announced that it has filed with regulators to hold an initial public offering of its stock, making it one of the first personalized-medicine companies to go public.

title: NetSuite On Track for I.P.O.
description: On-demand business software vendor NetSuite has confirmed that it is on target for an initial public offering around the turn of the year, which it hopes will see the company valued at $1 billion.

title: Chinas Dalian Port Hopes Oil Demand Will Fire Up Its I.P.O.
description: Chinas growing demand for oil will be a key selling argument for Dalian Port as it aims to raise up to HK$2.16 billion ($279 million) in an initial public offering ahead of a listing on Hong Kongs main board.

title: Ethanol Producers Plan I.P.O.s
description: Until now, public investors have had few choices when it came to investing in ethanol producers, with only a handful of listed companies out there. Sustained high commodity prices, however, coupled with President George Bushs recent endorsement of alternative energy, have inspired other ethanol plays to take their chances in the public domain as investor hunger for these assets grows.

title: California Hands Out First Stem Cell Grants
description: The California stem cell agency  armed with money borrowed from wealthy philanthropists  handed out its first research grants Monday, 17 months after voters approved borrowing $3 billion to fund the controversial science.

title: Kleiner Perkins Cleans Up Its Act
description: Silicon Valley venture capitalist John Doerr made his name and fortune with early investments in pioneering tech firms such as Sun Microsystems, Netscape and Google that went from scrappy start-ups to industry leaders.

title: WiMax Firm Aperto Picks Up  $43 Million
description: WiMax network equipment maker Aperto Networks has closed its Series E round of funding at $43 million, thanks to a $26 million follow-on from new investor GunnAllen Venture Partners. The new capital brings the total funding for the seven-year-old company, which has made noise about going public, to roughly $120 million.

title: Lawyer at Merrill to Head S.E.C. Fund Unit
description: Andrew J. Donohue, a lawyer at Merrill Lynch, will lead the division of the Securities and Exchange Commission that regulates mutual funds and investment advisers, the S.E.C.s chairman, Christopher Cox, said yesterday.

title: Russian Steel Maker Eyeing Bid for Arcelor Stake
description: The chairman of Russian steel maker NLMK, Vladimir Lisin, is interested in buying a stake in rival Arcelor and met Luxembourg Economy Minister Jeannot Krecke to discuss it, the Luxembourg daily Tageblatt said. Krecke told the newspaper that the Russian may want to buy into Arcelor, which is seeking to fend off a 20 billion euros ($24.3 billion) unsolicited takeover offer from sector leader Mittal Steel.

title: Small British Firms With Big Ambitions
description: A materials specialist whose products are saving the French police from blowing themselves up, a golf game that uses balls which you cannot lose, and a fledgling chain of upmarket childrens shoe shops are among Britains fastest growing, venture capital-backed companies. They all feature in new research conducted by Library House, which tracks high-growth private companies.

title: Pacific Venture Begins Fundraising
description: Pacific Venture Group, fresh off having a portfolio company stage one of the more successful initial public offerings in recent memory, expects to seek $200 million from its limited partners for a third fund.

title: Venture Firms Fit Jigsaw With Funding
description: Jigsaw Data, which built an innovative, user-created database of business contacts for salespeople, announced a $12 million third round of funding on Monday. The funding round was led by Austin Ventures and also included previous investors El Dorado Ventures and Norwest Venture Partners.

title: L.B.O.s Double Down in First Quarter
description: Despite closing only a few high-profile deals, the leveraged buyout market forged ahead in the first quarter of this year as buyout shops began to put all the money theyve raised over the past several years to work. The total value of completed L.B.O.s reached $33.54 billion in the first quarter, double the $16.88 billion recorded a year earlier, and the number of deals almost tripled to 141 from 54.

title: Promethean Fires Up Bid for British Bank
description: Promethean, the investment vehicle of Sir Peter Burt, the former Bank of Scotland chief executive, has made a 164 million pound bid approach to London Scottish Bank, the sub-prime moneylender. The discussions are at an early stage and no formal offer has been made, but Mr. Bart is keen to secure the support of London Scottishs management and a board recommendation for its mooted bid.

title: Wal-Mart Promises to Limit Its Banking
description: Wal-Mart Stores arrived in Arlington, Va., Monday with a reassuring message for banking regulators: It promises that it will never, ever open bank branches. That pledge could prove crucial for Wal-Mart, whose banking ambitions have sparked considerable protest and prompted the first public hearing in the 73-year history of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which would regulate a Wal-Mart bank.

title: Zale Says It Is Target of Inquiry by S.E.C.
description: Zale, the largest U.S. jewelry retailer, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started a probe into the companys accounting, executive pay and other matters. Shares of Zale fell $2.64, or 9.5 percent, to $25.16 in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Top A.I.G. Lawyer Moves On
description: The top lawyer at American International Group, Ernest T. Patrikis, will leave to join the law firm Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman after helping A.I.G. resolve state and federal accounting investigations. Mr. Patrikis, who was A.I.G.s general counsel, will run the regulatory practice for Pillsbury Winthrops financial services clients in New York, the firm said yesterday in a statement.

title: N.Y.S.E. Lawyer May Be Requestioned Over E-Mail
description: Richard Bernard, general counsel for the New York Stock Exchange, may be questioned further about the compensation case brought by Attorney General Eliot Spitzer against Richard A. Grasso, the former exchange chairman, a judge indicated in court Monday.

title: G.M. Details Fees in G.M.A.C. Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation said Monday that it expected to receive some $100 million a year in fees under the terms of a deal to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. G.M., which agreed to sell a 51 percent stake in the finance unit to a consortium led by the hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management, outlined the fee payments and the agreed profit-sharing framework yesterday in a filing with regulators.

title: Skilling, on the Stand, Implies Fraud Was Hardly Necessary
description: Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, took the stand in his own defense on Monday and declared that he was absolutely innocent of charges that he conspired to defraud Enron. He vowed that he would fight the charges until the day I die.

title: Safeway Rings Up $315 Million in Settlement
description: Safeway, the third-largest U.S. grocery chain, said Monday it expects to receive about $315 million in cash in the second half of 2006 after settling a federal income tax refund claim with the Internal Revenue Service. Safeway said the settlement relates to its claim for refunds in 1992 through 1999 for costs associated with debt financing.

title: VNU Urges Shareholders to Accept Buyout
description: The battle over the future of VNU heated up Monday as the Dutch media companys management urged investors to accept a proposed 7.5 billion euro buyout and reject a rival plan put forth by a dissident shareholder. VNU, which owns the AC Nielsen market research business, said the offer, valued at $9 billion, from a group of private-equity firms, would provide investors with the certainty of a cash bid, as well as a premium to the current share price.

title: Where Brashness Doesnt Play
description: It may work for Michael R. Bloomberg as mayor of New York City, but introducing a C.E.O. style to governing Thailand has not prevented that countrys billionaire tycoon-turned-politician, Thaksin Shinawatra, from running into serious trouble.

title: Swedens Mythical Wallenbergs
description: Contrary to popular myth, the Swedish Wallenberg family are not billionaires. Nor will they benefit personally from the tie-up with the Australian bank Macquarie in their joint bid through the private equity firm EQT for the airport and railway food concessions of Select Service Partner being sold by Compass.

title: For Once, Jessica Simpson Fails to Promote Herself
description: Jessica Simpson appears to have another breakup in the works. Over what was once touted by its owner as a celebrity fashion label with the potential to hit $1 billion to $2 billion, theres now a legal war between a major licensee and Simpson. Tarrant Apparel Group has sued Simpson and master license owner Vincent Camuto for $100 million over Simpsons alleged failure to promote her lines.

title: Vector Climbs Aboard Inter-Tel Buyout Bid
description: Vector Capital, which has been actively seeking to acquire troubled public companies, has found a new target: telephone provider Inter-Tel. Vector is teaming with Inter-Tels founder and former chief executive, Steven Mihaylo, to back Mihaylos all-cash tender offer for the Tempe, Ariz.-based company. The alliance is in its early stages, and it isnt clear how much the group is willing to pay for Inter-Tel.

title: The Prodi Factor
description: As Silvio Berlusconi and Romano Prodi duke it out over the election results, Breakingviews takes a look at what a Prodi win will mean for Italys banks, utilities and M&A.

title: UBS to Buy Piper Jaffrays Private Client Unit
description: UBS, Europes largest bank by assets, agreed to buy the private client network of Minneapolis- based Piper Jaffray Companies for as much as $875 million to expand its wealth management business in the U.S. UBS will pay $500 million in cash and an extra $75 million depending on business performance, the Zurich-based bank said in an e-mailed statement Tuesday.

title: G.M. to Sell Isuzu Stake to Japanese Partners
description: GM announced Tuesday that it would sell its 7.9 percent stake in Japanese truck maker Isuzu to a group of trading houses and a bank in a continued effort to revive its ailing fortunes, though the two will continue their 35-year relationship.

title: Phoebes
description: Gilbert Whites Selborne Journal: Sunday, 11 April 1784: 29 9/10 1/2; 42; W. Wet & blowing, dark, wet.

title: The Terrifying Thought of McCain 2008
With Parents At the Helm, Companies Fly Higher
description: Parents care more for their kids than babysitters ever could. The same apparently applies to companies: Fortune magazine finds that corporations run by founder-C.E.O.s  think Whole Foods, Apple Computer or Capital One Financial  consistently outperformed the market.

title: United Airlines Jettisons Online Loyalty Site MyPoints
description: Just a few months out of bankruptcy protection, the parent of United Airlines has sold its online loyalty business MyPoints for $56 million in cash. That is not a lot of money for a major airline, and it is less than half of the $117 million that Uniteds parent, UAL Corporation, paid to acquire MyPoints in 2001.

title: British Brewer Dampens Takeover Talk With Fosters Binge
description: British brewer Scottish and Newcastle announced that it will buy the European and Russian rights to Fosters beer, which it has brewed, bottled and marketed under license since 1995.

title: Roundup: Bookers Uniformed Fund-Raiser
description: The Star-Ledger writes that Cory Booker is being attacked as a hypocrite by Deputy Mayor Ronald L. Rice for a planned $200-a-head political fundraiser for Newark police and firefighters. Mr. Booker has frequently criticized Mayor Sharpe James for the practice of raising money from municipal employees and has pledged to discontinue the practice if he becomes mayor.

title: Canal Plus Punts Soccer Club to Investor Group
description: French broadcaster Canal Plus will sell its Paris Saint-Germain soccer club to three investors, including Colony Capital and Morgan Stanley, for 41 million euros ($49.66 million).

title: Slide Show: On the Street
Bush Paves the Way for Good Ideas
description: In the course of reviewing Francis Fukuyamas America at the Crossroads and Bruce Bartletts Impostor, Alan Wolfe writes in the Chronicle of Higher Education that President Bush may be the most anti-intellectual president of modern times. Yet at the same time, argues Wolfe, a Boston College political science professor, the Bush presidency is a dream come true for the ideas industry. Why? Because the failures of the Bush presidency stem directly from its bad ideas. Which proves, of course, exactly how important ideas are.

title: Hedge Fund Opposes Casino Buyout  But Politely
description: D.E. Shaw is one of several hedge funds that lately have tried to wangle more money from a would-be acquirer through a pointed letter to the targets board. The difference this time is how cordial the fund is being.

title: Learn How to Use the New Tools
description: Find out how to get stock alerts, find investment ideas, track your portfolio and more.

title: Just Dont Talk to Her About the Mayor
description: Two weeks after Mayor Sharpe James threw the Newark elections into chaos by withdrawing from the race, things have finally settled for most of his allies on the council. All except one.

title: Just Cant Get Enough
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Cheese-Off
description: (Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times)

title: Muhammad Ali, the Brand, Sold For $50 Million
description: Muhammad Ali is taking his well-known name to the bank.

title: Merrill, Goldman Employees Charged in Insider Trading Scheme
description: A Merrill Lynch analyst, a Goldman Sachs associate and a worker at a BusinessWeek printing plant were charged with running an insider trading scheme that scored more than $6.7 million, prosecutors said at a press conference Tuesday.

title: French Bank Doubles Stake in Korean Financial Firm
description: French bank BNP Paribas acquired an additional 5.6 percent stake in the Shinhan Financial Group Tuesday, more than doubling its holdings in South Koreas number two financial services firm.

title: Nasdaq Buys 15 Percent Stake in London Stock Exchange
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market may have officially dropped its bid for the London Stock Exchange, but its latest move suggests the story is far from over.

title: The Rice Machine Roars to Life
description: Deputy Mayor Ronald L. Rice might not be the most visible mayoral candidate Newark has ever seen, but his campaign offices are up and running.

title: My Fathers War: Iraq Is Not Another Vietnam
description: [Photo: Capt. Smith, left, before his deployment to Iraq, and his father, Ed Smith, preparing to leave for Vietnam in 1965.]

title: Iran's Nuclear Status
description: The Times's David Sanger reports that the White House and international community must now decide how to respond.  (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Frogger in Real Time
description: Oh, man, this ones so funny, I splurted my orange juice.

title: How Scalia Is Wrong
description: In my last post I defended Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalias dismissal of those who believe that the Constitution is a living organism that changes over time in response to societal change. (In a speech in February, he called them idiots.) The Constitution, I explained, is a document, not a Rorschach test. As a document  something intended to convey a particular message, not all messages  it has its own proper meaning distinguishable from the meanings one might prefer it to have, and it is the obligation of interpreters to figure out what that meaning is.

title: A District Coming to Terms With the American Swirl
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  Valentina Pereda was sitting in the cafeteria of Greenwich High School here on the Friday morning of Feb. 3, counting down the last minutes of a study period she didn't need, complaining to her friends from English class that she wished something exciting would happen. Just then, she caught sight of several security guards dashing past her chair. "Oh, my God," she heard someone crying out. "Oh, my God."

title: Essay Stirs Debate About Influence of a Jewish Lobby
description: When John J. Mearsheimer, a 58-year-old political scientist at the University of Chicago, decided to take on the United States' support for Israel, he considered the subject too touchy to confront alone.

title: Officials Issue Rebuilding Guidelines for New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 12  Federal officials issued unexpectedly lenient guidelines today for rebuilding the flood-damaged homes of New Orleans, potentially allowing tens of thousands of homeowners to return to their neighborhoods at costs far less than they had feared.

title: Iran Says It Is Making Nuclear Fuel, Defying U.N.
description: TEHRAN, April 11  Iran announced Tuesday that its nuclear engineers had advanced to a new phase in the enrichment of uranium, and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and a series of the country's ruling clerics declared that the nation would now speed ahead, in defiance of a United Nations Security Council warning, to produce nuclear fuel on an industrial scale.

title: Adis for a Spanish Hotel Where They Dressed to Kill
description: MADRID, April 11  In the ritualistic world of bullfighting, perhaps the most solemn ritual begins about 90 minutes before anyone confronts a bull, as the matadors and their teams begin to dress for the ring.

title: Foreign Minister of Australia Rejects Reports About Kickbacks to Hussein
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 11  Australia's foreign minister on Tuesday dismissed as insignificant three separate reports that an Australian wheat company paid kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Rieslings From Germany Scale the Heights
description: THE sap rises. The swallows return. And without fail each year something in the spring air touches the nerve that causes me to crave riesling.

title: As Levees Rise Near New Orleans, Skepticism Falls
description: ST. BERNARD PARISH, La., April 11  Robert G. Bea reached down, picked up a bit of dirt and popped it into his mouth.

However, the Milan prosecutor heading up the investigation pledged to resubmit the extradition request once Italy's new government is in place.

A case in point is the Moonstruck Chocolate Company in Portland, Ore., which this year has expanded its baby livestock menagerie from just bunnies, lambs and chicks to include cows, turkeys, pigs and ducks. The collection, called Country Critters, has a chick filled with cinnamon-almond ganache, a pig filled with crunchy toffee, a mocha-filled turkey, a cow with a milk chocolate center and a duck and a lamb with extra-bittersweet fillings, making for candies that might please adult palates better than children's. title: GATLIN ENTERS REEBOK GRAND PRIX
description: In 2004, Justin Gatlin won the 100-meter dash in the Olympics in Athens. Last year, he won the 100 and the 200 in the world championships in Helsinki, reaffirming his position as track and field's best sprinter, or at least one of the two best. Gatlin, 23, became the first entry yesterday in the Reebok Grand Prix, an international meet June 3 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island. It will be the first outdoor race in New York for Gatlin, a Brooklyn native. Gatlin ran the 100 meters in 9.85 seconds in 2004 and 9.88 in 2005. The world record is 9.77 by Asafa Powell of Jamaica, set last June. FRANK LITSKY (NYT)

description: The city's Franchise and Concession Review Committee voted 5 to 1 yesterday to approve a reduction in the value of the city's two-year-old contract with Snapple. "The revised agreement only reinforces my position that this was a flawed deal from the start," said City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., whose representative voted no. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIG, MARTHA K.
description: SELIG--Martha K. The Columbia University School of Social Work notes with great sadness the death of Martha K. Selig, a 1939 graduate whose commitment and creative leadership in professional social work training and Jewish communal services inspired and advanced the continuing excellence of the School, the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, and the UJA-Federation network. A major force in the colaboration of JBFCS and the School in its Center for Social Work Practice, she helped strengthen vitally important links between practice and research. A former member of the School's Advisory Council, part time lecturer and esteemed alumna, her accomplishments will be long remembered. description: A former fund-raiser at a private school on the Upper West Side was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a former student, the police said. The charge came eight years after a similar accusation led to his defrocking as an Episcopal priest. The fund-raiser, Bruce Jacques, 57, was accused of molesting the student, who was 16 at the time, both at the Robert Louis Stevenson School, on West 74th Street, and in nearby Central Park last October. Prosecutors said Mr. Jacques fled to Malaysia and was arrested as he tried to re-enter the United States through British Columbia. After his arraignment yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court on one count of committing a criminal sexual act, a felony, he was ordered held without bail. In 1998, he was defrocked by the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut for conduct unbecoming a priest after a 13-year-old boy accused him of propositioning him, according to The Associated Press.

Mr. Finlayson's, a brass-heavy group called Common Thread, was more solemn, and, at isolated moments, more explosive.

title: Arts, Briefly; Moses Battles 'Miami'
description: Among total viewers, CBS stood atop the ratings mountain on Monday night, despite the challenge presented by Part 1 of ABC's mini-series "The Ten Commandments." But the ratings for the mini-series were nothing to sneeze at: from 9 to 11 p.m., "Commandments" brought in 13.76 million viewers. Over all, ABC placed second among total viewers, and tied for No. 2 with CBS in the 18-to-49 demographic. For the night, Fox eked out a win in that age group, which advertisers love. "Prison Break" (7.98 million) was second behind NBC's "Deal or No Deal" (14.17 million) among 18-to-49-year-olds in the 8 p.m. hour, and "24" (12.2 million) gave viewers time to readjust their opinion of President Logan (Gregory Itzin), from moron to evil mastermind, after last week's episode revealed that he was behind the terrorist attacks. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEAR, STANLEY
description: SCHEAR--Stanley, 77. Died peacefully at home at the Schear farmhouse in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on Saturday, April 8, of esophageal cancer. Since 2001, Stanley dedicated himself to the low-income elderly residents of Westchester County as the Director of the LIFE Program (Living Independently for the Frail Elderly) of Family Service of Westchester. For the preceding decade, Stanley directed the Bridge Fund of Westchester, a program that prevents homelessness by making it possible for at-risk individuals and families to stay in their homes and apartments. Before becoming a full time advocate for affordable housing, Stanley was renowned for twenty-five years as the owner and operator of Jespersen's Pastry Shop in Scarsdale Village, where his famed chocolate pastry, named for Sarah Bernhardt, brought joy to countless fans. Stanley was also well known as a community activist who believed that all people deserve the dignity of a roof over their heads, regardless of their race, income, age, or mental health status. An avid defender of the U.S. Bill of Rights, Stanley served on the boards of the Westchester County and New York State Civil Liberties Unions, as well as the Paul Robeson Foundation. Stanley founded and organized the annual Bill of Rights Day Celebration for high school students, which takes place at St. Paul's Church in Mt. Vernon, the site of the trial of Peter Zenger, which established freedom of the press. Stanley is survived by Doris Schear, his loving wife and life partner of 58 years, his daughter Rose Anne and sons Stuart and Mitchell, and their families. Stanley leaves behind many friends, admiring colleagues, and fellow activists who believe in the full promise of the American dream for all. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Stanley's honor to the Sunshine Fund of Famliy Service of Westchester, which meets critical needs of the low-income frail elderly, so they may live with dignity. Donations to the Sunshine Fund may be sent C/O FSW, One Gateway Plaza, Port Chester, NY 10573. Burial will be private, and a public memorial Service will take place at the Westchester Society for Ethical Culture on Saturday, April 29, at 1 PM. For more information, please write sschear@nyc.rr.com. The family will be receiving guests on Monday, April 10, and Tuesday, April 11, starting at 5 PM, and on Sunday, April 16, starting at 2 P.M., at 230 South State Road in Briarcliff Manor, NY.

Take the hyperexuberant choral outburst that concludes Symphony No. 3, an ode to the Soviet May Day celebration, composed in 1929 when Shostakovich was in his early 20's. Or the strange second movement of Symphony No. 4, which seems a brazenly satirical riff on a Mahler scherzo. Of the great 20th-century composers, Shostakovich may be the most inscrutable.

title: Touring Castiglioni's Studio
description: To Milan's list of design destinations, add the studio of Achille Castiglioni, now a museum. Here, he contributed to the design of some 150 products -- 14 now part of the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection in New York -- including such icons as the 1960 Sanluca chair and the 1962 Arco floor lamp, shown with Castiglioni, above left, and the 1957 Mezzadro stool, inset. The museum has five rooms with models and renderings, above right, preserved as Castiglioni left them when he died at age 84 in 2002. He got his professional start in 1944 working alongside his brothers, Livio and Pier Giacomo. Livio quit the practice in 1952, but Pier Giacomo continued the partnership until his death in 1968. "Achille was endlessly curious," said his widow, Irma. "He could look at an object and see it in a way no one else could." He drew inspiration from miscellaneous objects; a slipper gave rise to the Sanluca chair, she said. Gigliola Pigni, who teaches at a high school near Milan, said, "It's very easy to teach the visual history of design in Italy from a book, but very hard to convey the spirit of creativity," adding that she recently led students through the studio not only to show them the famous tables, lamps and chairs, "but what went into creating them." The Studio Museo Achille Castiglioni is at Piazza Castello 27. For hours and reservations: (011) 30-02-805-3606.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHIN, TSUNG
description: CHIN--Tsung. Age 80, died April 8, 2006, following a brief illness, at Seabrook Village in Tinton Falls, NJ. A longtime resident of Poughkeepsie, NY, and Associate Professor at the University of Maryland, he was born in Taiyuan, China, on April 4, 1926, to Jiren Chin and Shu-lan Duan. He received a B.A. degree from National Taiwan Normal University in 1953, an M.S. degree from UCLA in 1965 and a Doctor of Applied Linguistics degree from Georgetown University in 1971. At the University of Maryland he first served as diirector of the Chinese and Hebrew Program before it became the Department of Asian and East European Languages and Cultures. He was the author of many articles, teaching manuals and books on the Chinese language, linguistics and calligraphy. He also founded the Calligraphy Education Group (CEG), an organization under the Chinese Language Teachers Association. CEG has sponsored regular international conferences to promote the understanding of Chinese culture and language through calligraphy. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Yin-lien C. Chin, Professor Emerita of Chinese Studies at Vassar College, as well as two children, his daughter Hsiao-lien Chin and her husband, James R. Boardman, of Riverside, CT, and their two children, Thomas and Ann, and his son Stephen H. Chin and his wife, Margaret M. Lanning, of Bedminster, NJ. A viewing will be held at the Ely Funeral Home in Neptune, NJ on Saturday, April 15, from 9-11 A.M., followed by a funeral service at 11 A.M. The committal ceremony will take place at the Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery on Rt. 9 in Poughkeepsie at 2:30 P.M. that day. For more information, contact the funeral home at 1-888775-0567. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Calligraphy Education Group (CEG), C/O Dr. Yea-fen Chen, 2201 East Beverly Road, Milwaukee, WI. 53211.

title: Fries With That?
description: Sometimes it's all too easy to lose perspective in the modern world. On Tuesday, The Times reported that McDonald's has begun experimenting with a new way of routing menu orders at the drive-through window. The voice you hear at the squawk box comes not from an employee inside the restaurant but from a call center hundreds, if not thousands, of miles away. The order is then relayed to the front of the very restaurant where you are bodily present and filled as usual. A man who wants a Big N' Tasty in Wyoming and a woman who wants an Egg McMuffin in Honolulu may be placing their orders with the same teenager in California. Several customers, told of the fact, seemed taken aback.

Mr. Chand, an untrained artist who was once a road inspector, currently has an exhibition at the American Folk Art Museum, "Concrete Kingdom: Sculptures by Nek Chand," through Sept. 24. Commissioned by the National Children's Museum in Washington, D.C., the sculptures, similar to the ones in India, are installed with photographs of the original Rock Garden in Chandigarh. ("King" fell to No. 3 this week with 185,000 sales, a 65 percent drop.) At No. 2 is the 21st installment of the pop compilation series "Now That's What I Call Music!," with 334,000 sales; the "High School Musical" soundtrack (Disney), still going strong, is at No. 4 with 181,000. Pink's "I'm Not Dead" (LaFace) opened at No. 6, Bubba Sparxxx's "Charm" (Virgin) reached No. 9 in its first week, and the Flaming Lips, at No. 11, had their best sales week ever, with 48,000 copies of their new album "At War With the Mystics" (Warner Brothers). title: The Trojan Pension Bill
description: Pension reform was among the unfinished business left behind last week when Congress adjourned for a two-week recess. The Republican leaders' self-imposed deadline for completing the pension bill had been April 7. But long before that, the bill -- laden with special interests -- had ceased to be only about pensions. And as the lawmakers were preparing to go home, it became increasingly about tax cuts. Before the recess, Congressional Republicans renewed their efforts to pass another round of tax cuts, and it quickly became clear that they wanted more than would fit into one tax bill without busting yet another budget. And so they began "cross negotiating." That's Hillspeak for trying to move provisions from one bill into another. This time, they raised the possibility of stuffing the excess tax cuts into the pension reform package.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: India's industrial output rose 8.8 percent in February from a year ago, as factories produced more goods to meet growing consumer demand for refrigerators, motorbikes and televisions. According to data released by the government's Central Statistical Organization, manufacturing grew 9.5 percent in February, compared with 8.8 percent growth in January and 5.9 percent growth in December. Manufacturing accounts for more than three-quarters of the country's industrial output. The output of capital goods, which is an indication of the extent of industrial activity, rose 13.5 percent in February, and consumer goods output rose 12.4 percent. With the government forecasting another year of normal rainfall in the main June-to-September monsoon, industrial output is expected to grow further on rising consumer demand. (SARITHA RAI, NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERNBERG, PAULINA, M.D.
description: KERNBERG--Paulina, M.D. Weill Medical College of Cornell University and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our respected friend and colleague Dr. Paulina Kernberg, professor of psychiatry at Weill Cornell, and director of child and adolescent residency training and founder of the Children of Divorce program at Payne Whitney Westchester in White Plains. Dr. Kernberg was a noted authority on child psychiatry, particularly in the area of personality disorders, and her work helped challenge the conventional wisdom on the impact of divorce on children. Generations of faculty, staff and students were moved by her warmth, wisdom, clinical excellence and leadership. We are forever indebted to her for the outstanding contributions she made to our program and to our field. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Dr. Otto Kernberg, and her entire family. Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Dean Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Herbert Pardes President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Dr. Jack D. Barchas Chairman and Psychiatrist-in-Chief NY-Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Philip J. title: Arts, Briefly; Jean Cocteau Meets Jean Genet, and Trouble Follows
description: In another blow to the Jean Cocteau Repertory, the impoverished theater troupe on the Bowery, the first two weeks of its latest production, "The Maids x 2," at right -- Jean Genet's classic, which was to be performed in two versions nightly -- have been canceled because the company has not obtained the rights. The Cocteau troupe, which merged last month with Ego Po Productions of New Orleans to form the new partnership EgoPo/Cocteau, discovered the error after several press previews had taken place late last month, said Peter Finn, the chairman. Opening night had been scheduled for March 31. Before the merger, Ego Po presented "The Maids x 2" in New Orleans and Philadelphia, and Lane Savadove, its artistic director, said the company had obtained the proper rights for those productions and paid the fees but had lost all the paperwork when its theater was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. But Charles R. Van Nostrand, president of Samuel French Inc., the theatrical publisher, said that the New Orleans production had not been properly licensed, and that approval for the New York production had been further complicated because the application was received at the last minute. He said yesterday that discussions were still under way with representatives of the Genet estate. Mr. Finn said he had offered to write a personal check for any back fees and penalties. The first public performance of "The Maids x 2" was scheduled for tonight, but Mr. Finn said that he did not know if it would go on. BEN SISARIO

Once you get the hang of it, said Steve Beshara, the chief branding officer for TurboChef, "the fear factor subsides immediately." Frog Design gave the high-tech oven a reassuring retro look with an analog clock and a rounded porcelain-enamel door (available in six colors).
