description: Go Daddy Group, an Internet-domain registration company infamous for its risqu television ads, has hired Lehman Brothers to manage an initial stock offering, according to MarketWatch.

title: Australian Leader Questioned at Inquiry on Kickbacks
description: SYDNEY, April 13  In brief appearance before a commission investigating allegations that an Australian wheat company paid millions of dollars to the government of Saddam Hussein, Prime Minister John Howard said he had never seen any cables that had come in over six years which raised suspicions about the payments.

title: Slide Show: Honda Element SC
SanDisk May Pounce on Lexar
description: SanDisk, a computer memory manufacturer, has hired Morgan Stanley to explore a possible unsolicited bid for Lexar Media, according to The Daily Deal.

title: Under New Policy, S.E.C. Will Rarely Subpoena Reporters
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously adopted a policy on Wednesday to issue subpoenas to journalists only in rare circumstances and only after exhausting other avenues of investigation.

title: Michael Jackson Bailout Said to Be Close
description: Michael Jackson, the onetime pop-music king who has endured a lengthy slide toward insolvency, is close to a deal that would keep him from bankruptcy by refinancing hundreds of millions of dollars in loans, The New York Times reported. As part of the transaction, he will also agree at some point in the future to give up a part of a prized asset  a song catalog that includes Beatles hits  to the Sony Corporation, people briefed on the plan said.

title: Slide Show: Mitsubishi Outlander
Foxes and Ducks
description: Gilbert Whites Selborne Journal: Tuesday, 13 April 1784: 29 4/10; 38; W. Frost, ice, sun, hail-storms.Mutton per pound..5dVeal..5Lamb6Beef..4 at Selborne.

title: DaimlerChrysler Will Hold On to Part of EADS Stake
description: DaimlerChrysler, the German carmaker, plans to retain at least a 15 percent share in European Aeronautic Defense & Space  and maintain the French-German balance should it reduce its holding further, Daimlers chief executive, Dieter Zetsche, said Wednesday.

title: eBay Purchased $2 Million Stake in Meetup.com
description: eBay invested $2 million in social networking company Meetup.com, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Tuesday.

title: PC Was the  Smoking Gun Behind Insider Trading Charges
description: It was a complex global case that stretched from Croatia to New York to the Dominican Republic to Wisconsin, but for investigators it was a local computer that became a smoking gun.

title: NYSE Fines Goldman Unit
description: The New York Stock Exchanges regulatory unit said Wednesday it had fined Goldman Sachs unit Spear, Leeds and Kellogg Specialists $200,000. It said the fine was partly for failing to disclose one or more contacts with prospective listing companies.

title: UBS Brings Australian Strategist on Board
description: UBS Australia has hired Kenneth Allen as a senior adviser to the bank on policy and strategic issues in Australia, the U.S. and China. Between 2001 and 2006 Allen was the Australian consul general in New York where he was responsible for representing the countrys interest in the northeastern United States.

title: MedManage Gets Cash Injection
description: MedManage Systems raised $10.75 million in late-stage investment to support an online platform that links physicians with pharmaceutical companies seeking to broaden markets through distribution of samples. QuestMark Partners of Baltimore led the round for Bothell, Wash.-based MedManage.

title: More Women Are Enjoying Being Their Own Bosses
description: Women are the fastest growing demographic of entrepreneurs and more often than not they are going it alone. The businesses they choose often dovetail with their own interests or expertise, resulting in a wide variety of start-ups.

title: Google Chief Rejects Putting Pressure on China
description: Googles chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, whose company has been sharply criticized for complying with Chinese censorship, said on Wednesday that the company had not lobbied to change the censorship laws and, for now, had no plans to do so.

title: Hyundais Dreams of Glory Thwarted by Investigation
description: South Korean prosecutors have been questioning Hyundai Kia Automotive Group executives about allegations that their companies created multimillion-dollar slush funds to bribe politicians and that they engineered shady deals to facilitate a father-to-son transfer of corporate control in South Koreas second-largest conglomerate after Samsung.

title: Enron Prosecutors Aim to Rattle, Not Be Rattled
description: After methodically laying out their case against Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay over nine weeks and 22 witnesses, the Enron prosecutors now have to start all over.

title: Exxon Chairman Got Retirement Package Worth at Least $398 Million
description: Last years high oil prices not only helped Exxon Mobil report $36 billion in profit  the most ever for any corporation  they also allowed Lee R. Raymond to retire in style as chairman of Exxon Mobil.

title: Chairman of RadioShack Will Resign
description: Leonard H. Roberts said on Wednesday that he was resigning as executive chairman at RadioShack, which has still not replaced the chief executive who left two months ago because of questions about claims on his rsum.

title: Documents Show Link Between AT&T and Agency in Eavesdropping Case
description: Mark Klein was a veteran AT&T technician in 2002 when he began to see what he thought were suspicious connections between that telecommunications giant and the National Security Agency.

title: Hearing to Consider U.S. Actions in KPMG Case
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that he would hold a hearing into whether the federal government pressured the accounting firm KPMG to withhold legal fees for former employees who were indicted in a case involving questionable tax shelters. Federal prosecutors have accused 18 defendants, including 16 former KPMG executives, of scheming to defraud the Internal Revenue Service by setting up bogus tax shelters that helped wealthy clients evade $2.5 billion in taxes.

title: Morgan Stanley Bets Its Own Money With New Trading Team
description: Morgan Stanley has assembled a team of top bond traders to wager its own cash in the market, The New York Post reports. Though the move could irk the investment banks hedge fund clients, it is part of a larger trend in which Wall Streets biggest firms use their massive capital bases and access to cheap capital to place huge bets for their own accounts.

title: VNU Postpones Annual Meeting as Shareholders Weigh Buyout
description: Dutch media giant VNU abruptly postponed its annual shareholder meeting, a move that may not bode well for a private equity groups $9.2 billion proposal to acquire the company. It has rescheduled the annual meeting until June 13, more than a month after the May 5 deadline for the buyout groups tender offer.

title: Adelphia Tries to Speed Takeover With New Bankruptcy Plan
description: Adelphia Communications filed a new version of its plan to exit bankruptcy that was intended to smooth the way toward Time Warners and Comcasts joint buyout of the cable company. Creditors have been haggling over how they will divide up the spoils from the $17.6 billion deal. Adelphias bonds tumbled after the new filing, as the company lowered the estimated recoveries for creditors.

title: Will Shareholders Gain From Tycos Breakup Plan?
description: A breakup of the conglomerate Tyco International may not be the magic bullet company management needs to create value for shareholders, Newsday writes.

title: Integral Systems Heeds Call to Explore Sale
description: Satellite software maker Integral Systems, under pressure to put itself up for sale, told shareholders at its meeting last night that it has hired an investment bank to get the process started. The news, also disclosed in a regulatory filing, pleased the companys largest shareholder, which has been agitating for a sale since February.

title: InBev to Pay $1.2 Billion For More of Quinsa
description: InBev, the brewer of Stella Artois, agreed to pay about $1.2 billion for most of the shares it doesnt own in Quilmes Industrial, gaining a larger slice of Latin American beer revenue. InBev will increase its shareholding in Quinsa, as the company is known, to about 91 percent from 57 percent.

title: U.S. Buyout Activity Slipped in First Quarter
description: The volume of private equity deals in the United States continued its recent slide in the first quarter amid rising prices for companies, increased competition from corporate buyers and a drying up of acquisition targets. U.S. deals slipped to 173 acquisitions worth $30.7 billion, according to financial data provider Dealogic. That was down from 174 acquisitions worth $30.8 billion in the year-earlier period.

title: For Weills Proteges, a Tough Act to Follow
description: As Citigroup Chairman Sanford Weill ends a half-century career on Wall Street, his proteges, Charles Prince and Jamie Dimon, are struggling to match their mentors record of making money for investors. Shares of Citigroup, where Mr. Prince is chief executive, have stagnated in the past year or so, while shares of J.P. Morgan Chase, where Mr. Dimon is C.E.O., have risen, but not as much as many of its peers.

title: China Merchants Drops Merrill From I.P.O.
description: China Merchants Bank, the countrys largest credit card issuer, dropped Merrill Lynch from its upcoming $2 billion Hong Kong initial public offering, citing concerns of a conflict of interest.

title: Bayer Begins $20 Billion Bid for Schering
description: Bayer began its takeover bid for fellow German drugmaker Schering on Thursday with 16.5 billion euro ($20.01 billion) offer, slightly higher than the 16.3 billion euro it had previously proffered and Scherings board had recommended for acceptance.

title: Slide Show: Operation Cacti
description: A cactus rescue effort in Arizona reflects a movement in the Southwest toward regionally appropriate, drought-tolerant gardening.

title: Man Group Raises $2.3 Billion For Hedge Fund
description: British hedge fund manager Man Group said it has raised more than 1.3 billion pounds ($2.3 billion) in what it claims is the largest ever private client launch of a hedge fund product.

title: Zillow Improvements
description: At midnight Wednesday, Zillow.com turned on another feature that will probably draw more people to the real estate price-appraisal site. Type in an address for New York City, San Francisco, Boston, Las Vegas, Los Angeles or Seattle and youll get an aerial shot of the property, but at a 45-degree angle so you can see the building.

title: How 2008 Is Like 1968
As Nasdaq Weighs Next Move in London, Hedge Funds Pile On
description: After snapping up 15 percent of the London Stock Exchange and taking a hit to its credit rating, United States-based Nasdaq is reportedly preparing to increase its stake even more. Meanwhile, two U.S. hedge funds decided to follow Nasdaqs lead and add to their positions in the L.S.E.s stock.

title: Slide Show: Audi TT coupe
Ask Science
description: Nicholas Wade answered select reader questions regarding his article about regeneration in this week's Science Times.

title: History Repeats Itself  But Can We Change History?
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Apr. 13 column, The Past Meets the Future:

title: Alcoa Readies Sale of Home Exteriors Unit
description: Aluminum giant Alcoa announced Thursday that it plans to divest its home exteriors business. Lehman Brothers will advise Alcoa on the sale of the 1,400-employee unit, which pulled in revenues of about $600 million in 2005. The business, which produces vinyl siding as well as railings for decks, no longer fits with our core global building and construction business portfolio, Alcoa chairman Alain Belda said in a press release.

title: Taking Aim At Consultants
description: Time political columnist Joe Klein has a new bookPolitics Lost: How American Politics Was Trivialized by People Who Think Youre Stupidcoming out next week. On Times Web site, he offers a sneak preview. Perhaps unsurprisingly, the People Who Think Youre Stupid are political consultants. Klein begins his analysis with a speech Robert F. Kennedy gave on the evening Martin Luther King, Jr., was assassinated. (The online column links to the audio.) No modern politician could give this speech, Klein concludes, and the consultants are to blame. He writes:

title: Slide Show: Bentley Continental GTC
WH Smith Says Split Proposal Is No For Sale Sign
description: Shares of British bookseller WH Smith rose 5 percent on Wednesday after it said it would divide into two separate companies, one for its retail operations and one for its magazine and newspaper distribution business.

title: Hey, Isnt That .
description: John James may not have as much money as the other folks, as he puts it, but he has one unique asset: his father, Mayor Sharpe James.

title: Entrepreneurs Gain (Some) Leverage in Venture Deals
description: It is getting easier for entrepreneurs to attract venture capital. Not only are venture investors loosening up their wallets, but perhaps more tellingly, changes in financing terms are showing both that investor confidence is ticking up and that investors are willing to cede a little more power to entrepreneurs to get deals done, CFO.com reports.

title: The Money Trail, Continued
description: Apparently were not the only ones examining how Newark has spent the millions of dollars in job training money it receives every year from the federal and state governments.

title: Another Takeover Option for NYSE?
description: Liquidnet  the electronic trading service that enables block traders to deal directly with each other, bypassing the hassles that come with using traditional trading desks and exchanges  is readying a new product: Liquidnet H20, which will match unanswered block trades with activity from liquidity providers such as (for example) Ameritrade.

title: Slide Show: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Festen," "Guardians," "Tryst" and "In Delirium."

title: Moussaoui Takes the Stand
description: April 13 - Confessed al-Qaida conspirator Zacarias Moussaoui says he can't get a fair trial so close to the Pentagon.

title: Ampd Mobile Rings Up $150 Million In New Funding
description: Ampd Mobile, which describes itself as a provider of integrated mobile entertainment  for youth, young professionals and early adopters, announced Thursday that it has landed a grownup-sized third round of funding  $150 million, bringing its capitalization to more than $250 million.

title: News Corp.s Poison Pill Suit Settled  for Now
description: After reading News Corporations announcement on Thursday that it had settled a lawsuit from a shareholder group over the extension of its poison pill antitakeover defense, we felt a bit, well, unsettled. The reason is that, depending on the outcome of a shareholder vote in October, the legal battle may not be settled at all.

title: BFF: Cory and All of Newark?
description: (Damien Cave/For The New York Times)

title: Qualcomm Pays $1.8 Million to Resolve Merger Suit
description: Without admitting or denying allegations of gun jumping in its $608 million acquisition of Flarion Technologies, wireless technology company Qualcomm has agreed to pay the Department of Justice $1.8 million to put the matter to rest.

title: David Rocker, Short Seller and Lightning Rod, Will Retire
description: The man who built one of the largest hedge funds focused on selling stocks short  and made enemies of many companies in the process  has announced plans to retire.

title: A Heady New Place
description: Caf dAlsace on the Upper East Side.(Photo: Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times)

title: Nuclear Jihad: Khan's Legacy
description: Top US and UN Officials, experts and reporter David Sanger explain that today's nuclear reality might be even more dangerous than during the Cold War. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad: The CIA
description: CIA veteran Art Brown, experts and reporter David Sanger discuss the victories and failures of the US intelligence community in tracking and stopping AQ Khan. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad: Terror
description: The State Department Official for Arms Control and other experts discuss the threat of nuclear attacks by terrorists and what is being done to prevent them. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Preview: Nuclear Jihad Documentary
description: Nuclear Jihad airs Monday, April 17, at 8pm on the Discovery Times channel. (Video courtesy Discovery Times Channel/CBC)

title: Nuclear Jihad: AQ Khan
description: Pakistani leaders, experts, reporters and acquaintances of AQ Khan help us understand who he was and how he was able to do what he did. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad: Black Market
description: A former intelligence officer, experts and Mohamed ElBaradei of the IAEA discuss the threat of others filling the void left by the Khan network. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad: Khan's Clients
description: Top international officials discuss what the transfer of technology by Khan to rogue states means for international security. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad:  Pakistan's Weapons
description: Pakistani leaders, a CIA veteran, experts and reporter David Sanger discuss the threat of Pakistan's nuclear weapons falling into the wrong hands. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad: Making a Bomb
description: New York Times reporters William Broad and David Sanger and Harvard's Matthew Bunn explain some of the science involved in making a nuclear bomb. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Nuclear Jihad: Iran
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, a former defense intelligence officer and David Sanger of the New York Times discuss the question of a nuclear-armed Iran. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Mark Cubans IceRocket Finds New Home
description: IceRocket.com, a blog search tool backed by Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban, is about become the latest addition to Think Partnerships motley collection of Internet properties.

title: Nuclear Jihad: Khan's Flights
description: Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf discusses how he first began to suspect Khan was up to no good after he became Army Chief of Staff in 1998. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

title: Campaign Confusion
description: As Councilman Ras Baraka runs for re-election, he would like to take issue with, well, issues. The problem, he says, is that the mayoral candidates arent talking about them.

title: Reverse Engineering the Tax Relief Kit
description: The Treasury departments Tax Relief Kit is a propaganda and spin exercise on behalf of the Bush tax cuts. Its an embarrassing document in many ways. But it contains a couple of useful nuggets.

title: TD Banknorth to Buy  Interchange Financial for $480 Million
description: TD Banknorth agreed to acquire Interchange Financial Services Corporation for $480.6 million in an all cash transaction. Interchange is based in Saddle Brook, New Jersey, and had $1.6 billion in assets and $1.3 billion in deposits at December 31, 2005 and operates 30 branches in Bergen and Essex counties.

title: Sudan Invades Chad
description: Im heartsick at whats happening in Chad. As you may have seen in the news, a rebel army has invaded it, seized strategic towns and is now fighting with government forces in the capital of Ndjamena.

title: Domestic Arts and Sciences
description: No reason a coffee table cant keep your coffee hot. Or yield up a cold Coke, if youd rather.

title: The Fight for $80 Million, Phase II
description: Cory Booker sued the city he seeks to run today in an effort to quash two redevelopment agencies set up last month by Mayor Sharpe James and the Municipal Council.

title: Newark's Branch Brook Park
description: The Times's Damien Cave explores the tranquil urban escape of Newark's Branch Brook Park. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

title: Movie Minutes: 'Kinky Boots'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "Kinky Boots," a British comedy about a drag queen who saves a failing blue collar shoe factory.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Take the Lead'
description: Stephen Holden reviews "Take the Lead," starring Antonio Banderas as a dance teacher at a South Bronx high school.

title: Forget Barack, Run With Hillary
description: Its happened again. Just the other day I got to talking with a dedicated Democrat about 2006 and 2008. Within a few minutes the appearance of two names and the absence of a third reminded me of why the party may very well blow it despite the fact that every morning brings news of a further drop in the presidents ratings and a growing discontent with the administrations management of everything  from the Iraq War, to the environment, the Katrina disaster, foreign-owned ports, huge budget deficits, prescription drug benefits, corporate scandals, trigger-happy vice-presidents, authorized torture, inhumane prisons, Halliburton profiteering, domestic spying, strategic leaking, illegal lobbying practices, indicted congressmen, indicted administration officials, rising energy costs, under-funded education mandates, huge trade imbalances, know-nothing science policies and disinformation campaigns. This weeks revelation: the existence (or so Seymour Hersh maintains) of a secret plan to bomb Iran.

title: New Orleans Is Rising
description: Last week found me in New Orleans. In addition to my duty as a combat artist I also carry the designation of combat camera officer. The Marine Corps comcam community has an annual conference, and this year they brought it to this beleaguered city. Altruism was at the heart of the conference planners choice  lets give the Big Easy our business when they need it most. However, most of us were filled with trepidation about spending a week in a place perhaps more like a war zone than the actual war zones weve been in. That was until we arrived here. Wow, what a fabulous town!

title: Qaeda Bomber Is Reported Killed
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, April 13  A senior figure in Al Qaeda who was accused of taking part in the bombings of the United States Embassies in Tanzania and Kenya in 1998 was killed late Wednesday night in a Pakistani airstrike on a compound in the region along the Afghanistan border, two senior security officials said Thursday.

title: Frank Gibney, 81, Writer and Authority on Asia, Dies
description: Frank Gibney, a noted writer on Asian affairs who was an authority on the culture and business practices of postwar Japan, died on Sunday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 81.

title: 3 Deaths in China Reveal Disparity in Price of Lives
description: GUOJIATUO, China  He Qingzhi's teenage daughter, Yuan, and her two friends lived on the same street near the Yangtze River, attended the same middle school and were crushed to death in the same traffic accident late last year. After that, the symmetry ended: under Chinese law, Yuan's life was worth less than the others'.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,356 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: In Polls, Illegal Immigrants Are Called Burden
description: Americans see illegal immigrants as using more public services than they pay for and want the government to do a better job of controlling the borders, but they favor legal status for current illegal immigrants under specific conditions, according to national polls released this week.

title: White House Mulls How to Move Immigration Bill Through Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  The White House is fast at work recalibrating how best to use the power of the presidency to save immigration legislation from languishing for the rest of the year, eager for a victory in what has been a difficult political season for President Bush.

title: Berlusconi's Election Fight Seems All but Over
description: ROME, April 14  Silvio Berlusconi's fight to remain prime minister appeared all but over today after the Interior Ministry announced a far smaller number of contested ballots in this week's narrow elections.

title: Berlusconi's Allies Start to Question His Insistence on Recount
description: ROME, April 13  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi seemed increasingly isolated on Thursday as even some allies cast doubt on whether a recount would change his narrow loss in last weekend's parliamentary elections, and on his claims of widespread fraud.

title: World Briefing: Americas, Africa, Europe and Asia
description: AMERICAS

title: 36 Hours in North Bennington, Vt.
description: NORTH Bennington, in the southwestern corner of the state, epitomizes preserved, picturesque Vermont. But behind the frozen-in-time beauty, the village subtly offers up big-city perks, accessible nature and bottomless history. The mills that sprouted along Paran Creek in the late 1700's are today the spare, loftlike structures that lend the village its modernity. Nearby Bennington, site of a Revolutionary War battle, is the home of one of the country's top private colleges. And then, of course, there are the woods, a living evocation of Robert Frost's most famous poems.

title: Insurgents Ambush Iraqi Police Convoy
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 14  A large Iraqi police convoy was ambushed Thursday night by insurgents just north of Baghdad after being refused permission to stay overnight on an American military base, an Iraqi police commander said today.

title: Young Nepalese Lead Their Nation's Push for Democracy
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 13  The Nepalese New Year dawns on Friday, with Nepal's young lashing furiously at the past.

title: U.S. Investigates Sale of Secret Data in Afghan Market
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 13  The American military said Thursday that it had ordered an investigation into reports that military data was being sold in an Afghan bazaar outside the main American air base at Bagram, north of Kabul.

title: Forget Computers. Here Comes the Sun.
description: Correction Appended

title: Students to Get No Warning Before Searches
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that police officers with metal detectors would conduct unannounced sweeps of students and their bags at middle schools and high schools throughout the city beginning later this month.

title: Complex Equation Determined Rules for Rebuilding in New Orleans, Federal Officials Say
description: The long-awaited flood advisories for rebuilding in New Orleans that the government announced Wednesday were met yesterday with a measure of relief  and confusion.

title: Setting His Sights High, on the Bottom Line
description: NOW we can count Diet Snapple lemon iced tea and playtime at the $168 million water park destined for Randalls Island among the many sacrifices  his golf handicap, the guilty pleasures of waist-threatening midnight pizza, and his private-sector investment-banker earning power spring to mind  that William C. Thompson Jr., chugging confidently along in his second term as New York City's upwardly mobile comptroller, is making for the sake of his career as a public servant.

title: Iran's Leader Calls Israel a 'Constant Threat'
description: TEHRAN, April 14  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said today that Israel is a "constant threat," and predicted that the Jewish state is on the verge of "elimination."

title: Helping Save Prickly Victims of Development
description: CATALINA, Ariz.  The operation began military-style at the crack of dawn. Bearing welders' gloves, shovels and tweezers for medical emergencies, the brigade of 40 moved across the desert, undaunted by rattlers, in single-minded pursuit of their well-defended targets.

title: German Tourist at Disney World Dies After an Amusement Ride
description: A 49-year-old woman who had become ill at Disney World after going on an amusement ride that simulates a space launching died Wednesday.

title: Australian Chief Denies Seeing Cables on Payoffs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 13  In a brief appearance before a commission investigating accusations that an iconic Australian wheat company paid millions of dollars to the government of Saddam Hussein, Prime Minister John Howard said he had never seen any of the cables over a six-year period that raised suspicions about the payments.

title: Hearing for Muslim Barred by U.S.
description: Government lawyers clarified some mysteries yesterday and deepened others in the case of Tariq Ramadan, a Swiss Muslim scholar and leading European theologian of Islam who has been barred by the Bush administration from traveling to the United States since July 2004.

title: Internal Report Urges Changes After Katrina
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Federal Emergency Management Agency, whose response to Hurricane Katrina last year was widely criticized, must train its employees better, improve its computers and get more support from the Department of Homeland Security, a department inquiry concluded today.

title: Militant Uprising at Jordanian Prison Is Quelled
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, April 13  Jordanian security forces stormed a high security prison outside Amman on Thursday, quashing a daylong uprising by Islamist prisoners and leaving one inmate dead and more than 35 guards and inmates wounded, government officials said.

title: Blasts at Famous India Mosque Injure 13
description: NEW DELHI, April 14  A pair of home-made bombs were set off in the courtyard of the capital's most important mosque this evening, injuring 13 worshippers but sparing the congregation from the kind of carnage and chaos caused in previous blasts in this country.

title: Moussaoui, Testifying Again, Voices Glee Over Witnesses' Accounts of Sept. 11 Grief
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 13  Zacarias Moussaoui took the stand Thursday for the second time in his sentencing trial and told the jury of the delight he had felt in hearing witnesses testify this week about their pain and grief from losing loved ones in the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Naughty and Nice: Bettie Page Beyond the Va-Voom
description: FOR a few blissfully underdressed years in the 1950's, Bettie Page was the pinup queen of the universe, or at least of lockers, garage walls and private stashes across the country. Blessed with a killer body and the perkiest smile this side of Sandra Dee, Ms. Page (she turns 83 this month) looked equally at ease wearing a homemade bikini or a fine mist of ocean spray. And while few people looked as happy naked as she did  the young actress Gretchen Mol, who plays her in Mary Harron's exuberant biographical film "The Notorious Bettie Page," comes charmingly close  in 1957 she buttoned her sweater for good, leaving the neon world of titillation and tease without a trace.

title: Italy Feasts on Details of the Phantom's Life on the Run
description: MILAN, April 14  For 43 years Italians knew so little about Bernardo Provenzano  the boss of all bosses of the Sicilian Mafia who had eluded escape for as many years  that investigators had nicknamed him the Phantom.

title: Seeing Plausible Target, Republicans Take Aim at a Democratic Seat in South Carolina
description: ROCK HILL, S.C.  Ralph W. Norman, a wealthy developer from the bedroom suburbs south of Charlotte, N.C., happily greeted local Republican leaders on the sunny lawn outside a strip-mall restaurant where he was to announce his run against John M. Spratt Jr., a 12-term Democratic congressman.

title: Bear Kills 6-Year-Old Girl in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. April 14  Game wardens in a remote Tennessee forest set traps baited with doughnuts and sardines today to lure a bear that attacked an Ohio family, killing a 6-year-old girl and mauling her mother and 2-year-old brother, the authorities said.

title: Al Qaeda's Man in Iraq Gets Encouragement From His HQ
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 13  Osama bin Laden's top lieutenant has released an Internet video calling on Iraqi insurgents to remain strong in the fight against Americans and praising the leadership of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the Jordanian militant who directs Al Qaeda's operations in Iraq.

title: Woman Who Died on Disney Ride Had High Blood Pressure
description: Hiltrud Bleumel, the 49-year-old German tourist who died Wednesday after riding on the Mission: Space attraction at Walt Disney World in Florida, was killed by "hypertensive" bleeding in the brain, the Orange County medical examiner said today.

title: Elderly Man Killed in Coptic Church Attacks in Egypt
description: CAIRO, April 14  Men wielding machetes attacked worshippers in three Coptic churches in the port city of Alexandria this morning, killing an 80-year-old man and wounding at least 6, the police there said.

title: Chad Threatens to Expel Sudanese Refugees
description: N'DJAMENA, Chad, April 14  A day after rebels infiltrated the Chadian capital, President Idriss Deby angrily broke off relations with Sudan today and threatened to oust 200,000 Sudanese refugees now in Chad to express his fury at what he called a Sudanese-inspired attempt to unseat him.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Today's Russian Newspapers
description: A summary of the top stories in the Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.

title: In the Nile Delta, Bird Flu Preys on Ignorance and Poverty
description: KAFR EL SHEIK IBRAHIM, Egypt, April 11  Given the choice between the possibility her children would fall ill from bird flu or the certainty they would go hungry if she got rid of the ducks she raised in her home, Hamida Abdullah said there was really no choice at all.

title: Europe Stalls on Road to Economic Change
description: BERLIN, April 13  After this week's extremely close election in Italy, there is a strong sense in Europe that, because of weak governments and divided publics, the Continent's big three countries are unable to make the economic changes that most political leaders agree are essential for restoring growth.

title: Nepal Protesters Shun King's New Year's Message
description: KATMANDU, Nepal April 14  The New Year here did nothing to lift Nepal out of its political crisis today, as leaders of the country's principal political parties denounced King Gyanendra's renewed offer of dialogue and vowed no let-up in the protests that have gripped this nation for more than a week.

title: Chadian Forces Repel Rebel Attack on Capital
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 13  Armed rebels entered Ndjamena, the capital of Chad, before dawn on Thursday, but government troops beat them back in fierce fighting, prompting the embattled president, Idriss Dby, to take to the airwaves and declare, "The situation is under control."

title: In 'Hard Candy,' an Internet Lolita Is Not as Innocent as She Looks
description: More sour than hard, this highfalutin exploitation flick starts with an unsavory premise -- possible pedophile meets the jailbait of his dreams -- that quickly becomes downright unpalatable. Working from an expository, intellectually clotted script by the playwright Brian Nelson, lingering in the shadows of Ariel Dorfman and Neil LaBute, among others, the director David Slade opens his first feature with his camera trained on a computer monitor. There, a teasing pas de deux is unfolding between two Internet chatters, Thonggrrrrrl14 and Lensman319. She's young (hence the 14), precocious (she namedrops Zadie Smith) and seemingly as eager as he is. They arrange to meet, silent alarms screaming.

title: Arts, Briefly; Bye-Bye, Bucky
description: Even though his version of Queen's "Fat Bottomed Girls" earned praise from the judges, Bucky Covington, below, was voted off "American Idol" on Wednesday night. The hourlong results broadcast, in the unusual period of 8:30 to 9:30 p.m., drew an estimated 21.83 million viewers. Relative to the show's own smashing success, that audience was smaller than usual. But it was good enough to put Fox far ahead in first place for the night and do more damage to ABC's "Lost." Wednesday's episode of the plane-crash mystery revealed that the island had cured not only the paralysis of Locke (Terry O'Quinn) but also the previously terminal illness of Rose (L. Scott Caldwell). "Lost" delivered its lowest 18-to-49 rating of the season (15.15 million), but it was still strong enough to put ABC in second place in that measurement over all. On Wednesday, April 5, the day Katie Couric announced that she would be leaving the "Today" show, the program brought in 6.2 million viewers and held that audience for the rest of the week. That was an improvement over the Monday (5.7 million) and Tuesday (5.5 million) viewer totals. For the week as a whole, "Today" was in first place, as it always is, outpacing ABC's "Good Morning America" (4.8 million) and CBS's "Early Show" (2.8 million).

title: The Listings: April 14 - April 20; PARADIGM
description: Dance is not simply a matter of triple pirouettes, body-scooping Martha Graham contractions or sky-high leaps. There are other, perhaps even greater, pleasures to be had in dance, among them the burnished artistry that comes with age. And proof of that will be offered in performances, beginning on Thursday at Symphony Space, by Paradigm, a modern-dance company founded in 1998 as an outlet for the distinctive skills of older dancers. Several dance legends will appear, among them Dudley Williams, Martine van Hamel and Carmen de Lavallade, who will be seen in "Will's Ladies," a solo in which Ms. de Lavallade shifts fluidly from one Shakespearean heroine to another. There will be new dances choreographed by Ms. de Lavallade and Gus Solomons Jr., as well as one that Judith Ren-Lay created for herself. But the point, most of all, is the dancers, who also include Hope Clarke, Valda Setterfield, Stuart Hodes, Alice Teirstein and Keith Sabado (at left, above, with Mr. Solomons and Ms. de Lavallade). All are over 60, and most have performed with major modern-dance and ballet companies. Mr. Solomons, who runs the company, admits that he did let one youngster sneak into the fold, a 47-year-old named Michael Blake, who danced with Donald Byrd, Jos Limon and Alwin Nikolais. It is a rich legacy he and the other Paradigm performers are passing along. But there is an even simpler rationale for a company like this to exist. Mr. Solomons talked of a call he received from one dancer on the program, who had heard of the company and wanted to join. "I'm still strong," she said. (Paradigm will perform through April 22 at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org.)

title: Naughty and Nice: Bettie Page Beyond the Va-Voom
description: FOR a few blissfully underdressed years in the 1950's, Bettie Page was the pinup queen of the universe, or at least of lockers, garage walls and private stashes across the country. Blessed with a killer body and the perkiest smile this side of Sandra Dee, Ms. Page (she turns 83 this month) looked equally at ease wearing a homemade bikini or a fine mist of ocean spray. And while few people looked as happy naked as she did -- the young actress Gretchen Mol, who plays her in Mary Harron's exuberant biographical film "The Notorious Bettie Page," comes charmingly close -- in 1957 she buttoned her sweater for good, leaving the neon world of titillation and tease without a trace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNEY, BESS
description: BERNEY--Bess, 102. Died April 6 in Brewster, MA. She was the wife of the late Charles Berney. Mrs. Berney was born in Philadelphia. At age 18 she sang in the Metropolitan Opera Chorus in NY. She then attended the University of Southern California and worked with archeologist Charles Lummis on digs in New Mexico and Arizona. During WWII she worked with Margaret Mead at the Museum of Natural History in NY. She also had a working relationship with Eleanor Roosevelt while holding the title of Executive Director of the Women's Trade Union League. She also worked for ASCAP where she met most of the American composers of the early part of the 20th Century. She moved to Brewster 5 years ago to be near her daughter and son-inlaw. She left a beautiful family including a daughter, Letitia Ciolkowski of Brewster, two grandchildren and four great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERNBERG, PAULINA., M.D.
description: KERNBERG--Paulina., M.D. Of Scarsdale, NY, died April 12, 2006 at age 71. Born January 10, 1935 in Santiago, Chile to Isaac and Rebecca (Ostray) Fischer. Dr. Kernberg was an eminent child psychiatrist and psychoanalyst. She was a Professor of Psychiatry at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University and served as the former Director of Child and Adolescent Training at New York Hospital - Cornell Medical Center, Westchester Division. Dr. Kernberg was Supervising and Training Psychoanlyst at the Columbia Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research. Based on her numerous professional accomplishments, the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Services selected Dr. Kernberg to serve as a key consultant on the Elian Gonzalez case. Survived by her husband, Dr. Otto Kernberg, children, Dr. Martin Kernberg (Karrie), Dr. Karen Bardenstein (David) and Adine Varah (Sean), six grandchildren, Annessa, Ian, Daniel, Sarina, Sonia, and James; siblings Leon Fischer (Sylvia), Abraham Fischer, Tomas Fischer (Evelyn), Violetta Berdichevsky (Manuel), and the late Mauricio Fischer (Raquel). Funeral service today, Friday at 10:00 A.M. at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains, followed by internment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Camp Koby or Personality Disorders Institute, Weill Cornell Medical College, for the study of personality disorders in adolescents.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Mad Cow Case Suspected

If confirmed, it would be the fifth case of the brain-wasting disease in cattle in Canada since 2003, when the first case caused the United States to ban Canadian beef until July 2005. No part of the cow being tested entered the human or animal food or feed chain, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency said. CHRIS MASON (NYT)

description: City Councilman Hiram Monserrate raised questions yesterday about the financing for the new Yankees and Mets stadiums, which would require the city to issue tax-exempt bonds that would be repaid by the teams through payments in lieu of taxes. Mr. Monserrate, whose district includes the site for the new Mets stadium, has asked that the Internal Revenue Service provide clarification on the tax implications of the stadium financing and ensure that it complies with federal laws. He has also lobbied for the Mets to provide additional benefits to the area nearby in return for building the stadium. The City Council is expected to vote on the financing plans on April 26. title: Houses of Straw
description: Men and women, families with small children and elderly relatives who have never lived outside of southern Louisiana are exiles in their own country more than seven months after Hurricane Katrina made land. They want answers about where and how to rebuild, and some, especially a vocal minority, already know what they want said: just the way it was before. This page has been heartened by the Bush administration's support for the rebuilding effort, including generous federal financing for homeowners who want to restore their old neighborhoods. But compassion needs to be leavened with responsibility. Officials need to get the word out that things will not be the way they were before.

title: The Listings: April 14 - April 20; SABADO DE GLORIA: ALL-STAR SALUTE TO THE GIANTS OF LATIN JAZZ
description: Sabado de Gloria is the Latin American version of Holy Saturday, which precedes Easter Sunday on the Roman Catholic calendar. It's a day of anticipation and renewal, cleansing water and purifying fire. (Also vengeful fire: the burning of a Judas effigy, often part of the celebration, is a custom unlikely to be hindered by recent debates about his innocence.) So it may seem exceedingly bold for the Central Brooklyn Jazz Consortium to schedule a blowout Latin jazz concert for tomorrow night, and to call it Sabado de Gloria. But there is an idea at work here: the concert pays tribute to the departed heroes of Latin jazz, with an explicit dedication to the King of Mambo, Tito Puente. (You can only assume that the percussionists Ray Barretto and Don Alias, who both died this year, will be honored as well.) Among the all-stars assembled for this purpose are Dave Valentin, one of the leading flutists in Latin music; Hilton Ruiz, a versatile and articulate pianist; Giovanni Hidalgo, above, a well-traveled percussionist; and Papo Vazquez, an audacious trombonist. The Cuban drummer Dafnis Prieto and the Puerto Rican bassist John Benitez will represent a newer generation of Latin players; the trumpeter Randy Brecker and the alto saxophonist Sherman Irby will represent the so-called jazz mainstream. In terms of repertory, the concert will draw from both sides, with an emphasis on musician-bandleaders like Rafael Hernndez Marn, Charlie Palmieri and Freddie Hubbard. The only voices unheard, it seems, will be those Catholics who maintain that Holy Saturday should be the quietest day of the year. (8 p.m., Kumble Theater for the Performing Arts, 1 University Place, Long Island University, Flatbush Avenue Extension and DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, (718) 488-1624; $65, $75 and $100.)

title: A 'Mountain Patrol' Struggles to Save Antelopes From Poachers (and Fashionistas)
description: The mountains that rise from the Tibetan plateau make a suitably dramatic backdrop for this story about the murderous cost we humans exact on the natural world. Based on depressingly true events, "Mountain Patrol: Kekexili" tracks the heroic efforts of a small group of Tibetans struggling to keep the Tibetan antelope, or chiru, from extinction. Although hunting the antelope was made illegal in the 1970's -- you need to kill the animal to harvest its wool, which is turned into a rare commodity called shahtoosh -- the population dwindled precariously, beginning in the late 1980's and early 90's, because enough wealthy consumers had no qualms about hitting the boldface scene with shahtoosh on their shoulders and blood on their hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLT, NICHOLAS
description: HOLT--Nicholas, 78, architect, AIA, died April 10, in Bangor, Maine after a long and vigorous life and a final struggle with Pick's Disease. He grew up in Maine and Dongan Hills, Staten Island, graduated from the Putney School in 1945 and from Princeton in 1949 where he continued graduate studies in architecture. Holt loved music and the arts, pursued political and social change, and enjoyed sailing and outdoor adventures. He served in US Army Intelligence under General MacArthur in Japan 1946 -1947. Marrying Patricia Ann Green of New York in 1960, he settled in Ellsworth, Maine and raised three daughters. Early in his architectural career, his design of the Knowlton School brought him to Ellsworth in 1958 where he opened Krumbhaar & Holt, the easternmost architectural firm in the US. Building a thriving practice statewide, his designs became known for energy conservation and innovation in affordable housing, nursing homes and schools. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Patricia Holt of Ellsworth, brother Thurston of Cape Elizabeth, ME, sister Margaret Wurlitzer of Milwaukee, and his daughters Victoria Holt of Washington D.C., Christina Holt of Portland, ME, Rebecca Holt of Nyack, NY.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BOUCHARD, MORTON S. JR.
description: BOUCHARD--Morton S. Jr., (Retired President & CEO of Bouchard Transportation Co., Inc.) of Hobe Sound Florida passed away suddenly on Tuesday, April 11, 2006. Morton was a long-time resident of Long Island New York prior to becoming a resident of Florida in 1988. Morton graduated from LaSalle Military Academy, Oakdale, New York and went on to attend Hofstra University prior to joining the U.S. Navy. Upon completion of his naval obligations, Morton joined his father, Morton S. Bouchard Sr., and his brother Fredrick Bouchard at Bouchard Transportation Co., Inc. In 1972, Morton took the helm at Bouchard Transportation Co., Inc. and guided its growth to become the largest independently owned ocean going petroleum Barge Company in the United States. In the years 1972-1983 Morton is credited with building the largest petroleum barges to service the Northeast and Gulf Coast Petroleum infrastructure, and provide the petroleum industry with efficient and environmentally safe transportation. Morton was the past recipient of the American Legion, Robert L. Hague Post, Maritime, Man of the Year. Morton was involved in bringing the Senior/Champions tournament to Long Island and developed a unique friendship with various professional golfers and went on to build the Bouchard Family Learning and Child Center at the Chi-Chi Rodriguez School in St. Petersburg Florida. Morton, throughout his professional and retired life was always there for various underprivileged children's organizations and believed that every child deserved a chance to grow both mentally and athletically. Morton had a passion for golf and passed away on the 18th tee of his favorite club. Morton is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 52 years, Jane, and four children, Kim Bouchard, (Palm City, FL), Morton S. Bouchard III, his wife Linda (Huntington, NY), Donna Glover, her husband Rick (Dix Hills, NY) and Denise Foxen, her husband Bill (Cold Spring Harbor, NY), 13 grandchildren and one great grandchild. In lieu of flowers, the Family has asked for donations be made to The Schneider's Children Hospital, the beneficiary of the Long Island Golf Champions, in the name of Morton S. Bouchard Jr. (address: 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021, (516) 465-2550. VISITATION IS: Friday, April 14, 2006 Young Prill Funeral Home 6801 S.E. Federal Highway Stuart, FL 34997 Phone: 772-223-9300 Time: 1:00 -3:00 PM Services in Funeral Home: 2:00 PM.

title: The Listings: April 14 - April 20; YI CHEN
description: Using cut-up photographs from Chinese and Western fashion magazines, Yi Chen creates fragmented fantasy portraits. Then on canvas he paints large copies of those collages in which the mismatched eyes, noses and mouths are realistically rendered, while other areas of the face, as well as hair, clothes and backgrounds, are loosely painted with broad brushes. The result is a savvy mix of modern styles: Cubism, Surrealism, Expressionism and Pop. The images also have a strange, monstrous glamour, a zany humor and an unexpected pathos. With her sad, soulful eyes, swatch of purple hair and radiant green, Constructivist background, "Holly Rejuvenation," above, could be a Postmodern Madonna. Mr. Chen was born in Beijing at the end of the Cultural Revolution, attended the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design, earned an M.F.A. degree at the State University of New York at Purchase and now lives in New York City. His paintings might be oblique meditations on the extreme shifts of cultural perspective he has had to adjust to in his life. Certainly, they have something to do with everyone's struggle to maintain a unified sense of self in the face of the constant barrage of social and cultural dissonance that is modern experience. (Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9889, through tomorrow.)

The renewed interest comes after a public re-enactment of the killings last July organized by civil rights leaders. title: Comedy Fortnight
description: When a guy in a Fudgie the Whale suit (impersonating the otherwise inanimate Carvel ice-cream-cake celebrity) finds himself attracted to a shy college student, he has to work extra hard to win her. And he has only 26 minutes to do it in David Baeumler and Drew Martin's film "Fudgie & Jane" (2003), starring Jonathan Frappier and Olivia Griego, above. It's one of the love-story shorts selected by the Chicago City Limits comedy troupe for the self-confidently titled "Best of First Sundays: A Hilarious Retrospective." In addition to the romantic comedies (described as the group's "favorite movies about love, romance and stalking"), there are evenings devoted to documentary, animated and low-budget shorts. (The low-budget one is followed, appropriately, by a beer-and-pizza reception with the filmmakers.) The Chicago City Limits retrospective is, in turn, part of the Two Boots Pioneer Theater's Comedy Fortnight, which runs through April 26. Its centerpiece is Brant Sersen's "Blackballed: The Bobby Dukes Story," a mock documentary about a disgraced paintball champion, played by Rob Corddry of "The Daily Show," who follows Steve Carell and Stephen Colbert in the diaspora of that show's cast. The series also includes clips from the New York video blog Rocketboom and screenings of Woody Allen classics, including "Manhattan" (1979), in which Mr. Allen's middle-aged character is torn between the high school girl he's been sleeping with and the woman his best friend loves. 155 East Third Street, at Avenue A, East Village, (212) 591-0434; $6.50 to $9.

36 Hours in North Bennington, Vt.
description: NORTH Bennington, in the southwestern corner of the state, epitomizes preserved, picturesque Vermont. But behind the frozen-in-time beauty, the village subtly offers up big-city perks, accessible nature and bottomless history. The mills that sprouted along Paran Creek in the late 1700's are today the spare, loftlike structures that lend the village its modernity. Nearby Bennington, site of a Revolutionary War battle, is the home of one of the country's top private colleges. And then, of course, there are the woods, a living evocation of Robert Frost's most famous poems. LAURA RASKIN

The I.R.S.'s Shotgun Marriage
description: Richmond - THIS tax season some 100 million married Americans will sign joint tax returns. Few understand the consequences. In signing a joint return, each spouse becomes responsible for the taxes due on both spouses' earnings for the year. That means that if a husband who is his family's sole breadwinner underreports his income and then abandons his wife, the I.R.S. can, and often does, go after the wife. Thus, the "innocent spouse" may be liable for taxes, interest and penalties on income she never earned and never owned.

Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Senyszyn also embezzled income derived from several real estate projects, Mr. Christie said. Mr. Senyszyn, a certified public accountant who was assigned to audit large- and mid-size businesses at the Internal Revenue Service offices in Paterson, was suspended without pay in February 2005, prosecutors said. A call to his lawyer was not returned last evening.

Among a certain clique of mothers-in-the-know (media feminists, mommy bloggers, Urban Baby posters), Flanagan isnt just disliked  shes reviled, Paul writes. These critics often say they dislike Flanagan, whose writings focus on the choices and compromises made by affluent working mothers, because shes an elitistwith a nanny, housekeeping help, a gardener, and a personal organizerwho doesnt follow her own advice. But heres what I think really bothers Flanagans critics, Paul says. No matter how vociferously they disagree with her on some things, they find themselves agreeing with much of what she writes.

title: 'The Great Quake,' a Documentary by National Geographic

Before joining the board in 2003, Mr. Rosenker, a major general in the Air Force Reserve, was a deputy assistant to the president and director of the White House military office. He had been the board's lead investigator on the ground for several accidents, including the December crash of a seaplane in Miami that killed 20 people and the October capsizing of the passenger vessel Ethan Allen on Lake George, N.Y., which also killed 20 people. The governor of Alexandria, Gen. Abdel Salam Mahgoub, said on state-run television that a 25-year-old mentally unstable person carrying two knives attacked all three churches, wounding two men before his arrest by the Egyptian police. title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Curfew Lifted After 13 Years
description: The government lifted a midnight-to-dawn curfew for the first time since 1993, saying most of Burundi was stable after years of civil war. The curfew meant that Burundi's bars had long ordered patrons just before midnight to make a choice: leave immediately or spend the night. The curfew followed the assassination of Burundi's first elected president, Melchior Ndadaye. He was a Hutu and was killed by Tutsi paratroopers, setting off a civil war that left more than 250,000 people dead. A cease-fire was reached by the Tutsi-controlled government and the main Hutu rebel group in 2003. The rebel leader, Pierre Nkurunziza, was elected president by Parliament in August 2005. One rebel group is still fighting in one of Burundi's 17 provinces, rural Bujumbura. MARC LACEY (NYT)

title: Budget Daze in Congress
description: Amid all the other Washington dysfunction, who might notice a bit of meanness in which cultural programs for the deaf suddenly had their federal grants cut off? For starters, the first lady, Laura Bush, might. Mrs. Bush lavished praise on one of the beneficiaries of the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act -- the Deaf West Theater Company -- when she saw its much-praised Broadway production of the musical "Big River." Yet somehow in December 2004 the $2 million in annual grants for the theater and a half dozen other time-proven programs for the deaf were struck from appropriations in the lunchmeat-making process Congress calls budgeting. The result is that for the past 16 months the National Theater of the Deaf has been scrapping productions and cutting jobs and salaries to survive. No one has yet been able to identify the Congressional malefactor who thought the cut was necessary.

title: Lost and Found New York
Arts, Briefly; A Youth Imprint (Not Necessarily Christian)
description: Thomas Nelson, the Christian publisher that had a best seller last year with "Liberalism Is a Mental Disorder" by the talk radio host Michael Savage, said it had started an imprint intended for 18-to-35-year-olds with titles that do not necessarily have explicit Christian themes. The imprint, Naked Ink, will be run by Rebekah Whitlock, 26, and is to be part of the company's general trade book group. Naked Ink plans to publish five books this year, starting with "The Hot Mom's Handbook: Moms Have More Fun!" by Jessica Denay, to be released on Monday. In August, it plans to follow up with "The Hippie Guide to Climbing the Corporate Ladder & Other Mountains: How JanSport Makes It Happen" by Skip Yowell, a co-founder of JanSport, the backpack manufacturer, and "Love Letters to the South," a book of celebrity photographs accompanied by notes of condolence to victims of Hurricane Katrina. Ms. Whitlock said in an interview that she hoped the books would appeal to readers looking for "authenticity, community, discovery," and to people interested in film, music and other forms of pop culture. She said she chose the name Naked Ink because it seemed "synonymous with authenticity and vulnerability and transparency." Ms. Whitlock acknowledged that the name could also conjure more carnal imagery but said, "I hope that by pairing it with the word 'ink,' people will get it and what we're trying to do." MOTOKO RICH

title: Arts, Briefly; Another President With Sinking Ratings
description: "Commander in Chief," the ABC drama starring Geena Davis, below, as the first female president, was once this season's most successful new series, and Ms. Davis's performance earned her a Golden Globe for best actress. But that was six months and two executive producers ago. (First, Steven Bochco replaced Rod Lurie, the creator of the series, as the executive in charge of the show, and now Dee Johnson has taken over from Mr. Bochco.) On Thursday, a retooled "Commander in Chief" appeared for the first time since January, and the results were not pretty. It drew an estimated 8.2 million viewers, and in the 10 p.m. hour, was last among adults 18 to 49, behind CBS's "Without a Trace" (18.65 million) and a rerun of NBC's "ER" (6.03 million). It even lost viewers from its first half-hour (8.25 million) to its second (8.13 million), never a good sign. For the night over all, CBS's new episodes of "Survivor" (15.07 million) and "CSI" (23.91 million), combined with "Without a Trace," to give the network an effortless victory in Nielsen's estimates. KATE AURTHUR

title: Arts, Briefly; A Chess Rift Repaired
description: The match is on. Thirteen years after the chess world was fractured by Garry Kasparov's break with the World Chess Federation, creating two competing claims to the title of world champion, the split will finally be repaired at the chess board. The two main claimants to the title, Veselin Topalov, a Bulgarian grandmaster, and Vladimir Kramnik, a Russian who is also a grandmaster, have agreed to play a 12-game match from Sept. 21 to Oct. 13 in Elista, the capital of the Russian republic of Kalmykia. The $1 million prize is to be divided between the players, regardless of who wins, but the chess federation said this week that it would recognize the victor as the undisputed champion. Mr. Topalov, the world's No. 1 ranked player, is the federation's anointed titleholder, having won in a world championship tournament last year in Argentina. Mr. Kramnik, who is ranked ninth, bases his claim on a match victory in 2000 over Mr. Kasparov, the world's top player from 1985 to 2005. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: Business Digest
description: Broadcast Networks Challenge Indecency Ruling Related to Profanities on Television Programs Four TV broadcast networks and their affiliates have filed court challenges to a March 15 Federal Communications Commission ruling that found several programs "indecent" because of language. ABC, NBC, CBS and Fox, along with their network affiliate associations and the Hearst-Argyle Television group of stations, filed notices of appeal in various federal courts, including those in Washington and New York. The appeals challenge the commission's finding that profane language was used on the CBS program "The Early Show" in 2004, incidents involving Cher and Nicole Richie on the "Billboard Music Awards" shows broadcast by Fox in 2002 and 2003, and various episodes of the ABC show "NYPD Blue" that were shown in 2003. CBS also asked the F.C.C. to reconsider a proposed record fine of $3.6 million against dozens of CBS stations and affiliates for a 2004 episode of "Without a Trace" as well as a proposed $550,000 fine for the Janet Jackson "wardrobe malfunction" during the Super Bowl in 2004. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PELL, JULIA LORILLARD WAMPAGE
description: PELL--Julia Lorillard Wampage of Middletown, Rhode Island, died of lung cancer on April 13, 2006, at Newport Hospital surrounded by her loving family. She was born in Washington, D.C. on May 9, 1953. She is survived by her life-partner, Julie Smith, her step-daughter, Elise McCaffrey, her parents, former Senator and Mrs. Claiborne Pell, her brother and sister-in-law, Toby and Janet Pell, and her sister, Dallas Pell. She is also survived by her nephews, Nicholas Pell, Clay Pell, and Eames Yates, Jr., and her nieces, Tripler Pell and Christina Randall. Educated at the Potomac and Madeira Schools in Virginia and graduated from Montesano, Gstaad, Switzerland, she received her Bachelor of Arts from the University of Rhode Island. She served on the boards of the Newport Art Museum, the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, and the Potter League for Animals. She was President of the Board and the lobbyist for the Rhode Island Alliance for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights, and a founding member of Equity Action, a Field of Interest Fund at the Rhode Island Foundation. Julie was a civil rights advocate and passionate about improving the lives of the disenfranchised, the oppressed, and those less-fortunate. Her father, former Senator Pell spoke out on the Senate floor about his daughter Julie, a lesbian. He said he now had a more profound understanding of the discrimination she faced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the ACLU Foundation of Rhode Island, 128 Dorrance St., Providence, R.I. 02903; Visiting Nurse Service of Newport and Bristol County, 1184 E. Main Rd., P.O. Box 690, Portsmouth, R.I. 02871; and Equity Action Fund at RIF, One Union Station, Providence, R.I. 02903. A memorial service will be held at 45 Ledge Rd., Newport, R.I. on Wednesday, April 19 at 11 AM. Condolences, information and directions available at www.memorialfuneral home.com

Paid Notice: Deaths   SIENKIEWICZ, ANNA
description: SIENKIEWICZ--Anna. Born July 14, 1921 died on January 4, 2005 at the age of 85. Ms. Sienkiewicz was a graduate of the Bellevue School of Nursing, class of 1943. A Certificate of Merit signed by Mayor LaGuardia was awarded to her in 1944 for outstanding service in the municipal hospitals during World War II. She also received a Commendation for Meritorious Service from the U.S. Surgeon General for her role as instructor for the U.S. Cadet Nurses Corp. during the same period. Ms. Sienkiewicz pursued her nursing career at Bellevue Hospital in such areas as the emergency room and the ambulance corp. She attained her B.A. Degree at Hunter College Summa Cum Laude in 1958, was elected Phi Beta Kappa and received the Kane prize for the Best Record in Biological Science. she attained a subsequent M.A. degree at Hunter plus a second M.A. at the Teachers College of Columbia University. Ms. Sienkiewicz joined the staff as an instructor at the Bellevue School of Nursing, later the Hunter-Bellevue School of Nursing. She became an assistant professor there and was a member of the honor societies of Sigma Theta Tau and the Phi Sigma Society. In 1981, she was awarded the Sigma Theta Tau Plaque on which is inscribed "An Award of recognition in appreciation for her many contributions." Her high standards for public service were reflected in her devotion to excellence in patient care and in teaching. In 1989, she was chosen as Teacher of the Year for the entire Hunter College. On January 7, 2006, a funeral Mass for her was held at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. She was then buried next to her brother, Joseph Sienkiewicz, at St. Joseph's Cemetery in Allentown, NJ. Ms. Sienkiewicz is survived by her daughter, Patricia Mullahy.

title: KEAN FACES THREAT FROM THE RIGHT
description: For the past five months, State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., the son of a former governor, has trained all of his political fire at the feisty Democratic power broker he wants to unseat, United States Senator Robert Menendez. But now, in a twist, it appears that Mr. Kean will have to contend first with a political distraction that he worked for more than a year to avoid: a challenger in the Republican primary. The potential rival is John P. Ginty, 41$(8$) a financial data analyst and former president of the Ridgewood Republican Club who proudly calls himself an ideologue and a social conservative. Last Monday, the filing deadline for the June 6 primary, Mr. Ginty filed petitions with 1,742 signatures. To qualify for a spot on the ballot, 1,000 valid signatures are needed. Mr. Ginty says that Mr. Kean has been a major disappointment, displaying moderate or muddled views on issues like abortion and stem cell research. He also accuses Mr. Kean of failing to "articulate some understandable program for cutting the size of government" at the federal level, and of not spelling out his views on foreign and defense policy. So far, Mr. Ginty has elicited praise from conservatives like Steven Lonegan, who ran for governor last year.

title: Questions for Michael Chertoff

If not, that statement provides ample evidence that the director of Homeland Security is indeed operating in the Dark Ages. How can the head of our most high-profile national department not use e-mail as the powerful communication tool that it is? Had Chertoff chosen to embrace the tools of the 21st century, he might have delivered a 21st-century response to Hurricane Katrina victims as opposed to the 19th-century response that was delivered. It seems that the Pony Express was to blame for the Katrina response debacle. Who knew?

title: 'Whiteman'
description: At nine a.m., the doorbell rang. I couldn't see who it was because of the high wall surrounding the house, but after a moment's debate whether I shouldn't just ignore it, I picked up the crowbar we'd been keeping handy and started across the courtyard to the security door. I'd talked with the girls about getting a gun in the black market, but we hadn't gone that far yet. "Jack's a man. He'll protect us," Samantha had winked and said, and I'd shaken my head and told them, "Then consider yourselves dead already." Because while I didn't like to think of myself as a coward, my first impulse on hearing gunfire was to hit the floor and crawl under something. At the door, I raised the crowbar like a baseball bat. I'd never swung a weapon at anyone, didn't know if I could now, but I held it like that anyway. "C'est qui?" I shouted, trying to sound larger and more menacing than I really was.

description: It doesn't take brute force to stop a rampaging writer in mid-monologue. Sometimes an innocent question does the trick. Late in his life Dwight Macdonald was holding court at a party when a young woman inquired from the peanut gallery, "Mr. Macdonald, what do you do?" According to Michael Wreszin's biography of Macdonald, "A Rebel in Defense of Tradition," the normally voluble billy goat was thrown for a loss. "Well, I, I, I was a writer, an editor of Partisan Review and Politics, wro . . . wrote for The New Yorker." The incident was more than ego-deflating -- it was demoralizing. It signified that to the younger generation Macdonald was an unidentified relic of unknown occupation. Talking about himself in the past tense brought him face to face with the erosion of his reputation and name recognition after a swashbuckling career as critic, editor, protester, provocateur and all-around word warrior.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: April 16 - April 22; FILM
description: As elusive and esoteric as the title suggests, JACQUES RIVETTE's notorious epic "OUT 1: NOLI ME TANGERE" is one of the great Moby-Dick movies: immense and beguiling, legendary in the extreme, a fearsome fomenter of quests and obsessions. More than 12 hours long, the film concerns the intertwined fates of a group of theater actors and a pair of eccentric flneurs as they venture into a labyrinth of coincidence, conspiracy, meta-narrative and role-playing. Made for and then rejected by French television, the film has remained all but unseen since a first public screening in 1971. (An imp of the cinematic perverse, Mr. Rivette surely delights in the fact that "Noli me tangere" is a Latin phrase meaning "Touch me not.") Soon thereafter the restless auteur set to work on a slightly more viable edit of the project, and in 1974 he distilled it into the four and a half brain-boggling hours of "Out 1: Spectre." In the repertory coup of the season, Anthology Film Archives will screen this mythic film in a small but invaluable program of little-seen Rivette. "Due to the extreme rarity of this film," state the program notes, "print quality is not ideal." As deterrents go, that's about as off-putting as a warning that some rediscovered bit of Sappho is missing a few words. description: I flew British Airways with my five children from Paris to Boston (via London). Upon arrival my three checked bags were not there. I went to the claims desk and filled out a mishandled-baggage report. I received two pieces a week later, but not the third. British Airways has offered me 20.22 euros [$25, at $1.24 to the euro] per kilo for the lost piece, which is fine. However, for the two delayed pieces I am being offered 188.70 euros [$234], whereas I presented receipts for $556.03 (clothes and shoes for six people and a further $45 for toiletries). I had no separate baggage insurance. An airline employee in Boston told me that they would reimburse me $70 per person. -- Francoise Lordet van der Wansem, Grand-Leez, Belgium

title: To Hell With All That
description: I DO NOT PLAN to have another wedding; I'm standing pat at two. But I must confess that after spending a pleasant hour gazing at the photographs in a recent crop of wedding guides, I began to feel a bit of the old itch. There is something deeply seductive about a wedding: romance in its great last stand, not yet sullied by routine and responsibility. Even a photograph of that ill-fated girl Diana Spencer, standing on the steps of St. Paul's, her veil caught in a gust of wind and her father waiting to take her hand, can provoke in me a vague yet undeniable longing. But it took only a few minutes of actually reading the texts of these manuals to bring me to my senses. More than fondness for my husband keeps me from getting on the phone to price tea roses and a tent.

The most confusing television series of our time returns from a hiatus on Wednesday (ABC, 8 p.m.), beginning a sprint to the story's conclusion in May. Viewers last saw the pregnant Sydney Bristow, played by the pregnant JENNIFER GARNER, on a ship in the middle of the ocean, having survived a torture session overseen by her mother (LENA OLIN). If you've lost track of which characters are good and which are bad, who is alive and who is dead, and what the Rambaldi prophecy is, join the crowd. But with a clear endpoint in sight, here's hoping for a lively and satisfying finish for "Alias."

title: Paperback Row
description: THE HUMMINGBIRD'S DAUGHTER, by Luis Alberto Urrea. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) Urrea, best known for his nonfiction accounts of hardscrabble lives on the Mexico-United States border, reaches back into his family history for this epic novel about a 19th-century Mexican saint, peasant and revolutionary. Born in 1873, Teresa Urrea, known as Teresita, was a distant relative, the half-Indian child of a wealthy Mexican landowner. Said to possess a supernatural gift for healing, Teresita suffers a terrible assault, rises from the dead and begins to perform miracles. Revered as the "Mexican Joan of Arc," she creates a democratic groundswell among Mexican revolutionaries. Our reviewer, Stacey D'Erasmo, described Urrea's book as "a mix of leftist hagiography, mystical bildungsroman and melancholic national anthem."

It's Josephine Baker, crooning "J'ai Deux Amours" at the Art Deco Rialto theater. And, ultimately, it's Humphrey Bogart, telling Ingrid Bergman that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world.

description: Choreographic surprises lie ahead, many of them to music by Stravinsky. His music is usually associated with ballet. But in "SOURCING STRAVINSKY," a program curated by ANNIE-B PARSONS, some modern and postmodern choreographers are letting this great 20th-century composer guide them into uncharted territories. YVONNE RAINER, a choreographer associated with Minimalism, is combining Stravinsky's taut "Agon" with Henry Mancini's "Pink Panther" theme. CYNTHIA HOPKINS uses original songs, texts and movement to complete an unfinished Stravinsky opera. DAYNA HANSON and LINAS PHILLIPS collaboratively examine both Stravinsky's life and American homelessness. And the often exuberant DAVID NEUMANN and RENNIE HARRIS, a hip-hop specialist, respond to Stravinsky's rhythms. In it, Mr. Andric focuses on a historic bridge (the 16th-century Mehmed-Pasha Sokolovic Bridge, which still stands) that links Muslims on one side of a river to Christians on the other. This bridge too was damaged during war. In a world that finds it so difficult to build bridges between people of different faiths and that so often destroys what bridges do exist by warfare, your picture and Mr. Andric's novel are especially moving.

The epicenter of this swarm was Bagneux, a riverine hamlet situated between Troyes and Nogent-sur-Seine, one hundred kilometers southeast of Paris. title: Inside the List
description: THIS WEEK IN GOD: Not unpredictably, Dan Brown's "Da Vinci Code," newly out in paperback, kicks sand in the face of every pop novel out there -- it moves directly to No. 1 on the paperback fiction list. (This ranking combines sales of the book in three new editions: mass market, trade and illustrated. The scratch 'n' sniff version can't be far behind.) To date, these editions haven't dented sales of the hardcover version of "The Da Vinci Code" -- it appears at No. 2 on the hardcover list. The Brown juggernaut continues to spin off companion books: the two most recent, published the same day as the paperback, are "Fodor's Guide to 'The Da Vinci Code' " and "The 'Da Vinci Code' Travel Journal." Another new book catching a ride on "Da Vinci Code" mania is Michael Baigent's "Jesus Papers" (HarperSanFrancisco), which lands on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. Baigent, you'll recall, is suing Brown in a British court; he claims that Brown, in "The Da Vinci Code," stole the "architecture" of his own book, "Holy Blood, Holy Grail" (1982), written with Richard Leigh. In "The Jesus Papers," Baigent suggests, among other things, that Jesus' crucifixion was faked. This is faith-based literature -- that is, you'll have to take Baigent's word for his claims. Much of his case is based on papers that he says he's scrutinized but that no one else will probably ever see. Critics haven't been kind to "The Jesus Papers." On a recent epidisode of "Dateline NBC," the scholar and writer Elaine Pagels said of Baigent's book, "It's imaginative, to say the least." Another historian, Craig Evans, added, "It's voodoo scholarship."

title: That Chemical Fire Matches Your Hazmat
description: First responders never looked so much like action heroes as in these images by Paul Shambroom. That wasn't his goal when he was taking the photographs, at training facilities financed by the Department of Homeland Security. Instead he was interested in the simulated terrorist attacks these emergency workers were participating in, and how the exercises blurred the line between fantasy and reality. Sometimes they involved elaborate environments, like an abandoned town -- with a bowling alley, bank and convenience store -- bought whole to serve as a testing ground. In exercises where volunteers were exposed to pathogens, he was struck, he said in a talk at Bard College, by the theme-park atmosphere, where "moonsuit-clad students go through their paces sniffing the air with exotic instruments." The images, on view at Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea, were inspired by the grand portraiture of the 18th and 19th centuries: subjects painted against stylized landscapes, in light at odds with the setting. "I've tried to suggest a similar quality in my portraits, although my subjects are actually photographed in the natural settings," Mr. Shambroom said. Another important difference in the setting: the painterly quality is a result of a decidedly 21st-century effect -- digital manipulation.

title: Wagner, Who Wanted Merely Everything
