Richard Wagner, in his writings and stagings both, insisted on treating singing as a kind of heightened speech. He was not immune to beautiful tone, but it was not his main concern. For the first "Ring of the Nibelungs," at his 1876 Bayreuth Festival, his last advice to his singers included the charge: "Distinctness! The big notes will take care of themselves; the little notes and the text are the chief things."

Among the locals enjoying a preview was Adam Salvo, who retired in 1996. The artists remember him as the rare teacher who treated them as adults and complained about the school administration. The instructor remembers his former students, too, and regularly treks to their shows. Each spoke to Andrew Adam Newman about those formative years.

description: KARCHES--Peter Frederick of Locust Valley, NY died on April 13, 2006 at the age of 54. Mr. Karches waged a valiant battle with chronic lymphocytic leukemia for several years. He loved his wife Susan of 30 years and his four children, Amy, Pamela, Peter Jr. and Nancy who adored him. He is the son of Clara and the late Lincoln Karches and brother to Robert. He was loved by many dear friends, brothers and sisters in-law and nieces and nephews. Peter attended Georgetown University and upon completion of his MBA at Columbia University, began his career at Morgan Stanley. He retired from Morgan Stanley in 2000 after 25 years with the firm where he was President and Chief Operating Officer of both Institutional Securities and Investment Banking. He served on the boards of Georgetown University, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, Friends Academy and was Co-chairman of the New York Racing Association. Peter will be remembered for his leadership, generosity, quick wit and love for his family and friends. title: 'Kingfish'
description: Huey Long climbed onto a large bale of fresh-picked cotton and gazed out at a crowd of farmers attending a country fair. For a few moments he stood motionless, his shoulders hunched like a boxer waiting for the first bell to ring. Leaning forward to talk to the men in the front row, Huey began speaking in a whispery voice so quiet that the crowd shuffled closer to hear him. After a couple of minutes, he slowly raised his voice, a little louder each minute, until he roared to the gathering throng. He threw off his coat, rolled up his shirtsleeves, and slackened the red silk tie hanging around his neck. His voice booming across the dusty fairgrounds, Huey pummeled his audience with old-fashioned soapbox oratory and hell-for-leather political bluster. He whooped and hollered, pounded his fist, and punched in the air at imaginary enemies. His face turned the color of a ripe tomato. Twirling his arms above his head in the sweltering Louisiana heat, perspiration pouring down his cheeks, he quickly captivated the audience with spellbinding charisma and homespun guile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AVIGAD, NATHANIEL (NATAN)
description: AVIGAD--Nathaniel (Natan). Of Yonkers, NY, on April 14, 2006. Beloved husband of Rosalyn (nee Press). Loving father of Jeremy and Joshua Avigad, and daughters-in-law Elinor Avigad and Laura Kaplan. Proud grandfather of Rebecca, Jordana, Ariella, Benjamin and Noah. Devoted brother of Tziona (Tzion) Tubi of Ramat Hachal, Israel, Devora Gadassi of Tel Aviv, Israel, and the late Tzila Avigad. Natan was an extraordinarily warm and loving man who lived a life of creativity and adventure. Born in Tel Aviv, Israel, to parents of Yemenite descent, he served in the Israeli Army during the War of Independence and the 1956 Sinai Campaign. Natan came to the United States in 1962 on a scholarship to the Brooklyn Museum Art School to study sculpture at which time he met his future wife, Rosalyn. Together they have traveled the world. Natan was a talented jeweler and the owner of Avigad Jewelry Company. He was a dedicated sculptor and over the years he produced a magnificent body of work in marble, bronze, wood and other media. Services will be conducted by Rabbi Vinas of the Lincoln Park Jewish Center, on Sunday, April 16, graveside, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Ave, Valhalla, NY, at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGSTAFF, ELLIOT KENNEDY
description: LANGSTAFF--Elliot Kennedy, distinguished international businessman and executive recruiter, died March 11, 2006 in Adamstown, Maryland. He suffered from Parkinson's disease and lung cancer. He was 83. Kennedy Langstaff's career included work in both government service and the private sector. In his early career, he was involved in the post-Marshall Plan reconstruction of Europe, and later focused on enabling third-world countries in Asia and Africa to establish basic infrastructure. In his last two decades of professional life, Langstaff was a partner with Ward Howell International, Inc. In 1955, Langstaff joined the American Overseas Finance Company. It was acquired in 1962 by International Basic Economy Corp. (IBEC), a company founded by Nelson Rockefeller. Serving as Regional Manager and Vice President -Greece, Middle East and Africa for Arbor Acres Farm, Inc., he established the first major poultry breeding joint venture operations, introducing inexpensive protein in India, Pakistan, Zimbabwe, Zambia, and Lebanon for the first time. From 1972-1989, Langstaff was a partner with Ward Howell International, Inc. in New York, where he conducted executive searches for clients in agribusiness, banking, health care, manufacturing, higher education and non-profit organizations. Born in 1923 in New York, Langstaff attended Grace Church Choir School and was a professional singer by age nine as an original member of the Bretton Woods Boy Singers of New Hampshire. His modest earnings were used to help support his family during the Great Depression. He went on to attend The Choate School in Wallingford, CT on a music scholarship where he graduated in 1940. In 1947 he graduated as a member of the Harvard class of 1944, having enlisted in the United States Army where he served in the Infantry as a First Lieutenant in the Pacific Theatre in World War II. In 1949, he received his MBA from the Harvard School of Business. Kennedy Langstaff was a Trustee or Director of The American Farm School, the Overseas Education Fund, and the Harvard Alumni Association. He was President of the Environmental Council of Stamford, CT, and served as a volunteer for the International Executive Service Corps. A member of the national Advisory Committee of Revels, Inc. he helped found the New York Revels, a community-based music and performing arts organization. Langstaff served as a member of the Board of Managers of the Harvard Club, and Chairman of the Admissions Committee. The son of Bridgewater Meredith Langstaff and Esther Boardman Langstaff of Brooklyn Heights, New York. He is survived by his wife of fifty-three years, Percy Lee Langstaff, of Stamford, Connecticut; three children: David Langstaff and Lee Langstaff, both of Comus, Maryland; Maxim Langstaff of Honey Brook, Pennsylvania; and four grandchildren. His wife, Percy, worked with Margaret Mead, and served as President of the League of Women Voters of the State of Connecticut, and is currently President of the Stamford Land Conservation Trust. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROPHY, B. GILES
description: BROPHY--B. Giles. B. Giles Brophy, an investment banker and owner of "Strike the Gold", Kentucky Derby winning horse of 1991, died on April 9, 2006 in Camden, SC. Mr. Brophy had leukemia. Mr. Brophy served in the U.S. Army and graduated from Hofstra University. He started four Wall Street investment firms, including two recognized bond dealerships, one of which was sold to Sanwa Bank. He may well be remembered for his thoroughbred horses "Thirty Six Red" and "Strike the Gold". Thirty-Six Red won the Gotham, Wood Memorial and Churchill Downs Handicap. Strike the Gold won the Bluegrass Stakes and the Kentucky Derby. He also bred and raised an award winning herd of Holstein cattle. He was a member of Deepdale Golf, National Golf, Shinnecock and Westhampton CC. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Rohrbaugh Brophy, his sister, Dr. Geraldine Brophy, five sons, Bernard, Eric, Steven, Andrew and Christopher; one daughter, Moira; and two grandchildren, Emma and Maeve Snover. Memorial service will be held on April 24 at the Bronx Botanical Gardens from 4:30 to 7:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society or the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation.

title: Correction
description: A review on March 26 about "Pets in America: A History," by Katherine C. Grier, gave an erroneous etymology for the phrase "dog days of summer" and attributed it incorrectly to the book. The term, which dates from ancient times, was applied to the uncomfortably hot days of July and August because Sirius, the Dog Star, rises and sets with the sun during that period. The expression did not originally denote a time when possibly rabid strays were slaughtered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODSKY, NAOMI (RICH MAN)
description: BRODSKY -- Naomi (Rich man). Died peacefully on April 12, 2006, at home, in Mt. Vernon, NY. Loving wife of the late Irving Brodsky, devoted mother of two sons, David (Stacey), of Scarsdale, NY, and Richard (Peggy) of Miami, FL, adoring grandmother of the late Kate, and of Peter (Lael), Jane (Jesse), Benjamin, Isabel and Nell, and proud great-grandmother of Jacob, Katherine and Lucas. Born July 8, 1915, in Cincinnati, OH, Naomi attended Pembroke College where she met Irving. They were married in 1939 and lived in Providence and on Cape Cod until Irving's death in 2000. United by their love of family, Brown University, classical music and travel to foreign lands, they set a shining example of love, integrity, and decency for their children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Naomi was a pioneer, teaching English at her beloved Lincoln School in Providence for twenty-two years, founding and running Operation Outreach, which provided scholarships to young African-Americans to attend independent schools in Providence, and then starting a continuing education program at Brown for retirees. Services will be at the Shalom Memorial Chapel, 1100 New London Ave, Cranston, on Sunday, April 16, 2006, at 2 PM. Interment at the Lincoln Park Cemetery, Warwick, at 3 PM. Contributions in her name to Brown University would be welcome. Shiva will be observed on Monday evening at the home of David in Scarsdale, NY.

TNT's made-for-television movie "Avenger" also aided its cause, bringing in an audience of 3.5 million on April 9. In the 18-to-49 demographic, TNT and USA Network tied for the week in the ratings, although USA had more viewers in that age group. Its Monday WWE broadcasts topped the week's 18-to-49 chart, followed by Comedy Central's "South Park." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODSKY, NAOMI (RICH MAN)
description: BRODSKY -- Naomi (Rich man). Died peacefully on April 12, 2006, at home, in Mt. Vernon, NY. Loving wife of the late Irving Brodsky, devoted mother of two sons, David (Stacey), of Scarsdale, NY, and Richard (Peggy) of Miami, FL, adoring grandmother of the late Kate, and of Peter (Lael), Jane (Jesse), Benjamin, Isabel and Nell, and proud great-grandmother of Jacob, Katherine and Lucas. Born July 8, 1915, in Cincinnati, OH, Naomi attended Pembroke College where she met Irving. They were married in 1939 and lived in Providence and on Cape Cod until Irving's death in 2000. United by their love of family, Brown University, classical music and travel to foreign lands, they set a shining example of love, integrity, and decency for their children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Naomi was a pioneer, teaching English at her beloved Lincoln School in Providence for twenty-two years, founding and running Operation Outreach, which provided scholarships to young African-Americans to attend independent schools in Providence, and then starting a continuing education program at Brown for retirees. Services will be at the Shalom Memorial Chapel, 1100 New London Ave, Cranston, on Sunday, April 16, 2006, at 2 PM. Interment at the Lincoln Park Cemetery, Warwick, at 3 PM. Contributions in her name to Brown University would be welcome. Shiva will be observed on Monday evening at the home of David in Scarsdale, NY.

The fire began shortly before 6:30 p.m. at 216 Delaware Avenue, and its cause remained under investigation, said Andrew Johnson, a department spokesman. The firefighters had the blaze under control about 40 minutes later, he said. A neighbor, Aschley Gonzalez, 15, said the victim, whom the authorities did not name, was her friend's mother. "It started from the basement and went up through the whole house," she said. "My friend's mother got trapped in the back room." The Red Cross provided shelter for 16 other people who lived in the building, Mr. Johnson said. One firefighter suffered second-degree burns when debris fell on him, Mr. Johnson said.

title: Two New Plays at Abrons Arts Center, With Their Playwrights as Actors

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judges Question Moves by Companies To Stop Paying Executives' Legal Fees Federal judges are beginning to question why companies are cutting off legal fees to their executives when they become caught up in criminal investigations. The judge in the tax-shelter trial of former tax professionals at KPMG last week ordered a hearing to determine whether prosecutors had improperly put pressure on the firm to stop paying the defendants' legal bills. This shift has occurred since the Justice Department set guidelines in 2003 amid a sweeping crackdown on corporate fraud. [Page C1.]

title: Racer Killed on Drag Strip in Queens
description: For as long as anyone who lives within earshot of Page Place can recall, the forlorn swath of industrial Maspeth, Queens, has been a drag racing hot spot, drawing young men and their tricked-out cars from as far away as North Carolina. Early yesterday, the illegal racetrack claimed the life of a 23-year-old telephone technician who, friends say, had a weakness for fast cars and the occasional drag race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, ARTHUR SHELDON
description: FRIEDMAN--Arthur Sheldon. Of Chappaqua, NY. On March 28, at age 79, after a brief illness. He was for over 50 years an outstanding civil trial lawyer in NYC, in time developing a nationwide practice and recognition. He never sought celebrity or public office, confining his energies to the courtroom. He is survived and missed by his wife of over 50 years, Betty Lucas Friedman, also of Chappaqua, his brother Robert of Briarcliff, NY, his son William (Ned) Friedman of Boulder, CO, his daughter Susan Friedman of Princeton, NJ, and two grandchildren, Peter and David Cohen, as well as the many co-wokers and lawyers he helped train and mentor. Mr. Friedman was born in 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, to Gertrude and Abraham Friedman. He was educated at Townsend Harris High School, Oberlin College (BA, Magna Cum Laude, 1946), and the Harvard Law School (LLB, 1949). He was a Partner in the firm of Gallup, Climenko and Gould. Later her formed the firm that became known as Friedman, Wang and Bleiberg, which in 2004 merged with Foley and Lardner. Mr. Friedman retired from the active practice of law in 2005. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on May 3, 2006, from 4-6 pm, at the Yale Club of NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KARCHES, PETER FREDERICK
description: KARCHES--Peter Frederick of Locust Valley, NY died on April 13, 2006 at the age of 54. Mr. Karches waged a valiant battle with chronic lymphocytic leukemia for several years. He loved his wife Susan of 30 years and his four children, Amy, Pamela, Peter Jr. and Nancy who adored him. He is the son of Clara and the late Lincoln Karches and brother to Robert. He was loved by many dear friends, brothers and sisters in-law and nieces and nephews. Peter attended Georgetown University and upon completion of his MBA at Columbia University, began his career at Morgan Stanley. He retired from Morgan Stanley in 2000 after 25 years with the firm where he was President and Chief Operating Officer of both Institutional Securities and Investment Banking. He served on the boards of Georgetown University, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, Friends Academy and was Co-chairman of the New York Racing Association. Peter will be remembered for his leadership, generosity, quick wit and love for his family and friends. Peter was an avid golfer and horse racing enthusiast who will be missed by all those who knew and loved him. Visiting at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY Monday 2-5 and 7-10. Funeral Mass St. Dominic RC Church, Anstice Street, Oyster Bay Tuesday 10AM. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family request donations to CLL Research Fund, Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY 11040 (Attention Dr. Kanti Rai, MD).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSO, MARGUERITE AGNES
description: RUSSO--Marguerite Agnes, 95, of Flushing, NY. For 58 years the beloved wife of the late Anthony C. Russo. Marguerite was born on Clinton Avenue in the Bronx, in the Parish of St. Augustine. She was baptized and married in St. Augustine's Church. Marguerite attended Cathedral High. She graduated Magna Cum Laude from the College of Mount St. Vincent in 1931; received a M.A. degree from Fordham University in 1934, and a M.S. degree in social work from Columbia University in 1945. She had a long and dedicated career in social services, and was the Supervisor of Medical Social Services at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, and also held positions at the NYC Department of Health and Welfare. She was an active and committed supporter of the Catholic Church and her local parish, the Church of Mary's Nativity, as well as the Diocese of Brooklyn. In the parish, she was a member of the Rosarians and Catholic Daughters. She is survived by her beloved and devoted cousins, Walter V. Reilly and Kathleen Gallagher, her devoted sisterin-law Tillie G. Russo; niece Andrea Russo--and her family: husband Michael Zierler, son Samuel Zierler; and nephew Michael Russo, and a very large and loving extended family. Marguerite had a strong and probing intellect that was engaged on a wide array of current topics. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. Visiting will be held on Monday, April 17, from 2-5 pm, and 7-9 pm, at the Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Tuesday, April 18, at 9:45 am, at the Church of Mary's Nativity, 46-02 Parsons Blvd, in Flushing. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Motorola is Making Eyes at Siemens Telecom Unit
description: Motorola is interested in Siemens loss-making telecoms unit Com, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung reported. The paper said one option in the talks between Siemens and Motorola was the complete takeover of Siemens Com  its biggest unit  that had sales of 13 billion euros ($16 billion) and 55,000 employees.

title: Law Firm Merger Raises Questions One Year In
description: Pillsbury Winthrops merger with Shaw Pittman a year ago was touted by leaders of both law firms as creating a formidable new player among the nations top shops. But tough choices that the firms made to get the deal done have raised questions about whether the marriage was worth the sacrifices.

title: Latecomer Citigroup Vaults to the Top of the Tech Heap
description: In the tech frenzy of the late 1990s, Citigroup was late to the game. The investment bank lagged rivals such as Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse in taking companies public, handling mergers and providing deal financing.

title: Sandy Weill Steps Aside
description: On Tuesday, Sandy Weill draws a veil over his remarkable 50-year career on Wall Street. At Manhattans Carnegie Hall, the performance centre he sponsored and oversees as chairman of the board of trustees, he will hand the keys to Americas largest bank over to his protege, Chuck Prince. For the first time, Citigroup, the banking giant he built through ambition and acquisitions, will no longer be in the hands of the 73-year old titan.

title: Paramax Emerges as Investment Banking Player
description: After several years as a middle-market business brokerage representing both sides of the transaction, Paramax of Amherst, N.Y. has further narrowed its focus on sellers with much bigger stakes. Paramax has emerged as a player in the investment banking industry, one of about 75 in the country working with divestitures with a value of up to $750 million.

title: Carlyles Willcom Calls in the Underwriters
description: Willcom, a mobile wireless company owned by Carlyle Group, hired Daiwa Securities SMBC to arrange an initial public offering of as much as 100 billion yen ($843 million), Bloomberg News reported. Willcom, formerly known as DDI Pocket, is in the process of choosing another bank, said the people, who declined to be identified before an official announcement. The next round of interviews will be held next week, they said.

title: Exchange-Traded Fund Spotlights I.P.O.s
description: Initial public offerings take their place in the growing world of exchange-traded index funds as the First Trust IPOX-100 Index Fund kicks off trading on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Standard Life Practices Self-Defense Before Float
description: The British insurer Standard Life is to shore up its defenses against unwanted predators as it moves towards demutualization by offering 2.4 million of its members additional loyalty shares if they stay on as shareholders for a year after it lists on the stock market.

title: Chinas Mindray Channeling  Nasdaq IPO
description: Mindray, Chinas largest maker of blood monitoring equipment, hopes to raise up to US$300 million on the Nasdaq in a possible record IPO on the exchange by a mainland Chinese firm, The Standard said. Mindray Bio-Medical Electronics, which makes equipment measuring blood pressure and blood oxygen levels, hopes to list on the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index in July.

title: For Achillion, IPO is Last Hope
description: Achillion Pharmaceuticals early this month filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, which may be the companys only hope for survival, officials admit. The New Haven, Conn. company is under financial duress, and in its own words, needs a successful IPO to remain in business. It has stated, for instance, that it has accumulated losses of $96.2 million.

title: Wary VCs Reconsider Succession Planning
description: A number of venture capital and private equity firms have lately been mired in messy succession-planning disputes  disputes that have prompted other venture capitalists to take steps to head off problems before they flare up in their own houses. At best, such battles are a distraction from a firms investment focus. At worst, key personnel have been known to jump ship to start their own competing outfits.

title: Which Exit to Take: IPO or M&A
description: When the Internet bubble burst, a lot of the hype, and a lot of the venture capital money following awful business plans, disappeared. But, while liquidity is returning, young companies are encountering a very different market when it comes to going public. There were 26 fewer IPOs in 2005 compared with 2004s 67, according to VentureOne.

title: Start-Ups Must Handle Investors With Care
description: It almost doesnt matter where they are or what sector they are in: Start-up companies are hot. The number of initial public offerings almost doubled over the past two years and the volume of global transactions hit $167 billion in 2005, according to a new report by Ernst & Young.

title: Kaboodle Gets Kitted Out by VCs
description: Kaboodle, a free ad-supported service that lets people do collaborative Web research, was set to announce on Monday that it has raised $3.55 million in Series A funding from investors, including former Google-related scientists.

title: KKR Snags Flextronics in Indias Biggest LBO
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts will buy Flextronics Software Systems for $900 million in Indias biggest leveraged buyout. Flextronics International, the worlds largest producer of electronics for other companies, will sell 85 percent of its Indian unit to an affiliate of KKR, the Singapore-based company said in a statement distributed yesterday.

title: Venture Rebound Gives Rich Texture to Quilt of Start-Ups
description: As the venture industry rebounds, the range of investments has broadened considerably.

title: Solar Start-Up Sees Light Years Ahead
description: Solar start-up Heliovolt, a company that envisions buildings coated with electricity-generating roofs and sidings, will begin building prototypes later this month. Heliovolt is one of several companies seeking to come up with cheaper ways to build material that can convert light to electricity.

title: Clash of the Titans: Cerberus Takes on KKR
description: It was an epic showdown between legendary buyout king Henry R. Kravis and New Age hedge fund manager Stephen A. Feinberg  and Feinberg won. On Apr. 3, General Motors announced that it would get about $14 billion over the next three years for selling a 51 percent stake of its highly profitable GMAC finance division to a group led by Feinbergs firm, Cerberus Capital Management.

title: Tapping Into the Hispanic Market
description: At many American private equity firms, a Mexican food deal means sending the junior analyst out to buy tacos. At Palladium Equity Partners, it means buying Taco Bueno, the fast-food restaurant chain itself.

title: Buyout Firms Eyeing Bigger Prey
description: The global takeover boom shows no sign of peaking. If anything, buyout firms are setting their sights on bigger targets, and corporations are stepping up the pace of purchases while financing remains cheap.

title: Judges Press Companies That Cut Off Legal Fees
description: Federal judges are beginning to question why companies are cutting off legal fees to their executives when they become caught up in criminal investigations.

title: As Pop Music Seeks New Sales, the Pussycat Dolls Head to Toyland
description: Interscope Records deal with Hasbro to create a line of fashion dolls modeled on the pop group the Pussycat Dolls is just one example of how record companies are seeking revenue-sharing arrangements that encompass far more than CDs.

title: In Silicon Valley, a Man Without a Patent
description: Geoff Goodfellow is a Silicon Valley entrepreneur who came up with an idea of sending electronic mail messages wirelessly to a portable device  like a BlackBerry. That idea has resulted in a $612.5 million payday for NTP, which lat month won its patent suit against Blackberry maker Research in Motion .

title: Financier Denies Inflating Price of Stock
description: The Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi denied accusations yesterday that he had helped inflate the share prices of a telemarketing company as part of a $130 million securities deal.

title: Networks Sue to Challenge F.C.C.s Indecency Penalties
description: After years of coming under assault in Washington on accusations of indecent programming, the television networks have decided to fight back. With no allies among either the Democrats or the Republicans on the Federal Communications Commission nor any significant ones in Congress, the four broadcast networks, joined by the Hearst-Argyle Television group of stations, embarked late last week on a low-risk strategy of turning to the courts.

title: TiVo Wins Patent Suit Against EchoStar
description: In case cast as crucial to TiVos survival, a federal jury decided that EchoStar Communication copied key technologies from the digital video recording pioneer and awarded nearly $74 million.

title: F.B.I. Links Big Film Names to a Detective
description: The chairman of Paramount Pictures and a onetime Hollywood superagent had far more direct dealings than they have acknowledged publicly with the celebrity detective at the center of a rapidly expanding wiretapping scandal, according to government evidence.

title: Jones Apparel Executive Gets the Boot
description: With its major footwear brands, including Nine West, Bandolino and Enzo Angiolini, losing share to rivals, the Jones Apparel Group yesterday reshuffled top management of the division, ousting longtime executive Rhonda Brown.

title: Injunction Bars Yukos from Selling Assets
description: A bankruptcy supervisor at the shattered Yukos oil company said Friday he had won a temporary injunction from a New York court banning the company from selling its assets as it goes into bankruptcy hearings.

title: Weinsteins Take Columbia to Court
description: Harvey and Bob Weinstein, the Hollywood movie moguls, are locked in a battle with Columbia Pictures over the rights to make films out of a series of books by the Chinese author of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

title: RealNetworks Wins Patent Suit Brought by Ethos
description: RealNetworks said Friday it has prevailed in a $200 million patent infringement lawsuit originally brought against it by Ethos Technologies in 2002.

title: Man Charged With Insider Trading Cant Make Bail
description: The 26-year-old Wall Street slickster busted by the Feds last week for masterminding a $7 million insider-trading scam is spending his first weekend in a federal lock-up  unable to scrape together his $3 million bail.

title: Swagger and the City of London
description: There is a certain swagger about the City of London these days  a self-confidence born of success. It has strengthened its position as Europes leading financial center and is a magnet for capital and talent from around the world.

title: Its High Noon in the Battle Over the Boardroom
description: For decades, the selection process for corporate boards of directors has had more in common with a Soviet-style system than with an American-style election. But now, the winds of change are blowing.

title: On Craigslist: Your Kingdom for My Paperclip
description: Kyle MacDonald had a red paper clip and a dream: Could he use the community power of the Internet to barter that paper clip for something better, and trade that thing for something else  and so on and so on until he had a house?

title: The Hard Edge of a Fluff Machine
description: Beneath its gossamer skin of celebrity sightings and innuendo, Page Six occupies a significant coordinate in the business cosmology of New York City. Scores are kept and settled on the page, deals are floated and brands, both personal and corporate, are forged and melted down.

title: Citigroup Reports 4 Percent Rise in Quarterly Profit
description: Strength in its international businesses and its investment banking operations helped Citigroup report a 4 percent rise in first-quarter profit on Monday.

title: Babcock & Brown Dials Up Deal for Eircom
description: Babcock & Brown, Australias second-largest investment bank, proposed buying Eircom Group, Irelands biggest telephone company, for 2.36 billion euros ($2.86 billion) to expand in the fastest growing economy in the 12 nations that share the euro currency.

title: From The Times: The Voucher Question
description: Cory Booker and Ronald L. Rice are both African-American Democrats. They both emphasize public safety on the stump. Ideologically, their similarities seem to outweigh their differences.

Gilbert Whites Selborne Journal: Saturday, 17 April 1784: 29 3/10 1/2; 44, 50; SW, NW; 31. Shower, sun, pleasant, & spring-like. The buds of the vines are not swelled yet at all. In fine springs they have shot by this time two or three Inches. Peaches, & Nectarines begin to blossom. Ring-dove builds in my fields. Black-cap sings.

title: Ryan Beck Files for $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Ryan Beck Holdings, which provides financial advice, filed with U.S. regulators on Monday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering of class A common stock.

title: Photographs: The Scene in Tel Aviv
description: The aftermath of a suicide bombing in a bustling commercial area of Tel Aviv during the Passover holiday.

title: Level 3 To Pick Up ICG for $163 Million
description: Information services provider Level 3 Communications agreed to acquire telecommunications firm ICG Communications for $163 million on Monday. Level 3 said the deal, which consists of $127 million in unregistered shares of its stock and $36 million in cash, will expand its transport, Internet protocol and voice businesses.

title: Columbia Sussex Joins Bidding War for Casino Owner Aztar
description: For casino operator Aztar, the stakes just keep getting higher.

title: Good Leak, Bad Leak
Deutsche Post C.E.O. Sees Smaller Deals Ahead
description: After stuffing itself with billion-dollar acquisitions, Deutsche Post World Net is content to sit back for the next two years, chief executive Klaus Zumwinkel said. But the company will still seek out smaller deals  that is, those under 250 million euro ($306 million).

title: Nobel Foundation Invests in Hedge Funds
description: The Nobel Foundation, which funds the prizes given to some of the worlds smartest and most talented people, has ventured for the first time into the world of hedge funds.

title: Little Tastes of Spain
description: Left: Jos Andrs sets a quail egg yolk on a mini Caesar salad at one of his restaurants, the Cafe Atlantico in Washington. Right: Mr. Andrss new book.(Photos: Left, Linda Spillers for the New York Times; right, Lars Klove for The New York Times)

title: Chinese Bank Denies Holding Talks Over Bear Stearns Stake
description: China Construction Bank is denying a report in Mondays edition of The Wall Street Journal that it is in early discussions with Bear Stearns that could lead to the Chinese concern taking a minority stake in the Wall Street securities firm. An official from the bank, one of Chinas Big Four state-controlled banks, tells Reuters that the bank does not have such a plan.

title: Who Exactly Is the New Nixon?
description: Has Dick Morris flip-flopped in the crucial opinionland debate over whether Al Gore or George W. Bush is the New Nixon? In a February column for the congressional newspaper The Hill, Morris wrote of Gores disappearance from the national stage, The hiatus has healed his reputation with the base in much the same way that the negative rap on Nixon for losing in 1960 was ameliorated by the Goldwater wipeout of 1964. But in todays New York Post, Morris writes of President Bush, Unlike his dad, he was able to persuade America to keep him around for another term. But he seems destined to spend the remainder of his tenure,  la Nixon, twisting slowly in the wind.

title: Shares of Wheeling-Pitt Surge Amid Takeover Reports
description: Shares of Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel jumped more than 16 percent on Monday after two newspapers reported that the steelmaker was in talks to be acquired. The stock was changing hands at $22.09 in midmorning trading, giving the company a market capitalization of about $324 million.

title: Schumachers future (Part 2)
description: I thought that after dominating Formula One for five years, Michael Schumacher might be someone that few people want to hear about anymore. But Ive noticed on this blog that my post on Schumachers future drew more comments than the others, so I guess the greatest driver of his generation still creates interest.

title: Pogo to Pay $750 Million for PE-Backed Latigo Petroleum
description: Oil and gas exploration company Pogo Producing said Monday it agreed to buy Latigo Petroleum, a company founded by two private equity shops, for $750 million in cash.

title: Ace Greenbergs Magic Act Is Back
description: As some industry veterans may know, Alan Ace Greenberg, who spent a half-century at Bear Stearns before stepping down as chairman of the securities firm in 2001, is also an amateur magician. He will perform some tricks at the Parkinsons Disease Foundation gala on May 17 at New Yorks Pierre Hotel, The New York Posts Page Six reports. Mr. Greenbers father suffered from Parkinsons.

title: Houston Exploration Pressured to Consider Sale
description: A major shareholder of Houston Exploration on Monday called on that company to buy back its own shares and consider putting itself up for sale.

title: TiVo Wins in Court, But Buyout Speculation Lingers
description: Thursdays decision by a federal jury to award TiVo $74 million in its patent lawsuit against EchoStar means that TiVos technology has a fresh validity in the market for digital video recorders. Investors were thrilled, sending TiVos shares up more than 11 percent on Monday, the first trading day after the verdict was announced.

title: As Tyco Pays Fine, Former C.E.O.s Art Goes on Sale
description: Its previous bookkeeping may be suspect, but Tyco Internationals latest accounting team seems to be right on the money. About a year ago, the conglomerate took a charge of $50 million, representing its best estimate of how much its fine from the Securities and Exchange Commission would be. It turns out that figure was exactly right.

title: The Battlefield is Not a Business
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Apr. 16 column, The Good Fight, Done Badly:

title: Roundup: Why the Suburbs Matter
description: Over the weekend, Brad Parks of The Star-Ledger looked at why all New Jerseyans have a stake in what happens in Newark on May 9. The article used an analysis of the citys school budget and municipal budget, the 2005 Essex County tax rolls and the 2004 Consolidated Federal Funds report to come to the conclusion that 81 cents of each dollar of public money spent by the city comes from outside sources.

title: Governor Ryan Is Convicted
description: April 17 - Former Illinois Governor George Ryan has been convicted of racketeering and fraud.

title: The Anti-Green Monster
description: Readers respond to Paul Krugmans Apr. 17 column, Enemy of the Planet

title: War is Not a Reality Show, Its Just Reality
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts April 17 column, The Fear Factor.

title: In WellPoint Merger, Executives Perks Were Big and Small
description: When Anthem and WellPoint Health Networks struck their $16.4 billion merger agreement in 2004, Californias insurance commissioner initially raised a red flag over the deals hefty payouts to company executives. He only relented when the two companies agreed to spend $265 million to help improve health services in the state  an amount the commissioner said was equal to the compensation that WellPoint C.E.O. Leonard D. Schaeffer and other top executives would reap in the deal.

title: The Next Big Buyout? Everybodys Guessing
description: As private equity firms raise one record-breaking fund after another, a cottage industry has cropped up to try to forecast which companies will become takeover bait.

title: Wired
description: From the beginning I knew it was going to be a rough week. The family desktop crashed, probably for the last time, over the weekend. Ka-ching! School tuitions are coming due. Ka-ching! Then there was the little matter of taxes  you know how that goes.

title: As Google Looks to China, Some See 51Job As Target
description: American depositary receipts of 51job, a Chinese human resources company, touched a new 52-week high on Monday after an analyst included the company in a list of possible acquisition targets for Google. The A.D.R.s closed at $21.53 on Monday, up nearly 13 percent.

title: How a Medical Device Article Was Prepared
description: On April 1, Dr. John Tuckman, of New York, wrote to the public editor to question the wisdom of  that days article on a neck artery treatment. The readers message was sent to the reporter, Barnaby Feder, whose response provides an interesting insight into the reporting process behind a medical-device article.

title: Pinup Calendar With a Purpose
description: Joe Sharkey poses with Miss January 2007 of the Stewardesses Stripped  calendar.  (April 18, 2006)

title: Women and Heart Disease
description: The Times's Denise Grady discusses an elusive form of heart disease that is especially prominent among women. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

title: Reader Comments on Chad
description: Here are some of the reader comments on Sundays column on Chad and Darfur.Joseph from Stone Mountain, Georgia writes: I believe the responsible parties could be stopped in their tracks if their sources of funding and arms were cut off. I remember a few years ago when Colin Powell threatened Somalia with a cut off of aid and an arms embargo should they not cease their aggression. Why has the U.S. not taken a more active role in waging peace?

title: Winning the Pulitzer
description: What a day! The Pulitzer Board announced today that I had won the Pulitzer for commentary, principally for my columns on Darfur. Its a little awkward having benefited from genocide, but I do hope the prize brings a bit more of a spotlight on the issue.

title: Before the Debate  A Debate
description: The debate was fierce tonight at a forum for three North Ward council contestants.

title: The Freedom Not to Speak
description: The tiny village of Tequesta, Fla., near Palm Beach, is making news these days because councilman-elect Basil Dalack is refusing to take the oath of office. The oath reads, I solemnly swear that I will support, protect and defend the Constitution and government of the United States and of the state of Florida. Mr. Dalack insists that by taking the oath he would be declaring his support for the Bush administration in general and the Iraq war in particular. No citizen of the United States should be required to swear to support the government, which is the Bush administration, Mr. Dalack told the Palm Beach Post. He has filed a lawsuit against the village claiming that the requirement of taking the oath is a prior restraint restriction on his right to speak freely, and he has composed on alternative oath in which the word support is deleted and replaced by respect.

title: Listening to the Land
description: (First Sgt. Gregory Westbrook)

title: World Briefing: Africa, Asia, Americas and Europe
description: AFRICA

title: Citing Security, C.I.A. Seeks Suit's Dismissal
description: State secrets are involved in a lawsuit against the Central Intelligence Agency brought by the wife of a former covert operative, lawyers for the agency said yesterday in a New York federal court, arguing that national security will be at risk if the case is allowed to proceed.

title: Perceptions: Everybody Except My Slender Friends and Me
description: Nine out of 10 Americans think most of their fellow citizens are overweight, a new survey shows. But only 70 percent believe that most of the people they know are. And when it comes to themselves, only about 4 of 10 think they weigh too much.

title: Risk: Doctors Link Diabetes and Secondhand Smoke
description: In a study that may offer new evidence of the hazards of secondhand tobacco smoke, researchers have found that people who are exposed to it may be more likely to develop diabetes.

title: Veteran Revolutionary Trapped in the Halls of Power
description: By SETH MYDANS

title: Keystone Kops? No, Kenyans, but Often Similarly Inept
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 12  Nobody was all that surprised last month when something went amiss as the authorities tried to burn more than a ton of cocaine seized in 2004 in the largest narcotics raid in the country's history.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,370 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Drug Found to Lower Breast Cancer Risk
description: A drug already in widespread use to prevent bone thinning in women past menopause can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Schizophrenia as Misstep by Giant Gene
description: Researchers have made progress in understanding how a variant gene linked to schizophrenia may exert its influence in the brain. The findings are tentative but, if confirmed, could yield deep insights into the biological basis of the disease.

title: Iceland's Fizzy Economy Faces a Test
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 13  It didn't take long for the 300,000 residents on this windswept fishing island to adjust to their mini-titan economy, where boutiques now sell Dior cosmetics and Gucci handbags and the flow of international money has been fueling a red-hot housing market and a crop of wealthy entrepreneurs.

title: Defying Poverty's Everyday Despair in Odets's 'Awake and Sing!'
description: Life begins tomorrow for the anxious souls inhabiting an overstuffed Bronx apartment in Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing!" Or was it over long before yesterday?

title: China Starts New Investigation of Journalist
description: BEIJING, April 17  The Chinese authorities, who last month unexpectedly dropped a state secrets case against a jailed researcher for The New York Times, have started an investigation period that could lead to reinstating the charges against him by early May, his lawyer said Monday.

title: Judge Allows Device to Be Used for Monitoring Lethal Injection
description: A federal judge who had ordered officials in North Carolina to find qualified medical personnel to supervise an execution by lethal injection ruled yesterday that a brain wave monitor could be used instead to ensure that the prisoner would be unconscious and unable to feel pain.

title: A Slight Change in Habits Could Lull You to Sleep
description: Faith Sullivan of Minneapolis was having a really hard time getting a good night's sleep. For years, she had slept about seven hours a night. Then, in her late 50's, something changed. After going to bed at 10 or 11 p.m., she would wake up around 3 a.m., unable to fall back to sleep.

title: Moussaoui's Childhood Is Presented as Mitigating Factor
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 17  Lawyers trying to persuade a jury to spare the life of Zacarias Moussaoui began presenting testimony about his childhood on Monday, to show that he grew up in a neglectful household in France where his father beat his mother regularly and that he spent much of his youth in orphanages.

title: Today's Russian Newspapers
description: A summary of the top stories in the Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.

title: Mediators Scramble to Save Sri Lanka Peace Talks
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 17  Officially, a cease-fire accord still holds between the government and the ethnic Tamil rebels here. But over the last 10 days, more than 60 people, mostly security forces, have been killed.

title: Before First Incision, Checking for an X to Mark the Spot
description: For patient and doctor, it is the ultimate nightmare: a surgeon operates on the wrong part of the body.

title: Nemo Beware: Fish Tank Can Be a Haven for Salmonella
description: Tropical fish seem the tidiest of pets: they never lick your face, leap from the cat box to the kitchen counter or take pleasure in rolling around in some wad of mysterious rot.

title: State Seeks to Supplant Red Cross
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  Frustrated with the performance of the American Red Cross, Alabama's governor has asked Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff for the federal aid necessary to let the state assume primary responsibility for operating its own emergency shelters in disasters.

title: Common Genetic Link to Obesity Is Discovered
description: A genetic variation predisposing people to obesity has been detected by a team of researchers at Boston University and elsewhere. Though the gene is expected to be just one of the many that contribute to the disease, its detection raises hopes that the others may be discovered within the next five years or so, said Michael F. Christman, a leader of the team.

title: Taiwan Moves Closer to Mainland, Pulled by Forces That Molded Its Mountains
description: Politically, Taiwan's relationship to Beijing could be characterized primarily as a rift borne of defiance on one side and menacing rebuke on the other. But geologically, the small island of Taiwan appears to be on a collision course with mainland China. Over millions of years, that is.

title: Suicide Bombing in Israel Kills 9; Hamas Approves
description: TEL AVIV, April 17  A Palestinian suicide bomber carried out the deadliest attack on Israel in almost two years on Monday when he detonated his explosives at a falafel restaurant in Tel Aviv  an act that Hamas, which leads the new Palestinian government, called legitimate.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Renovation of U.N. Complex Stalled by U.S., an Official Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 17  The director of the $1.6 billion plan to restore the aging and dilapidated headquarters of the United Nations said Monday that persistent objections from the United States were causing delays in meeting deadlines and jeopardizing the future of the entire project.

title: Research Ties Lack of Sleep to Risk for Hypertension
description: Getting too little sleep may be a significant risk factor for high blood pressure.

title: Anger Rises on Both Sides of Strike at University of Miami
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 17  Outside the University of Miami's main entrance, six janitors and five students continued their hunger strike on Monday, with several asserting that the university's president, Donna Shalala, was a union-buster.

title: Endangered, Rescued, Now in Trouble Again
description: WALL, S.D.  Black-footed ferrets, the weasel with the burglar's mask that was brought back to life after reaching the brink of extinction, are facing a new challenge from the spread of plague in prairie dogs, their only prey.

title: Giving Sacramento Good Reason to Have New Orleans on Its Mind
description: Like many Californians, Jeffrey Mount, a geologist, has done a lot of thinking about water.

title: A Lapse in Vigilance and a Lesson in Instinct
description: It would have been easy to ignore in other children, but when it comes to Jonah, our autistic son, nothing is beyond scrutiny.

title: Babylon Awaits an Iraq Without Fighting
description: BABYLON, Iraq  In this ancient city, it is hard to tell what are ruins and what's just ruined.

title: Evacuee Study Finds Declining Health
description: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found.

title: Israel Pressures Hamas Over Suicide Bombing
description: JERUSALEM, April 18  Israel said today that it would increase political pressure on the Palestinian government in response to a suicide bombing a day earlier. But Israel gave no hint of planning a major military action or targeting members of the Hamas-dominated Palestinian government.

title: Psychologist Says Moussaoui Is Schizophrenic
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 18  A defense psychologist told the jury considering whether to sentence Zacarias Moussaoui to death that he is a paranoid schizophrenic who believes that President Bush will soon set him free and that his court-appointed defense lawyers are engaged in a conspiracy to kill him.

title: For Adults, Allergies Bring a Surprising Twist
description: It came as a big surprise when Gittel Willner suffered her first bout of hay fever at the age of 47.

title: National Archives Pact Let C.I.A. Withdraw Public Documents
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The National Archives signed a secret agreement in 2001 with the Central Intelligence Agency permitting the spy agency to withdraw from public access records it considered to have been improperly declassified, the head of the archives, Allen Weinstein, disclosed on Monday.

title: In Heart Disease, the Focus Shifts to Women
description: Kim Kachmann-Geltz did everything right. She ran five miles a day, dutifully ate oatmeal and wheat toast, stayed slim, never smoked. Her blood pressure was perfect. Her genes, she thought, were lucky: her great-grandmother had lived to 102.

title: Specialities: Surgery Remains 'Macho' Field, Survey Finds
description: When researchers asked male and female medical students about careers in surgery, they found many similarities, researchers reported yesterday.

title: 'Andrew Wyeth: Memory and Magic' at the Philadelphia Museum of Art
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14  Near the end of "Andrew Wyeth: Memory and Magic," an exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, hangs a painting unlike any other in the show. It depicts a girl in a thickly padded, leather-upholstered seat of a private airplane, looking down through an oval porthole and a rift in the clouds to a white house and barn on the ground.

title: Safety: In the Emergency Room, Seat Belts Matter, Too
description: Of people who survive car wrecks, those who weren't wearing seat belts are three times as likely to die in an emergency room as those who were, researchers say.

title: U.S. and Iran Take Tough Stances in Standoff
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 As diplomats meeting in Moscow failed to reach agreement on how best to raise pressure on Iran over its nuclear program, the American and Iranian presidents, both using tough language, staked out unyielding positions today.

title: PBS and HBO Examine Global Warming, Dimming of the Sun and Vanishing Species
description: The global temperature is rising. As the poles become warmer, the domain of birds and insects is expanding. As humans take up  or mess up  more terrain, the habitat of large predators is shrinking.

title: Fish Gotta Eat; Swimming Is Optional
description: Like most fish, the eel catfish eats by sucking water into its mouth, bringing food along with it. But the eel catfish, which inhabits swamps in Gabon and other parts of tropical Africa, has a little secret. It can also hunt and catch insects on land.

title: U.S. Envoy to Expose 4 Sudanese in U.N. Debate About Darfur
description: UNITED NATIONS, April 17  John R. Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Selection In 9/11 Case
description: Jury selection began yesterday in Federal District Court in the long-delayed trial of Osama Awadallah, a student from Jordan accused of lying to a grand jury investigating the Sept. 11 attack. A jury was chosen in May 2005, but Judge Shira A. Scheindlin sent the jurors home after the government brought a last-minute appeal seeking to have the case transferred to another judge. That appeal was rejected in January. Yesterday, the jurors were recalled and new ones added to create a pool of 35 for the final selection. The judge questioned the candidates to see if their views had been affected by news about the sentencing trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, who pleaded guilty to conspiring in the 9/11 attacks. Mr. Awadallah is not charged with any role in the attacks. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

National Briefing | Washington: Air Marshals' Criticism
description: In a move to settle a lawsuit, the Department of Homeland Security has agreed to notify federal air marshals that they are not prohibited from publicly criticizing the agency, so long as they do not disclose inappropriate information about the highly secretive airline security operation. The lawsuit was filed last year by Frank Terreri, an air marshal who was taken off active duty after he sent a private e-mail message to another air marshal criticizing the agency. According to the American Civil Liberties Union, which filed the suit on behalf of Mr. Terreri, a statement will go out to air marshals saying that the agency's policy on public comment is not "intended to limit the free public expression of an employee's personal opinions about matters of public concern," as long as "the individual complies with all laws and policies safeguarding the unauthorized disclosure of official information." title: Arts, Briefly; Easter Offers No Feast For the Eyes
description: Easter Sunday was a slow night for television. A number of series hit season-low ratings, including ABC's "Desperate Housewives." But that comedic soap opera was still by far the night's most watched show in Nielsen's estimates, with 19.74 million viewers. That helped the series premiere of "What About Brian," which took the place of "Grey's Anatomy" at 10 p.m. The wistful "Brian" delivered 12.84 million viewers, meaning it lost a significant number of the "Housewives" audience. But in the 18-to-49 demographic, it fared better, and easily beat NBC's "Crossing Jordan" (12.46 million) and the conclusion of the CBS movie "Covert One: The Hades Factor" (6.76 million from 9 to 11 p.m.). On the Sunday schedule, NBC's "West Wing" (8.28 million) was not the only veteran show about to end its run forever. WB's "Charmed" (3.05 million) and Fox's "Malcolm in the Middle" (2.92 million) will also go gently into that good night in the coming weeks. KATE AURTHUR

He was for over 50 years an outstanding civil trial lawyer in NYC, in time developing a nationwide practice and recognition. He never sought celebrity or public office, confining his energies to the courtroom. He is survived and missed by his wife of over 50 years, Betty Lucas Friedman, also of Chappaqua, his brother Robert of Briarcliff, NY, his son William (Ned) Friedman of Boulder, CO, his daughter Susan Friedman of Princeton, NJ, and two grandchildren, Peter and David Cohen, as well as the many co-wokers and lawyers he helped train and mentor. Mr. Friedman was born in 1927 in Brooklyn, NY, to Gertrude and Abraham Friedman. He was educated at Townsend Harris High School, Oberlin College (BA, Magna Cum Laude, 1946), and the Harvard Law School (LLB, 1949). He was a Partner in the firm of Gallup, Climenko and Gould. Later her formed the firm that became known as Friedman, Wang and Bleiberg, which in 2004 merged with Foley and Lardner. Mr. Friedman retired from the active practice of law in 2005. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held on May 3, 2006, from 4-6 pm, at the Yale Club of NYC.

The agency is also developing a plan, based on another test project, to train screeners to recognize patterns of behavior, he said. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLATT, HAROLD
description: PLATT--Harold of New Rochelle, NY, died on February 23, 2006, after suffering a stroke. He was the beloved husband of Ann Platt for sixty-three years. Their children, Leslie, Marc and Laura, and his six grandchildren, Bill, Josh, Alex, Emily, Rachel and Sydney survive him. Mr. Platt came to America in 1939, served in the US Army in WWII, and rose from a sewing machine operator to co-owner of a leading clothing manufacturer and importer of men's clothing, including Adolfo Men's Wear. Mr. Platt was guided by the principle of helping others and passionately supported Jewish and Yiddish scholarship, Israel and the arts and education. He served on the Board of Jewish Education of the City of NY, was active in the Forward, the Bund, the Workmen's Circle, the Jewish Labor Committee, the Hebrew Actors Union, YIVO, and the Sholom Aleichem Memorial Foundation. He and Ann endowed the "Wall of Jewish Martyrs" in Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, where he served as a trustee. Mr. Platt helped to create the Platt Yiddish Summer Institute of Bar Ilan University in Israel where hundreds of students come to study. He and Ann helped endow a part of the Schottenstein Talmud Bavli, published by the Mesorah Heritage Foundation. Mr. Platt was Honorary President of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theatre, which he helped to save for future generations. Mr. Platt was an admired and respected friend of many writers, artists and poets, as well as rabbis and Talmudic scholars, political leaders in America and Israel, and professionals and working people of diverse backgrounds, religions and cultures.

Fred graduated from Regis High School and Went on to The College of the Holy Cross ('40), thence to Columbia Law School ('48) where he was a member of the Columbia Law Review. His studies were interrupted by military service when he was drafted into the Army early in World War II, and rose from the rank of Private to Captain. He served with the U.S. forces in the invasion of the Normandy beaches six days after the initial landing on D-Day, 1944. Following law school he joined the firm that is now Kelley Drye & Warren LLP, where he spent his entire legal career of over fifty-seven years, serving as the Firm's managing partner and as a member of its executive committee. Fred's law career was devoted initially to litigation, and subsequently to labor and employment law as a prominent member of the labor bar representing management. Among his clients were Chrysler Corporation, The New York Hospital, The New York Yankees, the Diocese of Brooklyn and Bridgeport and the Archdiocese of New York where he served as special labor counsel to Cardinal Cooke. He was admired, respected and beloved by his partners for many qualities, not the least of which was his unerring integrity. Fred served for nearly thirty years as a member of the Board of Trustees of St. Joseph's College New York, twelve years as its Chairman, and was instrumental in establishing the College's Long Island campus in Patchogue. He also served as President of the Loyola Council of the Weston School of Theology in Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Frederick T. Shea Scholarship Fund at St. Joseph's College New York, 245 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11205, c/o Sister Elizabeth Hill.

Antnio Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said Mr. Dby had assured him he would not order out the 200,000 refugees in eastern Chad who fled the Darfur conflict in neighboring Sudan. As for the oil dispute, an American deputy assistant secretary of state, Donald Y. Yamamoto, will visit Chad soon to mediate a disagreement over revenues between Chad and the World Bank. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISKE, ALICE H.
description: FISKE--Alice H. Of Sylvester Manor, Shelter Island, NY, on April 17, at age 88. The beloved wife of the late Andrew Fiske, the 13th-generation descendant of Nathaniel Sylvester, who settled Shelter Island in 1652. She helped restore Sylvester Manor and its gardens to their 19th century glory. As the founder of the Andrew Fiske Memorial Center for Archeological Research at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, she sponsored archeological "digs" at Sylvester Manor. She was a supporter of many East End organizations, among which were the Shelter Island Library, Shelter Island Historical Society, and the Shelter Island Garden Club. She is survived by her daughters, Susan Woodworth of Summit, NJ, and Elisabeth Williamson of Severna Park, MD, four grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations in her memory to the Shelter Island Library, PO Box 2016, Shelter Island, NY 11964, or to the Shelter Island Historical Society, Havens House, PO Box 847, Shelter Island, NY 11964. A memorial service will be scheduled later in the Spring.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Man Kills 3 And Himself
description: A catering company driver who was angry that his paycheck was being garnished for child support killed three women and wounded a fourth before killing himself, the St. Louis police said. The driver was identified as Herbert Chalmers Jr. The police said he fatally shot a former girlfriend, Sylvia Haynes, 53, at her home, then went to his employer, Finninger Catering Service, where he killed Cleo Finninger, 79, an owner of the business, and Christine Politte, 44, and wounded another employee before shooting himself, the police said. Earlier in the day, the suspect was seen in a Wal-Mart in Bridgeton with a gun, saying he had killed his child's mother and wanted to kill his boss, the police said. A Wal-Mart employee apparently notified the Bridgeton police, but the shootings took place only minutes later.

Among total viewers, CBS was No. 1, with its average of 11.59 million viewers in prime time, beating NBC (11.42 million) by a pinch. CBS was all repeats except for an original episode of "The New Adventures of Old Christine" (11.48 million). NBC's schedule featured the premiere of "Celebrity Cooking Showdown" (8.71 million), which is on every night this week, and failed to capitalize on its lead-in program, "Deal or No Deal" (15.03 million). title: Putting the Cat Back in the Bag
description: Documents wind up missing from public archives for many reasons. Sometimes they're shelved or labeled incorrectly, or lost, and sometimes they're even stolen. But at the National Archives, documents have been disappearing since 1999 because intelligence officials have wanted them to. And under the terms of two disturbing agreements -- with the C.I.A. and the Air Force -- the National Archives has been allowing officials to reclassify declassified documents, which means removing them from the public eye. So far 55,000 pages, some of them from the 1950's, have vanished. This not only violates the mission of the National Archives; it is also antithetical to the natural flow of information in an open society.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Another Step Back From A New Government
description: As Italy waited for a court decision on its close national elections, President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, 85, said in an interview published yesterday that he did not wish to serve a second seven-year term. His planned retirement added another element of uncertainty to a nation whose politics have been on hold since Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi refused to concede defeat after provisional results showed a slim election loss to Romano Prodi. Now, if Mr. Prodi does win, he will not be able to form a new government until late May, after the incoming Parliament elects a new president. Who will succeed Mr. Ciampi, one if Italy's most respected politicians, is also likely to be the focus of much negotiation, and possible friction, among supporters of Mr. Berlusconi and of Mr. Prodi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, DARWIN
description: DAVIS--Darwin. We are extremely saddened by Darwin's passing and extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. Darwin was a distinguished colleague, a cherished friend to many and an important presence in the insurance industry who clearly led by example. Among his many significant achievements, he joined the prestigious Million Dollar Roundtable, symbolic of success marketing life insurance products, after only two years in the business, and rose to become the first African American senior-level executive at The Equitable, in 1974, as VP in charge of field development. He was later appointed head of marketing for Agency Operations and named to head the Office of External Affairs in 1983. He became Senior Vice President in 1987. Among his many responsibilities in that role, Darwin led The Equitable's Agency Community Relations activities and worked to strengthen the company's relationships with multicultural communities. In 2005, Darwin was featured in a Fortune Magazine cover story, "The Bravest Generation -the inspiring stories of six black pioneers who broke corporate America's color barrier in the '50s and '60s." In February 1988, Black Enterprise Magazine named Darwin one of America's 25 most important and powerful Black executives. He gave of himself so generously to a wide range of civic and community affairs; he received the Lifetime Achievement Awards of the Executive Leadership Council, Jackie Robinson Foundation and the Black Leadership Commission on AIDS and was honored numerous times for his work in the multicultural community. In addition, he served as president of the Jesse Owens Foundation, as a member of the Pepsico Corporate Advisory Board and the Boards of Directors of Carnegie-Mellon University and the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science; founded 100 Black Men of Connecticut, and was a lifetime member of the NAACP, Alpha Phi Alpha and the Boule of Sigma Pi Phi Fraternities, among many other activities. We are extremely proud of all that he accomplished and will miss him greatly. AXA Equitable

description: Education advocates seeking more state aid for New York City public schools appealed to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, yesterday, asking it to force state lawmakers to allocate the extra money before the legislative session ends in June. description: A brush fire in marshlands in Marine Park erupted into a three-alarm blaze last night, causing severe traffic tie-ups on the Belt Parkway and the section of Flatbush Avenue that leads to the Marine Parkway Bridge, fire officials said. The fire, which was brought under control at midnight, was concentrated in the park's golf course and in dense woods and tall grasses opposite Floyd Bennett Field. No one was hurt, a Fire Department spokesman said, and there was no damage to buildings or boats in the nearby marina. Michael Krins, 49, a construction worker who was stuck in traffic on Flatbush Avenue, said that when he passed the fire hours earlier he saw intense high flames spanning an area 200 feet to 300 feet wide. ANN FARMER (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRULWICH, MARILYN ''MICKEY'' LEWIS
description: KRULWICH--Marilyn "Mickey" Lewis. Died peacefully in her Manhattan home April 17. She was 84 years old. Born in Tulsa, Oklahoma, she graduated Goucher College, then joined the Navy during World War II where she attained the rank of Lt. J.G. She married Allen Krulwich, who died in 1980 and she is survived by her children Robert and Sara, and grandchildren Jesse, Nora, Allen, and Samantha, her sisters Rita Rand and Josephine Stayman, her daughters-in-law, Tamar Lewin and Lynn Paltrow and many, many admiring nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Funeral services will be held Friday 11:45 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Justices Hear Case on Right to Choose Defense Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 - The right to counsel is a bedrock constitutional principle, guaranteed to criminal defendants by the Sixth Amendment. But what about the right to a particular lawyer? What about a defendant who wants the best, and can pay for it, but who is required as the result of improper government intervention to settle for second best, or worse?

For the most part, he has the chops and the temperament for this music, and if there were instances of smudged textures or odd phrasing, the performance as a whole had an appealing electricity.

Breslaw, MD, a longtime member of the Department of Medicine staff and a former President of the hospital's Medical Board. We speak not of the havoc far away in San Francisco, which, however awful and tragic, was a single catastrophic event. We speak of something far more long-lived, like the invention of the wheel and the flush toilet.

Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINER, ALVIN
description: STEINER--Alvin. September 10, 1914--April 17, 2006 at his home in Great Neck, NY. Beloved father of Warren and Amy and loving husband of his late wife Edith; brother of the late DeWitt. Retired as a Lieutenant in the NYPD in 1974, he devoted his retirement years to painting, singing, golfing and volunteer activities. In NY, he was involved with the DouglastonLittle Neck Community Ambulance Corps, as well as volunteer programs with school children and seniors. In Delray Beach, FL he was member of the Rainberry Bay choral group, and Community Emergency Response Team. He served for many years as a volunteer member of the Delray Beach Police Department. We will miss his great sense of humor, kindness, integrity and love of life. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Assoc., The American Cancer Society, or your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: 2 Duke Athletes Charged With Rape and Kidnapping
description: DURHAM, N.C., April 18 - Two Duke University lacrosse players were arrested Tuesday in a case in which a woman said she was raped at a team party by three players. title: Out of Asia, Big and Really Big
description: Giant Asian dining destinations keep coming, but Megu Midtown, right, which is to open tomorrow in the Trump World Tower, is a bit more intimate and less striking than its TriBeCa sibling, which opened in 2004. It has 115 seats on two levels that are framed by shimmering curtains on soaring windows. There is more emphasis on tasting menus ($70), less on  la carte dishes. Snarling white tigers decorate a mural behind the central food bar, where chefs will grill over charcoal: 845 First Avenue (47th Street), (212) 964-7777.

A New Breast Cancer Option
description: A large government-sponsored study has found that a drug widely used to prevent bone thinning in women past menopause can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, with fewer serious side effects than the drug currently recommended for breast cancer prevention. The finding has been hailed by some experts as a major advance in the war against cancer and by other experts as a more mixed result whose value is not yet clear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARLEY, ADRIAN MORGAN JR.
description: FARLEY--Adrian Morgan Jr., 93. Died Thursday, April 6 at Edgehill in Stamford, CT. Born in New York City in 1912 he moved to Greenwich, CT in 1920. He was a 1932 graduate of Berkshire School in Sheffield, MA where he was trustee emeritus. A WWII Navy Veteran, he married Harriet Severance McPherson now deceased. He was in the paper business and then the advertising and public relations business in New York City. He was a member of the Church Club of New York City. Funeral is scheduled for 2:30 P.M. Friday, April 21 in the Chapel at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLAPPER, HANS GEORGE
description: CLAPPER--Hans George. Of New York City and Norfolk, Connecticut, died April 17, 2006, at his home. Beloved wife of Ruth. Loving father of Joe and Juliette Clapper and Greg and Joanne Clapper. Devoted grandfather of Hans and Robert Clapper, Liora and David Connor, stepfather of Sharon & Bradley Connor. Born in Vienna, Austria in 1917, he came to the United States in 1936. A World War II Veteran, he served in the Army Intelligence Unit of the 15th Army Group and was the recipient of two Purple Hearts and the Bronze Star. He was Chairman of Wright and Lato, a jewelry Manufacturer and was active in civic and philanthropic organizations throughout his life. This gentleman was a warm and giving friend to all who made his acquaintance. He will be long remembered and sorely missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held on Friday, April 21 at 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the United Jewish Appeal.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebuke After Washington Forum
description: Russia rebuked the United States over a conference in Washington last week that it said "offered a platform for calls to commit new acts of terrorism on Russian territory." The Foreign Ministry summoned the American ambassador, William J. Burns, and delivered an unusually pointed protest. Glen Howard, president of the Jamestown Foundation, which sponsored the conference, said in a telephone interview that no one at the seminar had advocated attacks and that participants simply discussed rising militancy and extremism across the Caucasus -- "the type of things the Kremlin doesn't like to hear."

Our love and deepest sympathy to his adoring parents, Marion and Peter, wonderful sister Shana, loving wife Jennifer, devoted aunt and uncle Ruth and Bernie, and the entire Madoff family. description: It is a bit of poetic justice that the old blue and white striped fabric called seersucker should be in style uptown and down, in town and out.
