title: A Bumble in the Jungle, With Girl-Girl Kisses, in 'In Her Line of Fire'
description: "In Her Line of Fire" begins with an announcement that Congress has passed a universal health care bill and only becomes less plausible from there. Mariel Hemingway stars as Delaney, an ex-marine turned Secret Service agent tasked with the protection of the vice president (David Keith). After their computer-generated plane crash-lands on a remote island, her job entails a great deal of sub-"Rambo" shenanigans as she fends off a guerrilla force led by the usual clich-prone mercenary (David Millbern).

title: Raytheon Chief's Management Rules Have a Familiar Ring
description: William H. Swanson has become something of a management guru thanks to "Swanson's Unwritten Rules of Management." It is a compilation of folksy business advice from Mr. Swanson, the chief executive of Raytheon, that the company distributes as a free booklet. No. 3 in his list of 33 rules begins: "Look for what is missing."

title: Eschenbach and the Philadelphia Orchestra Perform Beethoven and Mahler
description: Christoph Eschenbach's program with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Friday offered alternative methods of writing music. Beethoven's Eighth Symphony is compression and containment, with a lot of energy trapped inside. Beethoven -- crafty, original and sometimes downright funny -- creates tight formats, but not quite the ones he leads listeners to expect.

title: A Book on Beauty With Major Backing
description: Last Tuesday, Rutledge Hill Press, a publishing house in Nashville, released "Universal Beauty: The Miss Universe Guide to Beauty" by Cara Birnbaum. Ms. Birnbaum, a former editor at Cosmopolitan and Allure, spent months interviewing former pageant titleholders and current contestants about their hair, skin and makeup secrets for the coffee table book, which retails for $29.99.

title: Keeping the Defenders From Communicating
description: The main (only?) drawback of a bridge column is that the reader can peek at all 52 cards. At the table as the card play begins, declarer can see only 27 cards -- his hand, the dummy's and the opening lead. If you prefer to try to create an at-the-table situation, cover the East and West hands in the diagramed deal, which occurred during the Rockwell Mixed Pairs at the Spring North American Championships in Dallas this month. You are the declarer in four spades after the given auction. West leads the diamond three, which is, given his two-diamond response and East's raise, fifth-highest from a five- or six-card suit. How would you plan the play?

The first installment was offered on Saturday evening, and already there was a glitch: Ichizo Okashiro's "Starry Night" was deemed too difficult, and was postponed. Still, the remaining scores, by Julia Wolfe, Benedict Mason and John Musto, made for a full and varied evening.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Silent Hill' Is on Top
description: Mixed genres characterized the weekend box office, with three wide releases scattered among some powerful holdovers. "Silent Hill" (Sony), an R-rated horror film starring Radha Mitchell, below, as a mother searching for her ailing daughter in a creepy suburb, opened at No. 1 with $20.2 million, according to studio estimates. "Scary Movie 4" (Weinstein Company) dropped to No. 2 with $17 million, according to Exhibitor Relations, bringing its 10-day gross to $67.7 million. "The Sentinel" (Fox), a political thriller starring Michael Douglas as a framed Secret Service agent seeking vindication, opened in third place with $14.6 million, followed by two holdovers: "Ice Age: The Meltdown" (Fox), which fell to No. 4 with $12.8 million, for cumulative sales of $167.8 million, and "The Wild" (Buena Vista), which took in $8 million at No. 5, for a 10-day gross of $21.9 million. "American Dreamz" (Universal), the satirical comedy directed by Paul Weitz ("About a Boy"), which spoofs an American pop show (headlined by Hugh Grant) as well as an American president (played by Dennis Quaid), opened at No. 8 with $3.7 million in ticket sales. Over all, the box office was up for the fifth weekend in a row, with ticket sales 22 percent higher than the same weekend last year. CATHERINE BILLEY

A crew had bulldozed a 300-foot-long trench along a giant drill bit in their desperate attempt to yank it loose from the riverbed. A supervisor later told him that the project's crews knew that drilling the holes was not possible, but that they had been instructed by the company in charge of the project to continue anyway.

Her loving sister Nancy Montgomery also survives her. Marjorie was so fortunate to have so many caring nieces, nephews and grandnieces, Caitlin Weissman, Lisa French, Carol French, Edward French, Avery and Margaret Weissman. Bloomberg announced a tentative contract yesterday with two unions representing 2,800 workers and supervisors at the Fire Department's Emergency Medical Service: Local 2507, representing emergency medical technicians and paramedics, and Local 3621, representing lieutenants and captains. The four-year agreement, retroactive to July 1, 2002, includes a $1,000 lump-sum payment and an 8 percent pay increase for members of the two locals, which are part of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The starting salary for newly hired technicians will be $27,295, down from $31,272; newly hired paramedics will be paid $37,346, down from $37,712. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

Lucian Chalfen, a spokesman for the Westchester County district attorney, said that the DNA linked Mr. Grant, 44, to the victim, Concetta Russo-Carriero, 56. Defense lawyers have also sought to have a confession Mr. Grant made to a police officer at the time of his arrest thrown out, arguing that he made it before his Miranda rights were read. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Coast Guard Relaxes Photo Policy

Mr. Hakim, an American-born convert to Islam, has been a merchant mariner since the 1970's and wore his round knitted skullcap in official photos for more than 20 years. title: Memo Pad
description: SECURITY EXPEDITING PROGRAM -- The Transportation Security Administration expects to have registered traveler programs running in 10 to 20 airports "as soon as this summer," said Kip Hawley, the head of the agency. The program will allow travelers who undergo a security check to buy an electronic identity card encoded with biometric data like fingerprints and iris scans; cardholders would then use designated lanes to speed their way through security. The agency has not yet said what specific time-saving benefits cardholders can expect. In its latest directive on the program last week, the agency approved a basic business model that requires the private companies operating the lanes to ensure that their cards are compatible with all competing programs and that cardholder privacy measures are in place. "While the combination of benefits and security measures available at each participating airport may vary," the agency said, all members of the program "should receive an expedited and more convenient checkpoint experience." The only registered traveler program currently in operation is run by Verified Identity Pass at Orlando International Airport in Florida; membership costs $79.95 a year. Steven Brill, the founder of Verified Identity, hailed Mr. Hawley's "clear promise" that the program would offer expedited screening. Mr. Brill said he expected that his company would introduce programs by June in Indianapolis, Cincinnati and San Jose, Calif., and at eight other airports in the summer and fall. Competitors are developing similar programs and preparing to start some of them this summer.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: $100 Million Authorized For Renovation
description: The General Assembly's budget committee approved appropriating $23.5 million and -- over the lone objection of the United States -- authorizing another $77 million needed to move forward on a $1.6 billion plan to renovate the United Nations headquarters complex. The $100 million will go to pre-construction commitments on a temporary building for the seven years it will take to refurbish the buildings. The committee also postponed for three days a showdown decision on Secretary General Kofi Annan's plan for overhauling the United Nations management, which is being disputed by developing nations that complain that it shifts power to the largest donor nations. Ms. Anderson, 39, graduated from Yale Law School, where she was notes editor of The Yale Law Journal and editor of The Yale Journal of Law and Feminism. She also clerked for a federal Court of Appeals judge in Los Angeles. She succeeds Kristin Booth Glen, who stepped down last year. CUNY also announced that Garrie W. Moore, 56, the associate provost and vice chancellor for student life at East Carolina University, would be its next vice chancellor for student development, succeeding Otis O. Hill. title: Arts, Briefly; Dj Vu All Over Again
description: As strange as it might seem, viewers actually watch clip shows, those recycled montage episodes that purport to bring the audience up to date on a series. On Sunday, the "Desperate Housewives" (15.78 million viewers) and "Grey's Anatomy" (14.44 million) clip shows were the night's two most-watched programs, and led ABC in its win in Nielsen's estimates. CBS ranked second among total viewers for the night. But its "60 Minutes" (11.28 million), "Cold Case" (12.46 million) and the television movie "In From the Night" (10.54 million) placed fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. Fox placed second in that age group, led by "The Simpsons" (7.04 million) and "Family Guy" (8.04 million). NBC was No. 3 in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. At 10 p.m. "Crossing Jordan" (11.28 million) was the network's most-watched show. Earlier in the night, Rob Lowe returned to "The West Wing" (8.42 million) as the likely deputy chief of staff in the Santos administration, and forced the unhinged Josh (Bradley Whitford) to take a vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MADOFF, ROGER
description: MADOFF--Roger. On your birthday I thank you for your gift. You graced us with your presence on this earth for only a short time, but that time was filled with love, laughter, sincerity, integrity and honor. My beloved brother, you always understood me and cared for me like no one could. You brightened my world with your incredible sense of humor and wit. Rebecca will never forget all the lessons she learned from her Uncle Roger. She loves you as I do with all her heart. We will miss you, think of you everyday, and smile when we speak your name. Happy Birthday. Your Devoted Sister and Niece and Goddaughter, Shana and Rebecca

title: Mozart's Reputation and Influence: By Word and Example
description: Charles Rosen's career is founded as firmly on his lucid thinking and writing about music as on his piano playing, but the two have always been closely allied. His recordings have given persuasive weight to the ideas that he has pursued in his writing, particularly about 18th- and 20th-century composers. And his series at the 92nd Street Y -- a 45-minute lecture followed, after a short break, by a full recital -- have given listeners something extra to mull over, beyond his choice of repertory and whether the performances of this or that work matched their expectations.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: University Security Breach
description: About 160,000 Social Security numbers belonging to faculty and staff members, students and many alumni were downloaded by a hacker who penetrated the computer system of the business school at the University of Texas at Austin, the university confirmed. The security breach, which was discovered Friday, may have occurred as early as April 11, campus officials said. There have been no reports so far of attempted identify theft, a university spokesman said. A former student was sentenced to probation and fined last year for hacking into a separate University of Texas computer system and accessing 40,000 Social Security numbers. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUMANN, JULIUS GERSHON, RABBI DR.
description: NEUMANN--Julius Gershon, Rabbi Dr. On 10 April 12 Nissan. Survived by beloved wife of 62 years, Rebbetzin Esther and loving children FranE (Shalom), Rabbi Tully (Joan), Nina (Serge) and the late Joshua (Rochelle). Devoted son of the late Sarah and Benjamin, beloved brother of Mrs. Maria Roth, Mrs. Lillian Gruen and Dr. Elizabeth Neumann. Adoring Zaidy of twelve grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Rabbi of Cong Zichron Moshe for 57 years, nurtured and served three generations of beloved congregants. Commissioner of Human Rights under Mayors Wagner and Lindsay. Member and Secretary Board of Visitors Manhattan State Hospital under Governors Harriman and Rockefeller. Staunch supporter of the State of Israel, honored for his tireless efforts on behalf of UJA, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, Israel Bonds, Soviet Jewry and countless Yeshivot and Rabbinical Institutions. He leaves a moral and ethical legacy: his life of Tzedakah (righteous acts) and Chessed (loving kindness). His Petira (passing) is a profound loss to his family, the myriad of lives he touched and to all who loved him. May his soul be bound to life eternal through our acts of kindness and our sweet memories. Shloshim Memorial Service Sunday 7th May at 2:00 at Cong Zichron Moshe 342 East 20th St.

description: An article on April 8 about New York City's plan to turn the closed Fresh Kills landfill into a park referred incorrectly to the harvesting of methane gas there. The city has in fact been harvesting and selling methane from the landfill since 1983; it would not be a new venture. The methane is distributed as natural gas to property owners; it is not converted into electricity.

title: Citing Security, Plants Use Safer Chemicals
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 - At least 225 industrial plants in this country have switched to using less dangerous chemicals since the 2001 terrorist attacks, lowering the risk that people nearby would be injured or killed by toxic plumes, a new study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADLER, GERALDINE SHIRLEY
description: NADLER--Geraldine Shirley. Age 98, passed away on Friday 7AM, April 21, 2006, at University Hospital at Tamarac, FL. Beloved wife for 53 years to Samuel C. Nadler, D.D.S., devoted mother to son Robert and daughter Wendy, cherished grandmother of Elizabeth Weinstein & Aaron Jettleson and beloved great grandmother of Devorah, Shoshana and Moshe Weinstein, Geraldine imbued her entire family with a love for literature and life. She worked as a successful sales representative for color photograph services in NYC until she was almost 80. She was exceedingly generous. She enjoyed parties, theatre, and a good game of canasta. She inspired countless nieces and nephews with her verve and energy including Joyce Oldak Scott, Emily Oldak, Jane Buchman and the late Susan Wolfson, Dr. Peter Oldak, Eliot Oldak, Lee Oldak. She will be remembered with love and greatly missed by all who knew her. Funeral Tuesday 3:30PM, at Levitt Weinstein Funeral Home, 8135 W. McNab Road, Tamarc, FL.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Audit Faults Staten Island Yankees
description: The Staten Island Yankees owe the city $570,202 in utility fees and late payment charges, according to an audit issued yesterday by City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. The audit also accused the minor-league baseball team of failing to properly count and report attendance. The team has a 20-year lease with the city's Economic Development Corporation for exclusive use of the Richmond County Bank Ballpark. The audit noted that the comptroller's office and the team disagreed on how to properly count attendance. Josh Getzler, an owner of the team and its chief operating officer, said the team has "been working closely with the E.D.C. to satisfy all of the comptroller's concerns." SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 10, Eroding Sri Lanka Cease-Fire
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 25 A The frayed cease-fire accord between the government and the ethnic Tamil rebels seemed closer to collapse today, as the air force fired on rebel-controlled areas after a suicide bomber attacked the military headquarters here. The attack killed 10 people and injured at least 28, including the country's top military official.

title: Rebuilding of Iraqi Pipeline as Disaster Waiting to Happen
description: When Robert Sanders was sent by the Army to inspect the construction work an American company was doing on the banks of the Tigris River, 130 miles north of Baghdad, he expected to see workers drilling holes beneath the riverbed to restore a crucial set of large oil pipelines, which had been bombed during the invasion of Iraq.What he found instead that day in July 2004 looked like some gargantuan heart-bypass operation gone nightmarishly bad. A crew had bulldozed a 300-foot-long trench along a giant drill bit in their desperate attempt to yank it loose from the riverbed. A supervisor later told him that the project's crews knew that drilling the holes was not possible, but that they had been instructed by the company in charge of the project to continue anyway.

description: JDA Software has agreed to acquire supply-chain software maker Manugistics in a deal that values the company at $211 million. Under the terms of the transaction, JDA will pay $2.50 for each Manugistics share.

title: Richard Clarke Buys Himself Some Security
description: Richard Clarke has $50 million burning a hole in his pocket. Mr. Clarke, the former White House security adviser who criticized President Bush for a lack of focus on counterterrorism prior to Sept. 11, 2001, and the former chief executives of two technology companies have created Good Harbor Partners Acquisition.

title: Dont Call Us: Vodafones Relationship with Goldman Sachs Beginning to Sour
description: Vodafone is probably Goldman Sachs best ever European client. The mobile giant used the bank for iconic transactions like the hostile Mannesmann bid. But, in another sign of how the banks franchise as a trusted adviser is being eroded, the deep relationship has deteriorated, according to Breakingviews.

title: Judge Questions Fairness of IPO Settlement
description: A federal judge Monday expressed skepticism about the fairness of a settlement agreement that would guarantee $1 billion in damages to 17 million plaintiffs in a raft of pending class-action lawsuits centered around hot initial public offerings during the tech boom. title: ICBC May Limit IPO to Boost Returns Per Share
description: Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, planning the worlds biggest initial public offering for six years, may limit new shares to 50 percent of the sale in a bid to boost demand. Capping new equity in the $10 billion I.P.O. will help the Beijing-based lender deliver returns per share similar to those of Hong Kong-listed China Construction Bank, sources told Bloomberg News.

description: Greenfield Indian refinery and petrochemicals company Reliance Petroleum surprised the market Monday by pricing its initial public offering just above the mid-point of the indicated price range despite the fact that more than 99 percent of all orders were placed at the top end of the range.

description: A number of factors are leading venture capitalists to pump more money into startup companies: an improved economy, greater broadband penetration and new Internet and wireless applications that make it easy for people to share digital photos, videos and text.

title: Illinois Governor Awards Stem Cell Grants
description: Gov. Rod Blagojevich awarded $10 million in Illinois state grants Monday to encourage stem-cell research and said he will look for ways to continue funding even if lawmakers refuse to support it. The Democratic governor, who was criticized by Republicans for slipping the $10 million unnoticed into this years state budget, wouldnt say how he might get around opponents again.

title: Software Chief Admits Guilt in Fraud Case
description: Just two weeks before they were to go on trial, two former top executives of Computer Associates International, the once-booming software company, pleaded guilty yesterday to eight counts each of securities fraud and obstruction of justice in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

description: Forbidden from publishing dissenting opinions and guarded in their relations with the media, the judges who sit on the European Unions second-highest tribunal were once a picture of unanimity when they pronounced on merger reviews, trademark law and trade disputes.

title: Skype Rings In Ground-Breaking Deal With Music Publishers
description: Internet phone giant Skype has reached deals with four major music publishers that will pave the way for it to launch an online music store. The deal, which the companies say is the first of its kind, will allow Skype to license the copyrights from EMI Music Publishing, Warner Chappell, Sony/ATV and MCPS-PRS for downloading and ringtones, as well as for a subscription music service.

title: Ex-Stockbroker Is Sentenced For Illegal Trading in 2004
description: A former stockbroker was sentenced yesterday to home detention and probation for trading on secret news about the acquisition of Metron Technology by Applied Materials. He learned about the takeover from his girlfriend, who was a lawyer on the deal.

title: Sentence in Tip Selling
description: A former floor clerk at the New York Stock Exchange has been sentenced to a year and a day in prison for alerting a day trader to orders by institutional clients of the clerks employer, the brokerage firm Lawrence Helfant. In addition to imposing the term on Friday, Federal District Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Brooklyn ordered the floor clerk, Frank Furino, 50, of Port Washington, N.Y., to pay $150,000 in restitution, according to court records.

title: On Wall Street, Whats Good for The Google Is Not Good for The Times

Consider, if you will, the differing ways the Street is treating The New York Times Company and Google, both of which have high-voting stock for insiders and low-voting stock for regular old public shareholders.

title: Will PE Firms Continue Their Spree Unfettered?
description: Private equity firms have enjoyed a perfect storm over the past year. This was the consensus of three industry leaders speaking last Thursday at a forum hosted by the Conference Board and the Week magazine. Low interest rates, enormous global liquidity, receptive capital markets, and a continuing flow of money into the sector from corporate pension funds have meant rapidly growing coffers and nonstop activity. But the big question is: Will the government leave them alone?

It backs an offer worth 22.5 billion euros by Gas Natural, the country's biggest gas provider. The antitrust clearance adds to European warnings to Spain not to block E.On and comes after a Spanish court suspended Gas Natural's bid on April 21. title: Lethal Cruelty

In today's case, Clarence Hill, a condemned man, is arguing that it would be unconstitutional for Florida to execute him with what he contends are its flawed lethal injection procedures. The case comes to the court in a tricky procedural posture that poses the question of whether Mr. Hill should be able to bring his claim at all. National Briefing | Education: Testing Officials Questioned On Errors
description: Margaret Spellings, the secretary of education, questioned testing industry executives about recent errors in test scoring and the industry's ability to handle the volume generated by the No Child Left Behind law, the Bush administration's centerpiece education measure. In a telephone news conference after the meeting, Ray Simon, the deputy education secretary, said the industry "assured us they did have the capacity" and that problems were the result of human error, not volume. "From the very beginning, we had concerns about the capacity of the testing companies to handle N.C.L.B. testing, and these things were brought to a head by some of the most recent scoring errors reported," Mr. Simon said, referring to mistakes involving the College Board's SAT tests. Organizations represented at the meeting included the College Board, the Educational Testing Service, Pearson Educational Measurement, CTB/McGraw-Hill and Harcourt Assessment.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Former Executive Settles Election Inquiry
description: James W. Treffinger, left, the former Essex County executive, his former campaign committee and a campaign staff member have agreed to pay $171,000 to settle an investigation by the Federal Election Commission, the commission announced yesterday. In May 2003, Mr. Treffinger pleaded guilty to corruption charges in Federal District Court on an unrelated matter. The election commission said Mr. Treffinger improperly used campaign funds to pay his legal fees. After negotiations with the commission, Mr. Treffinger, the staff member and the committee admitted accepting excessive contributions, the commission said. A call to Mr. Treffinger's lawyer was not returned last evening.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Rises
description: An index of business confidence in Germany hit a 15-year high in April, signaling a continuation of economic strength that appeared at the start of the year. The index, compiled by the Ifo Institute, rose to 105.9, its highest since April 1991, as industry brushed off high oil prices and a strengthening euro to express strong confidence in economic prospects for the next six months. Economists said the data confirmed a German economic rebound that was likely to continue into the middle of next year.

description: Cadbury Schweppes, the soft drink maker, agreed to pay $353 million to gain control of the Dr Pepper/Seven Up bottling unit in the United States from its partner in the joint venture, the Carlyle Group. Cadbury, which is based in London, said it was buying Carlyle's 53 percent stake in Dr Pepper/Seven Up and the remaining shares to take full ownership. The Carlyle Group is based in Washington.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Conflicts At Drug Agency
description: At least one outside adviser had financial ties to a drug maker whose product was at issue in 73 percent of 221 advisory panel meetings held by the Food and Drug Administration, a study has found. Yet only one in 100 panelists with potential conflicts were removed because of the links, said researchers who studied the agency's advisory meetings from 2001 to 2004. The study, published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, found that the most common ties were payments for consulting, grants or investments. Removing members with conflicts of interest would not have reversed the votes at the meetings studied, the researchers said, but it might have made the rulings less favorable. A spokeswoman for the agency said it had a strict code of ethics.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Top Leader Wins Another Term
description: Vietnam sent a signal of stability by handing a second five-year term to the Communist Party general secretary, Nong Duc Manh, 56, left, who has been the country's top leader during a period of economic liberalization and growth. At the eight-day party congress in Hanoi, Mr. Manh, 56, said he wanted the liberalization to accelerate as Vietnam sought to integrate itself with the world economy, aiming to join the World Trade Organization by the end of this year. A new 14-member Politburo, the nation's highest decision-making body, was also announced, and the party congress mandated a change in the three top government positions: president, prime minister and chairman of the National Assembly. In the most visible of those posts, Prime Minister Phan Van Khai, 72, is expected to be replaced by his deputy, Nguyen Tan Dung, 56, the youngest member of the Politburo.

description: ROSSOFF--Annie Rosenblum. Died April 25, 2006, age 89 in Southbury, CT. Born in Orangeburg, S.C., attended Winthrop College and Columbia University School of Library Science. There, she met Martin Rossoff, her loving and beloved husband for 63 years. Head Librarian at Midwood High School, Brooklyn, she enjoyed cooking, entertaining, folk and square dancing, bridge, travel and reading. She will be remembered for her warm friendships, enthusiasm for life and dauntless optimism. She was loved by all who knew her. title: Arts, Briefly; From 18 to 49, Fox Is Tops

Fox was led, as always, by its two episodes of "American Idol," which were the most-watched programs of the week in Nielsen's estimates. Helping its ratings for this week, Fox eked out a win on Monday among 18-to-49-year-olds. Its "Prison Break" (8.42 million) and "24" (12.83 million) combined to scrape by CBS and NBC in that age group. CBS drew the most total viewers over all, as its "CSI: Miami" (18.19 million) was the night's most popular show. Romance is blooming on the chilly procedural, which has Horatio (David Caruso) possibly heading toward marriage, as well as a love triangle among Miami's lint-picking lab police. The crime series easily beat its 10 p.m. rivals, NBC's "Medium" (9.67 million) and ABC's sinking "What About Brian" (5.44 million). KATE AURTHUR

description: Sovereign Bancorp said late Monday it expects to close its $3.6 billion pending acquisition of Independence Community Bank of New York and the $2.4 billion investment by Spains Banco Santander Central Hispano in Sovereign on or before June 1, subject to regulatory approvals.

title: General Dynamics Delays Deadline for Anteon Acquisition
description: General Dynamics has extended the deadline for completing its proposed acquisition of Anteon International because the federal government has not completed a review of the $2.2 billion transaction.

title: M&T Bank Gathers Citibank Branches
description: M&T Bank said Tuesday it will buy Citibank North Americas 21-branch upstate New York franchise to gain market share in bank deposits in the Buffalo and Rochester areas. No terms were disclosed. Buffalo-based M&T Bank (Research) will acquire $274 million in loans and assume $1.1 billion in deposits from Citibank, a unit of Citigroup.

title: Wireless Services Picks Up Mobile Medias Signal
description: Wireless Services plans to announce an acquisition today that places it in line to deliver content to the mobile phone, one of the hottest sectors in the wireless industry. The Bellevue, Wash. company said it has acquired Mobile Media North America of Vienna, Va., for an undisclosed amount in cash. With the acquisition, the company will be able to help companies deliver text messages or other content directly to the consumer without having to go through the carrier

title: Bank of China I.P.O. May Unleash Anti-Foreign Backlash
description: Bank of China, the countrys third-largest lender, will this week seek regulatory approval to raise up to $8 billion in Hong Kong, in a listing that could hand foreign investors led by Royal Bank of Scotland a paper profit of more than $4 billion.

title: Investment Firm on Track for  I.P.O. of Bertelsmann Stake
description: The chairman of Belgian investment firm Groupe Bruxelles Lambert said Tuesday he will go ahead with a long-anticipated initial public offering on the companys 25 percent stake in German media conglomerate Bertelsmann. Talks will begin the next month with the German media group on the I.P.O., GBL Chairman Albert Frere told the holding companys annual general meeting. He has the option to demand an I.P.O. starting next month.

title: EHealth  Files for IPO
description: EHealth, an online seller of health insurance, Tuesday said it plans to go public in an initial stock offering worth as much as $85 million. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., didnt disclose the number of shares to be offered or an estimated price range in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Indian Bank Raises Cash from GDR Sale
description: The Mumbai stock market may have had trouble topping the 12,000 mark over the past few days. But those problems have not stopped Indias Kotak Mahinda Bank from raising $99.9 million from its first ever global depositary receipts over the weekend.

title: Engelhard Plans Recapitalization to Fend Off BASF
description: Engelhard, the United States chemical company that has been resisting an uninvited takeover approach from Germanys BASF, said Wednesday that its board has authorized a recapitalization plan. The recap would include a self-tender offer for 20 percent of Engelhards shares at $45 apiece; that compares with BASFs offer of $38 per share, which Engelhard rejected.

title: Court Gives Neil Young Firm OK  for Model Train Venture
description: Rocker Neil Young Tuesday won a bankruptcy court ruling to form a joint venture with Lionel, the storied model train maker operating under protection from creditors.

title: Banks Dont Want Wal-Mart on Their Turf
description: Community and regional bank officials presented a nearly unified front Tuesday in opposing Wal-Mart Storess application to form its own bank.

title: G.M.A.C. Sale Is Cleared
description: General Motors sale of a majority stake in its financing unit to a group led by the private equity group Cerberus Capital Management received clearance yesterday from federal antitrust enforcers.

title: For Sun Microsystems, a Leader With Little Taste for Convention
description: Jonathan I. Schwartz, the new chief executive of Sun Microsystems, comes to the role of business strategist naturally. Maybe the future of Sun, he has suggested more than once, lies in the companys ability to sell services rather than software or hardware.

title: Ken Lay Holds His Ground
description: In his second day on the stand in his criminal fraud trial, Kenneth L. Lay, Enrons former chairman and chief executive, remained defiant, blaming Enrons former chief financial officer and newspaper articles for causing the market panic that led to the companys downfall, while saying there were no underlying problems with the business.

title: Taking $1 for the Team
description: In corporate America, few status symbols rival the one-figure salary.

title: Microsoft in European Court Says 2004 Ruling Is a Failure
description: While Microsoft and the European Commission took turns denouncing each others interpretation of events that resulted in the 2004 antitrust ruling against the company, they did agree on one thing on Tuesday: The commissions remedy for restoring competition in the market for software that plays music and videos has failed.

title: Developer Takes a Financial Deal for Ground Zero
description: The developer Larry A. Silverstein announced yesterday that he had accepted the economic terms of a new deal at ground zero. The proposal reduces his overall role on the 16-acre site and clears the way for construction of the Freedom Tower, the tallest and most symbolically important of five towers planned for the site.

title: Refco Creditors Seek Money From Bank
description: Creditors in the bankruptcy filing of Refco have filed court papers accusing an Austrian bank, Bawag, of aiding in the fraud by the firms former chief executive and asking that the bank return more than $1.3 billion.

title: Electronic Arts Settles Overtime Suits
description: Electronic Arts has agreed to settle the second of two class-action suits that alleged the company illegitimately avoided paying overtime to some of its employees.

title: Calpers Questions Pay at UnitedHealth
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest public pension fund, said yesterday that the UnitedHealth Group, the health insurance company, must explain the $2.4 billion in stock options granted to its top executives.

title: Spitzer Announces  Indictments in Mortgage Fraud
description: The New York Attorney General and the states banking department on Tuesday announced the indictments of eight individuals who are accused of participating in a scheme that defrauded residential mortgage lenders of tens of tens of millions of dollars over the past five years.

title: Director of Small Business Administration Resigns
description: Hector V. Barreto, the embattled head of the Small Business Administration, said on Tuesday that he would resign and take over a Hispanic advocacy group that has supported some of President Bushs initiatives. Mr. Barreto, who had run the agency since 2001, said he had not been asked to resign but had decided that this was the perfect time to change jobs.

title: The Two Sides of the Biovail-Overstock Story
description: Are Biovail and Overstock.com promising companies victimized by unscrupulous investors illegally conspiring with stock analysts and journalists? Or are they troubled firms whose executives have turned to wild conspiracy theories to divert attention from underlying business problems?

title: Walking Barefoot in Donald Trump Park
description: Donald Trump is donating 436 acres straddling two counties just north of New York City to create a state park in his name. The property, located about 45 miles from the city in Yorktown, is made up of two separate parcels and will be used for recreation such as hiking, said Peter Constantakes, spokesman for Gov. George Pataki.

title: Slide Show: Currents
description: The little house that came home, satyrs and other sculptures to adorn the backyard, new work from creative Brooklynites and more.

title: Slide Show: Personal Shopper
description: Some new clocks are so out of the ordinary that they require lessons in how to tell time.

title: Goldman Sachs C.E.O. Talks Back to Firms Critics
description: Goldman Sachs chief executive Henry Paulson Jr. defends his firms private equity and investing activities and talked about his future plans in a question-and-answer session with The Wall Street Journal.

Gilbert Whites Selborne Journal: Monday, 26 April 1784: 29 4/10; 49; SW. Showers, dark & mild, wet. Wagtail about. Crocuss out of bloom. Sowed a crop of onions, & several sorts of cabbage: pronged the asparagus beds. Radishes grow.

title: Mars Shores Up Pet-Care Business With Doane Deal
description: Candymaker Mars announced Wednesday that it will acquire the parent company of private-label pet food maker Doane Pet Care from Teachers Private Capital, the private equity arm of Ontario Teachers Pension Plan. The move is part of Mars effort to strengthen its pet care unit.

title: Blackstone Unloads German Cable Group
description: Swedish buyout firm EQT, controlled by the Wallenberg family, agreed to buy German cable, telephone and Internet service provider Kabel Baden-Wurttemberg from the Blackstone Group. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday the deal was valued at 1.3 billion euro ($1.6 billion), though an EQT spokesman declined to comment on the price.

title: Many Hedge Fund Advisers Hear From S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is making the rounds in Greenwich, Conn., and other centers of hedge fund activity, as the agency takes what The Financial Times is calling a more rigorous than expected stance in inspecting these investment pools.

title: Inter-Tel Hires UBS to Help Fight Takeover Bid
description: Inter-Tel said Wednesday that it has retained UBS as an adviser as part of its effort to fend off a takeover bid by the companys former chief executive.

title: Whats Good About High Gas Prices
Liberty Media Heads to Nasdaq; Another Loss for N.Y.S.E.
description: After Liberty Media splits into two companies, both stocks will trade on the Nasdaq, Chief Executive Greg Maffei told CNBCs Charles Gasparino. Libertys Class A and Class B shares are now trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Merrill Banker Warns of Brutal Private Equity Shake-Out
description: Private equity shops are headed into another huge year for fund-raising, but one Merrill Lynch banker sees some trouble ahead for firms whose returns have lagged the industry average.

title: Cerberus Won G.M.A.C, But What Does It Have to Lose?
description: As a group led by Cerberus Capital Management prepares to take a controlling stake in General Motors financing arm, money managers are still trying to wrap their heads around the complex $14 billion transaction, which pitted Cerberus against a group including buyout giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: China Should Be California Dreamin
description: Readers respond to Thomas Friedmans Apr. 26 column, Go West, Old Men

title: Op-Ed Puzzle Archive
description: Puzzles: Country Club (Oct. 22, 2007)

title: Lockheed to Reconsider Boeing Joint Venture
description: As a months-long investigation by the Federal Trade Commission continues to drag on, Lockheed Martin said it plans to review its decision to merge its satellite-launching rocket business with rival Boeing. The Washington Post reported the review on Wednesday, just two days after Reuters said antitrust regulators were close to approving the deal.

title: New York Hospitals May Split  Or Merge
description: Lenox Hill Hospital and the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital are re-examining their relationship, in light of financial troubles, according to The New York Observer.

title: Sharpe James: Fighting His Way Out the Door
description: With only a few months to go before leaving office, Sharpe James seems determined to jab and uppercut like a lame duck on steroids. Earlier this week, he fired a revered preservationist and arts advocate from the citys Landmarks and Historic Preservation Commission after she criticized the mayor for naming new members to several city boards, ensuring that they would serve through the next mayors first term, with the opportunity to block his agenda.

title: Royal Treatment
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Former Bankers Trust Building Sold for $1.2 Billion
description: Boston Properties has agreed to sell the former Bankers Trust building in New York City for $1.2 billion. The sale price represents a healthy profit over the $323 million it paid for the office tower, located at 280 Park Avenue, nearly nine years ago. It was the first building that Boston Properties bought after completing its initial public offering in June 1997.

title: How to Clear the Clutter of Speaker Wires
description: OK, am I the only person on earth who finds it incredibly annoying that the average PC doesnt have built-in speakers?

title: Should The New York Times Go Private?
description: In light of a Morgan Stanley portfolio managers recent hectoring of The New York Times Company over its two-tiered stock structure, The New York Observer examined whether it would make sense for the company to go private.

title: Reservations About Reservations
description: Taavo Somer, one of the owners of Freemans, says that his restaurant is trying to diminish the wait time for a table.(Photo: Rahav Segev for The New York Times).

title: Morgan Stanley Bankers in Europe Jump to HSBC
description: HSBC has hired two investment bankers away from Morgan Stanley to boost its presence in leveraged lending, a business that includes providing funds for private equity deals. Kevin Adeson joins HSBCs corporate, investment banking and markets division as global head of leveraged finance, and Oliver Duff comes aboard as global head of leveraged finance syndicate.

title: Bracewell & Giuliani Builds Out New York M&A Practice
description: Houston-based Bracewell & Guiliani has recruited three former Linklaters lawyers for its mergers and acquisitions advisory practice in New York.

title: Democrats Fall on Snow
description: If you bought stock in weather-related puns, its time to cash in: Tony Snow, a Fox News anchor and talk-radio host, is President Bushs new press secretary. In an ABC News blog entry titled Snow Day, George Stephanopoulos gives his thoughts on what the transition from journalism to politics will be like for Snow, from the perspective of someone who took the opposite route. For Snow, the biggest adjustment is psychological, Stephanopoulos writes. Hes been out of the White House on his own for more than 15 years, voicing his own opinions, building his own audience. Now hell have to learn to squelch his private views and deliver the party line with conviction.

title: Smile, Mayor James. And About That $80 Million . . .
description: Sharpe James (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

title: Revisiting Afghanistan
description: Things are finally settling down enough to allow me the time to do the actual thing I get paid to do: create art.

title: Blair Under Siege as Cabinet Blunders Abound
description: LONDON, April 27  Bad luck came in threes this week for Prime Minister Tony Blair, whose increasingly unpopular government suddenly found itself beset by three wildly dissimilar but equally embarrassing problems, each involving a different cabinet minister.

title: Guilty Verdicts in New Jersey Worker-Safety Trial
description: A federal jury found a New Jersey pipe foundry and four of its managers guilty yesterday of conspiring to evade workplace safety and environmental laws by lying to regulators, tampering with evidence and bullying employees into silence about dangerous working conditions. One manager was acquitted.

title: Highway of Heavenly Views Turns Commute Into Hell
description: MONTARA, Calif.  Living in a state prone to earthquakes, wildfires, floods and mudflows, many Californians would consider a road closed by rock slides a minor nuisance. Unless they live near Devil's Slide, a coastal bluff along Pacific Coast Highway known as much for its precarious pitch as for its panoramic vistas.

title: A Different Press Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  In formally naming the Fox News commentator Tony Snow to be his press secretary on Wednesday, President Bush completed a decade-long transformation of the role of the presidential spokesman from behind-the-scenes functionary to daily on-camera personality.

title: National Archives Says Records Were Wrongly Classified
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  An audit by the National Archives of more than 25,000 historical documents withdrawn from public access since 1999 found that more than a third did not contain sensitive information justifying classification, archives officials announced Wednesday.

title: Marburg Vaccine Effective on Infected Monkeys
description: For the first time, an experimental vaccine against the deadly Marburg virus has been shown to work in monkeys even if the shot is not given until after the animals have been infected.

title: World Briefing: Americas, Europe, Australia and Asia
description: AMERICAS

title: Olmert Clinches Coalition Deal in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, April 27  Ehud Olmert, Israel's prime minister designate, clinched a partnership agreement with the left-leaning Labor Party today and appeared close to forming a coalition government following last month's election victory by his centrist Kadima party.

title:
Republicans 
Offer Plan on
Gas Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Republican senators offered a relief package today for a public dismayed by rising gasoline prices. Trying to get out front on an issue that seems certain to be a factor in this fall's elections, the senators proposed a $100 "gas-tax holiday" in the form of a rebate check for every family.

title: Chicago Prohibits Foie Gras
description: CHICAGO, April 26  The City Council voted Wednesday to make Chicago the first city in the country to outlaw the sale of foie gras, the fatty livers of geese and ducks that many consider a delicacy but animal rights advocates describe as a product of inhumane treatment.

title: Chad and World Bank Strike Deal on Oil
description: The central African nation of Chad, which had tried to violate its agreement with the World Bank to dedicate most of the revenues from a bank-supported oil pipeline to poverty reduction, reached an interim deal with the bank yesterday that would give the bank and Chad three months to reach a final settlement, a bank official said.

title: Egyptian Police Beat and Arrest Judges' Supporters
description: CAIRO, Egypt, April 27  Thousands of riot police sealed off access to Egypt's High Court today, beating and arresting protesters who turned out to support two judges brought before a disciplinary panel for declaring that there was fraud in previous elections.

title: European Inquiry Says C.I.A. Flew 1,000 Flights in Secret
description: BRUSSELS, April 26  Investigators for the European Parliament said Wednesday that data gathered from air safety regulators and others found that the Central Intelligence Agency had flown 1,000 undeclared flights over European territory since 2001.

title: 80,000 Native Canadians to Be Compensated for School Abuse
description: TORONTO, April 26  In a long delayed conclusion to a dark chapter of Canadian history, negotiators have reached an agreement to compensate 80,000 Native Canadians who attended a government-financed school system where many suffered physical and sexual abuse.

title: Putin Reroutes Oil Line to Avoid Landmark Lake
description: MOSCOW, April 26  President Vladimir V. Putin ordered Wednesday that an oil pipeline being built across Siberia be rerouted away from the northern shore of Lake Baikal, one of the world's natural landmarks.

title: Sri Lanka Hits Rebel Positions, Leaving 12 Dead
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 26  Airstrikes by the Sri Lankan military against suspected Tamil Tiger rebel positions left at least 12 people dead on Wednesday, chased thousands from their homes and further weakened a cease-fire already stretched to the point of war.

title: Rice and Rumsfeld Back Iraqi Premier
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 27  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld concluded a one-day visit to Iraq this morning with a declaration of confidence in the prime minister designate, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, as someone eager to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid the country's security forces of infiltration by sectarian militias.

title: Senate Panel Calls for New Agency to Replace FEMA
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  The Federal Emergency Management Agency was so fundamentally dysfunctional during Hurricane Katrina that Congress should abolish it and create a new disaster response agency from scratch, leaders of the Senate Homeland and Governmental Affairs Committee said today.

title: Rebels Lift Nepal Blockade but Tensions Linger
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 26  In an apparent goodwill gesture, Maoist rebels called off their crippling three-week blockade of the countryside, opening the path for produce, fuel and other goods to be transported into the capital.

title: After Death of a Boy, Florida Moves to Close Its Boot Camps
description: Florida lawmakers decided yesterday to close the state's juvenile boot camps. The move comes more than three months after the death of a 14-year-old boy who was beaten by guards at a camp in Bay County.

title: Rice Visits Iraq With Rumsfeld to Press Leader
description: BAGHDAD, April 26  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld paid an unannounced visit to Iraq on Wednesday to press the prime minister-designate to re-establish public confidence in the government and rid the country's security forces of infiltration by sectarian militias.

title: She Who Controls Her Body Can Upset Her Countrymen
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  She goes by the name Bruna, the Little Surfer Girl, and gives new meaning to the phrase "kiss and tell." First in a blog that quickly became the country's most popular and now in a best-selling memoir, she has titillated Brazilians and become a national celebrity with her graphic, day-by-day accounts of life as a call girl here.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: City Schools Cut Parents' Lifeline (the Cellphone)
description: During the final stretch of David Ritter's hourlong trip to middle school, he pulls a cellphone from his jeans and calls his mother in Washington Heights to say he is out of the subway and moments from the Salk School of Science on East 20th Street.

description: A summary of the top stories in the Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.

description: The lexicon of the modern bed:

title: U.S. Options on Darfur Are Running Out
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  As the violence in the Darfur region of Sudan grows ever more deadly, Bush administration officials now acknowledge that they have few if any promising policy options for containing the carnage.

title: Rice Urges U.N. to Rebuke Iran for Nuclear Program
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 27  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said today that the latest talks between United Nations monitors and Iranian envoys had apparently failed to break the impasse over Iran's nuclear activities and that the United Nations Security Council had no choice but to rebuke Iran.

title: 'Oh, Baby...Now What?' and Growing Up
description: New to bookshelves last month was an anthology called "Mommy Wars: Stay-at-Home and Career Moms Face Off on Their Choices, Their Lives, Their Families." It joined "The Truth Behind the Mommy Wars: Who Decides What Makes a Good Mother?," "Mother in the Middle: Searching for Peace in the Mommy Wars," "The Mommy Chronicles," "The Mommy Myth" and "Confessions of a Naughty Mommy."

title: Nepal's Maoist Rebels Announce a Cease-Fire
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, April 26  Maoist rebels, apparently making a good-will gesture, announced a unilateral three-month cease-fire late on Wednesday and suspended a crippling three-week road blockade that had cut off the transport of essential goods into the capital.

title: Peacekeepers Targets of New Sinai Attacks
description: EL ARISH, Egypt, April 26  Two suicide bombers attacked members of a multinational peacekeeping force in the northern Egyptian Sinai on Wednesday, two days after a triple bomb attack killed nearly two dozen in a resort south of here.

title: Nepal Rebels Will Lay Down Arms Only if Army Does
description: NEW DELHI, April 27  The second in command of the Maoist rebels in Nepal said today that his organization would agree to sequester its troops only if the military, the Royal Nepalese Army, would agree to the same during elections for a new constitution.

title: Panel Warns of a Crisis in American Physics
description: Physics in America is at a crossroads and in crisis, just as humanity stands on the verge of great discoveries about the nature of matter and the universe, a panel from the National Academy of Sciences concludes in a new report.

title: The Bed, Remade
description: HERE'S what Serena Bass, the fashionable world's celebrity caterer and cookbook author, has on her bed. Sharpen your pencils: it's a long list, and you won't want to miss a thing.

title: At Prada, a Grand Premise Comes Unhemmed
description: AN architect once told me a story that illustrated the futility and impermanence of all grandly conceived construction projects. A wealthy client had commissioned a complicated living room that required the labor of a dozen workers skilled in hand-set stonework. After a year of work it was clear to the architect that the workers were fiercely proud of the project and considered it not just a room in a house, but also a piece of art in which their souls were invested.

title: Federal Victory in Terror Case May Prove Brief, Experts Say
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26  Despite predictions that their victory might not hold up on appeal, federal prosecutors on Wednesday savored their victory in a Sacramento courtroom, where a jury a day earlier convicted an American born in Pakistan of providing support to a terrorist group and lying to investigators.

title: Iran Threatens Retaliation if Attacked
description: TEHRAN, April 26  Iran's supreme religious leader vowed Wednesday that Iran would retaliate "twofold" if it were attacked by the United States over its refusal to comply with demands regarding its nuclear activities. He made his comments as other senior Iranians traveled to Vienna just days ahead of the deadline for international monitors to report on Iran's nuclear program.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,385 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Orders to Plug Gaps in Jerusalem Barrier
description: JERUSALEM, April 26  Israel's prime minister-designate, Ehud Olmert, told top security officials on Wednesday to swiftly plug the gaps in the separation barrier around Jerusalem. His order came nine days after a Palestinian suicide bomber struck in Israel.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts last Thursday about the Hollywood private investigator Anthony Pellicano and his dealings with the supermarket executive Ronald W. Burkle referred incompletely to published reports that Mr. Pellicano's clients included the movie producer Steve Bing, a friend of Mr. Burkle. Both Mr. Bing and Mr. Pellicano have denied reports that Mr. Bing hired Mr. Pellicano in 2001 during a paternity dispute.

title: Focus in Getty Trial Shifts to a Sicilian Antiquities Dealer
description: ROME, April 25 - Dozens of documents were dissected in a courtroom here on Wednesday as prosecutors sought to weave the doings of art dealers, collectors and museums into what they argue is a broad criminal pattern: the trafficking of archaeological artifacts looted from Italian soil.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stadium Financing Approved
description: The City Council yesterday approved financing plans for new Yankees and Mets stadiums. The plan for the Yankees' stadium in the Bronx passed 46 to 3 with one abstention and calls for the city to issue bonds worth $930 million that would be paid back by the team. The plan for the Mets' stadium in Queens was passed 48 to 1 with one abstention. The city will issue bonds worth $632 million, which would be paid back by the Mets. Completion is expected by 2009.

title: Lumber deal near for U.S. and Canada
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Kills 4 Afghan Soldiers
description: Four Afghan soldiers were killed and three were wounded in a roadside bomb explosion in eastern Kunar, close to the Afghan-Pakistani border. United States and Afghan forces mounted an operation against suspected Taliban insurgents in the province in recent weeks, while Pakistan has deployed troops in the adjoining tribal area of Bajaur in a coordinated movement. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

title: Reality TV for Children, With Better Health as the Prize
description: Chris, an 11-year-old from San Francisco, is a fitness buff and athlete whose perspective on the galloping rates of childhood obesity mostly comes from what he sees and knows.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUCKERMAN, MURIEL
description: ZUCKERMAN--Muriel. Died on April 26, 2006 at the age of 83. She worked many years for the Youth Consultation Service. Muriel is survived by her husband Sam, daughter Judith (Joseph) McGreal, sons David (Ferne) and Michael, grandchildren Mark, Lynn and Daniel, sister Doris Dreyer and four nieces. Services today at 12 noon at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY.

description: Correction Appended

title: Court Puts Teeth in 'Notice' Needed to Seize Property
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 - "An elementary and fundamental requirement of due process," the Supreme Court ruled many years ago, is that the government must provide "notice" and an opportunity to be heard before it seizes property.

title: Senate Diverts War Money To U.S. Border
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 - Prodded by Republicans, the Senate voted on Wednesday to trim President Bush's financing request for the Iraq war by $1.9 billion and to use that money to improve border security.

title: Sarkozy turns France to talk of immigration
Orders to Plug Gaps In Jerusalem Barrier
description: JERUSALEM, April 26 - Israel's prime minister-designate, Ehud Olmert, told top security officials on Wednesday to swiftly plug the gaps in the separation barrier around Jerusalem. His order came nine days after a Palestinian suicide bomber struck in Israel.

title: Olga Borodina and Ildar Abdrazakov Wrapped in a Blanket of Russian Melancholy
description: Russian singing voices were invented for the kind of music that came across the stage of Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. With Olga Borodina and Ildar Abdrazakov offering songs and arias that ranged historically from Glinka to Rachmaninoff, one heard the dark density of tone, slow moving arches of melody and what might be described as (if music had words at its disposal) a melancholy that settles over even the highest of spirits.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Official Admits Affair With Secretary
description: John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, acknowledged that he had had a two-year affair with a secretary in his office, ending in 2004. He said his wife of 44 years, Pauline, was "devastated" by the revelation, first reported in The Daily Mirror. Although a spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair said the affair between the 67-year-old Mr. Prescott and the 43-year-old woman, Tracey Temple, was a "private matter," the news was an embarrassment to a government that is trying to focus attention on its achievements as it prepares for local elections next Thursday. SARAH LYALL (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 13 about the 45th International Furniture Fair in Milan misstated the period represented by a retrospective of products by the design firm Kartell. It was four decades, not two.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Tears and Sneers
description: Paula Abdul was moved to tears by Elliott Yamin's version of "A Song for You" on Tuesday's "American Idol," and her fellow judge Simon Cowell laughed mockingly at her choked-up commentary. The entire spectacle brought in 27.99 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates and, coupled with the continually growing "House" (24.51 million), gave Fox an authoritative victory for the night. "House" hit another new ratings high among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds, and also retained more of the "Idol" audience than it ever had. CBS's "NCIS" (15.26 million) and "The Unit" (13.75 million) were, as usual, the only programs that could stand up to Fox's lineup, giving the network a distant second place ranking. At 10 p.m., with Fox out of the way, ABC's "Boston Legal" (9.95 million) was No. 1 among total viewers for the hour, but it achieved that against reruns on both NBC and CBS. This season's move to Tuesday nights has not benefited the legal drama. KATE AURTHUR

title: 4-Year-Old Girl Dies After TV Falls on Her
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed last night after a television set fell on her, the police said. It was the second such accident in Brooklyn this month.

title: U.S. Options on Darfur Are Running Out
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 - As the violence in the Darfur region of Sudan grows ever more deadly, Bush administration officials now acknowledge that they have few if any promising policy options for containing the carnage.

title: Actress Leaves 'Mr. Sloane'; Baldwin's Behavior Is Blamed
description: With just five weeks left in the Roundabout Theater Company's production of "Entertaining Mr. Sloane," Jan Maxwell has quit the cast, apparently unable to get along with a co-star, Alec Baldwin.

title: You're in Labor, and Getting Sleeeeepy
description: BETHESDA, Md. - "My parents definitely thought I was a bit crazy when I mentioned a hypnobirth," Adrienne Pratt said. Ms. Pratt, eight months pregnant, and her husband, Armando Guato, gathered with two other expectant couples on Easter Sunday afternoon to learn a newly popular technique for helping women remain serene during childbirth.

title: Gazprom grows in Europe

title: Remembering Chernobyl: Wet Rugs, Stonewalling Officials and a Run on Vodka
description: PARIS - The huge volume of recollections, photographs and documentaries dedicated to the anniversary of Chernobyl speaks to the extraordinary force that catastrophe still has 20 years later. That's not surprising: commemorations of great disasters are a way to pay tribute to the victims and the heroes, to learn to live with nightmares and fears. They are occasions to try to understand why such things happen, to ensure they won't happen again, to ask what our reactions revealed about us. The greatest catastrophes take on a personality, a name: Bhopal, Oklahoma City, 9/11, the tsunami. These names and others have entered the language as symbols of apocalyptic tragedies.

Otherwise, Billboard's Top 10 looks much the same as last week, only slightly scrambled: Toby Keith's "White Trash With Money" (Show Dog Nashville) dropped two spots to No. 4, which allowed "Now That's What I Call Music!," Vol. 21, to climb to No. 2 and the "High School Musical" soundtrack to No. 3. title: National Briefing | Washington: Chemicals Don't Present Risk

The agency, the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, a part of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, analyzed soil samples near DuPont's DeLisle Plant, in Pass Christian, Miss. DuPont says that while the plant suffered damage, it did not leak any hazardous chemicals. The agency said that while the concentrations "pose no apparent public health hazard to persons living in the area," it recommended testing crabs in nearby St. Louis Bay because those can concentrate the contaminants. title: The Soul of Havana on Biscayne Bay
description: Key Biscayne, Fla. - ANDY GARCIA, who came from Cuba as a young boy in 1961, remembers his first homes in Miami clearly: one-bedroom efficiency apartments, in what was then down-at-the-heels Miami Beach. He also remembers the jobs his father, who had been a lawyer in Cuba, took: working for a catering company, delivering socks on consignment. During the socks era, their home was the warehouse. The living room was O.K., Mr. Garcia says, laughing, but when you walked into the hallway or the bedroom there were boxes of socks everywhere. Every night after dinner, Mr. Garcia and his family sat at the table and sorted them, putting in little plastic hangers. He was pretty good at it, he says. He developed a system. It is a story out of Horatio Alger, except for the Cuban music of the 50's: Andy Garcia, The Little Sock Boy. And without the music, which he has championed, you do not have Mr. Garcia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISEMAN, JOSEPH S.
description: ISEMAN--Joseph S. Brilliant, adventurous, and kind father of Peter, Fred and Ellen, proud and beloved grandfather of Eugenie, Henry and Alex, loving former husband of Marjorie Frankenthaler Iseman and Jay Iseman, stepfather to Anne, Bill and Susan, stepgrandfather to Igor, Adriana, Lily, Julia, Amy and Ellen, devoted companion to Eleanor Munro Kahn, wonderful brother to his sister Allie, died suddenly of cardiac arrest at his home in Manhattan on April 25, 2006 just one month before his 90th birthday. A spectacular mind, a superb listener, raconteur and friend, a dedicated lawyer and educator, a community-spirited citizen and an enthusiast for life at every turn, he will forever be remembered by his family and the hundreds of friends he made around the world. Longtime partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, former President of Bennington College, a founder of U.S. public television, author and dedicated internationalist, he led an inspiring and fascinating life. Throughout his adult years, he remained dedicated to the schools from which he graduated-the Ethical Culture School in New York City, Harvard College (class of 1937) and Yale Law School (class of 1941). He was also on the board and an officer of many non-profit organizations and an active member of The Century Association. A memorial service in New York City is being planned by his children and details will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his memory to Seeds of Peace, Suite 401, 370 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 or Channel 13, 450 W. 33rd St, NY, NY 10001.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Shot By Police
description: A police officer shot a Queens man in the left shoulder early yesterday after the man knocked him to the ground and attacked his partner, the police said. The man, Floyd Johnson, 22, of Redfern Avenue in Far Rockaway, was in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, said Michael Hinck, a spokesman. The shooting occurred about 1:45 a.m. after the officers stopped Mr. Johnson's brother, Makai Jackson, on suspicion of trespassing in the Redfern Houses, the police said. Mr. Johnson charged the officers, knocking one down, and, with Mr. Jackson, struggled with the other officer, the police said. During the attack, the police said, the officer believed that his gun was being stolen and his partner fired one shot, striking Mr. Johnson. The police did not identify either officer. Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman, said the shooting appeared "to be within departmental guidelines." Sanford Rubenstein, a lawyer representing the family, said he would seek an independent investigation by the Queens district attorney's office.

Susanne Groom, a curator at the palace, which reopens to the public today, learned of it while lecturing at a local education group. A woman in the audience had seen the miniature house in a 1995 auction. As it turned out, it had been in storage for years at Kentshire Galleries in Manhattan, where Fred Imberman, the co-owner, had tried to sell it several times. "We always knew what we had," he said. "By sitting on our hands, so to speak, it ended up in the right place."

description: A Westchester County grand jury yesterday voted not to indict a New York City police sergeant who was involved in a deadly shooting outside a Yonkers bar and restaurant in January. The sergeant, Michael Ingram, 41, was being investigated for fatally shooting Peter C. Lee, 20, on Jan. 4 during a scuffle outside Rory Dolan's on McLean Avenue. Sergeant Ingram, who was off duty at the time, told investigators that he fired at Mr. Lee because Mr. Lee was stabbing another off-duty officer, who had stopped by the bar after work with Sergeant Ingram. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Settlement For CUNY Faculty
description: The union representing 20,000 City University faculty members, who have been working without a contract since November 2002, announced a tentative 58-month settlement yesterday. The union, the Professional Staff Congress, said the accord includes raises totaling 9.5 percent for 11,000 full-time and 9,000 part-time professors. "It's the best possible agreement within very tough political and economic constraints," said Barbara Bowen, the union's president. The agreement raises sabbatical pay to 80 percent of salary, from 50 percent, and gives nontenured faculty members a paid year to do research without teaching.

The defense argued that the inquiry would do not harm since both jurors, Evelyn Ezell, above, and Cynthia McFadden, had spoken publicly after the verdict. title: Arts, Briefly; The Whitney's Case For Expansion
description: Facing the last hurdle in its efforts to expand, the Whitney Museum of American Art went before the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday to make the case for its building addition, designed by Renzo Piano. The Whitney is seeking seven variances to zoning regulations for its 178-foot new tower, right, which would rise behind the historic brownstones on Madison Avenue between 74th and 75th Streets, connecting to the original 1966 Marcel Breuer building with a series of glass bridges. Yesterday's hearing was left open at its conclusion and will continue on June 20, the board said. A number of museum directors testified yesterday in the Whitney's behalf, including Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art; Lisa Dennison, director of the Guggenheim Museum; and Thelma Golden, director of the Studio Museum in Harlem. Ms. Dennison called Mr. Piano's design "an elegant and sensitive enlargement," adding that "good and appropriate design does not necessarily fit in the zoning box." Several neighborhood residents spoke in opposition to the project. "Which historic neighborhood will institutions destroy next?" asked one, Sally Garnett. "Cut this metal monster down to size." ROBIN POGREBIN

She played one of those programs at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening, to a nearly full house.

Mr. Hampton was shot and killed in his apartment in a police raid in 1969. Ms. Haithcock said her efforts were not intended to be disrespectful toward the police, who were outraged over the proposal. Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, SANFORD
description: KAPLAN--Sanford. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of our great friend, Sanford Kaplan of Los Angeles. A brilliant but modest man, Sandy was a noted philanthropist who supported numerous causes. His commitment to the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology was a manifestation of his profound love for the Jewish people and Israel. After serving in the Navy in World War II, Sandy launched a stellar career as a manager and financial executive at Scientific Data Systems, Xerox, and Intel, on whose boards he later served for many years. As a pioneer in the computer industry, Sandy also committed his energy and financial resources to the development of science and technology in Israel. His sustained generosity and devoted service as a member of the ATS National Board of Directors and Board of Regents and the Technion International Board of Governors earned him the most prestigious honors the university and the ATS can bestow: an Honorary Doctorate and the Albert Einstein Award. Through the Sanford Kaplan Chair in Aerospace Engineering, the Sanford Kaplan Family Dormitory, the Sanford Kaplan Prize for Creative Management in 21st Century High Technology, and the Kaplan VIP Rooms in the Technion's Leon and Julia Forchheimer Faculty Center, his name will be forever linked with the Technion, which he supported at the highest level. Our hearts go out to his daughters, Judith and Margaret Kaplan. Like their father, both are Technion Guardians and Margaret is a valued member of the National ATS Board of Directors. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Joan Seidel, Chairman, Southern California Chapter Nina Madden Sabban, President, Southern California Chapter Diane Siegel, Director, Western Region

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISEMAN, JOSEPH S.
description: ISEMAN--Joseph S. Brilliant, adventurous, and kind father of Peter, Fred and Ellen, proud and beloved grandfather of Eugenie, Henry and Alex, loving former husband of Marjorie Frankenthaler Iseman and Jay Iseman, stepfather to Anne, Bill and Susan, stepgrandfather to Igor, Adriana, Lily, Julia, Amy and Ellen, devoted companion to Eleanor Munro Kahn, wonderful brother to his sister Allie, died suddenly of cardiac arrest at his home in Manhattan on April 25, 2006 just one month before his 90th birthday. A spectacular mind, a superb listener, raconteur and friend, a dedicated lawyer and educator, a community-spirited citizen and an enthusiast for life at every turn, he will forever be remembered by his family and the hundreds of friends he made around the world. Longtime partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, former President of Bennington College, a founder of U.S. public television, author and dedicated internationalist, he led an inspiring and fascinating life. Throughout his adult years, he remained dedicated to the schools from which he graduated-the Ethical Culture School in New York City, Harvard College (class of 1937) and Yale Law School (class of 1941). He was also on the board and an officer of many non-profit organizations and an active member of The Century Association. A memorial service in New York City is being planned by his children and details will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his memory to Seeds of Peace, Suite 401, 370 Lexington Ave, NY, NY 10017 or Channel 13, 450 W. 33rd St, NY, NY 10001.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: 900 Dead Of Cholera

title: 'ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG: SILKSCREEN PAINTINGS 1962-63'
description: This show may be the perfect chaser to the lavish visual feast presented by the recent survey of Rauschenberg's 1954-64 combines at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For one thing, the exhibition is tiny rather than exhaustive: seven works displayed in the jewel-box gallery of Craig F. Starr Associates, one of New York's smallest and most pleasant viewing spaces for drawings and paintings. For another, it shows what happened next. Mr. Rauschenberg began experimenting with silk-screening, which he learned from Andy Warhol, as his combine period was winding down. It provided a form of paperless collage similar to Rauschenberg's innovative transfer method, used to good effect in his drawings for Dante's "Inferno." Silk-screened images could also be any size and more seamlessly integrated with brushwork. The paintings start out small and devoid of color. Their black, white and gray palette tends to be dark; one work, involving a view of New York's rooftop water tanks, is so Romantically gloomy you may be reminded of Goya. Other recurring images include a car's headlight and some mosquitoes (above) and the outline of a box, which would become something of a signature. Abrupt passages of brushwork impinge, revealing, as do the combines, Mr. Rauschenberg's persisting affinity for Abstract Expressionist paint handling. These works could almost be homages to Franz Kline; they make explicit the urban tumult that hovers just offstage in Kline's black and white work. But Mr. Rauschenberg was not above mixing real brushwork with silk-screened versions, as in "Payload," the largest and most confidant piece here. The combines also exert an influence. "Dry Cell" involves the metal frame of a folding stool, a coat hanger and a small sheet of Plexiglas printed with an image. Behind it you'll see a small piece of crushed metal that is supposed to spin when a sensor picks up movement in the immediate vicinity and the batteries to make it happen. (Craig F. Starr Associates, 5 East 73rd Street, 212-570-1739, through May 13.) ROBERTA SMITH THE LISTINGS | APRIL 28-MAY 4

description: Jean-Pierre Melville's "Army of Shadows" opens with the startling image of German soldiers marching down the Champs-lyses, framed by the Arc de Triomphe. The image was, this French director later admitted to an interviewer, a "crazy idea." Actors in German uniforms had not been permitted on the avenue since World War I, or so he claimed, and the shot was both costly and logistically complex. And yet, "it was a fantastic sight," Melville said with unmistakable satisfaction. "Wagnerian. Unfilmable." This former Resistance fighter had exacted a peculiar revenge on his complicit countrymen: he had invaded Paris himself, seizing it for his own vision.
